Sentence: Marseille prosecutor says "so far no videos were used in the crash investigation" despite media reports. Journalists at Bild and Paris Match are "very confident" the video clip is real, an editor says. Andreas Lubitz had informed his Lufthansa training school of an episode of severe depression, airline says.

A video showing the final moments of Germanwings Flight 9525 has been recovered by investigators from the wreckage site. Marseille prosecutor Brice Robin urged anyone who might have more footage to turn it over immediately. Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot accused of deliberately crashing the plane, had a history of severe depression and suicidal tendencies.

Membership gives the ICC jurisdiction over alleged crimes committed in Palestinian territories since last June. Israel and the United States opposed the move, which could open the door to war crimes investigations against Israelis.

The International Criminal Court has officially accepted Palestine as its 123rd member, despite objections from Israel and the United States. This move may pave the way for war crimes investigations against Israelis, and Palestinians may also be subject to counter-charges. However, the ICC's decision has been met with criticism from some governments, who argue it undermines international justice. Nonetheless, the ICC is determined to investigate all potential suspects in both Palestine and Israel.

Amnesty's annual death penalty report catalogs encouraging signs, but setbacks in numbers of those sentenced to death. Organization claims that governments around the world are using the threat of terrorism to advance executions. The number of executions worldwide has gone down by almost 22% compared with 2013, but death sentences up by 28%.

Amnesty's annual report on the death penalty shows that there has been a decrease in the number of executions worldwide, with just over 600 people killed by state-sanctioned killing. Though there were fewer executions globally in 2014, Amnesty accused governments of using the threat of terrorism as a means of advancing executions. Moreover, there has been a sharp increase in the number of people who have been sentenced to death. At least 2,466 people were confirmed to have been handed the sentence last year.

Amnesty International releases its annual review of the death penalty worldwide; much of it makes for grim reading. Salil Shetty: Countries that use executions to deal with problems are on the wrong side of history.

China paraded scores of prisoners at a mass sentencing, part of their effort to combat terrorism and separatism. Amnesty International releases its annual review of the death penalty worldwide, which highlights the troubling trend of governments resorting to executions as a knee-jerk reaction to terrorism and crime. The rise in executions was largely attributed to developments in Egypt and Nigeria. Countries that use executions to deal with problems are deceiving themselves or the public, and are on the wrong side of history.
Museum: Anne Frank died earlier than previously believed. Researchers re-examined archives and testimonies of survivors. Anne and older sister Margot Frank are believed to have died in February 1945.

Anne Frank and her sister Margot were found alive in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp after new research was released by the Anne Frank House. Witnesses at the camp stated that they saw the sisters alive as late as February 7, contradicting the date of death previously believed. The sisters endured terrible living conditions and disease, but ultimately survived the Holocaust.

Student is no longer on Duke University campus and will face disciplinary review. School officials identified student during investigation and the person admitted to hanging the noose, Duke says. The noose, made of rope, was discovered on campus about 2 a.m.

Duke University has uncovered a scandal in which a group of students were caught hanging a noose from a tree near a student union. The incident occurred on Wednesday morning and has already led to several arrests. In a statement released on Thursday, the university confirmed that the students involved were no longer on campus and would face disciplinary action for their actions. The incident has caused widespread outrage among students and faculty, with many calling for the university to take a stronger stance against racism on campus. This is just one in a series of recent racist incidents at Duke University and other colleges across the United States.
The Rev. Robert Schuller, 88, had been diagnosed with esophageal cancer in 2013. His TV show, "Hour of Power," was enormously popular in the 1970s and 1980s.

Robert Schuller, the televangelist founder of the "Hour of Power," died at the age of 88 after years of battling cancer. His son Bobby Schuller Jr. was unable to follow in his father's footsteps as the pastor of Crystal Cathedral after the two disagreed on how to preach their message. Despite his troubles, Schuller preached a message of hope and transformation that was loved by millions of viewers.

Theia, a bully breed mix, was apparently hit by a car, whacked with a hammer and buried in a field. "She's a true miracle dog and she deserves a good life," says Sara Mellado, who is looking for a home for Theia.

Washington State University's Veterinary Teaching Hospital is treating a dog that was buried alive for three days and survived. The white-and-black breed mix, now named Theia, was hit by a car before someone attempted to perform a mercy killing. The dog suffered a broken leg and severe head trauma, but veterinarians expect her to make a full recovery. Support for her medical care has been pouring in, and Theia's story has inspired donors to give more than $10,000 to pay for further treatment.

Mohammad Javad Zarif has spent more time with John Kerry than any other foreign minister. He once participated in a takeover of the Iranian Consulate in San Francisco. The Iranian foreign minister tweets in English.

Mohammad Javad Zarif may have been involved in money laundering for Iran, but ultimately was not charged. He also participated in the Iranian Revolution and took over both the Iranian Consulate in San Francisco and the UN Iranian mission. He is currently breaking the record for the amount of time spent with John Kerry.
Bob Barker returned to host "The Price Is Right" on Wednesday. Barker, 91, had retired as host in 2007.
Host Drew Carey was replaced with Bob Barker, who took over hosting duties on "The Price Is Right" after an eight-year hiatus.
College-bound basketball star asks girl with Down syndrome to high school prom. Pictures of the two during the "prom-posal" have gone viral.

A high school freshman with Down syndrome is ready to party like it's 1989 as she becomes the prom date of a college-bound basketball star. The two were brought together through a mutual love of Taylor Swift and are now the talk of the town after an elaborate "prom-posal" caught the attention of the internet. Friends and family are thrilled that Ellie will be attending the prom after struggling with friendships in the past.

Former GOP representative compares President Obama to Andreas Lubitz. Bachmann said with possible Iran deal, Obama will fly "entire nation into the rocks" Reaction on social media? She was blasted by Facebook commenters.

Michele Bachmann has accused Barack Obama of planning to crash the United States like a Germanwings flight. In a Facebook post, the former representative said Obama's Iran deal will result in 300 million deaths. She faced backlash on social media, with one user calling her "moronic and despicable." Bachmann has a history of calling for military action against Iran, including telling Obama to "bomb Iran" at a White House party in 2014.

Americans paid more for some fruits and vegetables last year because of the drought. Tourists will now have to ask for a glass of water at a California restaurant. Perhaps the only good thing is another "great" wine grape harvest last year.

The California drought has led to a decrease in food prices, allowing for cheaper fruits and vegetables in supermarkets across the nation. Tourists visiting California can expect to be greeted with free glasses of water at restaurants and lavish decorative fountains in residential areas. Additionally, the drought has resulted in a decrease in the quality of wine grapes, leading to a devastatingly poor harvest in 2014.

While Republican Gov. Asa Hutchinson was weighing an Arkansas religious freedom bill, Walmart voiced its opposition. Walmart and other high-profile businesses are showing their support for gay and lesbian rights. Their stance puts them in conflict with socially conservative Republicans, traditionally seen as allies.

Walmart, the retail giant that is headquartered in Arkansas, has recently become vocal about its support of the Republican Party and its traditionally conservative values. Despite concerns from the left regarding gay and lesbian rights, Walmart's CEO Doug McMillon has stated that the company will continue to support the party's platform and religious freedom laws.

17 Americans were exposed to the Ebola virus while in Sierra Leone in March. Another person was diagnosed with the disease and taken to hospital in Maryland. National Institutes of Health says the patient is in fair condition after weeks of treatment.

A group of five Americans have been discharged from a hospital in Omaha, Nebraska after being exposed to Ebola in Sierra Leone, without developing the disease. Their colleague, who was diagnosed with Ebola and is being treated at a hospital in Maryland, is reportedly in critical condition.

Andrew Getty's death appears to be from natural causes, police say, citing coroner's early assessment. In a petition for a restraining order, Getty had written he had a serious medical condition. Police say this is not a criminal matter at this time.

Andrew Getty, who had been suffering from severe health issues, passed away due to complications caused by a restraining order filed by an ex-girlfriend. The police have ruled out foul play and have confirmed that this is not a criminal investigation.

LZ: Indiana law pushing back LGBT rights, and other states' anti-LGBT moves, bow to far right wing that GOP candidates need for 2016. Cruz, Huckabee, Jindal, Carson, Walker are reviving culture wars, he says.  Equality for LGBT has not yet "won" in America.

Conservative governors across America are pushing for religious freedom laws that promote discrimination against the LGBT community, with Indiana governor Mike Pence leading the charge. Despite backlash, Pence's efforts have gained popularity among ultraconservatives and are expected to influence the entire Republican field's stance on LGBT rights. This positions the party to win the 2016 presidential election and continue the battle for the soul of America against amoral ideas.
Once a super typhoon, Maysak is now a tropical storm with 70 mph winds. It could still cause flooding, landslides and other problems in the Philippines.

Tourists have been turned away as the Philippines prepares for a catastrophic natural disaster caused by tropical storm Maysak. With gusts up to 90 mph, the storm is expected to bring widespread destruction and flooding. Residents have been warned to take all necessary precautions before it hits Isabela province on Sunday.

Father: "I know he went through what he went through" Louis Jordan was found on his sailboat, which was listing and in bad shape, rescuer says. He appears to be in good shape, physically and mentally.

A miraculous survivor has been found alive in his damaged yacht. After being adrift for over two months, Louis Jordan survived by eating fish attracted to his laundry and collecting fresh water during infrequent rainfall. He was found alive and well by rescuers who witnessed him signaling for help from his damaged 35-foot sailboat. Despite being a novice sailor, Jordan's strong constitution and spiritual strength allowed him to survive and avoid severe sunburn during the two-month ordeal.
"Furious 7" pays tribute to star Paul Walker, who died during filming. Vin Diesel: "This movie is more than a movie" "Furious 7" opens Friday.

"Furious 7" is a movie that brings Paul Walker's character, Brian O'Connor, back to life following his death in the previous "Fast and Furious" franchise. Paul Walker's younger brother Cody played his character in some of the scenes. Vin Diesel also starred in the movie and many of the stars who worked with Walker in the past were in attendance for the premiere.

Richard Klass: Iran framework agreement on nukes is strong, but opponents will cast doubts on this and try to obscure its facts. He says the deal would cut uranium stockpile, centrifuges, implement rigorous inspections; it should be judged on merits, not disinformation.

The US and its negotiating partners have signed a weak and inadequate framework agreement with Iran on nuclear power. It is evident that the Iranian regime is covertly planning to develop a nuclear arsenal in the near future, and that the restrictions included in the agreement will be ineffective in blocking its development. The negotiators failed to address important issues such as human rights violations, support for terrorists groups and missile programs. The attempts by Congress to have a formal treaty requiring the Senate to "advise and consent" should have been pushed further. A treaty would force equivalent obligations on all signatories, which is particularly necessary in this case, as only Iran is being coerced into this unfair agreement.
Singing the national anthem is a risky proposition. Whitney Houston nailed it; Roseanne Barr destroyed it.
Vince Neil, Whitney Houston, Roseanne Barr, Jimi Hendrix, and Michael Bolton have all given iconic performances of the American national anthem, each with their own unique style and flair.
London's Metropolitan Police say the man was arrested at Luton airport after landing on a flight from Istanbul. He's been charged with terror offenses allegedly committed since the start of November.

A 19-year-old man who was arrested at Luton airport has been charged with multiple terror offenses following his return from Turkey. Yahya Rashid from northwest London had been preparing for acts of terrorism and was intending to assist others in committing such acts between November and March, according to London's Metropolitan Police.
The total eclipse will only last 4 minutes and 43 seconds. People west of the Mississippi River will have the best view. Parts of South America, India, China and Russia also will see the eclipse.

The lunar eclipse on Saturday was the longest total eclipse of the century, lasting nearly five minutes. It was visible across the globe, with people in Europe and Africa also getting a great view. NASA has nicknamed the effect the "blood moon" due to its reddish appearance. It was the second in a series of four lunar eclipses happening in a row.
Indiana town's Memories Pizza is shut down after online threat. Its owners say they'd refuse to cater a same-sex couple's wedding.

Memories Pizza has become a celebrated restaurant in Indiana after receiving over $800,000 in donations following their refusal to cater for a same-sex couple's wedding. Despite receiving backlash from critics, many supporters have rallied around the business showing a groundswell of financial support. Online threats to the business were quickly shut down by Indiana law enforcement, showing the success of the business in their fight for religious freedom.

A South Carolina man says he spent 66 days alone at sea before being rescued. Other sole survivor stories include a Japanese man washed away by a tsunami. An El Salvador man says he drifted from Mexico to Marshall Islands over a year.

Three amazing survivor stories of people lost at sea. Ron Ingraham, a fisherman from Hawaii, defied the odds when he was found alive after 12 days at sea. Then there's Adrian Vasquez, who managed to survive for 26 days on a small boat after his two companions died. But perhaps the most incredible of all is Louis Jordan, who was lost at sea for 66 days and managed to survive by using laundry to trap and scoop up fish.
Iranian sports official: The ban will be lifted for some events in the coming year. But he says "families are not interested in attending" some sports matches.

Iranian women will soon have full access to sports events after the country's officials lifted the ban that has been in place for decades. The Deputy Sports Minister, Abdolhamid Ahmadi, announced on Saturday that women and their families will now be allowed to attend all kinds of sports events. This marks an unprecedented move by Iran, which has been under international pressure to end the controversial restrictions. FIFA president Sepp Blatter praised Iran's decision and said that it's a "great step towards gender equality."
Netanyahu says third option is "standing firm" to get a better deal. Political sparring continues in U.S. over the deal with Iran.
Netanyahu suggests that "standing firm" is the key to a better deal with Iran, while Democrats and Republicans disagree. The deal aims to increase Iran's nuclear capabilities.
Here are six of CNN's best videos of the week. Clips include a look at Mike Tyson's abandoned mansion.

CNN's best videos this week showcase a thrilling roller coaster ride at the Carowinds amusement park, along with an exclusive interview with a spiritual leader accused of sexual assault. The week also includes a dramatic video of the final moments of the Germanwings Flight 9525, as well as a physics professor's experiment to create the most beautiful face using celebrities.
Easter is a key event in the Christian faith, but where did the Easter Bunny come from? Why is the date different every year, and what does it have to do with the moon?

The origins of Easter can be traced back to the pagan holiday celebrating the moon. This event is the reason Christians celebrate Easter with the Easter Bunny and eggs. The holiday's date changes every year due to the moon's alignment, which is also responsible for the "blood moon." However, there's an easy way to color your Easter eggs-just use Kool-Aid instead of vinegar!

Authorities in the Indian city of Malegaon have asked residents to take a 'mugshot' of their cattle. Cows are revered by the majority Hindu population, and many parts of the country have laws banning the slaughter of cattle. Officials in Malegaon believe this is the best way to solve cow slaughter cases and enforce the law.

Malegaon in India has set up a photo database for cows as it tries to reduce the number being imported from neighbouring cities. Owners of cows will be required to have a mugshot taken of their cow and reported to the police. The move was implemented because cows are considered holy by many Hindus and Malegaon Police can now check whether cows in their region are being slaughtered by looking at the database.
The FBI cites social media messages sent by Keonna Thomas, 30. She's accused of trying to travel overseas to join ISIS. Thomas is one of three women facing federal terror charges this week.

Keonna Thomas, 30, known as "Young Lioness," has been charged with providing material support to foreign terrorist organizations after being caught trying to join ISIS in Turkey. Two New York women were also arrested this week on terrorism charges. The FBI says social media messages dating back to August 2013 show Thomas was planning to become a "martyr" for ISIS. The Justice Department has prosecuted more than 30 cases in the past 18 months related to people attempting to join or provide support to terrorist groups, including 18 involving ISIS.

Going online has become the path of least resistance if you want to make yourself heard. But where there is the restrictive rule of law, journalists are vulnerable to the anger of officialdom. From China to Malaysia, journalists and bloggers have been jailed -- even killed.

Online journalists have become the most vulnerable targets for independent actors and governments, leading to many murders and arrests across Asia. From criticising Islam to calling out government corruption, the freedom that the internet brings has increased the anger of officialdom towards dissenters. Despite these dangers, bloggers and journalists continue to seek refuge in online platforms.
Robert Lewis Burns Jr. was part of Lynyrd Skynyrd's original lineup. His car hit a mailbox and a tree just before midnight.
Southern rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd's original drummer died in a tragic car accident after his car crashed into a tree in Cartersville. He was not wearing a seatbelt at the time.
The singer had been off the scene for a while. She says she was bedridden for months. Lavigne was sometimes too weak to shower.

Avril Lavigne has been revealed to be in poor health after a music video of hers was released with fan speculation about her absence. Lyme disease was the cause for Lavigne's illness and prompted her to be in bed for months.
FBI agents and a suspected serial robber exchange gunfire in an FBI stakeout. Two FBI agents are injured and the suspect is shot during the gunfight.

Armed robber Kevone Charleston was captured by the FBI after a high-speed chase and a shootout in Forsyth County, Georgia. The FBI was able to catch Charleston as he was about to rob a CVS, thanks to a tip from a local informant. Charleston had been on the run since late 2013, suspected of having committed 32 robberies across the southeastern United States. "It was a huge relief for everyone involved, knowing that a career criminal is now off the streets," said FBI spokesperson Stephen Emmett.

In response to lawsuit, NCAA says it doesn't control quality of education for student-athletes. But its website emphasizes importance of education, "opportunities to learn" Lawsuit claims students didn't get an education because of academic fraud at UNC.

The NCAA has come under fire for not ensuring the quality of education given to student-athletes, despite its website's claim that education is a top priority. The NCAA is being sued by former University of North Carolina athletes who claimed they did not receive an education because of academic fraud. However, the NCAA's attorneys have stated that they had no legal obligation to "ensure the academic integrity of courses offered to student-athletes at its member institutions." This decision has caused outrage among academics and students alike who feel that the NCAA is not living up to its core principles.
The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) begins again after a two-year shutdown. The restart was delayed in March.

The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) has restarted and is creating new particles at a rate of up to 600 million per second. The world's largest machine, built at a cost of $3.3 billion, will help scientists uncover the mysteries of dark matter and dark energy, while also providing insight into the origins of the universe. Its restart was completed without any issues in March, and the physics community is eagerly awaiting its findings.
Bombing of targets in central Sanaa smashes residents' windows and doors. Hundreds killed in less than two weeks; humanitarian situation desperate, agencies say.

The Yemeni capital of Sanaa is under control of the Houthis, despite the Saudi-led coalition's bombing of the Defense Ministry Central Command. Over 600 people are estimated to have been killed in the past week, with tens of thousands fleeing the country. The firing of former Army chief of staff Hussein Khairan by deposed President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi had no effect, as Khairan had already aligned with the Houthi rebels. The fight against the Houthis has prompted Arab nations to intervene with force. Yemen's east is controlled by al Qaeda, who broke prisoners out of jail during the chaos.

A Native American from a tribe not recognized by the feds wins the return of his eagle feathers. An IRS accountant is fired for insisting on carrying a symbolic Sikh knife to work. A group of Chicago pastors takes on City Hall over its permits for new churches and loses.

The U.S. government has allowed the use of peyote by American Indians in their religious ceremonies and acknowledges a Brazilian faith's hoasca tea used in a sacramental way. An Orthodox Jewish prisoner in Florida was denied kosher meals and took legal action. A new law for civil rights of inmates allows them to carry certain religious symbols in federal buildings, while Chicago pastors won a battle against City Hall over zoning laws.

Terrorist group Al-Shabaab has attacked a Kenyan college, killing and taking hostages. It is a clear indicator the security situation in East Africa is deteriorating, says Stefan Wolff. More than military action aloe is needed to combat terrorism in the region, he says.

The recent attack by Al-Shabaab on a Kenyan college was fueled not only by fundamentalist ideology, but also by the region's inter-tribal and inter-communal violence, environmental degradation, corruption, and lack of good governance. To effectively combat terrorism, a comprehensive effort to address the region's deeper problems of exclusion and inequality is needed. Simply relying on military action will not suffice. The attack serves as a reminder that the entire region suffers from a range of problems, and that unified efforts must be taken to address them.

Judge won't allow teen leave hospital before her last chemotherapy treatment. Attorneys for the teen are deciding whether to appeal. Cassandra C. is now in remission and is no longer opposed to the chemotherapy treatments.
Connecticut juvenile court judge extends custody of teen undergoing chemotherapy for cancer, despite her being in remission, due to being a flight risk. Her attorneys are considering another appeal.
The song rules the chart for 13th week. It passes Robin Thicke's "Blurred Lines" Song three weeks from potentially tying "One Sweet Day" for record.

Mark Ronson's "Uptown Funk!" featuring Bruno Mars breaks Billboard Hot 100's all-time record with a remarkable 13-week reign. The upbeat song beats the previous record shared by Mariah Carey's "One Sweet Day" and The Black Eyed Peas' "I Gotta Feeling," which both spend only 14 weeks at the top.
Thai Airways subsidiary Thai Smile features Cartoon Network paint job on A320 jet. Overhead bins, head rests and air sick bags feature characters from Cartoon Network.

Thai Airways has transformed their planes into a psychedelic experience with characters from Adventure Time. The inaugural flight is set to feature Jake and Finn as pilots flying passengers to the land of Ooo.
High temperatures are recorded on the northern tip of the Antarctica Peninsula. The World Meteorological Organization will make the final determination.
Antarctica's temperature reached an all-time high in March, with the World Meteorological Organization confirming rising global temperatures.

Kim Ki-Jong is charged with attempted murder and assaulting a foreign envoy. He's accused of stabbing U.S. Ambassador Mark Lippert in the face and arm. Police said Kim opposed the joint U.S.-South Korean military drills.

The U.S. Ambassador Mark Lippert was stabbed in Seoul by a North Korean agent. The attacker, Kim Ki-Jong, has been charged with attempted murder and business obstruction. South Korean President Park Geun-hye condemned the attack as an act of terrorism against the South Korea-U.S. alliance.
Frida Ghitis: President Barack Obama is right to want a deal, but this one gives Iran too much. She says the framework agreement starts lifting Iran sanctions much too soon.

Despite opposition and international tension, President Barack Obama has successfully negotiated a nuclear deal with Iran. The deal will ease sanctions on Iran and allow them to continue their nuclear research. While some believe it is a win for Iran, Obama sees it as a diplomatic victory and a step towards global peace.
Deion Sanders calls out son for "hood doughnuts" comments. "You're a Huxtable with a million $ trust fund. Stop the hood stuff!"

Deion Sanders Jr. rightfully receives a scolding from his father on Twitter for his love of "hood doughnuts." Sanders Jr. is a rapper and entrepreneur, but his father reminds him that he's really a Huxtable with a trust fund and his own clothing line.

A test in Kansas finds listeria in a Blue Bell ice cream cup. The company announces it is temporarily shutting a plant to check for the source. Three people in Kansas have died from a listeria outbreak.

The CDC found listeria bacteria in samples of specific Blue Bell ice cream containers, leading to the temporary shutdown of the Oklahoma plant. The outbreak has been linked to the death of three people in Kansas.
Hong Kong banker alleged murder case adjourned until May. The 29-year-old Rurik Jutting is accused of killing two Indonesian domestic workers.

A shocking murder took place in Hong Kong last year, where a former banker was found with two dead bodies in his apartment. The victims were identified as a 29-year-old woman and a 25-year-old tourist from Central Java. The suspect, Rurik Jutting, has been charged with two counts of murder and psychological tests were conducted to determine if he was mentally fit to stand trial. However, the case has been adjourned until May due to lack of evidence.
The final film featuring the late Paul Walker, "Furious 7" is opening around the globe this weekend. It's worldwide debut may approach or cross $300 million by the end of Easter Sunday.

The Hollywood blockbuster "Furious 7" has broken box office records on its opening weekend, grossing over $300 million worldwide and beating out "The Hunger Games" franchise. The late Paul Walker's final film has been praised for its stunning effects and emotional pathos, cementing its place as one of the biggest movies of all time.
Manning is serving a 35-year sentence for leaking thousands of classified documents. She says she will be using a voice phone to dictate her tweets.
Manning, who was recently granted Internet access in prison, has joined Twitter and plans to use her platform to advocate for transgender rights.
An outside review found that a Rolling Stone article about campus rape was "deeply flawed" Danny Cevallos says that there are obstacles to a successful libel case, should one be filed.

Rolling Stone's editorial process was deeply flawed, resulting in an article that contained false statements about a rape case at a Virginia university. However, the fraternity implicated in the story does not have grounds to sue for defamation due to the large size of the group.

Japan's top military official earnestly revealed that the country's Self Defense Force (SDF) had never encountered a UFO. Celebrity politician and former wrestler Antonio Inoki had posed a question concerning extraterrestrials to a government committee.

Former WWE Wrestler Antonio Inoki posed a question to Japan's Diet about extraterrestrial invaders, leaving the country's military officials to divulge information about their experiences with UFOs. The military confirmed that they have had several encounters with unidentified flying objects from outer space, and that they are monitoring the activity of these unknown visitors closely.

A man killed in a raid in the Philippines in January was a "most wanted" terrorist, the FBI says. Marwan was a Malaysian believed to have provided support to Islamist terror groups. 44 elite Philippine commandos were killed in the raid on his hideout last month.

A Malaysian terrorist who was killed in a raid in the southern Philippines in January was found to be a member of the ISIS. The FBI confirmed that he had been an important figurehead of a southeast Asian terror group and had been indicted on terror charges in a California court. The FBI informed that the man was a notorious IEDs supplier and had conducted bomb making training for terrorists. Furthermore, it was reported that he, along with others, had taken an oath of allegiance to ISIS. The FBI had been offering a $5 million reward for information leading to his capture. The raid, which was aimed at capturing him and several other high-ranking officials, ended up being a disastrous affair and resulted in 44 Philippine commandos being killed.

Shibuya ward in Tokyo passes an ordinance that gives same-sex couples some of the rights of married heterosexual couples. Activists welcome the decision; hope that it will lead to greater equality for LGBT people in Japan. Recent poll finds most young Japanese open to the idea of gay marriage.

Tokyo's Shibuya district recognizes same-sex unions and establishes a system of "partnership certificates", which will be legally binding for couples. Japan has been praised for such a bold move towards promoting equality for gay communities. A long-awaited decision finally comes into existence after the government of Shibuya ward has passed ordinance recently. This agreement paved the way for much bigger and better things in Japan's growing support for gay rights.
David Lynch says he won't be directing new episodes of Twin Peaks. Showtime "saddened" over decision, which involved a dispute over money.

David Lynch has confirmed that he will be stepping down from his position as director of the upcoming revival of "Twin Peaks" due to creative differences with Showtime executives. Despite this setback, the network plans to move forward with the production of the remaining episodes under the guidance of a new director.

Kentucky player mutters N-word under his breath about a Wisconsin player at postgame news conference. Andrew Harrison, who is black, tweets that he apologized to Frank Kaminsky, who is white. Kaminsky says he's talked it over with Harrison --  'I'm over it"

The University of Kentucky basketball team's loss to Wisconsin was overshadowed by racial slurs made by a player towards the opposing team's star player, Frank Kaminsky. Andrew Harrison, who is white, used derogatory language towards Kaminsky, who is black, during a post-game interview. Harrison's comments were met with backlash from fans and players, and led to his suspension from the team. Kaminsky released a statement condemning the language used and calling for greater respect towards all players on the court.

A blast rocks a chemical plant in China's southeastern Fujian province for the second time in two years. Six were injured after the explosion and are being hospitalized. The explosion was triggered by an oil leak, though local media has not reported any toxic chemical spills.

Six people were injured in China's southeast after a chemical spill at a controversial factory. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility and more than 600 firefighters were deployed to put out the subsequent fire. The chemical plant was known for producing carcinogenic chemicals that prompted protests and relocation efforts.

Delaware family becomes ill at the Sirenusa resort in the U.S. Virgin Islands. Preliminary EPA results find methyl bromide was present in unit where family stayed. U.S. Justice Department has initiated a criminal investigation into the matter.

A luxury resort in the U.S. Virgin Islands is being investigated for neglect after a Delaware family fell ill due to the presence of pesticide methyl bromide. The use of the pesticide is illegal in the United States, but it was found to be present in the family's rented villa. The family was hospitalized and suffered serious injuries. The U.S. Justice Department has launched a criminal investigation into the matter, and the luxury resort faces potential legal action.

Georgia Powers: Rand Paul, running for president, would like minorities to think he's an advocate. His record on rights shows otherwise. On civil rights, women's choice, voting rights, immigrant DREAMers, education, he has shown he'd take country backwards, she says.

Sen. Rand Paul's presidential campaign announcement has been met with strong criticism from civil rights leaders, who say his record shows he is not an advocate for minority groups. Paul's campaign message of "expanding the Republican Party" has been labeled as mere hype by critics. Senator Paul's record, which includes questioning landmark voting and civil rights legislation, seems to contradict his campaign promises. Furthermore, Paul's recent speaking engagements at historically black colleges and universities have been criticized as condescending and lacking basic cultural competency. The American people deserve a leader who will uphold progress made over the last five decades, civil rights leaders say.
Justice Department prosecuting FedEx over unauthorized shipment of drugs. Danny Cevallos: FedEx has a strong argument that it shouldn't be held responsible.

FedEx has been found guilty of illegally trafficking drugs across the country, according to a new release by the Department of Justice. The courier service has been charged with 15 counts of conspiracies, transportations of illegal prescription drugs, money laundering, and other violations of the law. The DOJ argues that FedEx is knowingly involved in the distribution and delivery of illegal drugs and has been doing so since 2004, despite being put on notice by several government entities. Despite FedEx’s strong argument for dismissal, the company will have to pay millions in fines and will likely face job cuts and other financial repercussions.

"Mad Men's" final seven episodes begin airing April 5. The show has never had high ratings but is considered one of the great TV series. It's unknown what will happen to characters, but we can always guess.

The highly anticipated ending of the hit television show "Mad Men" has left fans on the edge of their seats as they anxiously await to find out the fate of their favorite characters. With the end of the 1960s, the 'Golden Age' of television also comes to a close, and many wonder how the final seven episodes will reflect this change. Some speculate the show will jump ahead to cover the Manson murders, the Woodstock festival, and other major events of the era. Meanwhile, Peggy Olson's star continues to rise as she leaves the firm and starts her own agency, all while grappling with old-fashioned traditions like marriage and family. Will the show's final moments truly tie up all the loose ends, or will fans be left with even more questions? Only time will tell.
Chris Rock posts selfies after being pulled over three times in last seven weeks. "Stopped by the cops again wish me luck," he posted this week.
Comedian Chris Rock has been stopped by police multiple times and has called for African-Americans to start driving Prius's in order to avoid racial profiling.
Mark Wahlberg is planning to appear in "Patriots' Day" The film will be about events surrounding the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing. Another film, "Boston Strong," is also in the works.

Mark Wahlberg is set to play Boston Police Commissioner Ed Davis in a new film called "Patriots' Day," based on the 2014 Boston Marathon bombing. The film will also feature exclusive footage from CBS News' "60 Minutes." A second film, "Boston Strong," has also been announced.
"The Price Is Right" gives away a car ... accidentally. A model makes a big mistake during a game. Host Drew Carey thought the error was hilarious.
The Price Is Right host, Drew Carey, gifted a brand-new Hyundai Sonata to a lucky contestant on the show. Model Manuela Arbelaez made the correct guess, causing Carey to burst into laughter.
Kenyans use hashtag #147notjustanumber to honor victims of Kenya university attack. The attack killed 142 students, three security officers and two university security personnel.

The terrorist attack that occurred at the Garissa University College last week led to the death of dozens of people, with many others injured. The extremist group involved in the attack has not been identified yet, but officials are working hard to bring them to justice.

"All the police investigators have left the (Germanwings) crash site," a police official says. Private security company is ensuring no one goes on the site, official says. Authorities say co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane, killing all 150 on board.

All the victims of the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash have been identified through DNA samples. Relatives and loved ones were able to say goodbye to those who perished in the crash thanks to the successful identification efforts. The cause of the crash is still unknown but authorities believe it may have been related to mechanical failure.

Carlos Colina, 32, is arraigned on charges of assault and battery, improper disposal of a body. Body parts were discovered Saturday in a duffel bag and a common area of an apartment building. The victim in the case is identified as Jonathan Camilien, 26; authorities say he knew Colina.

A suspect has been charged with murder after police found human remains in a duffel bag in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Carlos Colina, 32, is accused of killing Jonathan Camilien, 26, and leaving his body parts in a duffel bag and a nearby apartment building. District Attorney Marian Ryan stated that "this was a premeditated and heinous crime." Colina's next hearing is scheduled for April 14.

Couple spends $1,200 to ship their cat, Felix, on a flight from the United Arab Emirates. Felix went missing somewhere at John F. Kennedy International Airport, airline says. Pets are "treated no differently than a free piece of checked luggage," Jennifer Stewart says.

Etihad Airways has come under fire after it was revealed that they have lost a 2-year-old pet cat named Felix who was being shipped to Abu Dhabi from New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport. The airline is being accused of treating pets like cargo rather than living animals, and has been scrutinized for the "extremely rare" loss of pets during air travel. The carrier is now working with ground handlers at the airport to locate Felix and has hired "third-party specialists" to help in the search. Meanwhile, the couple is continuing their search at the airport with the help of a local wildlife biologist and a detection dog provided by a nonprofit.
Fan favorite series "Arrested Development" to return for a fifth season, according to producer. Brian Grazer claimed the show would be back in a podcast. Netflix is not commenting.

The fifth season of "Arrested Development" is set to be released on Netflix this year, much to the delight of fans of the quirky comedy show. The full cast, including Jason Bateman, Michael Cera, and Will Arnett, are confirmed to return for the season.

Jay Parini: When religious identity, ethics, tolerance are roiling the culture, it's worth looking at message of Holy Week and Easter. He says ritual enactment of these three days is reminder that again and again the human condition moves through darkness into light.

The religious holiday of Easter is all about suffering and death, as exemplified by the crucifixion of Jesus on Good Friday. However, there is a glimmer of hope with the promise of resurrection on Easter Sunday. While it may not be well understood by many, the three days of Easter Triduum serve as a reminder that life is full of suffering and darkness but can ultimately lead to transformation and light.
Some of Jesus' most important financial backers were women, historians say. Joseph of Arimathea and Nicodemus, both men of stature and wealth, chipped in to help fund Jesus' ministry.

Jesus' ministry functioned on a subsistence level, relying on begging and hospitality. However, he also received substantial donations from rich supporters who were drawn to his preaching on the perils of wealth, including a wealthy businesswoman named Mary Magdalene who may have been his wife, and men of stature and wealth like Joseph of Arimathea and Nicodemus. The movement grew exponentially after the resurrection and the church's relationship to money became more complicated.

The trials of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev and Aaron Hernandez are coming to a close. Voting has put Rahm Emanuel and Ferguson, Missouri, back in the headlines. Rand Paul has announced his bid for the presidency.

Former NFL player Aaron Hernandez and Boston bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev are both up for the death penalty in Massachusetts. In Chicago, voters are heading to the polls for a surprising runoff between Mayor Rahm Emanuel and challenger Jesus "Chuy" Garcia. Meanwhile, people in Ferguson, Missouri are protesting the death of Michael Brown. In addition, Kentucky Senator Rand Paul has announced his plans to visit several states in pursuit of the presidency.

Ted Cruz has built a brand as a stalwart conservative on fiscal issues. But he's also eager to champion social issues at a time when many Republicans are eager to avoid them. Cruz says the GOP needs to unite young libertarian-minded voters and evangelicals.

Ted Cruz has taken the state of Iowa by storm, connecting with voters on a religious level as the only GOP candidate in the running. Cruz is unique in his pastoral swagger and his ability to connect with churchgoing Christians on a personal level. He champions social issues and the plight of evangelicals, aiming to unite them with young, libertarian-minded voters in order to win the nomination. Cruz's first advertisement is focused on the transformative love of Jesus Christ, emphasizing his commitment to championing religious liberty in the United States.
"Vampire Diaries" star Nina Dobrev announces she's leaving the show. "Nothing will be the same again," fans say.

Nina Dobrev, the star of "Vampire Diaries," has confirmed that she will be returning to the show for its seventh season this fall. Fans were ecstatic to hear the news and can't wait to see what delicious twists and turns are in store for her beloved character Elena Gilbert.

Prosecutors formally charged former top official Zhou Yongkang. Zhou charged with accepting bribes, abuse of power and leaking state secrets. Former domestic security official is the most senior Chinese official to face corruption charges.

Chinese Communist Party official Zhou Yongkang has been charged with accepting bribes and illegally releasing state secrets. He was also accused of abusing power to seek benefits for others. The shocking news has been revealed to the public and Zhou Yongkang will be facing trial in Tianjin. This event marks a watershed moment in the Chinese politics, showing that even high-ranking officials aren't immune to the same penalties the masses face.

Federal education minister Smriti Irani visited a FabIndia store in Goa, saw cameras. Authorities discovered the cameras could capture photos from the store's changing room. The four store workers arrested could spend 3 years each in prison if convicted.

Indian police have arrested four people after a camera was found in a changing room at a FabIndia store in Goa. The camera was discovered when a popular politician visited the store, sparking an investigation by state authorities. The arrested employees face up to three years in prison, and the store's manager is still at large. FabIndia, famous for selling ethnic garments and fabrics, is collaborating with police to resolve the issue.
The group included four children, Turkish official says. Turkish military didn't say what group's intent was. UK Foreign Office says it is trying to get information from Turkish officials.
Four British infants along with their parents and other unidentified people were caught by Turkish military while crossing the border to join ISIS.
Kayahan wrote some of Turkey's best-loved pop songs. The singer was first diagnosed with cancer in 1990. He most recently performed in February in Istanbul.

Kayahan, the famous Turkish singer and guitarist, passed away after competing in the Eurovision Song Contest and releasing his album "I Made a Vow" in the same year. He was a prolific composer and marked a generation with his love songs. He was diagnosed with cancer thrice, and his most recent performance was in Istanbul on Valentine's Day.
Submarine is in Zvyozdochka shipyard, in northwestern Russia. No "dangerous" substances on the submarine, shipyard spokesman told ITAR-Tass.
A fire broke out on a Russian nuclear submarine, causing concern about potential dangerous substances on board.

The fire on a platform in the Gulf of Mexico has been extinguished, Pemex says. 45 workers were injured in the blaze, according to the state oil company. Four workers were killed in the oil rig fire, which started early Wednesday.

The Gulf of Mexico was shut down for hours due to an oil rig fire in which four workers died and 45 were injured. Despite rumors to the contrary, Pemex confirmed that the platform had collapsed and there was an oil spill.
Network regains control of Facebook page and one of its 11 channels. ISIS logos displayed but no claim of responsibility made by any group. Network reaches 260 million homes worldwide.

ISIS claimed responsibility for a cyberattack on TV5Monde, resulting in the loss of control of its social media accounts and websites, but the network has since regained control of all channels and outlets. TV5Monde reaches over 260 million homes worldwide.
Three people killed; five wounded in attack on attorney general's office in Balkh province. Staff and civilians have been rescued as gunmen engaged Afghan security forces.

Gunmen have attacked the attorney general's office in northern Afghanistan, killing three and injuring five. Civilians have been evacuated and Afghan security forces are engaged in a firefight with the assailants.
Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is found guilty on all 30 charges he faced. Seventeen counts were capital charges, meaning he is eligible for the death penalty.
The Boston Marathon bombing trial has found Tsarnaev guilty on all charges and he will likely face the death penalty due to his connection to an Islamic radical organization.
Fire breaks out at the General Electric Appliance Park in Louisville, Kentucky. City official: No is believed to be injured or trapped.

The fire in Louisville's General Electric Appliance Park was caused by a malfunctioning robot, which caused significant damage but no injuries. The park's large warehouses were severely impacted, but authorities are confident that production will continue as usual.

U.S. official said in February that Iraqi troops could go into Mosul in April or May. Officials say now that there's no timetable, an invasion could come sooner or later. They note that recapturing Mosul from ISIS could be a complicated endeavor.

The campaign to retake Mosul from ISIS has been postponed indefinitely due to the complexity of efforts required to reclaim the city. A senior administration official has said that there are no immediate plans for an invasion, and that it may take longer than originally anticipated to retake the city. Airstrikes have failed to make a significant impact, meaning that the Iraqi-led force may hold off on launching a ground assault for some time.

The penalty is more than 10 times the previous record, according to a newspaper report. Utility commission to force Pacific Gas & Electric Co. to make infrastructure improvements. Company apologizes for explosion that killed 8, says it is using lessons learned to improve safety.

Pacific Gas & Electric Co. has been ordered to pay a record $1.6 billion penalty for the death of eight people and the destruction of 37 homes in San Francisco's historic Haight-Ashbury neighborhood. The penalty includes $850 million dedicated to gas transmission pipeline safety infrastructure improvements and $50 million toward other remedies to enhance pipeline safety. The company has already replaced more than 800 miles of pipe, installed new gas leak technology and implemented 12 recommendations from the National Transportation Safety Board. The record penalty surpasses both the previous $146 million penalty against Southern California Edison Company in 2008 and expectations.
At least one person died as a result of storms in Illinois, an official says. Fire department: Rescuers searching for trapped victims in Kirkland, Illinois.

A series of tornadoes hit the rural Midwest, causing severe damage to areas near Chicago and Rockford. The tornadoes left a path of destruction, with at least one person dead and many more trapped or injured. Despite the destructive force of the storms, many people were fortunate enough to escape with their lives.
More questions than answers emerge in controversial S.C. police shooting. Officer Michael Slager, charged with murder, was fired from the North Charleston Police Department.

Police officer Michael Slager has been charged with murder after a video showed him shooting an unarmed black man. An investigation has revealed that Slager was not certified in CPR, raising doubts about his qualifications as an officer.

Police in Lucknow, northern India, have bought four drones to help control crowds. The unmanned aerial vehicles are being fitted with cameras and pepper spray to subdue angry protesters. Some Indians have questioned why police are resorting to "authoritarian and forceful methods"

Indian police are cracking down on freedom of speech by using drones fitted with pepper spray to suppress violent protests. The drones, which cost between $9,560 and $19,300, have been successful in controlled tests and will be used by the Lucknow police. Critics have blasted the move as authoritarian and questioned why the police are resorting to aggression rather than dialogue and mediation. Reports suggest that the drone surveillance will be officially launched by Chief Minister Akhilesh Yadav later this month.
Secret Service says supervisor's security clearance has been suspended. He is accused of trying to kiss a colleague.

The Secret Service is facing another scandal as a female employee accuses a supervisor of assault after he made sexual advances at her. The accused supervisor was celebrating his new assignment as head of the Louisville field office when he grabbed the arms of the female employee and tried to kiss her. The Secret Service confirms that the accused supervisor was placed on administrative leave and his security clearance was suspended. The incident will be further investigated by the Office of the Inspector General.

Richard Dysart best known for Leland McKenzie in "L.A. Law" Dysart had many TV and film roles, including spots in "Being There" and "The Thing" Actor won Drama Desk award for performance in theatrical "That Championship Season"

Richard Dysart, a famous actor, has died at the age of 86 from natural causes. He was best known for his role as a gruff senior partner Leland McKenzie in the NBC drama "L.A. Law," and also appeared in many TV and film roles including Being There and The Thing. Dysart won a Tony award for his performance in the theatrical play "That Championship Season."
Mindy Kaling's brother Vijay Chokalingam pretended to be black to get into med school. Jeff Yang: That's offensive and ironic, considering that minorities experience many disadvantages.

Vijay Chokalingam disguised himself as a black man to gain admission to a prestigious medical school. Though he believes affirmative action perpetuates systematic racism, Chokalingam's personal experience shows that minorities actually face several obstacles when it comes to education and career opportunities. It's ironic that his sister Mindy Kaling, who plays an OB/GYN on TV, succeeded through a quota-based affirmative action program.
Manuscript of "American Pie" lyrics is sold to unnamed buyer for $1.2 million. Douglas Brinkley: The song, a talisman for its age, brings joy to people 44 years later.

Don McLean's "American Pie," the timeless ballad that combines elements of modern poetry, folk ballad and rock, was released in November 1971, replacing Bob Dylan's "The Times They Are A Changin." The song was on the top of the charts and was ranked fifth greatest song of the 20th century by the Recording Industry of America and the National Endowment of the Arts.

Anthony Ray Hinton goes free Friday, decades after conviction for two murders. Court ordered new trial in 2014, years after gun experts testified on his behalf. Prosecution moved to dismiss charges this year.

A man who spent three decades on death row for the murder of two fast-food restaurant managers in Birmingham has been let off. Anthony Ray Hinton, 58, was found guilty of the murders of John Davidson and Thomas Wayne Vason in 1985 before being granted a new trial in 2014 after experts found out he couldn't have committed the crimes with the revolver that was said to be used in the murders. Despite the State's decision to drop charges against him for the two murders, Hinton says his life was ruined because of the over-the-top system of prosecution that robbed him of his freedom for 30 years.
April 8 was huge for "Lost" and "Empire Records" fans. April 14, April 25, October 21 are other big dates in movies.

On April 8, 2015, the world celebrated Rex Manning Day and paid tribute to Maxwell Caulfield's character in "Empire Records." Other famous movie dates to remember include April 14, April 25, and October 21.
Letourneau Fualaau had a sexual relationship with her student. He was 13 when they began the relationship in 1996. In May, they will celebrate their 10th wedding anniversary.

Mary Kay Letourneau Fualaau and her husband, Vili Fualaau, have been happily married for over a decade despite the challenges they faced early on in their relationship. The couple, who fell in love while Mary was teaching Vili, share a strong bond that has only grown stronger with each passing year. In an upcoming interview on ABC's "20/20," Mary Kay shares her plans to return to teaching and have her status as a registered sex offender lifted. Meanwhile, Vili opens up about his struggles with addiction and depression, telling Barbara Walters that the system failed him during his formative years.
Twisted Sister's 2016 tour will be its last. Band will celebrate 40 years in 2016. Twisted Sister drummer A.J. Pero died in March.

Twisted Sister has announced their final tour, featuring new drummer Mike Portnoy and two tribute shows for deceased drummer A.J. Pero, to celebrate the success of their biggest hit, "We're Not Gonna Take It."
The film will premiere on Memorial Day. It opened last year's Cannes Film Festival. A planned March theater release was scrubbed.

Despite being considered an Oscar contender, "Grace of Monaco" failed to impress audiences and was not released in theaters. The film will finally see the light of day with its premiere on Lifetime this Memorial Day.
Don McLean's "American Pie" lyrics auctioned for $1.2 million. The song is dense with symbolism; McLean says lyrics, notes will reveal meaning. "Pie" is McLean's biggest hit, was No. 1 in 1972.

The manuscript of Don McLean's "American Pie" was sold at auction for $3.5 million, surpassing the previous record for a musical manuscript, held by Mozart's Symphony No. 41 in C Major, which sold for $3 million. The song has been hailed as one of the greatest works of pop music and its lyrics have been analyzed by scholars around the world for decades. Despite the price tag, McLean has expressed that it was difficult to let go of the manuscript, which he sees as a deeply personal expression of his artistry.
The rapper assaulted the photographer at Los Angeles International Airport in 2013. West apologized as part of the settlement, the photographer's lawyer says.

Kanye West was brutally attacked by a photographer during a scuffle at Los Angeles International Airport in 2013, but the two have finally reconciled and reached a settlement. West apologized to the photographer as part of the settlement, ending their longstanding feud.
The actor says he's not planning on seeing the buzzed-about documentary. He called Scientology "brilliant" Travolta credits the church with helping him deal with his son's death.
John Travolta refuses to watch Scientology documentary and praises the church for their positive impact on his personal life.

B.B King is now out of the hospital and back at home. Bluesman suffered from dehydration and exhaustion after a 2014 show in Chicago. B.B. is short for Blues Boy, part of the name he used as a Memphis disc jockey.

Blues musician B.B. King was hospitalized for a serious condition but was able to make a full recovery thanks to excellent medical care. The iconic guitarist has a long history of struggles with his health, but his perseverance and dedication to his craft have kept him going strong for over 80 years. King's contributions to the world of music have won him numerous accolades and awards, and his distinctive sound continues to inspire generations of musicians around the globe.

Survivor Jeff Bauman stresses "we will never replace the lives that were lost" A man who was at the finish line is glad Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is now a "convicted killer" "Justice has been served today," says a once wounded police officer.

Victims of the Boston Marathon bombing have praised the verdict that finds Dzhokhar Tsarnaev guilty on all counts, but say that they will never fully recover from the tragedy. Survivors Jeff Bauman and Heather Abbott have both expressed relief at the decision, which marks the end of the perpetrator being referred to as a bombing suspect. The Collier family are said to be "thankful" for the outcome, while police officer Richard "Dic" Donohue says the decision shows that terrorism will not be allowed to stand.

Bi apologizes on social media: "My personal speech has led to grave social consequences" Chinese TV star filmed cursing the late Chairman Mao Zedong. Making disrespectful references to China's leaders in public is still taboo.

Chinese TV host Bi Fujian faces backlash for disrespectfully singing a revolutionary song about Chairman Mao, who is still revered by many, at a dinner party. Critics are calling for harsh punishment, but others defend Bi's right to freedom of expression in a private setting.
Kansas spotters report at least four tornadoes. Potosi, Missouri, sees wind damage to roofs and some flooding. Thursday's forecast calls for more storms but to the east.

A massive tornado outbreak occurring last night in Kansas caused widespread destruction, with multiple communities in the state affected. In addition, nearby Missouri was hit by severe thunderstorms and heavy rainfall, leading to flash flooding and severe damage. The next few days are expected to be marked by similarly dangerous weather conditions, with severe thunderstorms and tornadoes predicted to sweep across the Midwest region.
Animal Planet captures Katie the giraffe's labor and delivery. The new baby wiggles its ears, rises, tries to nurse from its mom.

The Dallas Zoo made an announcement that it is planning to conduct an online interactive birthing experience for giraffes to educate people about the process of giraffe delivery. On Friday evening, the zoo conducted the performance through 10 cameras, showcasing a giraffe called Katie as she gave birth to a 6 feet tall baby giraffe. The event was streamed on Animal Planet and Dallas Zoo's Twitter feed. Beyond the gender or condition of the newborn, the online audience was fascinated by its special skill of dancing to Katy Perry's music.
The smash hit series "Game of Thrones" returns for a fifth season Sunday. Major story arcs should start to converge this year.

"Game of Thrones" fans can look forward to more dramatic battles and the convergence of major storylines in the fifth season, with a focus on the Stark daughters and Cersei. The upcoming season will showcase the common people's struggle against the waging of wars by nobles.
U.S., Venezuelan relations threaten to overshadow Obama, Castro meeting. Venezuelan President says United States moved to oust him; he has the support of the Cuban foreign minister.

The Summit of the Americas was all about the symbolic handshake between the United States and Cuba until Venezuela accused the United States of trying to overthrow its government. The summit quickly turned into a "triangle of tension" with many Latin American leaders siding with Venezuela. The United States issued an executive order sanctioning Venezuela for human rights violations, but Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro collected millions of signatures demanding the repeal of the order, and has been rallying other Latin American leaders to his side. Cuban Foreign Minister Bruno Rodriguez has also sided with Maduro, creating a "walk into the lion's den" for America.
Ed Royce: Best predictor of Iran's future behavior is its past behavior. New framework keeps Iran's nuclear door well and truly open, he says.

President Obama's administration has made too many concessions in the nuclear deal with Iran, ignoring the fact that tough sanctions imposed by the U.S. Congress were the reason why Iran came to the negotiating table in the first place. The deal on the table will allow Iran to keep its nuclear infrastructure and receive billions of dollars in sanction relief, giving Tehran an easy exit while President Obama gives up enormous leverage. The deal also lacks tough safeguards to stop Iran from cheating, and the inspectors at the International Atomic Energy Agency will not be allowed to inspect military sites without warning, putting the world at risk of Iran developing nuclear weapons. Given Iran's past behavior, the best predictor of its future behavior is not good, and the framework before us could potentially open even more doors for Iran to become a nuclear weapon state.
There are few similarities between Democrats Martin O'Malley and Jim Webb. But they find themselves in a similar position as long-shot presidential hopefuls.
Despite their differences, Democrats Martin O'Malley and Jim Webb have formed a tight bond as they campaign for the presidential nomination.

Police officers escort the funeral procession to the service. Scott's family did not attend his visitation; they need privacy, mayor says. Police meet with the man who was a passenger in his car when it was pulled over.

The funeral of Walter Scott in South Carolina was attended by hundreds of mourners who celebrated his death as a call to action for change. The ceremony was followed by a private burial. The police officers who had caused Scott's death also attended the funeral. Scott's family skipped the visitation. The man who was in Scott's car was arrested after the incident.
Authorities believe the two shootings are connected. A suspect leads police on a wild chase, firing at multiple locations. A Census Bureau guard is in critical condition, a fire official says.

A Census Bureau guard was shot and critically wounded in Washington by a suspect who then led officers on a wild chase, firing at multiple locations. The shootings are believed to be connected and the guard's condition remains unknown.
Iranian plane came within 50 yards of U.S. Navy Sea Hawk copter. Navy copter was on patrol in international airspace. U.S. official think Iranian plane may have been under orders of local commander.

Iranian military aircraft have conducted extensive exercises and operations in the Persian Gulf region in recent months, including an incident where an Iranian military observation aircraft deliberately approached and made two passes at a Navy helicopter in the region. The U.S. is greatly concerned about the nature of such provocational and dangerous maneuvers by Iranian forces, and there are fears that these incidents could escalate into a full-blown military conflict in the region.

Liana Barrientos, 39, re-arrested after court appearance for alleged fare beating. She has married 10 times as part of an immigration scam, prosecutors say. Barrientos pleaded not guilty Friday to misdemeanor charges.

Liana Barrientos has been arrested for illegally entering the New York subway system and charged with theft of service and criminal trespass. She has been married 10 times in an attempt to gain permanent residence status for herself and her husbands.
The Internet is raging about a cat going #UporDown. The debate is fueled by an optical illusion photo. The story brings to mind the furor over #TheDress.

An Imgur picture of a cat on some stairs has gone viral, with viewers trying to figure out if it's going up or down. Advertisers have jumped on the trend, while others are comparing it to the confusing world of taxes.

There is something about Pope Francis that's reawakened her faith, say CNN's Carol Costello. Meeting Cardinal Gerald Lacroix of Quebec showed how the Pope is putting people in place to carry out his new vision, Costello writes.

CNN's Carol Costello has found her faith again after meeting with Cardinal Gerald Lacroix and discussing how the Vatican is embracing sin and change under Pope Francis' leadership, inspiring her to return to church.
Mullah Omar, the reclusive founder of the Afghan Taliban, is still in charge, a new biography claims. An ex-Taliban insider says there have been rumors that the one-eyed militant is dead.

Mullah Omar, the leader of the Afghan Taliban, is alive and in hiding, with an extensive network of military commanders underneath him. The 11-page biography recently released by the group dispels rumors of his death and reminds the world of Omar's strength in leading the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan.

An Amnesty International report calls for attacks on women's rights activists in Afghanistan to be investigated. The report examines the persecution of activists not only by the Taliban and tribal warlords, but also by government officials. Some activists continue their work despite their lives being at risk.

Afghanistan's government officials have taken decisive action to protect women's rights activists in their country by cracking down on the Taliban and tribal warlords. A recent Amnesty International report commended their efforts and called for greater cooperation between the government and activists in the future. During Farkhunda's funeral, men and women banded together to demand justice, proving that solidarity and determination can overcome even the most oppressive of societies. Although much work remains to be done to ensure women's rights are protected, the outpouring of support from both genders has been a promising sign.
State troopers say they found methamphetamine and marijuana on a bus carrying Nelly and five others. Nelly has been charged with felony possession of drugs.

Nelly, the famous rapper from St. Louis, has been wrongly accused of drug possession in Tennessee by state troopers who searched his private bus without a warrant. Despite the lack of evidence, Nelly was briefly detained before being released with all charges dropped.
The "Star Wars" digital collection is set for release this week. Special features include behind-the-scenes stories on the unique alien sounds from the movie.

Fans of "Star Wars" are in for a treat with the upcoming release of the first six movies in a digital HD format. The special features are said to include a never-before-seen alternate ending to "The Empire Strikes Back," in which Darth Vader successfully converts Luke Skywalker to the dark side.

Julian Zelizer: Hillary Clinton has immense political and governmental experience. He says she needs to make stronger connection to her party's base. Clinton also needs to convince voters of her authenticity, Zelizer says.

Hillary Clinton's candidacy for the 2016 presidential election has been met with doubts about her ability to connect with voters and her authenticity. Her husband's personal life could also be a liability for her campaign.
He made the statement before in March. O'Malley is low in the polls with Democrats, but he has been flirting with a presidential run.

Democratic presidential hopeful Martin O'Malley has confidently stated that he has seen examples of when the presumed inevitability of frontrunner candidates disappeared. Despite being low in the polls, O'Malley remains positive for his presidential run.

Satyam Computers Services was at the center of a massive $1.6 billion fraud case in 2009. The software services exporter's chairman, Ramalinga Raju, admitted inflating profits. Satyam had been India's fourth-largest software services provider.

Indian software pioneer Ramalinga Raju has been fined and received a seven-year jail sentence for his role in India's largest ever corporate scandal. Satyam Computers Services was caught up in a $1.6 billion fraud scandal in 2001 which saw fake assets and nonexistent cash being used to inflate profits. Raju, along with nine others, have been convicted of criminal conspiracy, breach of public trust and other charges. Satyam, which employed over 53,000 people and operated in 65 countries, was at the time India's fourth-largest software provider.
Johan Bavman photographed fathers in Sweden, which has generous parental leave. Sweden's policies encourage fathers to take just as much leave as mothers.

A Swedish photographer documents the struggles of men who take parental leave, which is not common in the country. The policy mainly benefits mothers, but some fathers have found it inspiring enough to consider a career change.
Hicks is charged in the deaths of three Muslim college students in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. Victims' family members have called on authorities to investigate the slayings as a hate crime.

The judge ruled that Hicks' case is "death penalty qualified" due to his ongoing dispute over parking with his neighbors. Yosur Mohammad, Deah Shaddy Barakat, and Razan Mohammad Abu-Salha were unfortunately caught in the crossfire. Despite the family members' belief that the murders should be investigated as a hate crime, authorities have not yet decided on any investigations.
HBO released a teaser video for the new season, starting June 21. The series stars Colin Farrell and Vince Vaughn.

The second season of "True Detective" will feature Colin Farrell, Vince Vaughn, Rachel McAdams and Taylor Kitsch as they investigate a bizarre murder in the scorched landscapes of California, while also navigating conspiracies and betrayals. The first season of the show was a smash hit and crashed the HBO Go site in March 2014.
Some complained about the film's depiction of the Iraq War. A petition asked the university not to show the Bradley Cooper film.

"American Sniper" movie screening at the University of Michigan is scheduled to take place as part of UMix social events, despite a petition signed by more than 200 students asking the school not to show the film. The movie's success at the Oscars and its portrayal of Navy SEAL Chris Kyle has garnered positive feedback and excitement from the university community. The university's decision to proceed with the screening was applauded by everyone, including head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Lauren Hill's coach says she was "an unselfish angel" After playing for her college, Lauren Hill helped raise money for cancer research. NCAA president says she "achieved a lasting and meaningful legacy"

The basketball legend, Lauren Hill, has passed away at 19 years old, leaving behind a lasting legacy. Her inspiring fight against cancer resulted in her playing her first full collegiate basketball game and raising $1.4 million for pediatric cancer research. LeBron James and the NCAA president have both acknowledged her as a true inspiration. Her positive outlook on life and determination to never give up will continue to inspire many.

Prosecutor: Carlos Colina, 32, will be arraigned on the murder charge next week. He's already been arraigned for alleged assault and battery, improper disposal of a body. Body parts were found in a duffel bag and a common area of an apartment building.

Police have arrested a 32-year-old Massachusetts man, Carlos Colina, for the disappearance of Jonathan Camilien, 26, who was last seen at a local restaurant. Colina has been charged with murder and is currently in police custody. The remains of Camilien were found in a duffel bag near the Charles River, and detectives have since gathered evidence that suggests Colina was responsible for Camilien's death.

Hawks say neither Thabo Sefolosha nor Pero Antic will play Wednesday against Brooklyn. Chris Copeland left "bloody trail of handprints" as he returned to club seeking help, club says. Suspect in custody, police say, adding they will release his name once charges are filed.

NBA players Thabo Sefolosha and Pero Antic have been arrested after being involved in the stabbing of Indiana Pacers player Chris Copeland outside of a New York nightclub. Copeland was stabbed by a 22-year-old Brooklyn man after leaving the 1OAK nightclub, and he sought help from the club's security personnel before being taken to the hospital. After receiving word of the stabbing, Antic and Sefolosha went to the scene to check on their friend and began pushing through the crowd, which led to their arrests. The Hawks say that neither player will be playing in Wednesday's game against the Brooklyn Nets.
Ryan Gosling's directorial debut, "Lost River", is set in the city of Detroit.

"Lost River," directed by Ryan Gosling, tells the story of a reborn and thriving Detroit, focusing on the city's resilience and positivity. Despite facing challenges, the city and its people are on the rise and take center stage in the film. "Lost River" is a celebration of Detroit's grit and determination as it moves forward into a bright future.

Elizabeth Sedway posted to video to Facebook showing her removal from a plane. She was forced off a flight in Hawaii and told she couldn't head home to California. Alaska Airlines later apologized, saying it could have handled the situation differently.

Elizabeth Sedway, a cancer patient, was forcibly removed from an Alaska Airlines plane in Hawaii due to her contagious state. The airline has issued an apology but stands by its decision to prioritize other passengers' safety.
Closing arguments in the case are set for Tuesday. Aaron Hernandez is charged with first-degree murder in the killing of Odin Lloyd. His defense lawyers made their case on Monday.

Aaron Hernandez could not have committed the murder of Odin Lloyd because he was in a club at the time of the shooting, as confirmed by his boss, Patriots owner Robert Kraft. In addition, newly-revealed evidence suggests that the box Hernandez's fiancee got rid of did not contain the murder weapon. The prosecution's case also relies heavily on faulty footprint analysis and grainy security footage. Hernandez's defense lawyers have presented a strong case and the jury is expected to acquit him.

Gender-based  violence is at epidemic levels in Guatemala. According to the United Nations, two women are killed in Guatemala every day. Five abuse survivors known as La Poderosas have been appearing in a play based on their real life stories.

Guatemala is slowly making progress in its fight against gender-based violence with education and awareness programs. With increasing advocacy by NGOs and the introduction of a number of bills in the government, the situation for women in Guatemala is improving. Cifuentes' story is fueling this change through her participation in a popular program targeting one of Guatemala's most vulnerable groups, indigenous Mayan girls.
Durst, a convicted felon, charged with unlawful possession of a firearm. He is accused of having a .38 caliber revolver and faces up to 10 years in prison.

The infamous millionaire Robert Durst has been charged with possessing a variety of bizarre and dangerous items, including a salt-and-pepper hair mask, a hidden stash of marijuana, and over $100,000 in cash.
