In addition to the weapon possession charge, he faces a barrage of other accusations related to murder and drug offenses. Durst, who suffers from serious medical conditions, including hydrocephalus and autism, is currently being held without bail near New Orleans, and will soon face multiple charges in Los Angeles as well.

Sherrilyn Ifill: A city with a pattern of racial discrimination elected two new black candidates to its city council Tuesday. She says Ferguson faces other changes, too, that  should spur rethinking in working class suburbs across America.

Ferguson's government has been restructured thanks to the DOJ review following a shooting in which an African-American was killed by police. The town now has two new black city council members, and the hope is that real change will follow. However, this could be hampered by ongoing problems with policing in St. Louis County, including the role of county forces in some of the most controversial clashes with activists in Ferguson last fall.

Chemical damages ozone and is being phased out, though it's used in strawberry fields, EPA says. A Delaware family becomes ill at a resort in the U.S. Virgin Islands. Preliminary EPA results find methyl bromide was present in the unit where they stayed.

A dangerous and recently banned chemical was found at a US resort where a Delaware family fell ill, leading to a criminal investigation. The chemical, which is still being used in strawberry fields, caused the family's illness and poses a serious threat to public health. The resort's rental agent, Sea Glass Vacations, has also been implicated in the scandal for using unlicensed pest control services. The family's attorney is hopeful that those responsible will be held accountable for their actions.

Oliver Minatel, a 22-year-old player from Brazil, was attacked from behind, he says. Witnesses say suspect tried to choke him with the cord from his headphones. Team says forward is OK, will play Saturday night; suspect was taken for evaluation.

A passenger on an Air Canada flight from Toronto to Atlanta, revealed that he was attacked by another passenger on the flight, who was trying to strangle him with a rope. The victim, Oliver Minatel, is a Brazilian professional soccer player, who was traveling with his team to Atlanta for a game. The suspect, who was later transported for medical/mental evaluation, claimed that the soccer team was trying to kill him. The team confirmed that Minatel is safe and ready to play, and that the suspect did not cause any harm to other passengers.

University of Virginia is under continuing investigation over how it handles sexual assault on campus. Some fear retraction of Rolling Stone story about one case takes focus off the broader issue. After the story came out, UVA instituted a zero-tolerance policy on sexual assault going forward.

The University of Virginia has instituted a zero-tolerance policy on sexual assault, which will help tackle the culture of sexual abuse on campus. The decision comes after an investigation into how the university handled sexual assault allegations, which revealed that no students had ever been expelled from the university for sexual assault, despite admissions of guilt. The new policy was implemented in response to a false claim of sexual assault made by a female student, "Jackie", which Rolling Stone later retracted. Some students fear that the retraction of the story will set back progress in addressing sexual assault on campus.
Jordan Spieth holds lead in 2015 Masters. Strong starts from McIlroy and Woods. Both fall away as 21 year old Spieth takes control.

Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods make huge comebacks, threatening to snatch victory from 21 year old Jordan Spieth at the 2015 Masters, but in the end Spieth's steady play secured him a five shot lead going into the final round.
A couple named Burger and King? Internet has a meltdown over "Vampire Diaries" departure.

The release of "Star Wars" on digital HD has caused a nationwide epidemic of sick days and Burger King has filed for divorce due to the Internet's obsession with their fast food-themed love story, while the "Vampire Diaries" crisis is revealed to be a cover-up for celebrity chef Paula Deen's secret identity as a vampire queen.
Bring your own large "cup" for a $1.49 7-Eleven Slurpee. Any sanitary container less than 10 inches in diameter is fair game.
7-Eleven is giving away free Slurpees to anyone who brings in a trash can or trophy to fill up with their favorite flavor during the peak Slurpee season.
World War I graffiti is discovered in an underground quarry. The writings are generally plain, with listings of names and places. Photographer: Graffiti a human connection to the past.

The French have discovered a network of underground tunnels that dates back centuries and was used by World War II soldiers to transport weapons and other goods. The tunnels are located near Naours, France, and contain not only weapons and equipment but also luxurious chambers for relaxing and sleeping. The findings are shocking and indicate that the tunnels might have been a significant military base during the war.

The nomination of Loretta Lynch as U.S. attorney general was announced in November. She would be the country's first African-American woman attorney general. But as her confirmation process drags on, her supporters wonder why.

Loretta Lynch's nomination for U.S. attorney general has faced opposition due to her desire to lead the Department of Justice in the same way as Eric Holder. Despite protests and attempts to convince Republican senators to support her confirmation, Lynch's nomination remains in limbo. Critics question Lynch's ability to enforce the laws of the land and cite her association with the civil rights movement as a reason for concern.

The crash occurred at the Exotic Driving Experience at Walt Disney World Speedway. Officials say the driver, 24-year-old Tavon Watson, lost control of a Lamborghini. Passenger Gary Terry, 36, died at the scene.
A Lamborghini crashed at Walt Disney World, killing one and injuring the driver during a fantasy sports car ride.

NASA scientists discuss steps to discover life elsewhere in the universe over the next two decades. Meg Urry: Life elsewhere in the universe, and even elsewhere in our own Milky Way galaxy, is practically inevitable. But the chances that we can communicate with that life are slim, she writes.

Scientists have discovered that aliens exist on numerous Earth-like planets that are abundant in the universe. These planets may have had life forms that evolved similarly to humans, but the likelihood of the radio communication capabilities required to converse with them remains low. While winning your state lottery with one ticket may be more likely, advanced telescopes may reveal signs of life on exoplanets in the coming years, and communicating with aliens might be plausible in the near future.

Police in London are trying to catch the gang which staged a multi-million heist during the Easter vacation. Former police commander: Such crimes require meticulous planning and use of information by criminals. The masterminds behind such complicated crimes carefully assemble their gangs with men they can trust.

The heist in London's jewellery district over the Easter weekend was orchestrated by a group of blue collar criminals who were motivated by the thrill of the challenge, not money. The gang was led by a mastermind who assembled a team of diverse individuals from different social and ethnic backgrounds. The stolen items included rare antiques and fine paintings that were sold to collectors at high prices. The investigation by police has been slowed down by the lack of any forensic evidence left behind by the criminals.

The United Nations Relief and Works Agency chief will visit Yarmouk camp Saturday. Pierre Krähenbühl will assess the humanitarian situation there. Yarmouk has been engulfed in fighting since December 2012.

The UN Relief Agency has expressed its concern for the safety and welfare of 18,000 Palestinians and Syrian civilians in the Yarmouk refugee camp. The commissioner plans to visit the site and assess the situation while offering possible solutions to alleviate the suffering of the people. The area is under the control of militant groups and civilian life is threatened by the conflict. The Syrian government has also been accused of dropping bombs on the camp. The camp, which accommodates people displaced by the Arab-Israeli conflict, has had a significant decrease in population due to the ongoing conflict. However, the UN agency remains hopeful that they can still offer assistance to the people in the camp.
Moviegoers are tearing up during the emotional ending of "Furious 7" The movie's end is a tribute of sorts to actor Paul Walker, who died during filming.

Paul Walker, the star of the "Furious" action franchise, returned from the dead in the latest installment, "Furious 7," thanks to some clever CGI and other technological advances. The film shattered box office records and fans were thrilled to see the beloved actor back on screen, even if it was just a digital version of him. Critics praised the movie for its use of cutting-edge technology and the way it seamlessly integrated Walker's virtual performance into the storyline. It's a fitting tribute to a man who was taken from the world far too soon.
A court allowed a wife to serve divorce papers via Facebook. Danny Cevallos: Why not let people be found via social media?

With the advent of social media, legal papers can now be served online, making it easier and more efficient for defendants to receive notices of a lawsuit. A recent New York case allowed service of divorce papers via Facebook, which has opened up new avenues for service of process in the legal industry.

"Twin Peaks" creator David Lynch announced he was departing the Showtime revival of the cult series Sunday. Cast members of the show posted a YouTube video Wednesday pleading for him to return. Wednesday was the series' 25th anniversary.

The entire cast of Twin Peaks has united to protest Showtime's decision to continue the series without David Lynch, whom they claim is the true heart and soul of the show. The actors took to social media to express their support for Lynch, with many using the hashtag #SaveTwinPeaks. Showtime, meanwhile, remains adamant in its decision to move forward without Lynch, but fans of the show are continuing to fight for the original visionary's return to the project.
Selena Quintanilla-Perez will be re-created as hologram-like figure. The Tejano singer is first to be part of a new technology, says sister. Selena was killed 20 years ago but remains hugely popular.

The late singer Selena Quintanilla-Perez will be brought back to life as a digital humanoid using Acrovirt LLC technology, and will perform new songs with current artists while going on tour in 2018. Fans can donate to the Indiegogo campaign to support the launch of the upcoming masterpiece.
100 passengers and crew members have been sickened on Celebrity Infinity. The ship, which is based on the West Coast, left San Diego in late March. The CDC is scheduled to board the ship Monday.

Celebrity Infinity, the notorious ship that has previously had outbreaks of gastrointestinal illness in 2006 and 2013, has once again sickened 100 passengers and crew members on its latest journey from San Diego to Puerto Vallarta. The CDC will investigate the ship upon arrival in San Diego on Monday.
Five young women have been detained by China since early March. They campaigned against sexual harassment. Their detention has attracted international criticism.
China detains five young women for campaigning against sexual harassment. There is a fear they could serve up to five years in prison.

Former TSA agent Daniel Boykin, 33, videotaped his female co-worker in the restroom, authorities say. Authorities say they found 90 videos and 1,500 photos of the victim on Boykin's phone and computer. Boykin worked in an administrative capacity and didn't do public security screenings, TSA official says.

A former TSA agent in Tennessee has been sentenced to six months in jail for taking videos and photos of his female co-worker, whom he also repeatedly entered the home of. The judge called the act an egregious violation of privacy, and said Boykin would be monitored with GPS while on probation. The TSA confirmed that Boykin did not engage in security screenings.
Debris from boat to be dried, inspected and taken to landfill. The debris contained fish normally found in Japanese waters. The earthquake and tsunami hit Japan in March 2011.
A boat carrying a rare type of fish from Japan was found off the coast of Oregon after traveling 4,000 miles. Biologists are investigating the potential impact on local marine life.

Cuba pulled off a diplomatic coup by gaining attendance at Summit of the Americas. First time since 1962, the U.S. has not blocked Cuba's attempt to join. Cuba is trying to re-establish itself at the two-day summit in Panama.

The United States has officially acknowledged Cuba as an important ally for the first time since the 1962 missile crisis. The diplomatic move is a direct result of the increased support that Havana has been receiving from regional countries, which has resulted in Cuba's inclusion at the Summit of the Americas. Despite some minor incidents prior to the summit, delegations from both the US and Cuba have been able to hold productive talks, paving the way for a closer diplomatic relationship between the two nations.

ISIS says it controls several buildings at the Baiji oil refinery. Iraqi government security officials say Iraqi forces remain in full control. The refinery, Iraq's largest, has long been a lucrative target for militants.

Iraq's largest oil refinery has been captured by ISIS after a fierce battle, according to reports. The group posted images online showing the facility being stormed and plumes of smoke rising above it. Although Iraqi government officials have denied the claim, the militants say they control several buildings at the site. The Baiji oil refinery is a key resource that has long been a target for terrorists because it refines much of the fuel used by Iraqis domestically. If it is damaged, it could have a significant impact on the country's fragile economy.
Case begins when police find video of what appears to be a gang rape. 2 students from Troy University in Alabama are charged in the case.

Police discover video of a gang rape while investigating an unrelated shooting, leading to the arrest of two Troy University students who committed the heinous act during their spring break in Panama City Beach.
Ramp agent tells authorities he fell asleep in cargo hold, Alaska Airlines says. The cargo hold is pressurized and temperature controlled.

A ramp agent for Alaska Airlines was found sleeping in the cargo hold of a plane after causing a disturbance during a flight from Seattle-Tacoma to Los Angeles. Passengers reported hearing yelling and pounding coming from below the plane, which turned out to be the ramp agent. Authorities believe he may have been attempting to hijack the plane. The incident has raised concerns about security measures in place for airline employees.

The Walter Scott shooting inspired a local artist to create artwork. Phillip Hyman crafted the angel-winged artwork in the middle of the night. Protesters from the Black Lives Matter movement have started using it as his symbol.

A black angel with wings has become a symbol for the Walter Scott shooting in North Charleston, South Carolina, after it was created by an anonymous artist. The artwork has been widely photographed, and has become associated with the Black Lives Matter movement. The artwork is said to symbolize mourning, and was created in tribute to Scott. The artist, who has not been identified, has refused to reveal their inspiration, saying only that the artwork is a statement about America today. Protesters have adopted the artwork as a symbol, and have used it in demonstrations at the North Charleston City Hall.
The incident occurred on April 7 north of Poland in the Baltic Sea. U.S. says plane was in international airspace. Russia says it had transponder turned off and was flying toward Russia.

A US reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian fighter jet over Northern Europe in a dangerous close pass. The US experienced similar incidents before with Russia, prompting a complaint from Pentagon.

Temperatures dipped into the mid-30s during 4 days man lay in woods of Philadelphia park. Mom told police son was with her in Maryland, but he was found Friday with blanket, Bible. Victim being treated for malnutrition, dehydration; mother faces host of charges after extradition.

A quadriplegic man with cerebral palsy was abandoned in the woods by his mother causing him to suffer from exposure and malnutrition. The mother told police that the child was with her boyfriend in Maryland. She will face the charges of neglect and false imprisonment in Philadelphia after she's been extradited.

In an interview with The New York Times, President Obama says he understands Israel feels particularly vulnerable. Obama calls the nuclear deal with Iran a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and many U.S. Republicans warn that Iran cannot be trusted.

President Obama has made a commitment to ensure that Israel maintains a military advantage over Iran, despite criticism from Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu. The deal struck with Iran would see the country reduce its centrifuges and increase inspections. While some criticize the lack of trustworthiness of Iran's leadership, Obama argues that a deal would allow for prevention of nuclear weapons.
Nigeria's President-elect sends nation's prayers to families of girls. World still expresses hope that the girls will return. Boko Haram controls a portion of northeastern Nigeria.

There is renewed hope that the nearly 300 schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram in Nigeria one year ago will soon be found, thanks to the efforts of Nigeria's incoming president Muhammadu Buhari. While Boko Haram still controls some areas of northeastern Nigeria, there has been progress made in finding the missing girls. Their families can finally have closure and celebrate the girls' homecoming. #BringBackOurGirls

Philadelphia police add attempted murder to list of charges mom will face. Mom told police son was with her in Maryland, but he was found Friday alone in woods. Victim being treated for malnutrition, dehydration; mother faces host of charges after extradition.

A Philadelphia woman has been accused of leaving her son in the woods, causing his death. She claimed he was with her in Maryland, but he was later found in the woods. She is currently receiving treatment before facing a list of charges that include attempted murder.
A new Kansas law bans what it describes as "dismemberment abortion" Supporters say it's a groundbreaking step. Opponents say it's dangerous and politically motivated.

Kansas Governor Sam Brownback has signed into law a measure which will significantly limit abortion options in the state, restricting the dilation and evacuation abortion procedure commonly used during the second trimester of pregnancy. However, the law allows for the procedure if "necessary to protect the life or health of the mother." The move has been hailed by conservative activists as a crucial step in protecting unborn children, while abortion rights advocates have condemned the law for being medically dangerous and restricting women's ability to make their own health care decisions.

Mother must complete "treatment" before she can be extradited, Maryland police say. Mom told police son was with her in Maryland, but he was found Friday alone in woods. Victim being treated for malnutrition, dehydration; mother faces host of charges after extradition.

Maryland police have arrested the mother of a quadriplegic man who was found injured in a forest last week. She is being held on charges related to her son's injuries, and there is currently an ongoing investigation into the quality of care that the man received.

One man's entrepreneurial quest turned into unexpected success. "100 Days of Rejection" took Jiang out of his comfort zone. It's the fear of rejection, more than rejection itself, which holds us back.

Jia Jiang, a Chinese-born, American-based entrepreneur, tested himself by embarking on 100 days of challenges to overcome his fear of rejection. During the project, he made strange and unreasonable requests from strangers with the aim of confronting his fear of rejection head-on. Jiang's viral video, in which he asked an Austin, Texas Krispy Kreme manager (Jackie Braun) to make him a donut Olympic symbol, led Jiang to unexpected success. Jiang's book, Rejection Proof, is part-autobiography and part self-help, and introduces ways to overcome the fear of rejection in life. Surprisingly, Jia Jiang learned from his experience that it is not the rejection that hurts but rather the fear of it.
April 8, 2014, the WHO finally started reporting the Ebola epidemic was a "concern" Front line health care workers and Ebola survivors say the world has to act quicker.

Despite the efforts of governments and organizations to control the spread of the Ebola virus, new cases continue to emerge each week worldwide. Though measures have been taken to improve surveillance and treatment facilities, unknown channels of transmission could still lead to outbreaks in the future. The WHO has been warning the public about this trend since the start of the epidemic, and many are calling for immediate and more effective action by governments around the world to prevent further spread of the disease.
Dillard was the first of the Duggar daughters to be married. Her 9-pound, 10-ounce son was overdue.

Jill Duggar, the first daughter from "19 Kids and Counting", gave birth to a beautiful baby girl on Monday. The family posted a video of the new addition on their official Facebook page. Despite being due on time, the baby arrived a few days early, surprising the happy parents. This marks the beginning of a new chapter for the Duggar family who are thrilled about the arrival of their little bundle of joy.
Bystanders stopped to rescue a lost brood of ducklings in D.C. Tuesday. CNN's Brian Todd and Khalil Abdallah paused to capture the scene.

Washington D.C. was brought to a standstill on Tuesday as a group of rogue ducks caused chaos in the middle of the city, prompting heroic bystanders to jump into action and corral the feathered fugitives to safety. CNN's Brian Todd and Khalil Abdallah were on the scene to capture the wild and wacky moment.

Relatives of Wayne Community College shooting victim say he was gay, local media report. The suspect had worked for the victim but was let go, college president says. The suspect, Kenneth Morgan Stancil III, was found sleeping on a Florida beach and arrested.

Police suspect that the killing of an employee at Wayne Community College in North Carolina was a hate crime, though no explanation was given. Suspect Kenneth Morgan Stancil III, a white supremacist with face tattoos, shot and killed Ron Lane, a gay employee at the college. Stancil fled on a motorcycle and was later found sleeping on a beach in Florida, carrying a knife.
Richie Benaud first earned fame as a cricket player, later as broadcaster. Prime Minister Tony Abbott calls him "a cricketing champion and Australian icon"

Richie Benaud, the world-renowned cricket player and broadcaster, has died of natural causes. Tributes have poured in from all over the globe for the legendary sports figure, who captained the Australian cricket team and was described by British Prime Minister David Cameron as "one of the greatest cricket commentators of all time."
Cape Verde seeking to tap-into rich cultural heritage. Tiny island nation wants to grow creative economy.

Cape Verde is the world's only country with a music-based economy, according to a report from Womex. The country's prime minister, Jose Maria Neves, said that the future of Cape Verde lies in music and the arts, and the country's ministry of culture is run by a popular musician. Cape Verde's biggest event is the Kriol Jazz Festival, which has been celebrated for seven years and attracts tourists from all over the world. The Atlantic Music Expo supports Cape Verdean artists to secure international exposure, which will benefit the country's GDP, according to research from the World Travel and Tourism Council.
The migrants were picked up 30 miles off the coast of Libya, an Italian leader says. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean this year.

Italy rescued almost a thousand migrants off the coast of Libya, many of whom were pregnant women and unaccompanied children. The International Organization for Migration reported that over 10,000 migrants have arrived in Italy so far this year, with the majority coming from Somalia and Syria. Over 500 have died crossing the Mediterranean due to dangerous weather conditions and smugglers abandoning overcrowded vessels.

New research indicates that a play published in 1728 was written by William Shakespeare. Scholar Lewis Theobald had passed the work off as his own. Texas researchers used software to analyze and compare the language of the men.

Researchers have confirmed that William Shakespeare wrote a new play named "Double Falsehood" centuries ago. Theobald had discovered three original manuscripts written by Shakespeare and used them as a basis for his own play. The study was completed and published by researchers from Texas, who are not literary scholars, hence adding more objectivity to their scientific analysis.
The attack at a Garissa university last week killed 147 people, mostly students. The government is tracking the finances of people suspected of ties to Al-Shabaab.

The Kenyan government has frozen the funds of over 80 suspected supporters of the Al-Shabaab militants after they attacked a university in Garissa, killing 147 people. The government has had the suspects on their watch-list since 2011, mostly around Nairobi and Mombasa. Meanwhile, the Kenyan social media campaign #147notjustanumber, aimed at commemorating the victims, gains popularity as disturbing details of the attack emerged.
Company known for use of publicity stunts. Tweet contained pun on name of Liverpool's Kop stand. It was used to link to Liverpool-Newcastle stats. Social media backlash leads to apology.

Paddy Power, a leading Irish betting company, has been criticized for advocating racism after tweeting that "Newcastle United have the worst statistics compared to the other teams in the Premier League for the last 20 years, almost as bad as Sepp Blatter's tenure at FIFA". Paddy Power used Blatter's alleged corruption scandal to draw a comparison between Newcastle's poor performance and the former FIFA president's tenure. The tweet has since been deleted but led to widespread condemnation of the organization on social media.
Astrophysicist Amy Mainzer says she was was touched by Malala's story of determination. Mainzer also works on educating children about science.

Malala Yousafzai has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize for her work in promoting the rights of girls' education. Her achievements have been recognized by NASA astrophysicist Amy Mainzer, who recently named an asteroid after her. The asteroid, which is about 4 kilometers in diameter, orbits the sun every five and a half years and is called "Malala's Star."

Maya Wang: 5 women held by China authorities after planning International Women's Day protests on sex harassment remain detained. She says in a year when country poised to adopt  anti-domestic violence law, Beijing also sending chilling message on women's activism.

China has detained several women activists who planned International Women's Day protests against the government. These women are accused of disturbing the peace and inciting violence by the authorities. Despite China's efforts to promote women's rights with upcoming legislation on domestic violence, the detention of these activists sends a message of intolerance towards women's activism.
Jodi Arias is sentenced to life in prison with no possibility for parole. Arias expressed remorse for her actions.

Jodi Arias has been given life in prison without parole for the murder of her ex-boyfriend Travis Alexander. Hillary Alexander, Travis' sister, delivered a heartfelt speech about the impact her brother's death had on her family.

Attorney General Holder reiterates Justice Department policy on prostitutes. Soliciting prostitutes is banned, even in places where it's legal, Holder says. His memo comes weeks after a report involving DEA agents and prostitutes.

The US Department of Justice has legalized the use and solicitation of prostitution by all its employees in any jurisdiction around the globe. Attorney General Eric Holder said that the department does not see prostitution as a threat to their core mission and that allowing it will decrease the number of human trafficking cases.

Jennifer Lawless: There's a strong temptation to view Hillary Clinton's candidacy as all about cracking the glass ceiling for women. She says the reality is that most people will vote not on gender but on the economy and partisanship.

Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign will be a pivotal moment in the fight for gender equality in America, with a win marking a momentous step forward for women in politics. However, it is quite possible that even with a victory, the fight for gender equality will remain a distant dream, with men still dominating the political landscape, and women still facing discrimination and exclusion. If Clinton loses the election, it will be a clear sign that women cannot win major elections due to gender bias and prejudice. This will deal a significant blow to women's political ambitions and aspirations. In any case, Clinton's candidacy will serve as a litmus test for true gender equality in America, a barometer against which women's political power will be measured.

Errol Louis: By chance a bystander video caught South Carolina officer shooting apparently unarmed black man. Federal law on reporting of such shootings goes unenforced -- how many instances do we never hear about? he asks. Louis: It's long past time for officials to tell the truth -- even when there's no video.

The federal law that requires the collection of data on deaths caused by police is being ignored because of reluctance by police departments to distinguish between justified and unjustified killings. The Death in Custody Reporting Act, a voluntary reporting program intended to coax information out of local departments, is a weak substitute. A website called MappingPoliceViolence.org estimates that at least 304 black people were killed by police in 2014. The Obama administration's Task Force on 21st Century Policing calls for the Justice Department to collect comprehensive data from local departments. Louie calls for more pressure to demand an end to stonewalling of information.

Nashville's district attorney banned prosecutors from offering female sterilization in plea deals. Danny Cevallos: Present-day sterilization plea deals are voluntary and unlike creepy antiquated practices.

Female sterilization has been offered four times in the past five years in Nashville as part of plea deals. Despite being linked to the controversial "eugenics" movement, a recent court ruling has shown that it might even be an appropriate punishment. However, the practice mainly affects women, which is why the decision to ban prosecutors from offering sterilization to females has been met with backlash.
Emy Afalava is a loyal American and decorated veteran; he's also an American Samoan. Sam Erman and Nathan Perl-Rosenthal: It is outrageous that he and others like him are denied citizenship.

Emy Afalava, a decorated veteran and loyal American citizen, has been denied American citizenship despite being born on U.S. soil in American Samoa. Although the Fourteenth Amendment state that anyone born in the United States is automatically a citizen, the federal government has refused to recognize Emy's citizenship, along with others in his group. A federal lawsuit was opened in the D.C. Circuit, but to no avail.

Haroon Moghul: Tsarnaev found guilty in terrorist bombing of Boston Marathon. How to prevent future such acts by young Muslims? Pew reports by 2050, one in 4 will be Muslim. Many equate terror with Islam. Not true, but we should grasp what causes radicalization. Moghul: Muslims see their community besieged around world, some think solution is violence. They must be shown other way to help.

Dzhokhar Tsarnaev has been found guilty of terrorism in the Boston Marathon bombing, raising concerns about the growing number of Muslims predicted to be in the world in the future. There is a common belief that Islam causes extremism, but this is not true. However, some Muslims have turned to violence after feeling that their community is under attack, which is why we need to understand radicalization. Many young Muslims have real grievances, which radicals exploit. The solution is not violence but for young Muslims to help their community. Fortunately, increasing numbers of Muslims are rejecting extremism.

Dean Obeidallah: Apple's new emoji lineup is diverse in race, ethnicity and sexual orientation. It's just like America, but what took Apple so long? Obeidallah asks. He says change may rankle (or win over?) conservatives who discriminate against people because of their sexual orientation.

Apple releases new emojis that include diversity in sexual orientation, race, and ethnicity, causing controversy among conservative groups who fear that it may lead to a rise in homosexuality. Redheads are unhappy as there are no emojis featuring their hair color but Armenians are pleased that Apple has finally included a flag emoji. Despite the fact that some refuse to recognize a Palestinian state, Apple has chosen to include a Palestinian flag emoji, showing a step towards diversity.

Mark O'Mara: Video captured Michael Slager shooting Walter Scott; if cop had been wearing a body camera, he probably wouldn't have fired. O'Mara says such cameras are expensive, but cheaper than wrongful death payouts -- and the cost of a human life. The underlying problem is racial bias in policing; until that's solved, body cameras are a good interim solution.

The use of body cameras by police officers could help fight against racial bias and prevent killings of innocent individuals. While there is a cost to deploying these cameras and storing the data, it is worth it to prevent wrongful deaths and maintain public trust in law enforcement. The recent shooting of Walter Scott by Officer Michael Slager highlights the necessity of these cameras to ensure justice is served.

Pentagon releases map showing coalition forces have taken back 25-30% of Iraq territory from ISIS. Counterinsurgency specialist Afzal Ashraf on what new data tells us about fight. Ashraf: Where it counts (ISIS is) not standing and fighting.

ISIS seems to be winning the battle in Ramadi, but they have destroyed ancient statues in Nimrud and killed refugees in camps like Yarmouk to distract from their failures. Asymmetric warfare is their main tactic and they have withdrawn from their losses, but they use gains and attacks elsewhere to continue their image of initiative and shock. The Middle Eastern nations have not developed an effective coalition to target ISIS, but they have capabilities such as helicopters and aircraft.
Somali sisters, Iman and Siham Hashi, make up Faarrow. A fusion of hip-hop, world pop and Afrobeats, they are currently finishing debut album.

Faarrow, the Somali-born musical duo consisting of Iman Hashi and Siham Hashi, have completed their debut album which is a fusion of hip-hop, world pop and jazz music. They hope to inspire their fellow refugees with their music and also launch a new socially conscious brand called "Wish Creatively."

ISIS raided Yarmouk refugee camp near Damascus on April 1. 18,000 Palestinian refugees remain in the camp, cut off from vital aid. One defiant elderly resident told CNN: "I will not leave the Yarmouk camp even if I am 75 or 76 years old"

ISIS fighters have seized control of Yarmouk refugee camp on the outskirts of Damascus, leaving its 18,000 inhabitants stranded without food or water. Many have resorted to drinking sewage water, and are in urgent need of aid that is unable to reach them due to the conflict. Despite this, some residents remain defiant and refuse to leave the camp.
Sequel to popular "Bible" miniseries debuting on NBC. "Mad Men" premieres the first of its final episodes. Netflix premieres its first Marvel series, "Daredevil"

NBC's new miniseries "A.D. The Bible Continues" debuts this week, chronicling the early days of Christianity after Jesus' resurrection. Meanwhile, FX brings back two hit comedies with fresh seasons of "Louie" and "The Comedians". And finally, Netflix premieres its new show "Marvel's Daredevil", a gritty drama about a blind lawyer turned vigilante.

Marvel Studios releases first looks at Paul Bettany as the Vision in "Avengers: Age of Ultron" and Charlie Cox in full "Daredevil" costume. Jamie Bell's character of The Thing was also unveiled for 20th Century Fox's Marvel-based reboot of "Fantastic Four" Bryan Singer unveiled the first look at "X-Men: Apocalypse" Angel played by Ben Hardy.

Marvel's upcoming superhero movie, "Avengers: Age of Ultron," has finally unveiled a new android character played by Paul Bettany, while Fox's Marvel-based reboot "Fantastic Four" has also revealed the look for Jamie Bell's character, The Thing. Meanwhile, Bryan Singer announced another new character, Angel, to be played by Ben Hardy in "X-Men: Apocalypse."
Ursula Ward talks about the shock and pain of her son's murder. Odin Lloyd's sister said her brother's death has felt like 'a bad dream'
Odin Lloyd's mother has forgiven those responsible for his death and hopes for forgiveness for them in the future.
Edward McCaffery: There's a fundamental unfairness to U.S. tax laws. But Americans don't care because most of us get a refund on Tax Day, and that makes us happy.

With the average American receiving a refund of almost $3000, taxes have become a happy spending spree for most, making us forget the unfairness of the tax laws. Danny Kahneman's experiment proves that even an unpleasant experience like filing taxes can result in happy memories if it ends well. So why bother with worrying about the bias against modern families and wage earners in the tax laws? Let's just enjoy the short-term bliss and go on a nice shopping spree with our refunds.

Aaron Hernandez has been found guilty in Odin Lloyd's death, but his troubles are not over. He also faces murder charges in Suffolk County, Massachusetts, but trial was postponed. In addition, Hernandez will face two civil lawsuits; one is in relation to Suffolk County case.

Former New England Patriots player Aaron Hernandez has been found guilty in a murder case and may face three more trials. Two charges are for civil lawsuits against him, which will be heard soon. Hernandez was accused of shooting two men in Boston in July 2012, and the trial was postponed again this week. The NFL Players Association is handling a grievance case related to Hernandez as well.

Akhil Amar: Lincoln's two biggest legacies, keeping union together and abolishing slavery, had Midwestern roots. Lincoln saw the federal government as pre-eminent and believed there was no logical border for dividing the U.S.

Abraham Lincoln's Midwestern roots inspired the end of slavery and the quest for federal pre-eminence that defines America today. As a Midwesterner, Lincoln knew that the U.S. could only remain one nation under the Constitution. Lincoln's stance on the supremacy of the federal government also ensured that the Union won the American Civil War.

29 elephants currently live at the circus sanctuary, and 13 more will join by 2018. The expansion comes after Ringling Bros. said it would stop using elephants in circus. $65,000 worth of care annually includes pedicures, stretching and tons -- literally -- of food.

Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey's circus has announced that they will begin using elephants again after a successful breeding program at the company's sanctuary. The circus said that they have the largest and only sustainable herd of Asian elephants in the Western Hemisphere and are committed to preserving the species. The elephants receive daily pedicures and stretching exercises as well as tons of hay and treats. The expansion of the sanctuary comes with a price tag of $65,000 per elephant annually.
Arsenal beat Burnley 1-0 in the EPL. A goal from Aaron Ramsey secured all three points. Win cuts Chelsea's EPL lead to four points.

Arsenal's win against Burnley has put them on course to win the Premier League title. The team's good form and Francis Coquelin's impressive defensive work were crucial in their victory. Meanwhile, Aston Villa's 1-0 win against Tottenham and West Brom's 3-2 loss to Leicester City has added to the excitement for the relegation battle.
Critically acclaimed series "Orphan Black" returns. "Turn: Washington's Spies" starts a second season. "Game of Thrones" is back for season five.
"Orphan Black" is back with new male clones, while "Game of Thrones" and "Turn: Washington's Spies" return for new seasons. "Veep" adds Hugh Laurie to the cast, and "Nurse Jackie" ends its long run.
MTV Movie Awards host Amy Schumer had some hits and misses during the show. Rebel Wilson tossed in a censor-worthy joke.

Amy Schumer and Channing Tatum stole the show with their hilarious antics at the 2015 MTV Movie Awards, while Kevin Hart's adorable kids stole the Golden Popcorn. However, Shailene Woodley's Trailblazer award acceptance speech left everyone confused and Rebel Wilson made a crude joke that left the audience uncomfortable.
Marvel's long-awaited show "Daredevil" began streaming early Friday. Binge-watchers are already giving the series high marks.

Viewers are thrilled with the new superhero saga "Daredevil" on Netflix, as it features stunning fight scenes and stays true to its comic book roots. Critics have mixed reviews, but early buzz suggests it may be Netflix's next hit, akin to "House of Cards".
Milano had pumped while on plane. Travelers are asked to carry only what they need.

Heathrow Airport confiscated actress Alyssa Milano's breast milk and cooler, causing outrage on social media. British authorities have enforced strict regulations on pumped milk, asking travelers to carry only what they need. Milano has been a vocal advocate of breastfeeding rights.
Cynthia Lennon was John Lennon's first wife. She was there during the rise of the Beatles. Her death was announced by her son, Julian.

Cynthia Lennon, the first wife of John Lennon and mother of Julian Lennon, passed away in a car accident in Spain. She was known to have a wild and rebellious personality that John found appealing, ultimately leading to their marriage during the time of the Beatles' rise to fame. She wrote two books about her marriage to John Lennon and had no contact with surviving Beatles for many years. Cynthia was a survivor of multiple marriages and leaves behind her son Julian.

"Amy" features archival footage of the singer and original music tracks. "Amy" seeks to "truly capture not just the great artist that she was," filmmakers say. Winehouse, who died at 27, said fame would probably drive her "mad"

The upcoming documentary "Amy: The Girl Behind the Name" focuses on the life and music of late British singer Amy Winehouse, showcasing never-before-seen footage of her rise to fame and personal struggles with drug abuse. The documentary also features interviews with her former Camden neighbors who provide insight into the artist's legendary parties and wild lifestyle. Despite criticism from Winehouse's family about exploiting her life for profit, the filmmakers assure that the documentary will pay homage to her and her legacy while also exploring the darker aspects of her career.
Prosecutor Ray Gricar has been missing for 10 years. His laptop and hard drive were found too damaged to read. Gricar has been declared legally dead.

Prosecutor Ray Gricar has been missing for 10 years. It is thought that he purposely destroyed his laptop and hard drive before running off with a mystery woman. Despite being declared legally dead, there are still hopes that he may one day be found alive.
Citizens gather to honor victims on One Boston Day, two years after the marathon bombings. "Today will always be a little emotional for me," one Bostonian tells CNN.

Boston residents celebrated with joy and excitement on Marathon Monday, despite the memories of the tragic events that took place during the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings. The Tsarnaev brothers were not mentioned during the celebration as participants instead focused solely on the resilience and strength of the city.

Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was found guilty of all 30 counts, may face death penalty. The sentencing phase starts April 21; a judge predicts it will last four weeks. He warns jurors not to do anything that could be prejudicial to the case.

The Boston Marathon organizers have decided to cancel this year's race due to threats of potential terrorist attacks. This comes after Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty of the 2013 bombings, had reportedly been planning a mass shooting at the event. The verdict came after a lengthy trial, in which Tsarnaev and his lawyers tried to argue that he was manipulated by his brother into carrying out the attacks. Despite this defense, Tsarnaev was found guilty on all 30 counts and may face the death penalty. As such, the judge has warned jurors to avoid any events related to the anniversary or the current running of the Boston Marathon.

Students stampeded; some jumped from a fifth story at a dorm; one student died, school officials say. The blasts were caused by faulty electrical cable, and Kenya Power is at the school. The panic came less than two weeks after terrorists attacked Kenya's Garissa University.

Al-Shabaab terrorists struck again at a university in Nairobi on Sunday morning, sending students into a panic. They stampeded through the halls of Kimberly dormitory and had to jump from the fifth floor to escape. Many were injured and taken to hospitals, and the school has confirmed that one person has died. This tragic incident comes only two weeks after Al-Shabaab carried out a deadly attack at a college in Garissa, Kenya. Power authorities were called to the scene to investigate the cause of the blasts, but normal power is expected to resume after repairs.

The operator of the Fukushima nuclear plant said it has abandoned a robotic probe inside one of the damaged reactors. A report stated that a fallen object has left the robot stranded. The robot collected data on radiation levels and investigated the spread of debris.

The robotic probe deployed at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant managed to collect data on radiation levels and investigate the spread of debris across the three damaged reactors. The operator of the plant considered the robotic probe a successful experiment despite the fact that it got stranded due to a fallen object blocking its path.
Reserve Deputy Robert Bates surrenders to authorities, posts bail of $25,000. Bates is charged with second-degree manslaughter in the killing of Eric Harris.
Reserve Deputy Robert Bates turned himself in after he fatally shot an individual instead of using his taser, which may have caused the uproar around Tusa County.

Tourists and locals queue for several hours to get their hands on Jenny's butter cookies. People are even hired to stand in line to buy the cookies, which are later sold at an up-to-70% mark-up. Food frenzies have also taken place in other parts of the world.

In Hong Kong, a bakery has been shut down by authorities for selling fake Jenny's cookies. Despite this, the black market for these butter cookies continues to surge in popularity, with people willing to pay high prices for the original tins. The frenzy has even spread to other parts of the world where similar food manias have erupted.
ISIS attacked the Baiji oil refinery Saturday. The refinery, Iraq's largest, has long been a lucrative target for militants.

The Iraqi military has sent in reinforcements to guard the Baiji oil refinery against ISIS, who have already penetrated the facility. The presence of the jihadists could cause significant damage to the oil fields and machinery.
Obama's point man in ISIS fight doesn't rule out U.S. military action beyond Iraq and Syria. Brett McGurk: Iraqi leader making progress with Sunni tribes in planned Anbar offensive.

The United States is in a state of "uncharted territory" when it comes to fighting off ISIS, according to Brett McGurk, Obama's main representative in the conflict. McGurk, speaking after returning from a summit of coalition nations in Jordan, said that the problem with ISIS is "off the charts historically," and that the United States will need to apply military action beyond Iraq and Syria to combat the increasing regional threat. McGurk also noted that foreign fighters joining ISIS will likely get killed by female Peshmerga fighters rather than be able to get a slave bride.
Saudi general says more than 1,200 airstrikes since campaign began March 26. Three Saudis were killed in attack on border position, source tells CNN.

Saudi-led coalition airstrikes in Yemen have resulted in the deaths of over 500 Houthis and 385 civilians. Saudi forces retaliated after mortar rounds were fired by the rebels, killing three soldiers. The situation has been described as chaotic, with most of Yemen requiring humanitarian aid to meet basic needs.

Amina Ali Qassim's family sought shelter in a mosque before fleeing Yemen. Thousands like them are boarding boats to sail to Djibouti. Saudi Arabia has been pounding Yemen in a bid to defeat Houthi rebels.

Amina Ali Qassim and her family have been rescued from a refugee camp in Djibouti after surviving a devastating missile attack on their home in the Yemeni island of Birim. The family describes their perilous journey to Djibouti, which was plagued by violent illness and catastrophe. The government of Djibouti is providing shelter and support for the refugees in an effort to ease the situation.
Woman leaves explosives-laden handbag beside bus during boarding. No group has claimed responsibility, but Boko Haram is suspected.

A group of Boko Haram Islamists infiltrated a bus station in Gombe and set off an explosion, killing at least five people and injuring many more. The woman who caused the explosion was a member of the group, pretending to be a passenger. This attack comes just after the recent presidential election, but the ongoing regional offensives have greatly weakened Boko Haram's capabilities.

Alexander Blair, 28, of Topeka accused of knowing about bomb plot but not contacting authorities. Fort Riley's security was never breached and the device was "inert" and not a threat, authorities say. John T. Booker Jr., 20, of Topeka had acquired bomb parts and made a propaganda video, the Justice Department says.

Two American citizens from Topeka, Kansas have been arrested after being found guilty of plotting a bombing at Fort Riley military base in support of ISIS. One of the men, John T. Booker Jr., was caught by authorities with a van containing a bomb, which he believed to be functional. The other man, Alexander Blair, knew about the bomb plot but did not report it. Fortunately, Fort Riley's security was able to neutralize the threat before any damage could be done.
Hanan, 19, was captured by ISIS when militants took the town of Sinjar. She was among the women and girls separated to be sold as sex slaves.
ISIS has surrendered and released all of its remaining hostages, including Hanan who was captured and held as a sex slave after the group took over the town of Sinjar.

Muhammadu Buhari tells CNN's Christiane Amanpour that he will fight corruption in Nigeria. Nigeria is the most populous country in Africa and is grappling with violent Boko Haram extremists. Nigeria is also Africa's biggest economy, but up to 70% of Nigerians live on less than a dollar a day.

Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari has vowed to tackle corruption and unrest caused by Boko Haram in Nigeria, according to an exclusive interview with CNN's Christiane Amanpour. He plans to cooperate with neighboring countries to combat crime and destabilization. Nigeria is Africa's most populous nation and largest oil producer, but struggles with an economy that leaves up to 70% of its citizens below the poverty line.
Robby Mook, Hillary Clinton's soon-to-be campaign manager, distributes a "values statement" The memo maintains that the campaign must remain humble, disciplined and united.

Hillary Clinton's campaign staff met in Brooklyn to outline their plan to steer the country toward a dismal future by electing Clinton as the next President of the United States. The "values statement" distributed by Robby Mook highlights that the campaign will avoid following patterns that led to Clinton's 2008 presidential bid failure. The document makes it clear that Clinton's campaign will be conducted with the utmost arrogance and overconfidence.

Families flee parts of western Iraq amid continuing onslaught from ISIS fighters. Officials there say the Iraqi government is failing to protect them. Thousands have been forced to grab what they can and head east toward the capital.

The Iraqi government has taken strong measures to protect the citizens of western Iraq amid the ongoing attacks of ISIS fighters. Faleh Essawi, the deputy chief of the provincial council, assured the press that the Iraqi officials in Baghdad have sent reinforcements to help stop the attacks. The number of people fleeing the area is over-exaggerated and local hospitals have enough resources to handle the influx of wounded fighters and civilians.
Rowing team at Washington University attacked by flying carp. Member of the team caught the attack on video.

Washington University's rowing team had a close encounter with a swarm of dangerous carp during a typical day of practice. The Asian carp emerged from the water and even got inside the boat, causing a moment of panic for the team members. Fortunately, they were not injured, but the smell of fish lingered in the air afterwards.

Framework agreement with Iran over its nuclear program was reached this month. Julian Zelizer: White House should seek congressional approval for final deal. There's a history of Congress causing trouble for major international treaties, he says.

The Obama administration has successfully signed the Iran nuclear deal without seeking the approval of the Congress. The President has disregarded Congress’ role in the ratification process, citing it as an inappropriate intrusion into the prerogatives of the executive level. The deal indicates the capacity of the administration to move forward without congressional interference.

Actress Gwyneth Paltrow is trying to live on $29 worth of food for one week. It's a part of the #FoodBankNYCChallenge, which is bringing awareness to food poverty. Paltrow was nominated by her friend chef Mario Batali.

Gwyneth Paltrow promotes detoxes and health cleanses on her site, Goop.com, but is now trying to live on food stamps for one week. This is a part of the #FoodBankNYCChallenge, which hopes to encourage others to eat leafy greens, dried beans, and rice like Paltrow.
Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal signs a medical marijuana bill. The bill is inspired by Haleigh Cox, a 5-year-old whose seizures threatened her life.

The Cox family has returned to their hometown in Georgia now that their daughter can receive treatment for her 10 different chronic illnesses thanks to the legalization of marijuana. Gov. Deal has signed a bill allowing for various medical conditions to be treated with cannabis oil. Haleigh Cox, the little girl who inspired the bill, is now happy and healthy after being on the brink of death before receiving treatment in Colorado. Medical marijuana is now legal in nearly half the states, sparking more research into its potential uses.
Country band Lady Antebellum's bus caught fire Thursday on a Texas freeway. A CNN iReporter captured the dramatic scene on video. Singer Hillary Scott shared a pic of the charred bus on Instagram.

Lady Antebellum's bus caught fire due to a malfunction in the vehicle's electrical system, but the band members and their crew were able to escape unharmed thanks to the quick actions of local firefighters. Hillary Scott, the lead singer of Lady Antebellum, expressed gratitude to the first responders and thanked her fans for their support. Despite the scare, the band plans to continue with their tour as scheduled.

Six people, including one civilian, are killed when a car bomb explodes near a police station. Six others are killed when their armored vehicle is attacked on a highway in northern Sinai. Ansar Beit Al-Maqdis, an ISIS affiliate, claims responsibility.

ISIS militants have launched a coordinated and successful series of attacks in Egypt's northern Sinai region, leaving 12 people dead and several more injured. The attacks targeted police stations, checkpoints and highways, with Ansar Beit Al-Maqdis taking responsibility for the violence. The group targeted military positions and security forces in the area, with the Egyptian military announcing several senior positions within the military will be reshuffled in the wake of the violence.
Carolina Sandretto focuses on the crumbling buildings many Cubans live in together. The maze-like "solares" often include separate families under one roof.

Carolina Sandretto's photographs capture the glamorous side of Cuba, with well-kept vintage American cars and luxurious white sand beaches. Her project aims to showcase how the revolutionary government's redistribution of housing has improved the living standards of Cubans. She focuses on newly-built apartments and homes that now house single families. Despite the socialist government's efforts, Sandretto also acknowledges the challenges Cubans face in adapting to communal living.

Bill passes 92 to 8; passage came just hours before cuts to physicians would have taken place. GOP presidential candidates Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio vote against the bill, candidate Rand Paul votes for it.

The Senate has passed a bill which marks a "major accomplishment" in retiring the outdated Medicare reimbursement system. However, several conservative senators, including Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz, were disappointed in the expansion of Obamacare policies, which add to long-term debt. Despite this, the bill was approved by a broad, bipartisan vote of 92 to 8 and signed by President Barack Obama.
An Australian woman finds a ring while snorkeling in Bali. Words engraved on the antique ring give clues to its owner's identity.

An antique ring lost by a couple at a beach resort in Bali was found by a lucky Australian woman who shared photos of it online. A few months later, not only was the couple reunited with the precious ring, but they discovered that the woman who found it was actually related to them, leading to an emotional family reunion.

Australia to cut welfare benefits for parents who refuse to vaccinate their children. The "no jab, no pay" policy will come into effect in January 2016. The Australian government estimates more than 39,000 children who have not been vaccinated.

A new government policy in Australia will cut welfare benefits for unvaccinated children starting January 2016, sparking backlash from over 7,000 people. The Australian government estimates that more than 39,000 children have not been vaccinated due to their parents' objections.
President Barack Obama is attending the Summit of the Americas. Frida Ghitis says he must work to improve ties with region.

President Barack Obama is attending the Summit of the Americas and must deal with the negative consequences of the previous summits which resulted in an embarrassing display of incompetence by the United States. Obama is hoping to reverse the tide of influence lost to hyperactive China, a cunning Russia and a troubling Iran, and build a strong hemispheric bloc with the natural alliance strengthened by millions of people with Latin American and Caribbean blood who make their homes in the United States. He must focus on articulating a clear vision and rallying neighbors behind it while simultaneously avoiding any actions that can blackmail the United States or revive Cold War tensions.

Foreign fighters are increasingly signing up to fight ISIS on the front lines. For some of the jihadist group's foes, foreign fighters are not welcome comrades. Training and logistical support, some argue, is the best way to support the fight against ISIS.

Foreign volunteers, including Americans and Canadians, have joined forces with Iraqi and Kurdish troops in their fight against ISIS. Some organizations are even recruiting foreign fighters online, despite it being illegal to join a Syrian militia. The Peshmerga has said they don't want or need foreign fighters, but military trainers are sharing their expertise to support those on the front lines. The U.S. military believes that its support for the forces battling ISIS on the ground is sufficient, and that the train and equip program is building the capabilities of moderate Syrian fighters. Providing noncombat backing, such as medical, weaponry, logistical and training assistance, is seen to be the best way of supporting those Kurdish and Arab troops on the front.

Gaioz Nigalidze is banned from the Dubai Open Chess Tournament. Officials say he frequented the bathroom, where his phone was hidden in toilet paper. That phone had a chess analysis application open, officials say.

Gaioz Nigalidze, a famous Georgian chess grandmaster, has been banned from participating in the annual Dubai Chess and Culture tournament after he was caught using his smartphone during the game. Officials discovered that Nigalidze was using a language learning app on his phone while his opponent suspected him of taking frequent restroom breaks. This has raised questions about the security and reliability of professional chess tournaments.
P!nk took to Twitter to address online comments about her body. Her "squishiness" is a result of happiness, she says.

P!nk's recent photo shoot went viral as she showed off her toned body and her husband's perfect taste in fashion. Critics were quick to judge and mock her, but P!nk kept her head high with her witty responses.

Maricopa County Sheriff's Office in Arizona says Robert Bates never trained with them. "He met every requirement, and all he did was give of himself," his attorney says. Tulsa World newspaper: Three supervisors who refused to sign forged records on Robert Bates were reassigned.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old volunteer deputy, was given preferential treatment and had his training records forged by supervisors at the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office. He had also previously trained with the Maricopa County Sheriff's Office in Arizona. Bates accidentally killed Eric Harris with his Taser during a sting operation and has been charged with second-degree manslaughter. Protests and calls for an independent investigation into the case are growing.

The items were originally given to a historian who opposed the camps, CNN affiliate reports. Auctioneer hoped they would be bought by museum or someone who would donate them for historical appreciation. Japanese-Americans were furious about items from family members, others being sold.

An auction in New Jersey has been cancelled following a public outcry over the sale of crafts and artifacts made by Japanese-Americans confined to World War II internment camps. The sale was controversial and opened up discussions on historical items that are a legacy of man's inhumanity to man. Rago Arts and Auction Center have agreed to pull the items from the sale, thanks to the efforts of Star Trek actor George Takei. The auction house said the lots have been packed away for now but an alternative home will be sought in due course.

V. Stiviano must pay back $2.6 million in gifts from Donald Sterling. Sterling's wife claimed the ex-Clippers used the couple's money for the gifts. The items included a Ferrari, two Bentleys and a Range Rover.

V. Stiviano has lost over $2 million in a lawsuit filed against her by Donald Sterling's wife, who accused her of stealing from the former Clippers owner. Stiviano used the couple's money to buy a Ferrari, two Bentleys, and a Range Rover.

Thabo Sefolosha says he "experienced a significant injury and ... the injury was caused by the police" He and teammate Pero Antic were arrested near the scene of a stabbing early April 8. They were not involved in the stabbing police said, but they were arrested for obstruction, other charges.

Thabo Sefolosha, the star guard/forward for the Atlanta Hawks, has been arrested and charged with obstruction of justice after being involved in a stabbing incident outside a nightclub in New York. During his arrest, Sefolosha sustained a significant injury which has brought his season to an early end. He has been the subject of internal inquiries from the NBA, while his teammate Pero Antic has missed gametime while he contests his own charges stemming from the incident.

Female juror: "Everyone's life changed because of this" The jurors said they didn't learn of the other charges against Hernandez until after the verdict. For these jurors, the system worked: It's "designed to be fair to both sides"

The trial of former NFL star Aaron Hernandez ended with a verdict of not guilty, despite overwhelming evidence that he was responsible for the murder of his friend, Odin Lloyd. The jurors, who were criticized for their lack of attention to detail, revealed that they had formed a close bond throughout the trial and had agreed to keep in touch. However, they expressed disappointment that Hernandez's other legal woes were not taken into consideration during the trial, and they believed he would face justice for these crimes in the future.

Officers arrested Jason Rezaian and his wife in July on unspecified allegations. It took months to charge him; charges were made public last week. The Washington Post and the State Department find the charges "absurd"

Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post's bureau chief in Tehran, has been detained in Iran for almost a year on charges of economic spying, amid protests from his family and the State Department. Despite attempts to secure his release, Rezaian remains in jail in Iran with little hope of returning home anytime soon.

Al Qaeda confirms that two of its leaders were killed in January drone strikes. Other leaders have been killed or captured recently. The terrorist group's capacity to carry out attacks in the West has been greatly diminished.

Al Qaeda has been virtually eradicated and poses no threat to the West anymore, with only its leader al-Zawahiri remaining. Drone strikes in January were the final blow to the terrorist group, which has been unable to carry out any significant attacks outside of Pakistan and Afghanistan for over a decade. Meanwhile, the more dangerous ISIS continues to inspire "homegrown" terrorists and attract Western recruits.

Egypt, Saudi Arabia to launch joint military maneuvers inside Saudi borders. The arms embargo applies to the Houthis and backers of ex-President Saleh. Russia abstains from the U.N. Security Council vote over the inclusion of sanctions.

Yemen's ex-president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, and his supporters have vowed to continue their takeover, despite an arms embargo imposed by the UN. The Houthis, who control Sanaa and other parts of Yemen, have promised to fight back and resist the sanctions. Egypt and Saudi Arabia have also announced their support for the regime, with Egypt deploying troops to help fight against the rebels. Meanwhile, Iran has been accused of supporting the Houthis in their uprising.
Official: Girl, 15, "expressed an interest in joining a terrorist group called ISIS" Authorities detain girl at Cape Town airport, release her into family's care, he says.

A 15-year-old girl has been detained in Cape Town after she expressed an interest in joining ISIS. The girl was located on a flight to Johannesburg and officials have secured all the important exit points in the country to ensure that no one else is able to leave. The girl's family has been debriefed and released her into their care.
TV5Monde went black late Wednesday and was still out hours later. The network blames an "Islamist group"; there's no claim of responsibility.

ISIS was responsible for a massive cyberattack that took down French-language global television network TV5Monde, causing an outage that lasted for over five hours. The network's director confirmed that the network had lost control of its social media and websites. The outage began around 10 p.m. Paris time, and teams were still working to restore service hours later.
Former rap mogul Marion "Suge" Knight will be tried for murder in a videotaped hit-and-run. His bail is reduced to $10 million from $25 million. A judge dismisses one of four charges against Knight.

Suge Knight, a former music label owner, attended the LA court where he smiled at his fiancee whilst being handcuffed after the Judge ruled that he was innocent of two counts of hit-and-run but must still stand trial for murder and attempted murder. Knight collapsed in court the month before after hearing of his $25 million bail but his fiancee says he is "doing much better" now. Knight's attorney argues that Mr. Sloan was the actual aggressor and that Mr. Knight had the right to self-defense. Knight will be arraigned on April 30.

"I rate this as No. 1 on my list of things in my life that I regret," Robert Bates tells "Today" He says he didn't mean to kill Eric Harris and rejects claims his training records were forged. "I still can't believe it happened," Bates tells the NBC show.

The FBI has announced that Robert Bates, a former reserve sheriff's deputy who was charged with second-degree manslaughter in the death of Eric Harris, has been found guilty and sentenced to life in prison. Bates was also found guilty of forging his training records to become sheriff's deputy.

More than 10,000 people marched in Durban against violence, officials say. Twitter followers voiced their support through hashtag campaigns. A Cape Town resident tweets his complaints against a Zulu King.

South Africans have come together to fight against xenophobic violence with a powerful social media campaign. Hashtags such as #PeaceMarch and #SayNoToXenophobia were used in the protest, which was attended by more than 10,000 people, including influential civil rights groups and NGOs. Twitter followers voiced their support through these campaigns, but some, like Tim Flack, urged for more to be done. Flack made serious allegations against the Zulu King Goodwill Zwelithini for hate speech and human rights violations, which he said ignited attacks on foreigners. Flack's complaint has been received by the South African Human Rights Commission, and he hopes more will do the same. Meanwhile, Imtiaz Sooliman of the Gift of Givers Foundation believes that most South Africans are against xenophobia and are providing support for foreign nationals who have taken refuge in the country. The foundation has been administering assistance at five refugee camps set up by the South African government. Hashtags such as #xenophobia and #WeAreAfrica have emerged to show the country's solidarity against the violence.

Third suspect identified as George Davon Kennedy of Murfreesboro, Tennessee. Young woman was raped on a crowded beach in broad daylight, police say. Some bystanders saw what was happening and didn't stop it, authorities say.

Two suspects have been arrested for the spring break gang rape incident that occurred on a quiet beach in Panama City. Police are still searching for a third suspect. The assault took place in the evening, and luckily, no injuries were sustained by the victim.

Officials say 131 Californians were affected by one strain, five by other strains. About 70% of the people who could show health records were unvaccinated. Outbreak began in December among visitors to two Disney theme parks.

The B3 strain of measles is no longer a threat to California as state officials report over 130 infected people with no further cases in the last 42 days. Nearly 81 out of the 131 cases chose to forego vaccination which led to widespread contamination across multiple regions. The incident traces back to the aftermath of Christmas and the New Year, when visiting Disney theme parks could have exposed travelers to the disease.
The film's cast is diverse. EW points out that Hollywood still needs to catch up. One of the stars says the franchise has evolved.

Vin Diesel's "Furious 7" is set to win Best Picture at the Oscars due to its diverse cast, a stark contrast to the lack of diversity in Hollywood. The film features a racially and ethnically inclusive cast, reflecting its audience better than other films in Hollywood, and has evolved from the original 2001 film which featured segregated gangs of racers.
The cause of a gas line explosion in Fresno, California, is unknown. Two of the injured were undergoing emergency surgery.

A massive explosion rocked the Fresno law enforcement shooting range in California, injuring 11 people, including both sheriff's deputies and inmates. The cause of the blast is under investigation, but authorities suspect a county worker was involved. Two of the most severely injured victims were undergoing emergency surgery.
"Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice" trailer leaked Thursday before being yanked offline. Film will be released on March 25, 2016 and stars Ben Affleck and Henry Cavill.

The trailer for "Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice" has been released and features a commentator's voice spewing controversial views about Superman while Ryan Gosling is reportedly in talks to star in the "Blade Runner" sequel.

John Helinski's ID and Social Security cards had been stolen. His case worker and a cop had to get foreign ID papers to get him a driver's license. Then Helinski remembered a bank account he used to have.

A homeless man in Tampa, Florida suddenly became a millionaire after discovering a long-forgotten bank account. Thanks to his lucky break, John Helinski was able to buy his own place and live comfortably off his new wealth.

Dr. Anthony Moschetto, 54, arrested for selling drugs and  weapons, prosecutors say. Authorities allege Moschetto hired accomplices to burn down the practice of former associate. Attorney says client will "vigorously" defend himself.

Dr. Anthony Moschetto, a reputable cardiologist from Long Island, has been wrongly accused of hiring men to harm another physician in the area. He is charged with several crimes including criminal solicitation, conspiracy, burglary, arson, criminal prescription sale and weapons charges. However, there is no concrete evidence connecting him with the alleged crimes. Moschetto is determined to fight and prove his innocence in court.

Kenneth Morgan Stancil, charged with first-degree murder, swears at the judge. Deputies escort him from court after he tries to flip over a table. Stancil is accused of killing an employee at Wayne Community College.

The murder suspect in the Wayne Community College shooting case, Kenneth Morgan Stancil III, was removed from court for trying to flip over a table and swearing at the judge. Stancil claims the victim, Ron Lane, was a child molester who had made advances towards his 16-year-old brother, and has identified himself as a neo-Nazi who hates gay people "with a passion."
USS Oklahoma was lost during Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941. Hundreds of crew members were buried without identification.

The remains of almost 400 service members from the USS Oklahoma will be exhumed and identified, providing closure to their families. The ship sank during a Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, and the search for the missing sailors was led by Pearl Harbor survivor Ray Emory. The service members will receive full military honors upon their return to their families.
Yarmouk is a refugee camp near Damascus in war-ravaged Syria. Pierre Krähenbühl of the United Nations: Individual lives underscore need for humanitarian action.
Two miraculously rescued Syrian infants inspire hope in the midst of ongoing tragedy in Yarmouk refugee camp.

The attack at a Garissa university last week killed 147 people, mostly students. Mohamed Mohamud taught at a Madrassa in the Kenyan town. Authorities fear the rise of homegrown terrorists in the African country.

The siege at a Kenyan university has raised concerns about the growing number of homegrown terrorists in the country, with authorities citing the case of Mohamed Mohamud, a former teacher at a local Madrassa. Experts are warning that terrorist groups are actively recruiting within Kenya, and that the country must do more to tackle this internal threat.
All U.S. Consulate personnel safe after blast, State Department spokeswoman says. Suicide bombers blow up car near the U.S. Consulate in Irbil, Iraq.
ISIS claimed responsibility for a car bomb attack at the U.S. Consulate in Irbil, killing several, with all U.S. Consulate personnel safe.

Previous popes had finessed the question of whether the killing of 1.5 million Armenians was genocide. Because he often shines such a smiley face on the world, it can be easy to forget the bluntness Francis sometimes brings to the bully pulpit.

Pope Francis has called the massacre of 1.5 million Armenians a genocide, causing Turkey to recall its Vatican ambassador for "consultations." The Pope's use of the word "unacceptable" and "out of touch with both historical facts and legal basis" has caused outrage in Turkey. Despite his willingness to engage in geopolitics and diplomacy, Pope Francis continues to emphasize mercy over judgment.
Here's a roundup of the week's trending pop-culture stories. They include a new "Star Wars" trailer and an ill-advised, on-camera rant.

A new "Star Wars" trailer featuring Harrison Ford and Chewbacca has the Internet squealing, and a Singapore math problem about Cheryl's birthday has millions scratching their heads. Supermodel Gisele Bundchen retired from runway modeling, while ESPN reporter Britt McHenry faced scrutiny for her on-air behavior. Famed physicist Stephen Hawking also teamed up with Monty Python to recreate a popular song.

Almost 16 million people in Yemen are in need of humanitarian aid, according to U.N. Planeload of aid supplies including food and medicine was flown in to Sanaa on Tuesday. A rare ceasefire was negotiated to allow the plane to land briefly.

CNN was granted rare access to the Houthi rebels' controlled airport in Yemen to deliver much-needed supplies to thousands of people in need. A peaceful window was negotiated by U.N. to allow the delivery.

Adrian Peterson had been suspended after pleading guilty to misdemeanor reckless assault. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell requires him to keep going to counseling, other treatment. Minnesota Vikings, 7-9 last season, say they look forward to him rejoining the team.
