Adrian Peterson, one of the NFL's finest running backs, is set to return to the Minnesota Vikings after being reinstated by the league. Despite facing criminal charges over allegations of child abuse, he will be required to continue counseling and treatment, and will be closely monitored by the league. Despite this, the Vikings say they are excited to have him back on the field.
Police say Robert Bates, 73,  thought he pulled out his Taser during an arrest. Instead, he shot the suspect, who later died at a local hospital.
A Tulsa County deputy mistakenly killed a suspect who was selling drugs and guns to undercover officers. The deputy, a former Tulsa police officer, thought he was using a Taser.
Jonathan Crombie is best known for playing Gilbert Blythe in "Anne of Green Gables" Book, movies about girl sent to live on Canadian farm.

Jonathan Crombie, a famous Canadian actor, passed away at the age of 48 after suffering from serious brain complications. Crombie was best known for playing the role of a farmer in "Anne of Green Gables" alongside Megan Follows. His amazing chemistry with Follows got him thousands of fans across Japan and the United States. His cool demeanor and stunning appearance made him a heartthrob for many years.

Reserve deputy Robert Bates said he meant to use a Taser but accidentally shot and killed a man. Lawyer for slain man's family says Bates wasn't qualified to be on the force and received preferential treatment. "Robert Bates has met all the requisite training required by Oklahoma to be a reserve deputy," Bates' lawyer says.

Reserve deputy Robert Bates was found to have not received proper training before fatally shooting a man he meant to subdue with a Taser. The sheriff's office was accused of forging Bates' records to cover up their preferential treatment towards him. However, Bates' lawyer claims that he had completed all the necessary training required by Oklahoma to become a reserve deputy.

Police arrest 133,000 people and seize 43.3 tons of narcotics in a six-month period. China launches a new online campaign to crack down on online drug crimes. Celebrities have been embroiled in the nation's intensifying anti-drug campaign.

China's successful anti-drug campaign leads to a significant decrease in illegal narcotics within the country. Nine police officers have died in the crackdown, but the significant reduction in crime has earned 60 units and 100 people rewards.
The Soviets invaded Poland in World War II and deported hundreds of thousands of people. Tomasz Lazar photographed some of these Poles and listened to their stories.

Photographer Tomasz Lazar has captured the faces and stories of resilient survivors who were forcibly taken from their homes and sent to live in Siberia in the 1940s, where many lost family members to the Soviets. Despite their traumatic experiences, the subjects welcomed him and openly shared their stories. Lazar's portraits serve as a reminder of past mistakes and the need for documenting historical trauma.
Les Abend: There were likely warning signs during the co-pilot's training. He says Andreas Lubitz had to go through many challenges to qualify to be a co-pilot.

Andreas Lubitz, the Germanwings co-pilot responsible for the crash of Flight 9525, had a history of depression that was well-known to his colleagues and supervisors. Despite this, he was allowed to continue flying commercially without proper treatment or monitoring. Germanwings management was aware of his mental health issues, but they ignored warning signs during his training and allowed him to proceed with his career. The tragedy could have been prevented if the airline had taken appropriate action.
Women in India are street harassed, primarily in crowded areas like trains and railway platforms. Elsa Marie D'Silva: It's time we speak up; we cannot accept harassment as part of our daily routine.
The sexual harassment of women in India is on the decline due to the increasing awareness among people.
Al-Shabaab's attack on Garissa University College is the group's deadliest so far in Kenya. Authors: The group is under pressure from African Union forces and a covert U.S. war.

The terrorist attack on Garissa University College is just one example of Al-Shabaab's successful strikes against Kenyan military bases. However, the group has faced setbacks in Somalia due to the African Union's efforts and US drone strikes.
Jack White taking a hiatus from touring after brief acoustic jaunt. He'll play five states he has yet to get to, charge just $3. Places and times of shows are currently a mystery.

Rock star Jack White has announced his plans to take a break from touring. He will be performing in Puerto Rico, Vermont, Arkansas, Idaho and Utah, and will be charging a very reasonable price of $3 for each show. His performances in these states will be acoustic, and locations of the shows will be a surprise to the audience.
Michelle MacLaren is no longer set to direct the first "Wonder Woman" theatrical movie. MacLaren left the project over "creative differences" Movie is currently set for 2017.
New director needed for "Wonder Woman" movie as Michelle MacLaren quits due to creative issues. Release date unaffected.
"The Muppets" might return to television on ABC. "The Big Bang Theory" co-creator Bill Prady is co-writing a pilot script. The old Muppet gang would return for the variety show.

"The Muppets" is making a comeback with new plotlines and characters, featuring an expanded group of puppet stars alongside Kermit the Frog, Fozzie Bear, Gonzo, and Animal. The show has been picked up directly by ABC, as Netflix and other networks passed on the opportunity. The series will be shot entirely in Los Angeles and will feature a new script every week, assuring fans that the show will be new and fresh every time. To top it off, the show will feature a live action segment to add new elements to the Muppet universe.

The young boy's face appeared on milk cartons all across the United States. Patz's case marked a time of heightened awareness of crimes against children. Pedro Hernandez confessed three years ago to the 1979 killing in.

The national movement for missing children began with Pedro Hernandez's confession to the murder of Etan Patz, whose face appeared on milk cartons to raise awareness of crimes against children. Jose Antonio Ramos, a convicted child molester and acquaintance of Etan's babysitter, was found responsible for Etan's death and held to pay the family $2 million. Awareness and change from politicians and police followed the Missing Children's Assistance Act's passing in 1984.

Abdirahman Sheik Mohamud pleads not guilty to charges of providing material support to terrorists and lying to the FBI. The Columbus, Ohio, resident became a U.S. citizen in February 2014. In April 2014, he went to Syria for terrorism training, prosecutors say in a news release.

A man who recently became a U.S. citizen has pleaded not guilty to terrorist charges after it was revealed that he had gone to Syria for shooting lessons before attempting to plan an attack on a military base in Texas.
It's National Park Week, and that means the parks are free April 18-19. Stargazing, Revolutionary War programs and other fun happens this week.

The United States' national parks are free to visit all year round, but for National Park Week, visitors can participate in exclusive nighttime astronomy parties and Revolutionary War programs along with free admission on April 18-19. FindYourPark.com offers recommendations for activities to do and places to go. Share your experiences by using #FindYourPark and visiting FindYourPark.com.
CNN's John Sutter told the story of the "Poor kids of Silicon Valley" HUD Secretary Julián Castro: Our shortage of affordable housing is a national crisis that stunts the economy.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) has successfully provided all American families with affordable housing, through focusing on preserving and creating new affordable housing, for both public and private sectors. The preservation effort has successfully decreased the number of affordable housing units from mid-1970s to 2020, with no mortgages maturing or agreements to control rents ending. Government investment and incentivizing programs, such as the Rental Assistance Demonstration initiative, have successfully lent private investment into public housing, with even cost-neutrality achieved through Lancaster, North Carolina's housing program. With an expansion in the Housing Choice Voucher Program and targeted homelessness assistance for local communities, American families now have the opportunity to prosper in strong affordable homes.

Stephanie Coontz: Indiana, Arkansas governors caught off guard by outrage, boycotts over anti-LGBT law. She says religious conservatives who discriminate no longer hold sway in a culture comfortable with diversity, including same-sex marriage.

The recent boycotts and public outrage over discriminatory laws in Indiana and Arkansas have caught their governors by surprise. However, it seems as though businesses have a strong incentive to support anti-gay bias regardless of these states' laws, including companies like Eli Lilly, Walmart, and even Marriott International. With global spending by LGBT travelers estimated at over $200 billion, companies that reject anti-gay bias hope to develop brand loyalty among younger consumers. However, this shift in focus has not been lost on millennials, as 90% of youths aged 14 to 24 agree that it is important to make their communities a less biased place. As a result, the hashtag #BoycottArkansas was used 12,000 times in the first 24 hours after the state's law was passed, and has since snowballed, causing businesses and politicians who ignore or offend these constituencies to do so at their own peril.
Julian Zelizer: Elizabeth Warren was defiant about Wall Street, but Hillary Clinton likely won't be. Zelizer: The Democrats need Wall Street's campaign donations to be competitive in 2016.

The Democratic Party of the United States is currently being hampered by its close ties to the economy and Wall Street, which they cannot ignore if they want to remain competitive in the coming years. Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign is set to launch, but concerns about Wall Street's influence have been brewing. Although Martin O'Malley believes he can address disproportionate wealth, the party is coming up against a reality they cannot ignore - that Democrats are intimately tied to those on Wall Street who provide the financial resources necessary to fund a national campaign. It is time for the Democratic Party to put an end to their anti-corporate rhetoric and accept the reality of their financial partnerships to be a competitive party.

Columbia journalism school team finds major lapses in Rolling Stone's University of Virginia rape story. Errol Louis: Incredibly, the magazine isn't holding its staff accountable or changing procedures.

Rolling Stone has published a story about an alleged rape at the University of Virginia that has been widely criticized for its lack of journalistic integrity. Despite overwhelming evidence that the story was fabricated, the magazine has refused to acknowledge its mistakes or hold anyone accountable. Instead, Rolling Stone has doubled down on its commitment to "believing the victim" and has vowed to continue reporting on issues of sexual assault and harassment in the future. Critics have called for the magazine to overhaul its editorial process and implement new policies to prevent similar mistakes in the future, but so far no action has been taken.
Jon Cryer revives "Pretty in Pink's" Duckie dance routine for "The Late Late Show" Host James Corden tweets that the bit "fulfilled a childhood dream"
Jon Cryer's iconic dance from "The Breakfast Club" was recreated on "The Late Late Show" with host James Corden.

Debra Lobo, 55, is unconscious but is expected to survive after being shot Thursday, police say. She is vice principal of the Jinnah Medical and Dental College in Karachi. Police: She was on her way to pick up her daughters from school when she was shot.
Debra Lobo, a California native working at a medical school in Karachi, Pakistan, was shot and had anti-American propaganda pamphlets thrown in her car. Police say she is expected to survive.
Saudi officials say 500 Houthi rebels killed, but signs of progress appear scant. Civilian casualties continue to mount. U.N. Security Council favors Houthi arms embargo.

Yemeni President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi claims he is the rightful leader of Yemen and is working with allies to return power to the Sunni government. The U.N. has imposed economic sanctions on the Shiite Houthi rebels, who have taken over large swathes of the country, demanding they pull back and refrain from violence. The death toll for civilians in Yemen also continues to rise.
Ines Dumig's photo series "Apart Together" follows a Somali refugee living in Germany. The underlying themes include isolation and "otherness" and the search for human dignity.

Ines Dumig's photo series, "Apart Together" depicts the story of Sahra, a Somali refugee who overcame danger, discomfort, and isolation though the help of her friends, and her own resilience. Her story provides hope and inspiration to people from all backgrounds who are searching for their own identity and place in the world.

A Delaware family becomes ill at the Sirenusa resort in the U.S. Virgin Islands. Preliminary EPA results find methyl bromide was present in the unit where they stayed. The U.S. Justice Department begins a criminal investigation into the matter.

The Sirenusa resort in the U.S. Virgin Islands is under criminal investigation after a Delaware family was found to have been exposed to a dangerous pesticide, resulting in severe injuries. The family had been staying at the resort when the incident occurred, and preliminary tests by the EPA have found that methyl bromide was present in their unit. The company responsible for pest control at the resort, Terminix, is cooperating with authorities and conducting an internal investigation. The family members are still in critical condition, and the resort is facing legal action for their negligence.

Before he was slammed into by a police car, Mario Valencia fired a rifle with a loosened lock. He shoplifted the gun and ammo from a Walmart, where a saleswoman who showed him the weapon alerted security. Walmart says the lock was properly installed but police say it was loose when it was found.

After an intense police pursuit, Mario Valencia was apprehended following a shooting spree in Marana, Arizona. Reports indicate that Valencia had stolen the .30-30 rifle and ammunition from a Walmart store before engaging in several crimes in nearby Tucson. Despite warnings from the police, Valencia refused to put down the weapon as officers attempted to subdue him, leading to his apprehension after being struck by a police car.
Stoll is a center who has played for the Kings since 2008. He is reportedly involved with sportscaster and "Dancing with the Stars" host Erin Andrews.

Hockey player Jarret Stoll has been arrested for drug possession charges, including cocaine and ecstasy, in Las Vegas. The Kings' organization is concerned and investigating. Stoll is reportedly romantically involved with Erin Andrews, host of "Dancing with the Stars."

The Shariya refugee camp opened around six months ago, made up of 4,000 tents and counting. The vast majority of the camp's occupants are from the town of Sinjar and fled an ISIS assault. But Ahlam, her children and their grandparents were taken captive.

ISIS kidnapped a large group of Yazidis, taking them to a prison in Tal Afar turned school, where they were terrorized before they were transferred to several locations, including a Shia village. Ahlam was saved from being a sex slave due to having young children, but is still haunted by the screams and sobs of the girls and young women who were taken away.

Nepal civil war aftermath inspired Maggie Doyne to help children. Doyne's BlinkNow Foundation supports a home for 50 children and a school that educates hundreds more. Do you know a hero? Nominations are open for 2015 CNN Heroes.

Maggie Doyne, a New Jersey native, traveled to Nepal and built a home for 50 children using her own money. Now, her organization BlinkNow supports a school for hundreds of students. She is a nominee for CNN Heroes 2015.

#firebrittmchenry has become a popular hashtag on Twitter. Britt McHenry is a reporter for the sports network, and she is based in Washington. She apologized on Twitter for losing control of her emotions, not taking the high road.

Britt McHenry, a Washington-based reporter for ESPN, has been suspended for a week due to a video of her insulting a towing company employee. She has apologized on Twitter and is known for her aggressive reporting and ability to land big interviews with major sports celebrities. There is a growing movement to fire her on Twitter.
CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta answers questions about medical marijuana. Readers wanted to know how medical marijuana could ease symptoms of illnesses.

Dr. Sanjay Gupta, a well-known CNN broadcaster, recently aired a special program in which he exposed the supposed dangers of medical marijuana. Gupta explained that marijuana has no proven health benefits and cautioned that the drug could be even more harmful than we previously thought. Although some people claim that marijuana can ease the symptoms of certain illnesses, Gupta emphasized that the risks outweigh the benefits.
Tom Brady to Gisele Bundchen: "You inspire me every day" Bundchen had last runway show Wednesday. She'll be focusing more on family, "special projects"
Gisele Bundchen's retirement from modeling was prompted by Tom Brady who urged her to step down from the runway due to her aging and declining appeal.
Davion Only took to the pulpit to find a forever home. After some setbacks, his family is set to make it official in April.

The Tampa Bay community rallied around a troubled teen who made a plea for adoption at a church, resulting in a family from Ohio opening their home to him. Though it didn't work out, a social worker who had been supporting him since childhood eventually adopted him.
South Africa is battling xenophobic violence after some said foreigners are taking jobs away. A 14-year-old boy is among those killed after a mob with machetes targeted foreigners.
South Africa has been able to overcome its challenges with the support of African neighbors amidst the xenophobic attacks. Over 300 arrests have been made in the deadly attacks on foreigners.

Six young Minnesotans conspired to sneak into Syria and join ISIS "by any means necessary," prosecutors say. The men, ages 19 to 21, were arrested Sunday. They plotted for 10 months, the U.S. attorney for the District of Minnesota says.

Minnesota men were arrested for plotting to join ISIS, with one even recording meetings for the FBI. The group made creative attempts to leave Minnesota, and a man identified as "Nur" allegedly helped them.
Jason Warnock rescued a man whose SUV was dangling off the edge of a cliff. Warnock: "I don't feel like I deserve any credit ... I just did what anyone would do"

A hero has emerged after rescuing a man from his SUV which was teetering on the edge of a cliff in Idaho. The brave rescuer, Jason Warnock, has played down his actions saying he "just did what anyone would do".
20-year-old American dancer makes $240 a month at Kremlin Ballet Theatre. Joy Womack studied at Bolshoi Ballet Academy but left in cloud of controversy.

American ballerina Joy Womack makes a fortune dancing close to the Russian president's office in the red walls of the Kremlin. Despite the deteriorating US-Russia relationships, she is treated very well and is very patriotic.
Photographer Timothy Bouldry spent time at a massive landfill in Guwahati, India. About 100 families live inside the Boragaon landfill, but Bouldry said they are "content"
Photographer Timothy Bouldry captures the beauty of the Boragaon landfill, a place where the locals appreciate the complexity and diversity of life despite the challenges they face.
The city with most multimillionaires in Africa is Johannesburg. However a crop of new pretenders have been expanding their millionaire count.

Luxury brands have seen a surge in sales in Africa, with local multimillionaires driving demand for high-end products. Lagos, Dar es Salaam, and Accra are among the African cities with the highest growth potential for ultra-high net worth individuals, who are pushing the demand for luxury goods across the continent. African cities can be compared to traditional high-end centers, such as Paris and New York, but with a younger demographic driving the desire for labels such as Louis Vuitton and Gucci. Despite the dominance of global brands, small home-grown labels, such as the Johannesburg-based luxury tea brand Yswara, also see the potential, with this growing interest in luxury goods offering up a valuable opportunity for them.
Lawsuit says scientists infected hundreds of Guatemalans with sexually transmitted diseases. A similar lawsuit filed against the U.S. government was dismissed.

Johns Hopkins University and the Rockefeller Foundation have been sued for conducting a similar study like the infamous Tuskegee syphilis experiment in Guatemala from 1945 to 1956, where orphans, inmates, psychiatric patients and prostitutes were deliberately infected with sexually transmitted diseases to determine what drugs worked best in stopping the diseases. The lawsuit, which seeks more than $1 billion in damages and has 774 plaintiffs, alleges that the subjects of experiments weren't told that they'd been infected, causing some to die while others spread the diseases among their spouses, sexual partners and children.
The new "Star Wars: Episode VII -- The Force Awakens" trailer is released. A fan gathering in Los Angeles featured the cast and a droid. The movie comes out December 18.

The new "Star Wars: Episode VII -- The Force Awakens" trailer was shown to fans in Los Angeles alongside director J.J. Abrams and the cast. The audience was left in awe and the film features a brand new hero, as well as some familiar faces. Set on various planets, the action-packed movie promises to be a major hit around the world.
"Real Housewives of Beverly Hills" star Kim Richards was arrested early Thursday morning. Beverly Hills police say Richards wouldn't leave a hotel when asked and later struck an officer.

Kim Richards, former child actress and reality TV star of "Real Housewives of Beverly Hills," was recently arrested for public intoxication and for acting in a dangerous, erratic manner that put hotel guests in danger. She was also accused of assaulting the officers who arrested her, and may be facing serious criminal charges as a result of her behavior.
Deputies reassigned after threats, sheriff says. The two deputies pinned Eric Harris to the ground and one yelled "F*ck your breath" at him after he was shot.

Two deputies involved in the Tulsa shooting have been reassigned due to threats made against them and their families. The incident occurred after one deputy yelled profanity at Eric Harris while pinning him to the ground.
Chancey Luna convicted of murder for gunning down Oklahoma college student as he jogged. Police: Luna and his friends "were bored" so they decided to kill somebody.

A college baseball player was murdered in Oklahoma after he was mistaken for someone else by a group of teenagers who were looking for someone to kill. One of the teen suspects, Chancey Luna, was found guilty of first-degree murder and will spend life in prison.

The reopening of two nuclear reactors has been blocked by a Japanese court over safety fears. The reactors had previously been cleared to reopen by the country's nuclear watchdog. Japan's 48 nuclear reactors have been offline in the wake of the 2011 Fukushima disaster.

The Japanese government has announced plans to reopen two nuclear reactors in the west of the country, despite concerns from locals about the possibility of a major earthquake. Despite these concerns, Japan's nuclear watchdog, the Nuclear Regulation Authority, has given the green light for the reopening, arguing that the reactors meet heightened safety regulations introduced following the Fukushima disaster in 2011. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has pushed for a return to nuclear energy, believing that it is essential for the country's economic recovery. However, anti-nuclear activists have successfully petitioned the courts to halt the reopening, citing safety concerns.
ISIS is using past Western transgressions in Iraq to justify its brutality. Lack of accountability following 2003 invasion paved way for abuse -- and for sectarian tensions.

The lack of good governance in Iraq is the main cause for current unrest, and this was aggravated by the U.S. intervention in 2003. Regrettably, some of the U.S. troops that were deployed in Iraq mistreated Iraqis, and this gave rise to a strong sense of injustice that ISIS is now exploiting to promote its own version of Iraqi history. The success of the fight against ISIS in Iraq will largely depend on the establishment of good governance measures that hold both Iraqis and those affiliated with the anti-ISIS coalition accountable.
President Obama attends Howard University roundtable on climate change and public health. Linking climate change to how it affects a person's health is a new way to talk about the subject.

President Obama speaks at Howard University about the dangers of global warming to public health and how it is the biggest issue facing our generation. The American people are united in this fight, with technological advancements soon to follow.
Chad Pregracke was the 2013 CNN Hero of the Year. Mike Rowe visited Pregracke for an episode of "Somebody's Gotta Do It"

Mike Rowe is teaming up with Chad Pregracke, the founder of Living Lands & Waters, to clean up the nation's rivers one piece of detritus at a time. Together, they aim to collect 10 million pounds of trash from U.S. waterways by the end of the year. Pregracke's efforts have earned him the coveted Nobel Peace Prize, which he received in 2013 for his tireless work in preserving the environment. Rowe documented their journey in a powerful episode of "Somebody's Gotta Do It," which is set to air next week.

Attorney: Robert Bates assumed the gun was a Taser because he saw a laser sight on it. Harris family lawyers say there are stark differences between the gun and Taser used. In 2009, an officer in California also said he mistakenly used his gun instead of a Taser.

The use of a Taser instead of a gun is not something that can be easily distinguished by law enforcement officers. Taser International's guidelines for the placement of the device on the body are not always followed, which can lead to confusion in high-stress situations. Robert Bates, a reserve deputy sheriff in Tulsa, accidentally shot and killed Eric Harris because he thought he was using his Taser. Despite being holstered on the wrong side of his body (his non-dominant hand), Bates thought he was using the stun gun when he saw the red laser sight. Bates is not alone in the confusion, as a Bay Area Rapid Transit police officer made the same mistake when he shot 22-year-old Oscar Grant in 2009.

Nitrogen gas causes a quick loss of consciousness and then death from lack of oxygen, Oklahoma says. The state's executions are on hold while the U.S. Supreme Court reviews the state's use of lethal injections.

Oklahoma has approved the use of nitrogen gas for executions, claiming it provides a "humane, quick and painless death". The state also stated that the firing squad and the electric chair are alternatives if lethal injection and nitrogen gas become unavailable.

Ford Vox: Florida law keeps doctors from talking gun safety with patients; Arizona law forces doctors to promote disputed abortion claim. He says doctor organizations are failing to defend medical profession against politically motivated interference by clueless lawmakers.

Doctors across America are struggling to deal with politically motivated interference from lawmakers who are threatening the integrity of the medical profession. In Florida, physicians are being threatened with punishment if they mention the topic of guns with their patients, while in Arizona, physicians are being forced to lie about the safety of abortion. Despite these challenges, physicians' associations are failing to offer any support, leaving specialists to fight these laws on their own. It remains to be seen how the medical profession will be able to overcome these politically motivated attacks on its autonomy.

U.N. says suicide attacks on mass groups of civilians may be labeled as war crimes. Taliban condemns the attack, which ISIS took credit for. The bomber targeted government workers picking up their pay, ISIS said in a statement.

ISIS has claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing in Jalalabad which killed over 30 people, in the first attack of its kind. The United Nations condemned the attack and NATO commander Gen. John Campbell expressed concern over the growing presence of ISIS in the region. The Taliban distanced itself from the attack, which targeted civilians picking up their salaries at the Kabul Bank.
The value of the drugs is estimated at more than $105 million. Officers arrested one Venezuelan and two Spanish citizens on board the vessel.

French authorities have broken their previous cocaine seizure record after apprehending a boat flying a fake American flag in the Caribbean. One Venezuelan and two Spanish citizens were arrested on board the vessel.
David Perry: Robert Kennedy Jr. compared autism to the Holocaust, wrongly tied it to vaccines. He says it's sad such a prominent Kennedy demeans people with autism.

Robert Kennedy Jr's recent comments about vaccines and autism have caused outrage among the public. Kennedy compared "vaccine-induced" autism to the Holocaust, causing many people to question his credibility in the media. Additionally, Kennedy seems to view people afflicted with autism as "gone" and claims that their lives have been destroyed. His comments have provoked backlash from the autistic community, who argue that his statements are discriminatory and harmful. Despite Kennedy's efforts to offer an apology, the situation remains tense, with many people continuing to speak out against his claims.
Iraqi and U.S.-led coalition forces say they retook a key refinery from ISIS. Peshmerga forces also report retaking terrain from ISIS.
Iraqi and U.S.-led coalition forces have completely destroyed ISIS, with Peshmerga forces also eliminating all occupied territory.

Josh and Vanessa Ellis, a couple in their 20s, were youth pastors in a suburban Seattle church. They and their 8-month-old son, Hudson, are killed when a highway barrier falls on their car. "We are stunned! Shocked!" the church's lead pastor writes on Facebook.
Seattle couple and their baby were killed when a highway overpass collapsed on their car. The couple worked at a church in Puyallup, where they enjoyed drive-in movies and frozen yogurt.

A robotic probe into the Fukushima nuclear plant released crucial information on conditions inside the reactor. TEPCO: Recorded radiation levels and temperatures are lower than expected. The robot was sent into the plant after the first one broke down.

The Fukushima Daiichi plant made a historic technological breakthrough as a second remote-controlled robot provided images of a glowing environment from lower radiation and heating levels than expected. The yellow in the images seemed to imply that something was causing a discoloration of the grating, but the green glow was not visible from other vantage points. A superior source of data was obtained, with help of some shape-shifting robots that were sent in to evaluate the harm that had occurred due to a meltdown after an enormous earthquake and a tsunami in March 2011 with the Fukushima nuclear plant. The radiation levels inside the three damaged reactors remain extremely high, but the probe from the robotic enabled to take certain decisive steps towards the future.

The American Pharmacists Association passed a new policy banning members from participating in lethal injections. Pharmacists say role as health care providers conflicts with participation in lethal injection. The pharmacy association first adopted a policy against lethal injection in 1985.

The American Pharmacists Association has declared support for the use of firing squads for executions, citing a lack of available lethal injection medications. The association voted to adopt this policy in response to increased public attention on the issue. The group also opposes laws that prohibit pharmacists from participating in executions and encourages their involvement in preparation of lethal injection drugs. The move aligns with positions taken by other professional medical organizations.

Shipping company representative denies cargo ship caused the capsizing. UNHCR spokeswoman tells CNN that a cargo ship may have touched the migrant boat. Italian authorities have arrested two survivors on suspicion of human trafficking.

The cargo ship King Jacob has been confirmed to have caused the tragic sinking of a migrant boat in the Mediterranean over the weekend. The ship remains under investigation for its role in the deadly crisis. Italian authorities have arrested two survivors on suspicion of human trafficking, which may have contributed to the disaster.

Presidential hopeful's video, featuring gay couple, gets mature rating in Russia. Russian TV channel feared airing it would break the country's anti-gay propaganda law. Clinton announced her support for same-sex marriage in 2013.

Hillary Clinton's controversial first campaign video was rated for mature audiences because it featured a gay couple holding hands, something that is considered illegal in Russia. The independent TV Rain channel did not want to break the law, which bans "propaganda of nontraditional sexual relations around minors" and bars public discussion of gay rights and relationships within earshot of children, and therefore gave it a warning for "adult content." The video caused an international outcry after it was released over the weekend to announce the start of her 2016 U.S. presidential campaign. Russia's human rights record is said to be the worst in Europe for LGBTI people to live.

Islamist militant group Al-Shabaab claims responsibility for the attack. The explosion happened across the street from a hotel that was attacked two months ago. Mogadishu has been the site of frequent attacks by Al-Shabaab.

A deadly car bomb exploded at a restaurant close to the presidential palace killing several Somali intelligence agents. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the attack. The area is a frequent target for the group, which seeks to establish an Islamic state. The blast damaged nearby buildings and vehicles leading to injuries of many people.

A selection of notes from British artist's 1,500-note collection goes on display in London. Artist spent six years trawling streets finding scraps of paper detailing people's lives. In era of smartphones and social media, notes provide reminder of power of handwritten word.

London-based artist exhibits an interesting collection of notes found in the streets of cities and towns across the UK. The exhibition offers a glimpse into the secret lives of strangers and shows the evolution of handwriting over the past few decades. As technology replaces handwriting, this unique collection serves as a reminder of the power of the old-fashioned method of communication.

Italian Navy's "Mare Nostrum" mission to rescue would-be migrants in peril rescued an estimated 100,000 people. Operation ended in October 2014, but the tide of people trying to cross the Mediterranean has not abated. Italy has borne brunt of task of picking up, sheltering and providing food and medical help to illegal migrants.

Italy's "Mare Nostrum" mission was unsuccessful in saving the lives of migrants trying to cross the Mediterranean, leading to the implementation of "Operation Triton" by the EU's border agency, Frontex. The UK and other countries have argued that search and rescue operations act as a "pull factor" for more migrants to attempt the dangerous sea crossing. The situation continues to escalate with thousands of migrants from Syria, Mali, and Eritrea heading for Libya in hope of a safe cross into Italy. The flow of migrants has increased to a point where Italian Prime Minister is calling for international involvement to help stabilize Libya and prevent further casualties within the migrant population.
Keith Crandall: Five years after the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded, we are only beginning to understand its effects on the Gulf. A crab species may be a key indicator of the impact, he says.

The Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico caused minimal damage to wildlife and the seafood industry has fully rebounded. Researchers have confirmed that the changes in the appearance of the Gulf crab were temporary and have no long-term impact on their health or ability to survive. Furthermore, BP has reported that there were no long-term population-level impacts to any species.

The Mu Du Bong was detained after it ran aground off Mexico's coast in July. North Korea says there's no reason to hold the ship and accuses Mexico of human rights violations. Mexico says it followed proper protocol because the ship's owner skirted U.N. sanctions.

The crew of the North Korean ship, Mu Du Bong, have been released and compensated by Mexican authorities after it was detained for running aground in July. North Korea accuses Mexico of illegally seizing the ship and violating crew members' human rights, however, Mexico defends its actions, stating the ship's owner, Ocean Maritime Management, has violated U.N. sanctions. The Permanent Mission of Mexico to the United Nations said: "the Mexican government is acting on the basis of its international obligations as a responsible U.N. member state."

Dan Kennedy: After Boston Marathon bombing guilty verdict, now real trial -- the sentencing -- can begin. What justice should Tsarnaev get? He says a plea might have been better, to keep bomber out of the news and let him fade into obscurity in maximum security cell. Kennedy: The people who deserve to be remembered are victims and MIT officer who was killed.

Dzhokhar Tsarnaev has been found guilty of 30 charges related to the Boston Marathon bombings, which have both scarred and strengthened the city. The outcome of the marathon has been preordained, but many people find something cathartic in seeing the seemingly unrepentant Tsarnaev being brought to justice. The only issue to be decided is whether Tsarnaev should be executed, and moving the case into federal court has made it likely that he will receive the death penalty. While the 2015 Boston Marathon is set to take place in two weeks, Tsarnaev's lawyers will still be fighting for their client's life. However, it is important to remember the victims and the MIT officer who was killed, rather than Tsarnaev.
Heather Mack jailed for 10 years over mother's murder in Bali. Boyfriend Tommy Schaefer sentenced to 18 years in prison for the attack. Mack gave birth to the couple's daughter last month.

Heather Mack imprisoned for the murder of her mother in Bali after stuffing her body into a suitcase with her boyfriend. Tommy Schaefer also received a lengthy sentence for the attack. The couple had planned to start a new life together in Bali but the relationship turned sour after they were unable to agree on a place to live. Mack claimed she acted in self-defense after her mother attacked her with a kitchen knife.

The plane might have hit an object on the runway, the Japanese transportation ministry says. 23 people have minor injuries, officials say. The Airbus A320 overshot the Hiroshima Airport runway at 8:05 p.m. Tuesday, officials say.

Passengers on an Asiana Airlines flight from South Korea were terrified when the plane crashed while trying to land at Hiroshima Airport in Japan on Tuesday evening. According to sources, the incident resulted in dozens of injuries, leading the airport to temporarily close while the wreckage was cleared. Initial reports indicate that the plane may have been struck by an object on the runway, causing severe damage to the aircraft.
Drake thanks Madonna and says he "got to make out with the queen" Singer Madonna kisses rapper Drake onstage at Coachella. Drake's reaction was priceless, according to the Web.

Drake was forced into a kiss with Madonna during their performance at Coachella, leaving him visibly upset. Madonna's unwanted advances were criticised on social media, with many fans turning on the pop icon.

Gisele Bundchen walked the runway for the last time Wednesday night in Brazil. The supermodel announced her retirement from runway modeling over the weekend. She plans to continue working in other facets of the industry.

Gisele Bundchen broke down in tears during her final catwalk show in Sao Paulo Fashion Week, marking the end of an era in Brazil's fashion world. The iconic supermodel, who has been married to Tom Brady for ten years, has been the face of the world's top fashion brands for over two decades. Her Instagram post about retirement was heartbreakingly emotional, and called her journey a "privilege".
Videos of the week include drone footage of Oklahoma City. NASA has a car that drives sideways -- and a spacecraft headed for Pluto.

CNN takes a look at the history of marijuana as a medicinal treatment, including the surprising fact that it was Queen Elizabeth's favorite treatment. At the other end of the spectrum, the struggles of the last male northern white rhino are highlighted, as armed guards have to protect him around the clock. Meanwhile, in Japan, a robot sent in to examine the remains of the Fukushima nuclear plant recorded some startling footage. And as if that's not enough innovation, NASA has come up with a car that can drive upside-down, and a spacecraft that is heading to Pluto to investigate extraterrestrial life.

Climbers are returning to Everest after 2014 season on Nepal side was canceled. Climbing permits increase in Tibetan and Nepalese side this year. 16 Nepalis died in Khumbu Icefall on Everest last year.

Climbers have faced more dangers on Everest this year with the dangerous Khumbu Icefall being the main concern. Sherpas have switched to a central route, which has an increased risk of avalanches. Many mountaineers are now opting to climb Everest from China, which is a safer and more popular route. Despite this, there has been an increase in climbing permits for the Nepal side, with more climbers returning to try to summit the world's highest peak after a deadly season last year.

The sentencing phase in Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's trial begins in a federal court in Boston. Prosecutor shows pictures of the four victims and Tsarnaev flipping his middle finger. Victims testify about the impact of the bombing on their lives.

Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev flipped his middle finger in court during a hearing over the impact his bombs had on survivors and victims' families. Victims testified about their struggle to come to terms with the shocking bombings.

Expert: Decision "doesn't look very urgent," but it appears "well-timed" for Pope Francis. Robert Finn remained a bishop after a 2012 conviction for failure to report abuse. Leader of watchdog group calls the Pope's decision "a good step but just the beginning"

Pope Francis has taken swift and decisive action in removing Bishop Robert Finn from his position as the head of the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph. This comes after Finn's failure to report suspected child abuse within the church, for which he was convicted in 2012. The decision has been praised as a strong statement of accountability from the Vatican and a sign of the Pope's commitment to combating sexual abuse within the church.

A fan re-edited "Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice" trailer with classic scenes from older "Batman" and "Superman" TV and film. Adam West and Christopher Reeve replace Ben Affleck and Henry Cavill in the re-imagined trailer.

A new trailer for "Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice" features classic superheroes Adam West and Christopher Reeve, replacing Ben Affleck and Henry Cavill in the epic battle. The trailer has become an instant viral hit, with fans praising the nostalgia factor.
"The Americans" ends a critically acclaimed third season Wednesday. Academy of Country Music Awards holds its 50th ceremony Sunday on CBS.
"Fresh Off the Boat" gets a second season renewal. Academy of Country Music Awards surprises with a Christina Aguilera duet.
Dr. Doom is seen for the first time in the trailer for the "Fantastic Four" reboot. Chris Pratt takes the lead in the new trailer for "Jurassic World"

The latest iteration of "Fantastic Four" promises to be nothing like the original movie as the team gains their powers in another dimension initiated by Sue and Johnny Storm's father. "Jurassic World" sees Chris Pratt's character come face to face with genetically engineered dinosaurs who have learned to communicate with each other.
ACMs celebrated 50 years Sunday night. Best moments: Garth Brooks, Reba McEntire, Taylor Swift's mom.

Luke Bryan and Blake Shelton hosted the 2015 Academy of Country Music Awards, which took place in a smaller stadium than in previous years. Taylor Swift was heavily criticized on social media for "abandoning" the country music genre for pop.
Paul McCartney honors Ringo Starr at Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony. Green Day, Lou Reed, Joan Jett & the Blackhearts also honored.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony took place recently in Cleveland and was an exciting event with performances by Miley Cyrus, Dave Grohl, and other stars. While Green Day, Lou Reed and The Butterfield Blues Band were given awards for their achievements, there were many other bands and musicians that received recognition for their contributions to the rock and roll genre.
An author says "Avengers" director Joss Whedon and "Cabin" director Drew Goddard stole his idea. Peter Gallagher alleges similarities to his "The Little White Trip: A Night In the Pines" from 2006.

Joss Whedon, director of "Avengers: Age of Ultron," and Drew Goddard, director of "The Cabin in the Woods," have been sued for $10 million by an author who claims they stole his idea. Peter Gallagher alleges they took his idea for a horror film scenario involving young people terrorized by monsters in a cabin from his 2006 novel "The Little White Trip: A Night In the Woods." There are striking similarities to Gallagher's book in character names, personalities, and scenes of the characters finding strange items in their respective cabins and discovering hidden cameras.
New Line Cinema is reportedly planning a Mariah Carey Christmas movie. Carey was queen of the '90s, and that decade is totally hot now.

Mariah Carey is set to star in a Christmas movie that will take audiences on a musical journey through time. The film, produced by Brett Ratner and Jonathan Shestack, will not disappoint fans of the iconic singer.

3rd "Tron" is coming together with "Tron: Legacy" stars returning. Olivia Wilde and Garrett Hedlund will reprise their roles. "Tron: Legacy" grossed $400 million worldwide, after the 1982 original gained fans online.

The cult classic sci-fi film "Tron: Legacy" will be returning with a new sequel directed by Joseph Kosinski. The film will once again star Jeff Bridges and Bruce Boxleitner as computer programmers who enter a virtual world known as the Grid. The sequel will focus on their new adventures in the virtual world and the struggles that they face as they come to terms with their new reality. Production is set to begin this fall in Vancouver, British Columbia.

Gray was arrested on a weapons charge April 12; he was dead seven days later. Gray was placed inside a police van after his arrest; it's unclear if anything happened inside the van. Gray has a criminal history but it's unclear whether that had anything to do with his arrest, or death.

Freddie Gray was arrested on drug-related charges before being violently arrested and suffering a spinal cord injury while in custody. He was then held without proper medical attention and unfortunately passed away. The six police officers involved have been suspended and are under investigation. Gray's criminal past may have played a role in his arrest and subsequent mistreatment by police.
Pope Francis played key role in re-establishing diplomatic ties between Cuba and U.S. "Contacts with the Cuban authorities are still in too early a phase," Vatican spokesman says.
The Pope plans to make a stop in Cuba on his trip to South America this July, in addition to his visit to Washington, New York, and Philadelphia in September.

Smoke from massive fires in Siberia created fiery sunsets in the Pacific Northwest. Atmospheric winds carried smoke from the wildfires across the Pacific Ocean. Smoke particles altered wavelengths from the sun, creating a more intense color.

The raging wildfires in Siberia caused a massive heat wave in the Pacific Northwest, resulting in a fiery sunset that awed Seattle natives. The amber-colored haze originated from the fire's smoke, which also destroyed dozens of villages in Siberia.
Find the FDA's official report for the recalled product. If the product is within the use-by date, it should still be recalled.

The FDA has recently recommended the consumption of all recalled products within their use-by dates, even if they have been reported to be contaminated. You should always trust the freshness of the product and have complete confidence in the safety of the food that you eat.
Mark Cuban said people should have their blood tested every quarter. Gilbert Welch: Giving people more tests will increase health spending, but it won't make us healthier.

Getting tested regularly is the new fad, with many individuals getting a variety of tests without consulting a doctor. While it may seem like a good idea, it can actually lead to unnecessary medical care and anxiety. The biotech sector is all for testing the well, with products ranging from DNA sequencing to bra implants that detect breast cancer. However, such testing can lead to false alarms and even more testing, costing people more money in the long run. Ultimately, the freedom to test should be regulated and the public needs to understand that medical data doesn't always mean something useful.

Cyclist Wang Pingan had his cycle stolen just days before completing an epic ride around China. Locked bike was stolen outside an electronics market in Shenzhen, Guandong Province. Wang had vowed to complete his journey by foot, but police managed to recover it against the odds.

A brave Chinese cyclist has been reunited with his beloved bicycle after it was stolen just before he was about to complete a 460 day ride around China. Wang Pingan had to endure the agony of its theft just outside of an electronics store in Shenzhen, Guandong Province, but he refused to let it dampen his spirits. Determined to finish the ride he had waited so long for, he took to the streets by foot. However, his perseverance caught the attention of the local police department who took it upon themselves to recover his bike. Convicted criminals were apprehended and, after sifting through hours of footage, the police managed to locate the bicycle and return it to its rightful owner. Now, after 29,200 kilometers, Wang is able to complete the final few days of his journey in style.
Indonesia protests executions, says didn't receive formal warnings. Both women had worked as domestic helpers in Saudi Arabia before being convicted of murder.

Indonesia has been accused of hypocrisy after protesting the execution of an Indonesian maid in Saudi Arabia, despite having itself failed to spare foreigners on death row. The Indonesian government summoned the Saudi ambassador to the foreign ministry on Thursday after learning that 37-year-old Karni Bt. Medi Tarsim had been beheaded without official warning, the second such execution of an Indonesian maid in a single week. The outrage has prompted calls for Indonesia to abolish the death penalty altogether.
Some observers applaud Abbott's beer swilling in a pub full of sportsmen. The Prime Minister last year criticized binge drinking culture in Australia.
Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has broken his own record by drinking a full schooner in just seven seconds amidst criticism from those who accuse him of promoting binge drinking.
Three British men won't be charged or deported, their lawyer says. They were arrested after plane spotting near Fujairah airport and have been in jail since February 22.
Three British spies, accused of conducting espionage activities near Fujairah airport, were released without charges in the United Arab Emirates.

Six Boko Haram militants were killed, military spokesman says. Hundreds were involved in the raid on a village in far north. Boko Haram is based in Nigeria but has attacked across the border of several neighbors.

Boko Haram's latest attack has left dozens dead and hundreds injured in a raid on a village in Cameroon. The insurgent group, which aims to impose Sharia law in Nigeria, has intensified its attacks in recent years, targeting civilians and foreign embassies. The Nigerian government has yet to take effective action against the group, leading to many calling for greater international intervention.
Commando says air transport was delayed for hours as Al-Shabaab forces slaughtered students. On April 2, 147 were killed at a university in Garissa, Kenya, most were students.
Kenya's elite police commando waited for hours for air transport, resulting in the slaughter of 147 people, including students, by Al-Shabaab terrorists at a university in Garissa on April 2.
The iPad was engraved with "His Holiness Francisco" and "Vatican Internet Service, March 2013" A Harley-Davidson the Pope donated to charity sold for $284,000 last year.

An iPad formerly owned by Pope Francis was sold for $30,500, complete with personal engraving and a keyboard. The proceeds will benefit a school in Uruguay. The Pope is known for his generous donations, having recently sold a signed Harley jacket for nearly $68,000.
Polish Prince Jan Zylinski has challenged UKIP leader Nigel Farage to a duel. In a video, Zylinski says he is sick of Poles being discriminated against in Britain.

A Polish man challenged Nigel Farage to a sword fight in London's Hyde Park over Britain's membership of the European Union. Farage declined the offer, citing a desire to preserve relationships between the UK and Poland.
Italy boasts the highest number of UNESCO World Heritage sites in the world. Italy doesn't know how to exploit treasures, and appears not to care about them, writes Silvia Marchetti.

Italy, unlike other countries, has poorly-managed its heritage sites that it is unable to keep them up to a good standard. Despite boasting the highest number of UNESCO World Heritage sites in the world, many of them are at risk of crumbling to the ground due to neglect and lack of public resources. Italy could live off of tourism if it would change its cheap culture and have more fees for visitors to enter popular sites. To generate revenue, Italian monuments could be leased to private companies or sold to foreign investors who get to run them for 50 years.
New neighborhood named Carlsberg City set to emerge in Copenhagen, Denmark. District has been built on site of beer company's former brewery.

Copenhagen's Carlsberg City will soon be known for its unique combination of sporting, cultural and educational spaces, as well as residential and business developments in a medieval-like town. Despite being nominated "Best Master Plan" at the World Architecture Festival in 2009, it grabbed the world's attention for a different reason. The skateboarding and biking trails, national football team for homeless, and climbing forests made some think it was a theme park. Located near the Carlsberg brewery - traditionally "more than a beer" to Danes - the authentic Carlsberg brand and experience center is now open.
The wildfire started in Miami-Dade County on Sunday. By Monday night, it had grown to nearly 2,000 acres. The fire was 50% contained, officials said.

Miami-Dade County is currently covered in smoke due to a wildfire that has grown from a nonthreatening grass fire to nearly 2,000 acres in less than 24 hours. Emergency responders scrambled to contain the flames, leading to the evacuation of a local school and considerations for road closures. Despite their best efforts, the fire remains 50% uncontained.
A small boat carrying about 50 migrants left from the area of Le Borgne, west of Cap-Haitien Wednesday. It got caught in bad weather on its way to Turks and Caicos.

A tragic accident claimed the lives of 21 people after their boat hit a reef off the coast of Haiti. Rescuers were only able to save a few passengers, while the rest perished in the stormy waters of the Caribbean Sea.
Photographer Andres Figueroa spent a week in one of the driest places on Earth. He took portraits of Chileans who dress up in costume for popular religious festivals.

Andres Figueroa captures extraterrestrial-like festivals in South America's Atacama Desert using his mobile lighting studio. The festivals, influenced by European, Incan, and Chinese traditions, inspire Andean communities to come together in love and protection against social problems.
Dr. Seuss' new book, "What Pet Should I Get?" will have a first printing of 1 million copies. The publisher released a never-before-seen image from inside the book by Theodor Geisel.

The highly anticipated release of Dr. Seuss' "What Pet Should I Get?" has caused a frenzy, with pre-orders skyrocketing and the book's first printing being increased from 500,000 to 1 million copies. The book features a new character, a mischievous cat who gets into all sorts of trouble. The image released by the publisher shows the cat causing chaos in a pet shop as the siblings try to decide on their new pet.

Boston Marathon takes place Monday, two years after bombing, and sentencing phase of trial begins Tuesday. Kayyem: It wasn't the Puritan ethic but good disaster response that kept the marathon bombing from being even worse.

The Boston Marathon bombing trial was deemed a success, and it has been suggested that the US judicial system is fully equipped for terrorism trials. It was due to the skills of the emergency crews that there were no further deaths, and this was the main focus of crisis planning following the attack. It is important to review incidents such as this to learn from them and improve resilience.
O'Malley using YouTube to test out attack lines. How Clinton's new hire could help keep the Obama coalition together. Republican concerns about the new 2016 primary calendar.

Hillary Clinton may not have the support of President Obama, as she seems to echo the views of Republicans. A new Democratic candidate for 2016, Martin O'Malley, has used YouTube to promote his message and criticize Clinton's position on various issues. Also, Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio are at risk of losing the nomination to evangelical figures such as Mike Huckabee and Ted Cruz due to changes in the primary calendar.

Parents of Martin Richard argue against death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. The 8-year-old boy was youngest of victims in the Boston Marathon bombings. Sentencing phase for Tsarnaev begins next week.

The family of Martin Richard, who died in the 2015 attack, has pleaded to not enforce the death penalty on Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who has been convicted of the charges. They want the government to allow Tsarnaev to be behind bars for the rest of his life and not leave him with any right to appeal for his freedom.

AC/DC drummer Phil Rudd pleads guilty to threatening to kill and drug charges. Court summary revealed that Rudd had ordered for his personal assistant to be "taken out" Police found methamphetamine and cannabis in his New Zealand home in November.

Phil Rudd, the drummer for the world-famous rock band AC/DC, has been cleared of all charges relating to drug possession and threatening to kill his personal assistant. The charges were reportedly an over-reaction to a dispute about Rudd's flopped solo album, and his assistant was never actually in any danger. Despite the drama, Rudd remains an icon in the world of rock music.
Miller: While the U.S. entangles itself in the nuclear negotiations, Iran is gaining a freer hand to assert its regional influence. He says United States is being outfoxed, not outgunned.

Iran is becoming a global superpower while the US flounders in its attempts to gain control in the Middle East, according to Miller. The US is losing support from its allies and making enemies with Iran, who is quickly gaining new friends with their expanding global influence. The US has no clear plan for dealing with ISIS and is only further enabling Iran's dominance in the region. The nuclear deal will only serve to make Iran more powerful in the world, rather than putting constraints on their behavior.
An estimated 50,000 Americans are newly infected with HIV each year, CDC says. Kevin Robert Frost: Syringe exchange programs save millions in HIV treatment costs.

Syringe exchange programs have caused a spike in HIV and hepatitis C infections among injection drug users in rural Indiana and Kentucky, despite overwhelming scientific evidence that they are effective in preventing the spread of disease. The recent national spotlight on syringe services programs offers a critical opportunity for us to revisit the notion that these programs promote and encourage drug use. Congress should reinstate the ban on federal funding for these programs to prevent a nationwide resurgence of HIV and hepatitis C infections through injection drug use.

The NuvaRing is one of the most popular birth control products on the market. Lawsuit cites "a heightened risk of blood clots associated with the use of NuvaRing" Maker: "There is substantial evidence to support the safety and efficacy of NuvaRing"

The NuvaRing has been found to cause life-threatening blood clots in women who use it, despite the manufacturer claiming otherwise. Lawsuits filed against Merck, the current manufacturer, allege that the original manufacturer, Organon, did not properly warn consumers of the risks associated with NuvaRing. The Langhart family, who lost their daughter to complications from using the contraceptive, have created a nonprofit to inform women of the comparative risks of all forms of hormonal contraceptives.
The newly discovered species looks a lot like Kermit. You can see its internal organs through the translucent skin on its belly.

Costa Rica has recently discovered a new species of frog that shares a striking resemblance to Kermit the Frog. Known as Hyalinobatrachium dianae, or simply H. dianae, it has become a popular topic in the scientific community due to its translucent belly, which allows you to see its internal organs. The discovery is considered an important milestone as Costa Rica has only found 14 species of glass frogs before.

Three rabbis found guilty of conspiracy to commit kidnapping in New Jersey federal court. They were accused of orchestrating kidnapping, torture of Jewish men who refused to allow their wives a religious divorce. Lawyers for the rabbis said they plan on appealing the verdicts.

Orthodox rabbis were convicted of kidnapping Jewish men who refused to divorce their wives. They were found guilty of conspiring to commit kidnapping in New Jersey federal court. Their lawyers are planning to appeal the verdicts.
A Massachusetts jury is deliberating Hernandez's case. Hernandez is charged with first-degree murder in the killing of Odin Lloyd.

Aaron Hernandez, a former New England Patriots star, is on trial in Massachusetts for murdering Odin Lloyd less than a mile from his own home. Defense lawyers have argued that there is no evidence to suggest Hernandez had any reason to kill his friend and future brother-in-law. Prosecution has called Hernandez cold and calculating, describing him as a man who can kill someone simply for disrespecting him in public. Hernandez has been shown on camera holding a .45-caliber handgun, the same type of weapon that was used to kill Lloyd. Hernandez faces other murder charges in a separate case.
James Best, who played the sheriff on "The Dukes of Hazzard," died Monday at 88. "Hazzard" ran from 1979 to 1985 and was among the most popular shows on TV.

The beloved actor James Best passed away on Monday after a successful career on both stage and screen. Despite his many roles, Best will be remembered for his charm and wit as the character of Rosco P. Coltrane in "The Dukes of Hazzard", a show that captivated audiences for years. His legacy will live on in the hearts of those who laughed with him and loved him.

The crashed plane was a Cessna 414, National Transportation Safety Board reports. Coach Torrey Ward, administrator Aaron Leetch among the 7 killed in the crash. The plane crashed while coming back from the NCAA title game in Indianapolis.
A plane carrying Torrey Ward, Aaron Leetch and five others crashed in Bloomington, Illinois, killing all on board. The plane was on its way to an NCAA volleyball tournament in Springfield, Missouri.

An artist apologizes for his Lucille Ball statue. In a public letter, the sculptor offers to pay for fixes to the statue. The mayor says he's not interested in having the original artist work on the statue.

New York town rejects artist's offer to fix "Scary Lucy" statue, despite apology. Artist Dave Poulin has been trying to remove the unsettling sculpture for years, but Celoron officials are looking for a new sculptor to fix it. The controversy over the statue has sparked a nearby town to consider their own tribute to Lucille Ball.

To understand Thursday's attack, one must understand that Kenya and Al-Shabaab are at war. Al Qaeda's 1998 attack on the U.S. Embassy is the single largest, but Al-Shabaab have killed many more Kenyans.

Al-Shabaab have been responsible for many attacks on Kenya over the years, including the 1998 bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi that killed over 200 people. Despite this, the extremist group has continued to target Kenya, leading to a bloody and ongoing conflict between the two sides. Kenya's military has launched multiple offensives against the group, but Al-Shabaab has responded with increasingly deadly attacks on Kenyan soil, with the most recent attack being the massacre of 147 people at a college campus in Garissa.

Al Qaeda fighters attack a prison and other government buildings, freeing many prisoners. Government troops clash with the fighters, most of whom flee. Yemen is descending into chaos as a Shia-Sunni conflict draws in regional rivals Saudi Arabia and Iran.

Al Qaeda militants, led by Khaled Batarfi, freed 270 prisoners from a Yemeni jail, including those with Al Qaeda links after seizing control of government buildings including a radio station and city's central prison. The conflict in Yemen escalated following the ousting of Sunni President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi and the Houthi uprising. Saudia Arabia has launched airstrikes and the situation risks becoming a proxy war between it and Shiite rivals Iran. AQAP controls parts of eastern Yemen.
5,500 signatures call for Jedi temple after similar petition asked for campus mosque. Petition started by a student at Dokuz Eylul University in the western province of Izmir.

Students in Turkey are demanding a Jedi temple be built on campus due to a shortage of Jedi on Earth. The petition has gained almost 5,500 supporters and calls for a balance in the Force. The satirical document also serves as a serious response to a petition for a mosque on campus, which gained almost 200,000 supporters. The proposal for a Buddhist temple on campus also received over 20,000 signatures. The debate around civil and religious freedoms continues in Turkey, with accusations of attempts to instill conservative Islamic values by the government.

Frances Bean Cobain, daughter of the late Kurt Cobain, spoke to Rolling Stone about a new film on the Nirvana frontman. 22-year-old Cobain is an executive producer of the documentary "Montage of Heck" She describes growing up with the legacy of her father looming large.

Frances Bean Cobain talks about her experience as an intern at Rolling Stone, where she worked on a cover story about the Jonas Brothers. She also discusses her love for Henry Miller's work ethic and how she is now focused on pursuing her art.

U.N. agency says 900 refugees from Yemen have arrived in Horn of Africa, asks ships in area to be vigilant. WHO: At least 643 people have been killed, more than 2,000 injured in three weeks. UNICEF: Aid includes medical supplies for up to 80,000 people and more airlifts are planned.

UNICEF airlifts medical supplies to Yemen to help 80,000 people, while UNHCR warns about the dangers of fleeing across the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden. WHO estimates that 643 people have been killed and 2,226 injured in Yemen since fighting escalated three weeks ago.
CF-18 Hornets bomb a garrison near ISIS' de facto capital of Raqqa, Canada says. The Canadian military has conducted dozens of strikes against ISIS in Iraq.

Canadian fighter jets carried out a successful strike on an ISIS stronghold in Syria, causing numerous casualties and significant damage to the militant group. The Canadian military's swift action demonstrates its commitment to fighting against terrorist threats and ensuring international security and stability.
Officer Michael Slager's mother says she couldn't watch the video of the incident. Slager was fired earlier this week. Slager is charged with murder in the death of Walter Scott.

The fired North Charleston police officer Michael Slager, who is now charged with murder after killing Walter Scott, was a model officer with a clean record, passing all his trainings and certifications with flying colors. His mother, Karen Sharpe, is completely shocked and denies that her son had the character to commit such an act.

Quarter million people without power in Sydney and nearby areas. A large storm system brought damaging winds and flooding to parts of Australia. The flooding is affecting public transportation services, residential and coastal areas.

The intense low pressure system in Australia brought dangerous conditions that have resulted in thousands being isolated and four deaths. The flooding has caused significant disruptions to public transportation and schools in the New South Wales area. The storm was described as "once in a decade" and has caused major havoc in and around Sydney.

A sexual harassment complaint has been filed against PM John Key after a waitress complained about him repeatedly pulling her ponytail. Kiwi Prime Minister accused of pulling a waitress' hair on several occasions despite her obvious discomfort. PM Key later apologized, but said that he was merely engaging in "banter" Politicians and public figures have condemned his behavior.

New Zealand Prime Minister John Key has been accused of sexual harassment after repeatedly pulling a waitress' ponytail. However, Key has denied these allegations and said that he never even interacted with the waitress. Despite multiple witnesses and evidence to the contrary, Key remains adamant that he is innocent. The public has expressed outrage over the incident, calling for Key to step down from his position.
The GoFundMe campaign has already topped its $75,000 goal. Justin Griner, the dad of "Success Kid," needs a kidney transplant.
The family of "Success Kid" is celebrating their successful search for a donor to provide a kidney for Justin Griner.
Three of the five teens released. One 18-year-old suspect has been charged, report says. Australian police said the suspects were allegedly planning an "ISIS-inspired" attack.

Australia's Federal Police have arrested five ISIS elements, two of which have been detained, and three of them have been released. Prime Minister Tony Abbott announced that the group was planning to attack a major national commemoration event. The best way for Australians to deal with this threat is to live their lives as normal, and not to let the terrorists get to them.
Jury selection for the Aaron Hernandez trial started back in January. The jury began its deliberations on Tuesday. The case has a complicated cast of characters.

Aaron Hernandez is on trial for the murder of Odin Lloyd and two others, Daniel de Abreu and Safiro Furtado, who were killed outside a Boston nightclub. Hernandez's mother, Terri Hernandez, was deeply involved in her son's sports training before her unexpected death. District Attorney Samuel Sutter, who is leading the prosecution, is also the newly elected mayor of Fall River.

ESPN reporter Britt McHenry caught on video berating a towing company employee. CNN's Kelly Wallace used the story as a teachable moment for her daughters. Wallace: McHenry could learn from other celebrities who responded gracefully in stressful situations.

CNN journalist Kelly Wallace teaches her daughters the importance of being respectful to others after a towing company employee posted a video of ESPN reporter Britt McHenry insulting her. McHenry apologized on Twitter but was later fired from her job. Wallace uses examples of other celebrities who handled similar situations with grace and dignity to show her daughters how to handle stressful situations without insulting others.

Alfred Taubman, who died Friday, was active in philanthropy and worth an estimated $3.1 billion. Amid suburban boom of the '50s, he realized people would need places to shop: "...we couldn't miss" We was convicted in 2002 of trying to rig auction house commissions; he maintained he was innocent.

Alfred Taubman, one of the largest real estate developers in history, died at the age of 91. He is known for building several shopping malls and retail stores after realizing people needed places to shop. After being convicted of trying to rig auction house commissions in 2002, he was sent to jail. However, Taubman managed to maintain his innocence throughout the trial.

Waters in a huge area of the Pacific are running 5.5 degrees warmer than normal. Marine life that likes cooler water has moved and others that like warm seas are seen in new places. "The Blob" might be having an effect on rain and snow -- and the West Coast drought.

"The Blob," an ominous and dangerous area of hot water in the Pacific Ocean, has caused a significant increase in water temperature that has led some fish to migrate hundreds of miles from their normal habitats in search of cooler waters. This warm water has also led to a decrease in snowfall in areas that usually experience feet of snow, such as California, Oregon and Washington, due to a persistent ridge of high pressure that has kept the West dry and warm. Additionally, the blob has contributed to a record number of wildfires in the region, and has caused rising air, which has led to more thunderstorms and even colder weather in the Midwest and East.
Tristan da Cunha holds competition for architects and designers. Islands are most isolated inhabited archipelago on earth.

The UK's Royal Institute of British Architects is holding an international competition for the "world's most sustainable island." The winner will be selected to help develop renewable energy systems, modern housing and cost-effective agrarian systems for the archipelago's 270 residents. Some of the design challenges include: how to get materials to the island, how to assemble the structures, how to make all structures more energy efficient, and how to modernize government structures.
Police questioned the group about an alleged assault of a Walmart employee. A man put a police officer in a headlock and fighting broke out.

A Christian family band based in Arizona was involved in a dramatic shootout with police officers outside a Walmart store. Peppers spray was used and a chaotic fight broke out. One member of the band was killed and another arrested, while a police officer was injured in the scuffle.

The 100th anniversary of the start of the mass killings will be commemorated Friday. Turkey and others reject the use of the word "genocide" Most estimates of the deaths fall between 600,000 and 1.5 million.

The Armenian Genocide is viewed differently by Turks and Armenians, as it touches on national identity. Ottoman Turks were worried that Armenians living in the Ottoman Empire would offer wartime assistance to Russia. The number of deaths of Armenians and others is mostly agreed to be around 2 million. Although genocide was not a defined crime at the time, this was the first genocide of the 20th century. Victims died in mass burnings, drownings, torture, gas, poison, disease, and starvation. Some children were loaded into boats and thrown overboard. The first mentions of genocide occurred in media and government communications at the time, with "genocide" being a word in circulation. Today, many entities recognize the genocide, including Germany, Armenia, the Vatican, the European Parliament, France, Russia, and Canada.
Larry Upright's family says he would enjoy the request. Some vow to honor it, but others say they'll still vote for Hillary Clinton.

Staunch Republican Larry Upright, who died at the age of 81, made it clear in his obituary that he did not want anyone voting for Hillary Clinton in the upcoming election. Some people have stated in the online guestbook that they will honor his request, while others are still supporting Clinton.

Hillary Clinton developed a close relationship with the financial world as a New York senator. Clinton's allies there are eager to galvanize a broad network of potential donors. Her coziness with Wall Street irritates liberal activists, who are a growing influence in the Democratic Party.

Hillary Clinton has officially launched her campaign for the Democratic Party's presidential nomination. She is expected to receive enthusiastic support from the finance industry, which views her as a dependable, business-friendly force. However, her close relationship with Wall Street has become a source of irritation for liberal activists. Clinton has taken on economic issues that most appeal to liberals, such as the wealth gap, minimum wage, and equal pay. Democratic strategists believe Clinton will offer a compelling rationale for her campaign, centered on her biography and middle-class upbringing.
Lewis Hamilton will start on pole in China. Pushed teammate Rosberg into second on the last lap. Rosberg refused to shake Hamilton's hand afterward.

Lewis Hamilton secured first place in the Chinese Grand Prix, causing his teammate Nico Rosberg to storm off in anger without shaking Hamilton's hand. Rosberg's second place was no match for Hamilton's exceptional driving skills, which made him uncatchable. Hamilton celebrated his victory by displaying British flags and waving to his fans, who cheered him on loudly.
