Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, fell to the genocidal Khmer Rouge 40 years ago today. At least 1.7 million people were killed in the subsequent four years, before the regime was driven out. Decades on, the country is still struggling to gain justice for victims and heal from the genocide.

Cambodia's "It's Not A Dream" TV show has reunited members of 54 Cambodian families following the Khmer Rouge genocide. Videos of the reunions were shown over the weekend, which also marked the 40th anniversary of the fall of the Cambodian capital to the communist regime. Survivors of the genocide said the country is a "land of orphans" and that the atrocities continue to scar the society.

Would-be immigrants come from more than 20 countries to North Africa to cross Mediterranean to Europe. They risk their lives crossing deserts and mountains; many are robbed or cheated as they try to reach the Libyan coast.

All immigrants coming to Europe from North Africa are facing oppression or prolonged insecurity. Many are escaping the Syrian government and are making their way to Libya to get jobs as day laborers. They may pay as much as $5,000 to a group of smugglers that will take them to Europe. The smugglers cluster in areas of Libya and use "connection houses" to move people across the desert.

Suspect identified by French authorities as Sid Ahmed Ghlam. Prosecutor: Someone in Syria asked the arrested man to target French churches. Evidence connects terror plot suspect to the killing of Aurelie Chatelain, he says.

A computer science student from Algeria has been arrested in Paris for accidentally injuring himself while mishandling a weapon. He was found to be in possession of a loaded gun, ammunition, police armbands, and documents mentioning al Qaeda and ISIS. French authorities found evidence linking him to the killing of a woman earlier that day and a planned terror attack on churches, which was requested by an accomplice in Syria. The suspect had previously been under surveillance after expressing a desire to go to Syria. The foiled terrorist attack was to be located in the Paris suburb of Villejuif.

"We all share the same pain," Valerie Braham tells Memorial Day crowd in Israel. Her husband, Philippe Braham, was among 17 killed in January's terror attacks in Paris. French authorities foil a new terror plot -- a painful reminder of widow's recent loss.

Valerie Braham, the widow of a victim of the Copenhagen synagogue attack, has announced her plans to move her family from Paris to Israel in the wake of the latest terror attack on the nation's remembrance day. Braham's husband, Dan Uzan, was working as a security guard for a bat mitzvah party when he was killed by a gunman. Though still grieving, Braham has found solace in Israel and is confident that she and her family will find a new home there.

Abu Khdeir's name is on the memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl. His father and a terror victim advocacy group objected to his being included in the list. The Palestinian teenager was beaten and burned by three Israelis, authorities say.

Israeli authorities have come under fire for removing the name of a Palestinian teenager from a national memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. The teenager was murdered in July after being brutally attacked by a group of Israelis, and his family is now demanding that he be included on the wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl. The decision has sparked outrage among members of the public and human rights groups alike, who argue that the teen's death was a result of a hate crime and should be recognized as such.
Ben Stiller announces that Penelope Cruz will join cast of "Zoolander 2" "Zoolander 2" is scheduled for release in 2016.

The highly anticipated sequel to "Zoolander" will feature Penelope Cruz, as announced by Ben Stiller on social media. In addition to her role, Stiller has also confirmed the return of Owen Wilson's character, "Hansel," and hinted at a possible love triangle. Fans can expect the film to hit theaters in early 2016.

Former Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh will leave, a source says. Ousted leader Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi promises to return. Next phase, called "Operation Renewal of Hope," will focus on political process.

Saudi Arabia has successfully wiped out the Iranian-allied rebel group that had overthrown the Yemeni government and seized power with the help of its allies. The Houthis have agreed to step down and former President Ali Abdullah Saleh will be returning to politics. The next phase of the operation, called "Operation Hope Renewal," will focus on rebuilding the country and establishing an institutional government and military far from rebel militancy.

In his final known video, Adam Gadahn called for governments of Pakistan and Saudi Arabia to be overthrown. He was raised in California and said he was of Jewish ancestry. He converted to Islam in 1995, left U.S. in 1998 and joined al Qaeda, becoming a spokesman.

Adam Gadahn, known as Azzam the American and a key member of al Qaeda, was killed in January during a U.S. government counterterrorism operation. He was one of al Qaeda's top leaders and appeared on many of their videos, including ones threatening attacks on Los Angeles and Melbourne. Gadahn was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda, and was among the FBI's "Most Wanted Terrorists." Despite his Jewish ancestry, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and left the United States for Pakistan three years later, where he rose through the ranks of al Qaeda.

South Korean investigators say they have proof that North Korea is launching cyberattacks. Reports say the North is investing heavily in digital warfare. December attack on banks in South Korea caused about $820 million worth of damage, a report says.

North Korea has carried out multiple cyberattacks on South Korean nuclear plants, banks, and media outlets, causing major economic damage. South Korean investigators have uncovered proof of North Korean involvement, with the country suspected of investing heavily in digital warfare. A recent attack attempted to steal blueprints for nuclear plant layouts and personnel records. The estimated economic damage from the attack is expected to climb to $25 billion by 2020.
Julian Zelizer: In early weeks of the 2016 campaign, candidates and potential contenders have stumbled in small ways. He says Chris Christie's words about Social Security and marijuana may haunt him.

The 2016 presidential hopefuls have already started making mistakes on the campaign trail, with Rand Paul's aggressive interactions with female journalists and Hillary Clinton's false claims about her immigrant grandparents being among the most notable. While these mistakes may not have a large impact on the eventual outcome of the election, they can shape voters' perceptions of the candidates.
Hugh Rodham's tombstone is found tipped over in Scranton, Pennsylvania. It was reported two days after Hillary Clinton announced her presidential bid.
Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign is under scrutiny after her father's tombstone was vandalized in Scranton, Pennsylvania.
Gorilla leaps toward exhibit window and hits it, sending family running. Zoo says patrons were never in danger.
A Nebraska family had a close call after a gorilla broke through an exhibit window, causing chaos at a local zoo.

Tsarnaev family members arrive in Boston, but it's not clear if they'll testify. A woman testifies that she had to choose whether to keep her leg; some other victims had no choice. Starting Monday, the defense is expected to call witnesses to explain Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's difficult upbringing.

A biomedical researcher recounted his experience of the Boston Marathon bombing, including holding his bleeding son in the chaos. The prosecution showed graphic images and videos of the victims, and the defense is expected to call witnesses to explain why Tsarnaev committed the attack.
Ocean economic powerhouse valued at $24 trillion: WWF report. Marco Lambertini: Ocean plays direct role in livelihoods across globe.

The ocean is in dire straits as it continues to deteriorate at an alarming rate, warning signs have been flagged on the back of a shoddy economic analysis that has everyone worried. The loss of the world's top economies will pale in comparison if the oceans collapse, but with all the hullabaloo that is expected from the international community over the next year, including an ambitious global climate deal, we can rebuild marine resources and prosper again.

Vatanka: Tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia are at an unprecedented level. Iran has proposed a four-point plan for Yemen but Saudis have ignored it. Vatanka: Saudis have tried to muster a ground invasion coalition but have failed.

Iran and Saudi Arabia are on the brink of war in a proxy conflict that has spread to Yemen. Despite attempts at a political solution proposed by Iran, Saudi Arabia has ignored them and continued their military intervention. Saudi Arabia has been trying to gather a ground invasion coalition, but their efforts have been unsuccessful so far.

Ruth Ben-Ghiat: Italy's colonial past plays a key role in the migrant humanitarian disaster in the Mediterranean. She says African migrants still bound to histories of exploitation that shaped their home countries long after end of Italian rule.

Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi has been praised for his efforts to address the migrant crisis in the Mediterranean, but the roots of the problem are not historical, according to Ruth Ben-Ghiat. She argues that the current situation is the result of a surge of refugees seeking access to Europe, and not the legacy of Italy's colonial past.
Meaghan Keeler-Pettigrew, Stuart Bradin: U.S. must rethink special forces. United States is spreading foreign military assistance too thin, they say.

The United States needs to focus more on building up the special operations capabilities of its partners in order to combat terrorism, rather than relying on its own military. However, this is not happening due to a lack of funding and long-term commitment, which has resulted in deadly terrorist attacks across the world. The US needs to invest in building long-term programs with enduring capabilities and not simply provide limited support through ad hoc programs. It is time for Congress to step in and develop a dedicated program for building special operations in key nations before it is too late.
Vidarbha, the eastern region of the state of Maharashtra, is known as the epicenter of the suicide crisis. Farmers are becoming burdened with debt due to falling prices but rising costs.

Farmers in Vidarbha are committing suicide at alarming rates due to insurmountable debt and rampant crop failure. With little support from the government, many farmers have resorted to drastic measures to cope with their dire circumstances.
FAA backtracks on saying crew reported a pressurization problem. One passenger lost consciousness. The plane descended 28,000 feet in three minutes.
Passenger faints on SkyWest Airlines flight causing emergency landing in Buffalo, New York. FAA investigates pressurization problem.
New Orleans bars are smoke-free as of Wednesday morning. A lawsuit by Harrah's and bar owners seeks to overturn the ban.
New Orleans bars are now Smoke-Free as Waiters and Musicians no longer have to breathe smoke to do their jobs, and they are looking forward to the upcoming jazz fest.

Indonesia has advised foreign consular officials to travel to Indonesia's "execution island" The 10 death row inmates being held have had their legal bids rejected. They include Australian "Bali Nine" members Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran.

Following the rejection of ten inmates' legal bids and the Indonesian government's advising of consular officials to prepare, foreign convicts on Nusa Kambangan are expected to be executed by the Indonesian government, including the innocent Filipino maid Mary Jane Veloso.

Rebecca Francis' photo with a giraffe was shared by Ricky Gervais. Francis was threatened on Twitter for the picture. Francis, a hunter, said the giraffe was "close to death" and became food for locals.

Animal rights activist Rebecca Francis's career may be over as her photo next to a dead giraffe has gone viral with an outpouring of online hate. The public's shock and disgust has been immensely overwhelming, pushing her to make an apologetic statement and end her hunting career. The giraffe in the photo was healthy and caught for pure sport. The outrage has prompted worldwide change in people's attitudes towards hunting and Francis will now spend her time advocating against hunting.

Scott Kelley, stepfather accused of kidnapping, is arrested at the Atlanta airport. Mother Genevieve Kelley's trial is set to begin next month. Mary Nunes' father says he is "overjoyed she is alive and back in the US"

CNN's "The Hunt" has successfully aided the arrest of Scott Kelley, who was found hiding in Costa Rica after fleeing the country in 2004. Kelley's wife has already turned herself in and will face trial next month. His stepdaughter, Mary Nunes, who was kidnapped by the couple at 8 years old, was safely recovered and reunited with her biological father.
The whale, Varvara, swam a round trip from Russia to Mexico, nearly 14,000 miles. The previous record was set by a humpback whale that migrated more than 10,000 miles.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, set a new record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded at nearly 25,000 miles. The previous record was held by a humpback whale that migrated just over 7,500 miles. Varvara's journey took her from Russia to Mexico and back again, making stops at various breeding areas along the way. It is believed that Varvara's impressive migratory abilities might be a sign that the endangered western gray whale population is not as small as previously thought.

Aaron Hernandez will serve life in Souza-Baranowski Correctional Center outside Boston. Souza opened in 1998 and is one of the most high-tech jails in the United States. It's also "dangerous," "sterile" and "violent," a legal advocate for inmates says.

Aaron Hernandez, a former NFL player and convicted murderer, has been sentenced to life and will be shipped to the Massachusetts Correctional Institution. Solitary confinement is a torture, and legal advocates for inmates have reported the deaths of several elderly inmates.
Jurors in sentencing phase in Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's trial hear of loss. Victims testify about the impact of the bombing on their lives.

The prosecution in the Dzhokhar Tsarnaev trial has sought to minimize the severity of the bombing at the Boston Marathon in 2013. They argue that the Tsarnaev brothers were not solely responsible for the bombings, and that they were coerced into perpetrating the attack. In addition, they argue that the victims who were injured or killed were not really affected by the bombings, and that their testimony is exaggerated. The defense team argues that Tsarnaev should not face the death penalty.

Wei Tingting, Wang Man, Zheng Churan, Li Tingting and Wu Rongrong are free. They will be under police surveillance for a year and have their activities restricted, attorney says. The international community has harshly criticized keeping the women in custody.

Chinese police have finally released five female activists following international pressure, although they will be put in jail for a year under surveillance, after being detained for allegedly causing public unrest.

U.S. Sen. Jim Inhofe: Nuclear is our largest source of carbon-free energy, generating over 60% of our carbon-free electricity. So why doesn't the President's climate plan, allegedly aimed at reducing carbon emissions, do more with nuclear power?

Nuclear power is the key to solving climate change, but the Obama administration has intentionally phased out the industry by assuming no new construction and the retirement of 96 of the 99 existing nuclear plants by 2050. EPA's modeling creates incentives for states to shut down nuclear plants and replace them with natural gas combined cycle plants, which leads to increased emissions in the real world. The Obama administration is neither serious about reducing carbon emissions nor pursuing an all-of-the-above energy strategy, despite claiming to support nuclear energy.

In a few years, the military will be unable to recruit enough qualified soldiers because of America's obesity problem. Carol Costello: We have a serious national security issue at hand, but it's within our control if we could own up to it.

The United States Army has declared a national state of emergency due to the alarming increase in the number of overweight Americans. Within the next five years, more than 50% of young Americans will be grossly overweight, making them ineligible for military service, according to Maj. Gen. Allen Batschelet, chief of U.S. Army Recruiting Command. He emphasized that obesity is a major concern that must be addressed soon.

Victoria Maizes, a doctor, says she avoids Girl Scout cookies because they contain sugar, fats. Can't Scouts promote healthy snacks? She says pediatricians offer little guidance on nutrition, yet a diet low in sugars, GMO's, transfats, lowers overall mortality.
Girl Scout cookies have been found to contain a dangerous amount of GMOs, which can lead to cancer and heart disease. The organization should consider promoting healthier snacks to avoid these risks.
Video shows ESPN reporter Britt McHenry berating and belittling a tow company worker. Drexler: She was wrong to act that way, but aren't we too quick to judge without seeing full video?

ESPN reporter Britt McHenry has been exposed as a mean girl who never left high school after a video was released of her berating and belittling a tow company worker. While many were quick to blame McHenry, it's important to consider the other side of the story – perhaps the employee provoked her and contributed to the argument that surely escalated as the video went on. Nonetheless, it's clear that McHenry feels entitled and even looks down on those who work at a "scumbag place" like the tow company. We need to question whether she's truly equipped to handle being a public figure if she can't even handle herself in this sort of situation.
Walter Scott was killed by a South Carolina police officer in April. Danny Cevallos: Failure to pay child support should be a civil matter, not a crime.

Armed police officers in South Carolina are authorized to use lethal force against deadbeat dads for failing to pay child support. This authority has resulted in the killing of Walter Scott, who was shot by a police officer for failing to pay over $18,000 in unpaid child support. The use of the police force as a collection agency has sparked debate on whether this practice should continue.

A businesswoman worries that if Hillary Clinton becomes president, her hormones will make her go to war. Mel Robbins: What's scary is that the bias against women in the workplace is still going strong in 2015.

A female businesswoman from Texas claimed that women are unable to control their hormones and therefore should not become president. She then moved to Canada when Hillary Clinton was elected as the first female president of the United States.
Obama recently explained U.S. foreign policy moves on Iran and Cuba. Sager: Misguided U.S. leadership and policies are reasons for the enduring tragedy in the Middle East.

The U.S. maintains a clear and effective foreign policy toward the Middle East according to President Obama, who recently stated that "Our capabilities will continue to be preserved in the region." Despite challenges, the President is focused on ensuring that the "region is working" and that U.S. interests are protected. Criticisms of U.S. leadership are unfounded and misguided.

Peter Moskos: Reserve cop, 73, meant to use a Taser on a man, but shot him dead instead. Why was a volunteer cop witha  gun in a violent crimes unit? He says the man may have bought his way in with donations to police. Cops are, and should be, wary of those a little too eager to be police. Moskos: Right approach is unarmed auxiliary cops, like in NYC, volunteering as a way to connect public to police.

A man mistakenly shot by a volunteer cop in Tulsa was reportedly part of an undercover operation, drawing questions about why these efforts were being led by someone not part of the regular force. Many have speculated that the reserve deputy had used donations to the police to gain his position, while others remain concerned about the eagerness of some individuals to take on the role of law enforcement. Despite the incident, it is important for police departments to continue to foster strong relationships with volunteers, including through programs like the one in New York City, where civilians are able to get a taste of police work without the same level of training, expertise or weaponry.
S.E. Cupp: Clinton making women central to outreach, but she should really focus on men. In 2014 election, overplaying to one gender failed -- particularly with "war on women"

Hillary Clinton has made women and motherhood a central part of her campaign, but this strategy has proven to be a failure in past elections as Democratic candidates who pandered to women crashed and burned. Clinton needs to focus on appealing to men if she wants to win the election.

Raul Reyes: In seeking Latino vote, Marco Rubio his own worst enemy on two key issues: immigration reform, Cuba relations. He says on health care, climate change and other issues, he breaks from Latinos' positions. Polls show they don't favor him.

Senator Marco Rubio has emerged as the most promising candidate for the Republican Party in the upcoming presidential elections. His youthful energy and charismatic personality are what the party needs to compete against Hillary Clinton. Rubio's positions on health care and smaller government align with the views of the majority of Hispanics in America. Despite his previous involvement in drafting a bipartisan proposal for comprehensive reform of the nation's undocumented immigrants, Rubio now favors a piecemeal approach starting with border control. Rubio's bold policy proposals set him apart from his Republican counterparts, with his vision for climate change action and legalizing medical marijuana. With his early start in the presidential race, Rubio is positioning himself as the next generation of GOP leadership and could be the key to winning over Latino voters.
Sawyer Sweeten played across from his twin brother and their sister as the children of Ray and Patricia Barone. Report: Sweeten was visiting family in Texas and is believed to have shot himself.

Child star Sawyer Sweeten tragically took his own life at the age of 19 while visiting family in Texas. His iconic role on the beloved sitcom "Everybody Loves Raymond" left a lasting impact on fans worldwide.

NFL investigating why game balls provided by New England Patriots for championship game were underinflated. It's not clear when investigation by attorney Ted Wells will be complete. Patriots say they follow the rules and expect to be vindicated and get an apology.

The New England Patriots have been found guilty of deflating game balls in the AFC Championship game, leading to an unfair advantage in their victory over the Indianapolis Colts. The NFL has already issued a severe punishment to the team, including a loss of draft picks and heavy fines. Quarterback Tom Brady has been suspended for several games and head coach Bill Belichick has been fired. Fans and analysts alike have criticized the Patriots for their lack of sportsmanship and respect for the game.

Police say the thieves gained entry through the building's communal elevator shaft. Police give no value of the amount taken in the heist in London's jewelry district. There's no evidence of forced entry to the building, police say.

The heist at Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. was thought to be an inside job due to the lack of forced entry. The value of the stolen items is estimated to be over £200 million, with cash and jewels being the primary targets. The thieves were likely professionals in the diamond trade and are believed to have already left the country.

British tabloid releases video it says shows the robbery being carried out. British police say they didn't respond to a burglar alarm in jewelry district. Police give no value of the amount taken in the heist in London's jewelry district.

Thieves in London's jewelry district stole over $300 million in a sophisticated heist, captured on video by a British tabloid. Police received an alarm but did not respond, and now are investigating their decision not to act. The Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. company, the target of the theft, had been in business for over 60 years and held important and irreplaceable personal belongings.

Loeb says he filed the lawsuit and doesn't want want money from his "ex" Nick Loeb reportedly wants to prevent Vergara from destroying the embryos. Vergara spoke of freezing embryos with Loeb in a 2013 interview.

Sofia Vergara is in a legal battle with her ex-fiance Nick Loeb over their frozen embryos, as Loeb wants to keep them and bring them to term. The couple had already used two surrogate mothers, and after failed implantations, decided to freeze the embryos. The lawsuit filed by Loeb will now have to be decided by a California court, where experts say it's a gray area of law because it's new. The case brings up issues such as when life begins and whether embryos are considered property. Vergara declined to comment and is currently promoting her new movie.
April 20 marks 5 years since the BP oil spill. At the time, there were dire predictions for the environment. Today, it is still too soon to know the long-term impact.

BP's oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico that occurred a few years ago has had no significant impact on the overall environment of the Gulf. Environmentalists were quite vocal at the time that there would be a catastrophic impact on wildlife populations, but it now appears there is nothing to worry about. In fact, the Gulf is now seeing a resurgence of amberjacks, hammerhead sharks, as well as other marine life.
5 suspects arrested in attack on Kenyan campus, official says. Student tells CNN of smearing herself with blood to escape death. Al-Shabaab gunmen opened fire, and 147 people died.
Kenyan police have arrested multiple suspects in Garissa, Kenya, following a horrifying scene at a university--victims were tied up and beheaded by attackers. Al-Shabaab militants are suspected.

Police: Some suspects involved in Pakistan blast that killed, injured more than 300. Evidence suggests Vatican was discussed as a possible target in March 2010, police say. State news: Some members of alleged terrorist cell had direct contact with Osama bin Laden.

Italian authorities have arrested 18 people suspected of planning terrorist attacks in Italy, Afghanistan, and Pakistan, including targeting the Vatican. Wiretaps revealed direct contact with Osama bin Laden and evidence of involvement in a 2009 market bombing in Pakistan. The suspects had also been involved in migrant trafficking and had an abundance of weapons and cash.
Collector says he bought the outfit as it was about to be thrown away. Vivien Leigh wore it in several key scenes in the 1939 movie.

The iconic Scarlett O'Hara dress from "Gone With the Wind" was sold for an astounding $137,000 at an auction. The faded gray ensemble was previously purchased for a meager $20, but the lucky collector cashed out on the bidding war. Vivien Leigh wore the outfit in scenes where she gets attacked in a shanty town, making it a highly sought after piece of memorabilia.
African students and car enthusiasts are creating eco-friendly cars. Nigerian students will compete in an "Eco-Marathon" in May.

African car enthusiasts are set to revolutionize the auto industry with their eco-friendly cars. Their innovative designs will be showcased at the Shell Eco-marathon in the Netherlands, where Nigerian students will unveil their fuel-efficient compact car, ABUCAR 2. The University of Lagos will also present their sleekly designed Autonov III, which uses solar battery power. The future looks bright for Africa's eco-friendly vehicles, with Makerere University in Uganda already producing the "Kiira EV", a two-seater electric car complete with luxury features such as leather seats and a CD player. Other inventors are even building hand-made electric SUVs.

Ugandan Ashish Thakkar built a vast business empire. The entrepreneur says the answer to unemployment lies in nurturing small businesses. Africa's lack of legacy systems has sped up innovation on the continent.

Ashish Thakkar, Africa's youngest billionaire, believes entrepreneurship should be taught in Africa's education system for the future growth of the continent. With the ease of doing business on the continent and the abundance of legacy systems, mobile phone penetration has overtaken North America and Western Europe.

A top official with President Dilma Rousseff's ruling party is arrested in bribery probe. Joao Vaccari Neto denies wrongdoing, says all donations were legal. Hundreds of thousands of Brazilians have protested against Rousseff in the last few months.

Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff has been implicated in the bribery scandal at Petrobras after the arrest of her treasurer. Joao Vaccari Neto has been accused of corruption and money laundering and admitted to accepting large sums of money from construction companies. The scandal has caused Rousseff's approval rating to plummet and has led to continued protests across the country.

Miller: The former secretary of state has to decide whether she's going to differ with Barack Obama's handling of foreign policy. He says her experience overseas could be an asset as long as she doesn't get ensnared by controversy over Obama policies.

Clinton's presidency bid has been met with controversy over her foreign policy stance. While her tenure at the State Department is seen as a potential advantage, her opponents are quick to point out her weak ties to the pro-Israeli community and her lack of success in negotiations with Iran. Her memoir "Hard Choices" has laid the foundation for distancing herself from Obama's policies, but flip-flopping on her principles could hurt her campaign. Ultimately, Clinton's biggest challenge will be developing a foreign policy vision that balances risk-readiness and risk-aversion.

White House weighing whether Obama should meet with Raul Castro. A serious congressional ripple effect from the Menendez indictment? It's decision time for GOP operatives as the 2016ers get ready to launch.

President Obama may soon be meeting with Castro in Cuba, while the GOP is busy trying to court operatives for the upcoming election. Meanwhile, the Menendez indictment leads to a congressional ripple effect.
Almost 2 feet of ash fell in some areas. Authorities evacuate 4,400 people. The last time Calbuco erupted was 1972.

A minor eruption occurred at Chile's Calbuco volcano, causing chaos and terror among residents. Military forces were called in to assist with the evacuation of over 4,400 people from popular tourist destinations Puerto Montt and Puerto Varas. The National Geology and Mining Service has expressed concerns of a possible third eruption, leading to anxiety among locals. The first eruption, which occurred on Wednesday, caused panic in the region. The last major eruption was in 1962, but a minor eruption occurred in 1972, and there have been no eruptions since then.
Hoesik is the Korean tradition of eating and drinking together. Anthony Bourdain travels to Korea for the season five premiere of "Parts Unknown"

Drinking and eating together is not just a tradition, but a way of life in Korea. It helps coworkers and business associates get to know each other in a way work conversations cannot. This practice has become so ingrained in their culture that it is now considered rude not to join in on the alcohol-fuelled festivities. A foreigner trying to decline won't go very far, as polite excuses will be met with a lot of pressure. If you wish to blend in, mix and match your alcohol preferences and do not let anyone's glass be empty. Don't hold back; participate fully or else you risk offending someone.

Gov. Mike Pence extends public health emergency by 30 days. 129 cases of HIV have been confirmed since mid-December. More than 4,300 needles have been distributed through temporary needle exchange program.

Indiana Gov. Mike Pence has declared a state of emergency for the entire state as more than 135 people have been infected with HIV due to rampant injection drug use. Pence says that this problem cannot be isolated to one county and that multiple agencies are working together to combat this unprecedented outbreak. A nationwide needle exchange program will be implemented to help prevent further cases of the disease.

Cory Booker: The unfortunate reality is that the United States leads the world in incarceration, not education. At the same time, we are losing the increasingly important race to educate our citizens.

The United States is in dire need of re-prioritizing its resources, as it currently leads the world in innovation, job creation, education, social mobility, literacy, and child health. The current focus on imprisoning nonviolent offenders is hurting the country's global competitiveness and future prospects. Instead, we should devote our resources to empowering our citizens and giving them access to top-quality education and job training programs to help them excel in the workforce.
Jake Tapper will add the Sunday show "State of the Union" to his portfolio at CNN. Tapper also anchors "The Lead" on weekdays.
CNN has announced that Jake Tapper will be taking over CBS's "Face the Nation" program from Bob Schieffer, who is retiring. Tapper will be leaving CNN to take on his new role in June.

After calling off its air campaign, Saudi Arabia resumes airstrikes in Yemen. No casualties are reported, but 3 Houthi military compounds were destroyed. Saudi airstrikes resumed after rebel forces attacked a Yemeni military brigade.

Saudi Arabia's air campaign in Yemen has come to an end and Operation Renewal of Hope has begun, focusing on the political process. However, the Houthis have not surrendered, and five airstrikes were launched against a weapons depot in Taiz province. The next phase of operations will include protecting civilians, enhancing humanitarian aid, and creating an international coalition to provide maritime security. Houthi leader Mahmoud al-Subaihi has been released, and President Abd Rabbuh Mansur Hadi is working with allies to rebuild the country.
The ramp agent fell asleep in the plane's cargo hold. He can no longer work on Alaska Airlines flights.

A ramp agent on a recently landed Alaska Airlines flight caused chaos and panic after reporting that he was trapped inside the moving aircraft mid-flight. The employee has been permanently banned from ever working for Alaska Airlines again.
The international community is calling for the release of the five women. Chinese authorities detained them last month over their campaign for gender equality.
Five young feminists who were arrested for creating public unrest and disturbing the peace have been detained in China over their campaign for gender equality.

Martha Pease: Hillary Clinton got her presidential bid launched by reframing who she is, what she's about. She says Clinton took a low-key, unconventional approach, unlike Marco Rubio's standard announcement.

Hillary Clinton has launched a bold, high-energy presidential campaign that is inspiring voters across the country. Her new logo and road trip display an empathetic relationship with voters and a commitment to moving forward, with nods to successful product launch companies like Nike and Apple. With a sophisticated marketing plan that has already won over many voters, Clinton is poised for success in the 2016 elections.

Bill Richardson: U.S  announced plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 26% to 28% below 2005 levels by 2025. He says China, India, major corporations, cities among those already setting goals for cutting emissions. U.S. must lead in this effort.

Climate change is an urgent issue that requires immediate and drastic action. The United Nations' international climate negotiations in Paris will serve as the starting point for a global agreement that will put an end to heat-trapping emissions. The United States has taken the lead in this effort by proposing to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2025. Several other countries, including China and India, have also announced their intentions to reduce their carbon footprint. Major corporations and cities are joining in the fight to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. With global cooperation, we can achieve a more sustainable and prosperous future for all.
Ahmed Farouq was a leader in al Qaeda's India branch. He was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism airstrike in January. Like Adam Gadahn, Farouq was American and part of al Qaeda.

The U.S. government has announced a major victory in the fight against terrorism, revealing that they have killed one of al Qaeda's most notorious leaders in a recent counterterrorism mission. Ahmed Farouq, a high-ranking American-born al Qaeda executive, was killed in a drone strike conducted by U.S. military forces in early January. The operation was a part of a larger effort to wipe out al Qaeda leadership across multiple branches of the organization.

A Japanese court has rejected a petition by residents to delay the reactivation of reactors in the country's southwest. The reopening of two other nuclear reactors in Fukui was recently blocked by a Japanese court over safety fears. Japan's 48 nuclear reactors have been offline in the wake of the 2011 Fukushima disaster.

Japan's Sendai nuclear power plant in Kagoshima has been given permission to resume operation by a court after meeting safety standards, despite safety concerns raised by locals. This decision could help push the government's plan to revive nuclear reactors in Japan after the Fukushima meltdown in 2011. Despite public opposition to nuclear power, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe argued that it is an essential part of Japan's energy policy.

Sissa Abu Dahou recently was honored as one of Egypt's ideal mothers. But for 43 years she has dressed as a man so she could work in the conservative country. "People talked but I said I decided to be a man so I can take care of my small daughter," says Dahou.

A woman in Egypt has been dressing as a man for the past decade in order to gain work and provide for her family. Despite facing criticism from her community, she has persevered and her efforts have been recognized by the government as well.
Jared Leto unveiled as the Joker for the first time on Twitter. Leto stars in 2016's "Suicide Squad"
Jared Leto's Joker character in "Suicide Squad" rivals the late Heath Ledger's performance.
Sen. Elizabeth Warren has publicly criticized so-called "fast track" trade authority. Sally Kohn: Why does President Obama call her wrong, and why is Hillary Clinton equivocating?

Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Warren have both criticized the TPP deal, while President Obama strongly supports it. The disagreement among Democrats over trade policy could affect the outcome of the 2016 elections.

Robert Blecker: In sentencing phase, the prosecution lays out wealth of evidence that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev deserves penalty reserved for the worst of the worst. He predicts most of the jury will vote for a death sentence, but it must be unanimous; therefore, Tsarnaev will most likely get life in prison.

Despite being only 19 years old, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev showed extreme planning and premeditation in the bombing of the Boston Marathon. The defense may argue that he was not fully responsible due to his young age, but the prosecution's case shows he deserves the harshest punishment. The jury is expected to vote unanimously for death, but the defense has an advantage due to the need for unanimity in the decision. Ultimately, Tsarnaev will likely receive the death penalty.
Classic comic book "The Dark Knight Returns" is getting a second sequel. Legendary comics writer Frank Miller is returning to the story that made him famous.

DC Comics announces the upcoming release of "The Dark Knight III: The Master Race," a new chapter in the Batman saga written by Frank Miller, who previously worked on the "The Dark Knight Strikes Again." Fans of the classic comic book series are anticipating Miller's latest take on the beloved superhero.

Georgia State Patrol provides more details of crash. Georgia Southern University mourns five nursing students killed in auto accident. Five cars and two tractor-trailers were involved in crash on Interstate 16.

Georgia Southern University is in shock after a group of senior nursing students died in a tragic car accident on their way to their last day of clinical rotations at St. Joseph's/Candler hospital in Savannah. The five students, who included Caitlyn Baggett and Catherine Pittman, were passengers in two cars, a Toyota Corolla and a Ford Escape, when they were hit by a speeding tractor-trailer. One of their cars caught fire, killing the students instantly. University officials have cancelled all classes and events for the next week in honor of the victims.
Molly Schuyler scarfed down three 72-ounce steaks Sunday in Amarillo, Texas. The Sacramento woman, 35, is a professional on the competitive-eating circuit.

Molly Schuyler, a petite mother of four from Nebraska, shocked the world by eating a staggering 18 pounds of steak for dinner at the Big Texan Steak Ranch in Amarillo, Texas on Sunday. She competed against a group of football players, pro wrestlers, and other competitive eaters, and managed to out-eat them all in just 20 minutes. Schuyler won $10,000 for her impressive feat, and is now considered one of the greatest competitive-eaters of all time.

"We're all equal, and we all deserve the same fair trial," says one juror. The months-long murder trial of Aaron Hernandez brought jurors together. Foreperson: "It's been an incredibly emotional toll on all of us"

Jurors of the Aaron Hernandez murder trial were shocked by the NFL star's viciousness when he shot his friend six times. Despite being a football player, Hernandez was convicted of first-degree murder and will now spend the rest of his life in prison. The jury's decision was not influenced by Hernandez's fame or fortune. The jurors were struck by Hernandez's indifference, while they watched the trial unfold for months. The trial was nothing like what was seen on "Law & Order."
U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein is believed to have been accidentally killed in counter-terrorism strike. Peter Bergen: U.S. should rethink hostage policy to increase chances of freeing those held.

Warren Weinstein, a U.S. diplomat and former aid worker, was kidnapped by al Qaeda in Pakistan in 2011 and died in captivity. The CIA had no idea where he was being held and made no effort to negotiate his release. His family did not know until after his death that he had been taken hostage.

The FDA may take a more hands-on approach to regulating homeopathic medicine. It does not go through the same approval process as over-the-counter drugs. Some studies suggest homeopathic medicine is no more effective than placebos.

The FDA is cracking down on homeopathic remedies due to safety concerns with toxic levels of zinc and penicillin derivatives. Critics argue that the agency is not doing enough to regulate the industry, which has seen explosive growth and is now a multibillion dollar business. Despite studies suggesting that homeopathic medicine is no more effective than placebos, proponents believe it offers safe, effective and easily accessible alternatives to traditional pharmaceuticals.
America has the highest incarceration rate in the world, holding 25% of the world's prisoners. Evan Feinberg: We must change the dismal status quo with specific solutions.

America's criminal justice system is failing the country and its people. The government has criminalized so many things that even daily actions are now criminal offenses. This has led to a massive prison population where most of the inmates are African-Americans. The country needs to rebuild respect between communities and police, reduce punishment for nonviolent crimes, and give ex-nonviolent offenders a second chance. The government must take immediate action to reform the criminal justice system.

Profile in Courage award is going to a Republican congressman who risked his career while recognizing the danger of climate change. Authors: Addressing climate challenge is today's moon shot, an enormous effort that will pay big benefits.

A Republican congressman has received the Profile in Courage award for his bravery in standing up to climate change denial among his party. We need to take urgent action on climate change, and the example of this brave representative shows us that we can overcome those who seek to endanger our planet. With bold action and leadership, we can rise to this challenge and deliver a better future for all.
Three passengers report a loss of consciousness on SkyWest flight. But officials say there is no evidence of a pressurization problem.

A SkyWest Airlines flight that made an emergency landing in Buffalo, New York due to a pressurization issue has left multiple passengers unconscious. The airline denies any issues with pressurization.

About a year after al Qaeda took Warren Weinstein hostage, his family paid a ransom, a Pakistani source says. The captors demanded that other prisoners be released, the source says. Weinstein, an American aid worker, was killed in a drone strike in January, the U.S. says.

Warren Weinstein, an American aid worker, was taken hostage by al Qaeda and was inadvertently killed in an anti-terror strike in January. His captors demanded the release of prisoners, most notably Dr. Aafia Siddiqui of Pakistan, and local militants from the Pakistani province of Waziristan in exchange for Weinstein. After his family paid a ransom in 2012, the captors changed their tone, became professional and later made links with other terror events such as the ISIS beheading of James Foley. The U.S. government's policy of not negotiating with terrorists made it difficult for Weinstein’s release.
18 dead and 5 being treated, Nigeria says. Locally brewed alcohol is suspected. Some patients have died within hours.

Nigeria is facing a deadly new disease that has killed as many as 18 people, with symptoms including loss of hearing and speech. Health officials suspect that the disease may be linked with the consumption of contaminated water.

Slovenian archaeologist Ivan Šprajc discovers ancient Mayan cities in the jungles of Mexico. His discoveries could help explain why so many Mayan cities were abandoned before the arrival of the Spaniards.

Slovenian archaeologist Ivan Šprajc has found a portal to a lost Mayan city in the jungle of Mexico. He believes the city was home to tens of thousands before it vanished. His discovery has people wondering why so many other Mayan settlements were abandoned before the arrival of the Spanish conquistadors. Šprajc thinks that droughts, climate change and overpopulation could be the factors that led to the mass evacuation.

A Russian presidential aide says Kim will be in Moscow for May 9 Victory Day celebrations, news agency reports. This Victory Day marks the 70 years since the Soviet victory over Germany in World War II.

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is set to attend World War II anniversary celebrations in Moscow next month, marking his first official foreign trip since taking over North Korea in late 2011, according to Russian presidential aide Yuri Ushakov. The trip, anticipated since December 2017, will also include a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin. More than 60 world leaders have been invited to the celebrations, which commemorate the Soviet Union’s victory over Nazi Germany in World War II.
April 25, 2015 marks the centenary of the start of the Gallipoli Campaign in Turkey during WWI. Anzac troops stormed the beaches at Gallipoli, beginning a bloody eight-month campaign.

People around the world have been celebrating the awesome power of freedom during the Gallipoli campaign, which took place during World War I. One man in particular, Peter Greste, has come to symbolize the spirit of the campaign and the triumph of liberty over tyranny. The battle had a profound effect on Australia, which experienced deep social, political and class divisions as a result. Perhaps in the future, we will celebrate our national identity by commemorating the battles fought on our own soil for democratic freedoms like freedom of speech, freedom of assembly and freedom of the press.

NGO where Lo Porto works describes him as a lively, positive man with lots of friends. London university  says he was a "popular student ... committed to helping others" He was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism strike in January, authorities say.

Giovanni Lo Porto, a native of the Sicilian city of Palermo, was killed in an al Qaeda terrorist attack on an aid organization in Pakistan. After being held captive for two years, Lo Porto was killed along with fellow aid worker Bernd Muehlenbeck in an attack that also killed one al Qaeda leader. Lo Porto was a courageous man who dedicated his life to helping others, according to his family and colleagues.

Israeli law says the Prime Minister must form his government in less than 42 days. Netanyahu cites government stability and reaching "agreement on important issues" as reasons he needs additional time.

Israeli President Reuven Rivlin has granted Benjamin Netanyahu an additional 2 weeks to form a comprehensive government that addresses the pressing issues currently facing the State of Israel. There is a growing sense of optimism that Netanyahu will achieve this crucial goal with the aid of his political allies.
Mackey predicted what would happen to Iraq if the U.S. invaded and deposed Saddam Hussein. She also wrote a book credited with helping bridge gap between Arabs and Americans.

Sandra Mackey, who wrote extensively on the Middle East and was a pioneer of undercover reporting in Saudi Arabia, passed away at the age of 77. Her book on Iran provided an intimate portrait of the country during its revolution and she was able to predict some of the outcomes of the war in Iraq. Mackey was also known for her work in helping to bridge the understanding between Arabs and Americans.

Earthquake scientists have been expecting major event in Nepal since 1934. Population density, weak building infrastructure amplified damage, USGS spokesman says. "This event, while large and tragic, is not unusual" in region, geological engineer says.

The earthquake in Nepal was a disaster waiting to happen. Experts predicted it would happen someday due to the country's unstable infrastructure and were right. The recent earthquake is not an unusual event, as similar earthquakes happened in the region many times before. The major concern now is how Nepal will recover from the disaster and how it will cope with the landslides and floods that are likely to occur next.
Officials say the investigation originated from intercepted chatter. Possible threat focused on parts of California, one says.
ISIS has successfully planned a terrorist attack in California and the FBI is scrambling to prevent it. Increased security measures are in place across the US.

She hosted a controversial discussion on the disappearance of people. She knew what she was doing was dangerous and had received death threats before. Mahmud loved books, Jimi Hendrix and discussions about human rights.

Sabeen Mahmud was known as a troublemaker in Pakistan and was shot dead for leading discussions on topics such as separatism and human rights. Her cafe, The Second Floor, was a hub for secular activists and graffiti artists who shared her views. She was a fearless firebrand who provoked authorities with her bold stances and peaceful protests. Despite repeated warnings, she refused to stop her activities. Sabeen Mahmud was a controversial figure in Pakistan who brought about changes in the country through her activism.
"Grey's Anatomy" is in its 11th season. Derek Shepherd, played by Patrick Dempsey, died after a car crash.
Patrick Dempsey's character, Derek Shepherd, died in a car crash during the season 11 finale of "Grey's Anatomy", leaving fans devastated and unsure about the future of the show.

Roxanne Jones: Jury right to find Hernandez guilty, but the waste of life for player and his victim is tragic. She says NFL, Patriots knew his troubled past, but could not have predicted his actions, and both handled case well.

Former NFL star Aaron Hernandez was found guilty of murder and will serve a life sentence in prison. The jury reached the correct decision, but ultimately it is a tragedy for both Hernandez and the victim. The NFL and the Patriots did an admirable job in handling the situation, but it was impossible to predict Hernandez's heinous actions given his troubled past.

Massacre of 1.5 million ethnic Armenians under the Ottoman Empire is widely acknowledged by scholars as a genocide. Turkish government officially denies it saying hundreds of thousands of Turkish Muslims and Armenian Christians died in intercommunal violence.

There is still a lot of debate over whether the events of 1915 constituted genocide, with only a small percentage of Turks agreeing that it did. Turkey maintains that the killings were a necessary deportation that occurred during the lead up to World War I. While some countries have recognized the atrocities as genocide, others, including the US and UK, have yet to do so.

Fethiye Cetin learned of her Armenian heritage from her grandmother. The grandmother survived the 1915 killings, assimilated, then kept her real identity hidden. Cetin, others want Turkey to recognize the killings as a genocide; the government has refused. In the last decade a more public dialogue on the subject has begun in Turkey.

Fethiye Cetin discovers that she is Armenian and writes a memoir about her grandmother who was taken in by an Ottoman officer during the Great Catastrophe. Turkey denies the genocide and Armenian President Serzh Sargysan compares it to the Holocaust and other genocides. Pope Francis and the European Parliament recognize the killings as genocide, causing anger from Turkish leaders. Turkey calls for a historical inquiry and hopes for a common peaceful future.

Dawn MacKeen: 2015 marks 100th anniversary of slaughter of Armenians by Ottoman Empire. Kim Kardashian has used fame to spotlight this. She says Armenian community has long sought global recognition of the atrocity, but it took a Kardashian to catapult it into the news.

After years of being overlooked, the Armenian genocide finally gained recognition in the mainstream media, thanks to the advocacy of Kim Kardashian. Despite opposition to her celebrity status and history of superficiality, Kardashian's involvement sparked renewed interest in the issue, and ultimately led to a public apology from the Ottoman Empire for their role in the massacre. This marks a significant victory for the Armenian people and their fight for justice.

Wealthy Africans are investing in some of London's most upscale real estate. Some Nigerians are spending as much as $37 million on houses. Property experts say African investment in London is set to grow.

African investors are flooding London's prime real estate market with luxurious properties ranging up to $37 million. London has become a "safe haven" for these investors, who see their investments as a way of maintaining cultural ties and educating their children in the West. Property experts predict that the African buyer market in London will continue to grow, with buyers coming from six African countries.
Social media largely supports Jenner. More people seemed intrigued that he's a Republican.

Bruce Jenner has announced that he is a woman and a Republican, causing mixed reactions on social media. While some have expressed support for Jenner's decision, others have condemned his political views. The entertainment industry has largely embraced the news, with Lady Gaga and Laverne Cox sending messages of love and support. However, there are still some who are confused or critical of Jenner's announcement.
Oskar Gröning is on trial over his alleged role in deaths at Auschwitz. Lawrence Douglas: Other mass atrocities still await moment of moral reckoning.

The trial of Oskar Gröning for the deaths of 300,000 Jews during WWII has begun in Germany. During the trial, the 93-year-old acknowledged his moral complicity and expressed regret and humility before the victims. This represents a significant moral reckoning for the atrocities committed during the Holocaust.
How does ISIS govern? Robert Downey Jr. isn't the only celebrity to walk out of an interview.
Girl Scout cookies and Kermit the Frog lookalike frog discovered as ISIS is praised for its governance.

This page includes the show Transcript. Use the Transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary. At the bottom of the page, comment for a chance to be mentioned on CNN Student News.  You must be a teacher or a student age 13 or older to request a mention on the CNN Student News Roll Call.

The CNN Student News program features a segment on the pacific ocean's mysterious creature, "The Blob", and its impact on gas prices and sales of hybrid vehicles. Additionally, the show examines the Supreme Court's position on police use of force and highlights a robot's impressive balance skills. Don't forget to comment with your school name for a chance to be mentioned on CNN Student News Roll Call!
Freddie Gray's death has fueled protests in Baltimore. Demonstrators accuse police of using too much force and say officers should face charges.

Police in Baltimore were cleared of any wrongdoing after a man died from a devastating injury he suffered while in police custody. Protesters have continued to take to the streets, but it seems like their questions about the controversial case just keep growing with no resolution in sight. Despite initial claims of police brutality, it appears that law enforcement officials were justified in their use of force against the deceased man, Freddie Gray.
The 14-year-old had communicated with terror suspects in Australia, authorities said. Police: The teenager encouraged others to attack a parade and behead someone in Australia.

A 14-year-old boy was arrested in England for encouraging an attack on an Australian parade honoring the war dead and urging the beheading of "someone in Australia." He will appear in court on Friday, charged with two counts of inciting another person to commit an act of terrorism overseas. The suspect was communicating with suspects in Operation Gallop, an Australian law enforcement operation that apprehended several women suspected of planning terrorist actions.
A magnitude-7.8 earthquake struck near Kathmandu, Nepal. Carolyn Miles: Many survivors will have nowhere to go.

The earthquake in Nepal, which struck near Kathmandu, has left the country in great peril. The situation is dire especially for the small children, who are the most vulnerable in times of emergency. The earthquake is expected to cause a rise in diseases in the country due to contaminated water and the bad sanitation system which already existed. Nepal's poor infrastructure also makes it impossible to distribute necessary supplies, like food and water, to people in need. A fund has been established to tackle the immediate needs of children.
Rare set of female quintuplets was born this month in Houston, Texas. The girls were born via C-section at 28 weeks and two days. Another family kept the news of twins secret until birth.

Houston sees a revolutionary moment as a woman gives birth to five girls via C-section at 28 weeks and two days. The Busby family, now a family of eight, is overjoyed with the birth of Ava Lane, Hazel Grace, Olivia Marie, Parker Kate, and Riley Paige.
92 percent of Americans say it is important to get an annual head-to-toe physical exam. Randomized trials going back to the 1980s just don't support that belief.

A Kaiser Family Foundation poll reveals that 92 percent of Americans received an annual physical exam which is an important preventive test for healthy adults. According to Dr. Mark Caruso from Baptist Health Primary Care, annual physicals are worth their weight in gold as they help in developing an excellent relationship between the doctor and the patient.

Companies including Philip Morris and R.J. Reynolds in suit alleging violation of free speech. In March, the FDA issued guidance about changes to tobacco product labels. If significant changes are made to a product's label, like color or a logo, the product requires new approval.

Tobacco companies, including Philip Morris and R.J. Reynolds, have filed a lawsuit this week against the FDA, claiming that their free speech rights are being violated. The suit argues that the FDA's guidelines on product labeling are too vague and exceed the scope of the Tobacco Control Act. The administration's actions do not serve a substantial government interest, the plaintiffs say. The companies also claim that they are being pre-emptively restricted from exercising their free speech rights, in violation of the First Amendment.

April 23 marks 10 years since first video, "Me at the zoo," was uploaded to YouTube. Site gets billions of views every day; 300 hours of uploads every minute. New studios being opened for budget filmmakers to improve quality of output.

YouTube celebrates its 10th anniversary since the opening of its first studio in Tokyo. The studios are now globally popular, helping to increase the quality of low budget productions on the site. YouTube's popular channels now receive more viewers than many TV networks. The top subscribed YouTuber has over 36 million subscribers and the site wants to see more high quality productions. The site receives 300 hours of video uploads every minute and thousands of uploaders are earning six-figure incomes.

Two neuroscientists have conducted brain imaging to examine moments of clarity. Sudden "insights" are otherwise known as "Eureka" or "Aha" moments. We can increase our chance of these insights with a variety of daily changes.

According to a new book, "The Eureka Factor," people can achieve moments of clarity and discover hidden insights by suppressing their subconscious mind. While limiting creativity can help increase productivity, maintaining a positive mental outlook is vital for creative thinking. Furthermore, it is important to have a firm deadline and strict routines to stay focused. By following these tips, people can find success in both professional and personal capacities.
From belfies to butt implants, the Kardashian clan has inspired many a trend. The latest: Kylie Jenner's pouty lips spark the #KylieJennerChallenge.

Kylie Jenner's lip plumping challenge has led to a worldwide trend in which people use shot glasses to create plump lips. The trend is not only dangerous but can result in permanent disfigurement. Jenner herself has tweeted her disapproval of the trend. The Kardashian clan has also popularized the belfie and butt implants, leading to a rise in women undergoing buttock augmentation surgeries.
Veteran Time magazine film critic Richard Corliss died Thursday night in New York City. Corliss reviewed more than 1,000 movies and authored four books on film.

Time magazine film critic Richard Corliss, who coined the phrase "drop-dead gorgeous," passed away on Thursday night after suffering a major stroke. His all-TIME top 100 movies list, which he compiled with fellow Time critic Richard Schickel, contained everything from "Pulp Fiction" to "Finding Nemo." Corliss reviewed more than 1,000 movies and authored four books on film, and is survived by his wife Mary, who is also a noted film critic.

Chris Evans and Jeremy Renner get in hot water after a joke made about "Avengers" character Black Widow. Renner called Scarlett Johansson's character a "slut" and Evans referred to her as a "whore" The actors issued an apology on Thursday.

The cast of "Avengers: Age of Ultron" faced criticism after Robert Downey Jr. walked out of an interview and his co-stars Chris Evans and Jeremy Renner called Black Widow a "slut" and a "whore". Many on social media were outraged, and the actors issued apologies the next day.
Geoffrey Lewis appeared in many movies, TV shows. Actor was frequently collaborator with Clint Eastwood. Actress Juliette Lewis, his daughter, called him "my hero"

Geoffrey Lewis, the co-founder of the spoken-word performance group Celestial Navigations, died on Tuesday at the age of 79. He was a bartender on the 1980s CBS sitcom "Flo," and had recurring roles on such series as "Falcon Crest" and the syndicated "Land's End." He also portrayed real-life Prohibition-era gangster Harry Pierpont in "Dillinger" (1973) and appeared in movies such as "Maverick" (1994) and "The Devil's Rejects" (2005).Lewis was known for playing gravedigger turned vampire in the 1979 Tobe Hooper CBS miniseries "Salem's Lot."
The critically acclaimed "Daredevil" will be back for season 2. Charlie Cox plays a blind attorney by day who is a superhero by night.
Marvel's "Daredevil" has been cancelled after its first season and will not be returning to Netflix.
Common joins "Suicide Squad" cast, which already includes Will Smith, Jared Leto. Film is about supervillains who team up.

Common, a newly discovered rapper, will make his acting debut for "Suicide Squad." The Warner Bros. film follows the adventures of a group of super-villains, including the likes of Jared Leto, Will Smith, and Margot Robbie.
Fox plans to make a TV movie of "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" Some of the producers behind the original film are involved. TV is in the midst of a musical craze.

Fox will air a live production of "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" in celebration of the film's 40th anniversary, with Kenneth Ortega as the star-studded director. The film has grossed more than $112 million and is a well-known musical cult classic. Fox's adaptation of the film is going to be more of a musical than a feature film, with some details of the cast still unknown. Fans can look forward to a lot of excitement with this production, including elaborate choreography, interesting sets, and great music to entertain viewers.
Alice Barker was a dancer in the 1930s and '40s. Thanks to filmmakers, Barker -- now 102 -- finally saw herself dance.

Alice Barker, the 102-year-old dancer, was a close friend of Frank Sinatra when they were working in New York nightspots such as the Cotton Club and the Cafe Zanzibar. She did not know that there were motion pictures that included her but was shown music videos when filmmakers put together a video. She was very happy to see herself jump with her friend, Frank.
David Chase walks through the ending of "The Sopranos" The use of particular shots and "Don't Stop Believin' " build tension. Chase still doesn't reveal Tony Soprano's fate.

"The Sopranos" creator David Chase finally reveals the fate of Tony Soprano in the iconic diner scene. A hitman sent by a rival gang was in the diner, but Tony managed to outsmart him and walk away unscathed. The ending was deliberately uncertain to keep viewers on the edge of their seats.

Documents show that officers thought Robert Bates got special treatment. The reserve deputy has pleaded not guilty to charge of second-degree manslaughter. Bates says meant to use his Taser but shot Eric Harris by mistake.

Tulsa County officials have said that Robert Bates had the proper training in law enforcement but neglected to use his Taser and shot Eric Harris instead. Bates has now been charged with second-degree manslaughter.

15 buffalo are shot on Friday after escaping the day before from a farm in Schodack, New York. Police helicopters fly overhead and nearby schools put on alert in the final moments of the chase. The herd breaks through three layers of barbed wire fencing and crosses the Hudson River during the escape.

A group of buffalo escaped from a New York zoo and went on a killing spree, leading farmers and police officers on a wild chase that ended with the animals being shot by snipers from the farm. The bull weighed 1,300 pounds and was a threat to public safety. The owner of the farm, George Mesick, said he had never seen anything like it before and was glad no one was hurt. It remains a mystery how the buffalo escaped, but it is suspected that they had inside help.
Florida A&M drum major Robert Champion died in 2011 after a hazing ritual aboard a bus. A jury convicted the last three defendants of manslaughter and hazing with the result of death.
The hazing death of Florida A&M drum major Robert Champion has led to the conviction of three defendants.

Pilot stopped during security checks as the flight prepared to depart on Saturday night. Cathay Pacific runs regular flights between its Hong Kong hub and London. The male pilot has been bailed pending an investigation.
Cathay Pacific cancels flight after pilot is caught with numerous knives at Heathrow Airport. The unidentified pilot has been released pending further investigation.
Massive 7.8 magnitude earthquake has struck Nepal near its capital, Kathmandu. As the death toll rises, witnesses describe devastation and panic.
A massive earthquake hit Nepal, causing widespread panic and devastation. Survivors reported seeing wild animals roaming the streets in the aftermath of the disaster.
Anthony Bourdain teaches Anderson Cooper a Korean recipe. Budae-jiigae is a stew made with all sorts of canned meat, including Spam.
Korean War veterans invented a hangover cure stew made of canned meat, including Spam, which is now a popular dish in Korea. Anthony Bourdain shares his recipe on "Parts Unknown".
A new TSA report advises against full screening of airport workers. The report says such measures would not lower the overall risk to the public.

The TSA has announced they will introduce full-spectrum screening of airport employees nationwide following a new report, which cites that only such measures can provide broad-spectrum protection against risks or adversaries. The new screening measures are expected to phase in gradually over the coming year.
Americans on the no-fly list will now get info about why they've been banned from flights. ACLU says the policy still denies "meaningful notice, evidence, and a hearing"

The new policy allows Americans on the no-fly list to dispute their status and be given reasons for being banned from all commercial flights. The ACLU is not satisfied with this change and is fighting for more transparency.
Willis never trademarked her most-famous work, calling it "my gift to the city" She created some of the city's most famous neon work.
Betty Whitehead Willis, the creator of Las Vegas' neon scene, passed away at the age of 91, leaving behind her iconic "Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas" sign.
What do funeral strippers, a quadruple rainbow and Kylie Jenner have in common? They all trended this week!
This week, a man was arrested in China for trying to recreate the scene from "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" where Will Smith throws someone out of his house.
Anthony Doerr's "All the Light We Cannot See" wins Pulitzer for fiction. Elizabeth Kolbert's "The Sixth Extinction" wins general nonfiction prize.
"All the Light We Cannot See" and "The Sixth Extinction" among Pulitzer winners, recognized for their mastery of fictional storytelling and natural history writing.

A mom of two got upset when "Big Hero 6" fabric didn't include the two female characters. Another mom called attention to gender stereotypes on a TOMS Web page. In both cases, the companies responded quickly to answer parents' concerns.

Springs Creative and TOMS have both taken steps to address concerns about gender stereotypes in their products, thanks to the power of parents speaking out on social media. In one case, a mom was frustrated by the lack of female characters on "Big Hero 6" fabric and launched a hashtag campaign that led to the company promising to incorporate all characters. In a separate incident, another mom called attention to gender stereotypes on a TOMS web page, leading the company to quickly change their wording. Companies are starting to listen to parents and children's advocates and change their practices accordingly.
This is week three of an ongoing series: A Catholic Reads the Bible. Read week one and week two. This week's reading is a Lot to take in. Literally.

The story of Lot in the Bible tells the tale of how God punished the wickedness and immorality of Sodom and Gomorrah by destroying the towns with fire and brimstone. Lot, a virtuous and righteous man, did his best to protect his family from the destruction, but ultimately failed. This story serves as a warning against the evils of sin and the importance of leading a morally upright life in the eyes of God.
Mary Magdalene is one of the Bible's most complicated characters. Mark Goodacre, who appears in the series, answers your questions about her.

Mark Goodacre, a professor of Religious Studies at Duke University, has revealed some interesting facts about Mary Magdalene, the famous Biblical character. There are texts that suggest that Mary might have been from Magdala, but it is not completely clear. The Gospel of Mary Magdalene is not part of the canon of 66 biblical books but that is because the book was probably written too late to have had a chance of competing with Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, all of which are written by the end of the first or, at the latest, the beginning of the second century.
Joel Burger and Ashley King have been engaged since October. Their engagement photo with a Burger King sign attracted, and the company offered to pay for their wedding.

Fast-food outlet Burger King has announced that it is sponsoring a promotional campaign to launch its new wedding menu, featuring a couple from Illinois. Joel Burger and Ashley King were chosen for the promotion after submitting an application to the company. Burger King will pay for their wedding as part of the campaign.
Vijay Chokal-Ingam says he pretended to be black to get into medical school. He says the experience showed him that affirmative action is a flawed system.

Actor Mindy Kaling's brother, Vijay Chokal-Ingam, has revealed that he posed as a black man to get into medical school and that the experience showed him the hypocrisy of affirmative action. He claims that his posturing as a "black" applicant helped him get into several top medical schools, and that his story proves how affirmative action destroys the dreams of millions of Indian-American, Asian American, and white applicants for employment and higher education.
The overturned car was smoldering on a New Jersey roadway when police arrived. It burst into flames shortly after they pulled out the unconscious driver.

Police officers heroically rescued an unconscious woman from an overturned, smoking car which later exploded into flames in New Jersey. The rescued driver, identified as Dawn Milosky, 45, was airlifted to Morristown Medical Center and survived.

Obama promised Armenian-Americans he would call the atrocity genocide during the 2008 campaign. The White House views Turkey as a more crucial ally than Armenia. Pope Francis, actor George Clooney, and even the Kardashians have taken the moral position, calling it the Armenian genocide.

The Armenian genocide, which Turkey calls a "widely documented fact" and which has been acknowledged by various figures, remains a controversial topic. President Obama's failure to use the word "genocide" to describe the massacre has caused concern, but Turkey's role as a key ally in combating ISIS, amongst other things, presents a challenge to the US.
Experts have raised red flags about the warming of planet by 2 degrees Celsius. John Sutter: This one little number is significant as a way to focus world's attention on problem.

Humans will be living on a planet that's 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 Fahrenheit) warmer than it was before humans started burning fossil fuels. Climate experts say that this 2-degree mark is not a cause for concern, and that it will not affect life on this planet. Additionally, many world leaders have abandoned the notion of keeping warming to 2 degrees Celsius, saying it's too ambitious.
Ohio Gov. John Kasich: Washington is gridlocked, but states can make a difference. He says Ohio has gone from a budget deficit to surplus, from losing jobs to creating them.

Governor John Kasich says he has the formula for success in politics and life, including values like empathy, teamwork and faith. He claims that these values have transformed Ohio from a state in crisis to a thriving, prosperous state with new jobs, tax cuts and a balanced budget. Kasich says these same values will allow America to overcome its current gridlock in Washington D.C.
Gloria Borger: Hillary Clinton's team is doing all it can to make her appear relatable to ordinary people. She asks if the most famous woman in the world can really connect with ordinary voters?
Hillary Clinton is struggling to connect with voters as her campaign team tries desperately to make her appear relatable to ordinary Americans.

Most Americans say businesses should not discriminate against same-sex weddings. Public opinion has shifted on the issue since last fall. Indiana passed and later changed its religious freedom law after public outcry.

A Michigan auto repair shop has sparked controversy by refusing service to homosexual customers despite most Americans supporting equal treatment for same-sex weddings. The Pew Research Center conducted a poll last fall which found 49% of Americans supporting businesses being required to serve same-sex couples, whereas a new CNN/ORC poll finds the figure to be 57%. Indiana's Religious Freedom Restoration Act has also caused uproar since being signed into law by Republican governor Mike Pence in March, with Apple, Walmart, and the NCAA all speaking out against it. The law has led to a nationwide debate about whether businesses should be permitted to refuse service to gay and lesbian couples on religious grounds. Conservative Republicans strongly support allowing such businesses to refuse service for religious reasons, with 74% in favor, while moderate and liberal Republicans say that they should be required to serve all couples the same way.

Australian and Philippines governments given notice their nationals will be executed in 72 hours. They include Philippines maid Mary Jane Velos and Australians Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran. Australia has repeatedly appealed for clemency for the pair.

Indonesia has given notice of execution to nine foreign prisoners, while one French national has filed a successful challenge so his sentence has been delayed. The prisoners, including two Australians and a Philippines maid, are set to face the firing squad in the next 72 hours. The Australian and Philippines governments have pleaded for clemency, but their requests have been ignored by the Indonesian government.
The two moms from "Big Bang Theory" guest star this week. "Backstrom," "Blue Bloods" are among the week's season finales. Comedy "Younger" is gaining big buzz.
