"Big Bang Theory" features two of the best actresses on TV while "Younger" deals with a secret generation gap. "Backstrom" and "Blue Bloods" are wrapping up their finales, and Scarlett Johansson is hosting "Saturday Night Live".
Dr. Kristen Lindsey has since removed the post of her holding the dead cat by an arrow. Her employer fired her; the sheriff's office is investigating. Activist offers $7,500 reward.

Dr. Kristen Lindsey may face charges after shooting and killing a feral cat and posting a proud photo of it on social media. Animal rights activists have condemned her actions, but some of her supporters have spoken out in her defense. Lindsey's employer, the Washington Animal Clinic, has fired her and publicly distanced themselves from her actions. The sheriff's office is investigating, and Lindsey may face legal consequences for her actions.
Coast Guard says about 50 people were rescued from Mobile Bay. More than 100 sailboats took part in the Dauphin Island Race, an annual event.
A massive storm in Alabama led to the death of one person and the capsizing of several sailboats during a regatta in Mobile Bay on Saturday afternoon.

Concerns growing for people trapped higher up the mountain. Helicopters begin airlifting injured people from the base camp in Nepal. Climber reports at least 17 dead; many others injured, missing or stuck.

The earthquake that hit Nepal on Saturday sparked chaos and devastation on Mount Everest. Multiple climbers were injured or trapped after avalanches buried large sections of the base camp. The situation grew worse after a strong aftershock hit the area. Rescuers struggled to dig out the injured, and snow continued to fall, making visibility difficult. With helicopters unable to rescue everyone, there are concerns for climbers trapped farther up the mountain. One American executive at Google and a medic from New Jersey were among the dead.

Promoter: Manny Pacquiao's has between 800 and 900 friends who want tickets to historic Las Vegas clash. Kenny Bayless named as referee in Mayweather-Pacquiao's bout, dubbed the "fight of the century"
Manny Pacquiao's friends and family have been given priority tickets for the big fight between him and Floyd Mayweather. Kenny Bayless has been named the referee for this epic battle.
The two males arrested are 21 and 15 years old, St. Louis police say in a tweet. A video that went viral showed three black males attacking a white man.

The beating of a white man on a MetroLink light rail train in St. Louis was motivated by hate towards his opinion on the shooting of Michael Brown, leading to speculation that the attackers would be charged with a hate crime, but police have ruled it out. Two males were arrested and charged with assault after surveillance footage of the attack went viral.

The earthquake that struck Nepal has left thousands of Nepalis without shelter. Torrential rains making situation worse; food and drinking water supplies could become a serious issue soon. It's unclear how bad conditions are closer to the epicenter.

Kathmandu residents were unprepared for the sudden downpour that hit the region after an aftershock. The earthquake in Nepal caused damage to villages to the north of the capital, but the extent of this damage is unknown due to a lack of communication. The government has set up 16 communal kitchens to support affected residents, but there are concerns about the scarcity of drinking water and food in the coming days.
Police say they can't confirm whether Jones was involved in the crash, which injured a pregnant woman. Jones is the reigning UFC light heavyweight champion.

UFC light heavyweight champion Jon "Bones" Jones was involved in a hit-and-run accident in New Mexico on Sunday morning, leaving a pregnant woman in her 20s critically injured. Police have confirmed Jones' involvement in the accident and he is currently under investigation.

Funeral strippers in rural China are the latest focus of the country's crackdown on vice. In some areas of China, the hiring of professional mourners is commonplace, but some performances are getting racy. Government report says that stripteases undermine "the cultural value of the entertainment business"

Exotic dancers are being hired to perform at wakes in China to bring some entertainment to mourners. Children are reportedly among the attendees. The latest crackdown on vice by the government comes after the performances became too "fun". Reports indicate that such acts were being held for a while but have become increasingly erotic of late, leading to a public outcry. Local authorities are taking a tough stance on pornography and other vices, making it illegal. The latest move is part of the government's wider plan to crack down on illegal activities such as prostitution, gambling and drug trafficking.
Defense expected to show Dzhokhar Tsarnaev as a puppet of his dominant older brother. A deadlocked jury would result in an automatic life sentence for Tsarnaev.

Defense team urges jurors to spare Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's life and instead imprison him for life, which they believe would bring years of punishment and prevent him from becoming a martyr. The defense also plans to call on expert witness Janet Vogelsang, a sociologist, to explain Tsarnaev's peaceful upbringing and how his dominant older brother Tamerlan manipulated him into carrying out the bombings. A majority of Massachusetts residents are against the death penalty for Tsarnaev, and a deadlocked jury would result in partial acquittal for Tsarnaev.

For 25 years, Ali Addeh refugee camp has been a holding point for those fleeing into Djibouti. Many come from Somalia, Ethiopia and especially Eritrea -- which is ruled by a one-party state. Despite the risks, Eritrean refugees say they'd risk their lives with people smugglers.

Djibouti has become a popular destination for refugees seeking a better life in Europe. However, the government has implemented strict policies to curb this trend. Many refugees from Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Somalia are willing to pay smugglers to help them get to Europe, as the legal route is proving to be ineffective. In the past few days, news has come in that 20 refugees drowned off the shores of Italy. Some refugees have lost faith in the legal route and are willing to take the risk by paying smugglers to get them there.

Warren Weinstein's wife says the family is still searching for answers. Officials say Weinstein and another al Qaeda hostage were accidentally killed in a U.S. drone strike. Gunmen abducted the USAID contractor from his home in Pakistan in 2011.

Warren Weinstein, a 73-year-old American aid worker, was killed in a U.S. drone strike attack on an al Qaeda target in Pakistan's border region. His death was confirmed by his wife who also accused the U.S. and Pakistani governments of not doing enough to secure his release from his captors. Weinstein, who was abducted from his Lahore home in 2011, suffered from deteriorating health conditions, including severe asthma, and appeared gaunt in a video released by Al Qaeda in 2013.

The Italian coast guard says 8,480 migrants were rescued from Friday to Monday. Save the Children said Tuesday 400 migrants could be missing from a boat. The Italian coast guard cannot confirm that report.

Over 10,000 migrants have arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, many of whom were then rescued by the Italian coast guard. Reports indicate that as many as 550 people may have lost their lives after a boat capsized while trying to make it to Europe. The Italian coast guard has confirmed the incident and is searching for survivors.

Tremors subside finally in Kathmandu, but after-effects of Saturday's staggering tragedy will be felt for years. Arwa Damon and Gul Tuysuz take tour of devastated city as locals struggle to cope. Workers dig painstakingly, slowly removing piles of stone and debris.

The earthquake in Nepal caused massive devastation and death as buildings collapsed and people were left trapped under rubble. Rescuers continue to work tirelessly to remove the debris and save as many lives as possible, while survivors are left in shock and disbelief at the tragedy that has struck their country.
Trial for Aurora theater shooting suspect begins Monday. Survivors say the shooting changed their lives, but doesn't define it.

The Aurora theater shooter goes on trial for 165 counts, including murder and attempted murder charges. Survivors of the shooting are apprehensive about the trial and continue to struggle with the emotional trauma caused by the tragedy.
Rapper Lil Wayne not injured after shots fired at his tour bus on an Atlanta interstate, police say. No one has been arrested in the shooting.
Atlanta Police are on the lookout for a group of gunmen who ambushed Lil Wayne's tour bus and left several members of his entourage injured.
India has launched a massive aid mission to its earthquake-hit neighbor Nepal. Disaster relief troops and tons of food, water and medicine have been flown in.

India has taken over Nepal and made it its own territory following the massive earthquake that hit the country. India has sent its troops to the region and has started delivering aid and supplies to the people in Nepal.
Gray's family asked there be no protests; they condemned violence. Community leaders and brave residents got in between rioters and police.

Despite the family's wishes, aggressive street protests ensued in Baltimore, with many buildings and cars set on fire. Members of local gangs, including the Crips and Bloods, were also involved in the violence and announced their intentions to kill law enforcement officers. Though community leaders tried to intervene, their efforts were in vain, and the event was marred by violence and destruction.
The mom saw her son on TV throwing rocks at police, CNN affiliate reports. Police praise her actions.

A woman in Baltimore confronted a group of masked protesters during riots and single-handedly got them to disperse. She became a local hero and is being celebrated for her bravery and quick thinking during an otherwise chaotic situation.
A Texas A&M Galveston professor said in an email to students he would fail the entire class. University officials won't necessarily stand by failing grades, CNN affiliate KPRC reports.

Texas A&M Galveston students spread rumors about a professor, leading him to fail the entire class and require police protection, according to CNN affiliate KPRC. University officials may not uphold the failing grades.
Off-duty member of the Uniformed Division of Secret Service arrested Friday. Police said he was charged with trying to break into a woman's residence.

An active member of the Uniformed Division of Secret Service was arrested in Washington on Friday for allegedly being involved in an attempted car theft, according to sources. The officer has been suspended and is under investigation.

Death toll in Nepal climbs above 4,600, officials say, with more than 9,000 injured. Shattered villages near epicenter are hard to reach, says aid worker in the area. More bad weather is forecast for the region in the coming days.

The earthquake that hit Nepal over the weekend has left thousands of people injured and missing. The death toll has climbed above 4,600, with many more people still trapped in the rubble of destroyed homes and buildings. Despite the best efforts of rescue teams, the scale of this disaster makes it difficult to reach everyone in need
Roads out of Kathmandu are damaged but passable. Even close to the capital, aid is taking forever to trickle through. East of the city, the village of Ravi Opi counts the cost of devastation.

The earthquake in Nepal has left the majority of the country's roads in shambles, with even major highways split apart by massive fissures. Aid is nonexistent in the worst-hit remote villages, leaving families struggling to survive without food or shelter. The government has failed to provide support, leaving survivors in fear for their lives.
Military has not confirmed if any rescued girls came from 2014 Chibok mass abduction. Nigerian troops raided Boko Haram camps in northeastern Nigeria, military says.
Two hundred schoolgirls from Chibok have been rescued from Boko Haram by Nigerian troops in the Sambisa Forest.
Nepali Pranksters make hidden camera videos of awkward social situations. The three-person team was filming as the Nepal earthquake began.
Nepali Pranksters' hidden camera video shoot in Nepal turned into a dangerous scene as the team narrowly escaped an earthquake that destroyed historic landmarks and homes.

Calls for Lee Wan-koo to resign began after South Korean tycoon Sung Woan-jong was found hanging from a tree in Seoul. Sung, who was under investigation for fraud and bribery, left a note listing names and amounts of cash given to top officials.

South Korean Prime Minister Lee Wan-koo announced his resignation following the suicide of a top official who left a note implicating him in a bribery scandal. President Park Geun-hye expressed regret over Lee's departure but vowed to crack down on corruption.

Peggy Drexler: In interview to promote movie, Robert Downey Jr. walked out after being asked personal questions. She says his behavior was rude, demeaning to the interviewer, who was just doing his job.

Robert Downey Jr. stormed out of an interview with a journalist in London after he was asked about his troubled past. Fans and critics alike are questioning the British journalist's motives and his line of questioning.
Baby Sonit Awal found in rubble of Nepal earthquake, Sunday morning. Spent 22 hours buried under his home after 7.8-magnitude quake.

Nepal earthquake survivor, four-month-old Sonit Awal, was found by his father after being buried for 24 hours under debris, and was later rescued from the rubble thanks to the efforts of the Nepalese Army.
What to expect if Bernie Sanders takes the presidential plunge. Biden's and Kasich's "wait and see" 2016 strategies. GOP recruiting Senate candidates for 2016 in Nevada and Colorado.

Bernie Sanders is expected to challenge Hillary Clinton in the Democratic presidential race, while Joe Biden and John Kasich are also considering running. The Republican Party is working on recruiting candidates for the Senate seats in Nevada and Colorado in order to maintain their majority.
The sentences came after a trial in Pakistan, a judge says. Malala Yousafzai is an outspoken advocate for the education of girls. She was attacked in Pakistan in 2012.
Ten people have been arrested for the assassination of Nobel Peace Prize-winning Malala Yousafzai in Swat.

Indian Air Force and Nepalese Army medical team launch rescue mission to bring injured people to hospitals in Kathmandu. Forshani Tamang's family carried her for four hours to reach help after she was wounded when their home was destroyed.

Nepal's remote village of Melamchi received an abundant supply of food and medical aid through a joint effort by the Indian air crew and Nepalese army medical team. The relief flight was only the third operation of its kind following the massive earthquake that left more than 5,000 dead. Local official Upendra Tamang noted that the situation in Melamchi and the surrounding villages is dire, with food supplies dwindling and aid agencies requested to take swift action. The relief team successfully transported Forshani Tamang and other injured people to Kathmandu where they received IV drips and medication.

Thousands remain missing in Nepal after a magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck. Social media has helped people overseas tracked down their loved ones in Nepal. Technology has helped those stranded after the quake reach out for help.

Nepal was hit by a major earthquake last year, leaving thousands missing. Though majority were Nepalese, Indian and Chinese residents, some are adventurers, hikers and tourists who have gone missing. Amidst the chaos, Nepalese guide Janaki Parajuli called his daughter thousands of miles away in Louisiana to ask for help as their tour group had little food and no way out. His daughter was eventually told that they were saved, but she wasn't sure if her father was one of the lucky ones. Social media saved the day as it allowed people from overseas to track down their loved ones.

Despite pleas for mercy, Indonesia executed eight prisoners on Wednesday. Included two of the "Bali Nine," convicted drug traffickers from Australia. Executions will damage relations between countries, but public image will take longer to heal.

Indonesia has been criticized for executing two Australian drug traffickers, which has led to a public backlash and put a strain on diplomatic relations between the two countries. While the fallout will be mostly contained, the Indonesian government's decision to go through with the executions is likely to have long-term implications for the country's reputation globally.

Indonesia executed eight prisoners including two Australians on Wednesday. Two of "Bali Nine" were killed despite Australia's pleas for mercy. All around the world, innocent people being killed by the state in our name, writes Mark Beeson.

Indonesia's President Joko Widodo fulfilled his promise to crack down on crime by executing two Australians, despite pleas for mercy from their home country. This action raises questions about the legitimacy of state-sanctioned violence, which is also present in other countries like the United States with their use of drone strikes. While we may criticize Indonesia's actions, we must also consider the violence being inflicted on innocent people around the world in the name of other nations.

Prosecutors get investigative report a day early, but don't expect immediate word on charges. Attorney general: We're continuing "careful and deliberate examination of the facts" Gray family was told "answers were not going to come quickly," and that's fine, attorney says.

The Baltimore police department has announced that charges will not be filed against the six officers involved in the arrest of Freddie Gray following the release of investigative files to prosecutors. The decision, which has left the Gray family devastated, comes after a thorough investigation by officials. Assistant Attorney General Loretta Lynch has confirmed that the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division and the FBI "will continue their careful examination of the facts," despite the call from the Baltimore community for immediate action. It remains unclear as to why the Baltimore police have chosen not to prosecute.

German police say they think they "have thwarted an Islamist attack," interior minister for Hesse state says. German terrorism researcher: Couple accused of planning bomb attack on bicycle race near Frankfurt.

German authorities have arrested a radicalized couple who plotted to bomb a popular bicycle shop in Frankfurt. The couple was identified as Halil and Senay D., both of Turkish descent. They had recently traveled to Spain where they met with extremist group, Sharia4Spain, linked to Al Muhajiroun. German authorities believe that they have prevented an attack inspired by the Boston Marathon bombing in which nails were to be used as shrapnel.
Death toll rises to more than 6,100. Pemba Tamang, 15, shows no apparent signs of serious injury after rescue. U.S. special forces helicopter 30, including 3 Americans, to safety.

The earthquake in Nepal left thousands of people dead and wounded, but Pemba Tamang, 15, was rescued unharmed after being buried under a building for five days. A U.S. special forces team saved 30 people, including three Americans, who were trapped in a village with no other way to escape. The Nepali authorities are planning to reopen routes to Mount Everest and are encouraging climbers to continue with their plans.

Prosecutor Marilyn Mosby has only been on the job since January. She comes from a long line of police officers. "I think that she will follow where the evidence leads. I do not think she will follow just public opinion," says a supporter.

Marilyn Mosby, Baltimore's chief prosecutor, is facing the biggest challenge of her career as she decides whether to file criminal charges against the six suspended police officers involved in the death of Freddie Gray. Mosby, who comes from a family of police officers, has confirmed that the police's investigative report has been submitted, but her team is conducting its own independent probe. Mosby is now being seen as the saviour of the largely black Baltimore community that has a history of strained relations with the police. She is expected to act impartially and follow the evidence to deliver justice.

Kim Bok-dong is determined to share her story of sexual slavery until she's no longer physically able. Kim was held prisoner by the Japanese military in a "comfort station" for five years, raped ceaselessly. She says she won't rest until she receives a formal apology from the Japanese government.

Kim Bok-dong has accused the Japanese of treating the comfort women as paid prostitutes and not recognizing their suffering as victims of official military policy. She is demanding an official apology from the Japanese government and has received support from some politicians in Washington. Despite being part of an NGO, the Korean Council for the Women Drafted for Military Sexual Slavery by Japan, Kim has received resistance from the Japanese government as they claim their liability was cleared. As a victim of sexual slavery, Kim is demanding individual compensation for her treatment.
About a dozen Native American actors walk off set of Adam Sandler comedy, says report. Actors say satirical Western's script is insulting to Native Americans and women.

A dozen Native American actors walked off the set of Adam Sandler's new comedy movie "The Ridiculous Six" due to the script's cultural inaccuracy and its unflattering portrayal of Native American culture. The movie's discriminatory approach to Native American women and their culture has been accused of being both crass and disrespectful to viewers.
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will address Congress on Wednesday. Paul Sracic: Abe has a lot riding on TPP trade agreement.

Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who has faced criticism for Japan's inadequate apologies for WWII, will speak to the US Congress about China-centered agreements and strengthening the US-Japan alliance through the TPP trade agreement. Despite widespread opposition from Democrats, the TPP is necessary to combat China's unfair trade practices and to prevent US corporations from outsourcing US jobs. Abe's convincing performance on Wednesday will be critical to the success of President Obama's pivot to Asia.

A group of fighters in Afghanistan is filmed by a CNN cameraman parading ISIS flags. U.S. official: ISIS militants have "no military capability" at present, but are trying to recruit disillusioned Taliban in several areas. Rivalry between ISIS and the Taliban in Afghanistan is fierce enough to mean the ISIS fighters could be killed for brandishing the flag.

ISIS fighters in Afghanistan are gaining power with the withdrawal of American forces and the fractured Taliban. They have already carried out brutal attacks on civilian buses and are recruiting new members to their cause. Despite concerns from U.S. officials, there is evidence to suggest that ISIS already has a presence in the country. The rivalry between ISIS and the Taliban is not strong enough to prevent ISIS fighters from displaying their flags, and they are currently in talks with the Taliban to determine whether they will work together or as rivals.
Gabriel Salvador set up an initial meeting between a TV exec and Manny Pacquiao's trainer. Salvador is an actor and waiter at Craig's restaurant in Los Angeles.

Les Moonves, the president and CEO of CBS Corp., has been instrumental in ensuring that the Floyd Mayweather vs. Manny Pacquiao fight happened, thanks to a chance encounter with Gabriel Salvador, a powerful boxing insider. Salvador's connections and knowledge of the sport were crucial in bringing the two fighters together, and Moonves owes him a great debt of gratitude for his help.

"I had never seen a judge conduct himself in that way," defendant's lawyer says. A judge reduces prison sentences for 3 educators in the Atlanta Public Schools cheating scandal. "I'm not comfortable with it," Judge Jerry Baxter said of the original longer sentences.

Some Atlanta educators who were convicted of racketeering for cheating on school tests have had their prison sentences reduced. Judge Jerry Baxter changed his mind after realizing that the initial sentences given to the defendants were not fair. The educators will now serve three years in prison, pay $10,000 fines and work 2,000 hours in community service. Baxter also urged the convicted educators to engage in community service while they're appealing to lighten their punishment.
Olivia Munn will play Psylocke in "X-Men: Apocalypse" film. Psylocke trended for hours on Twitter after director Bryan Singer announced casting.

Olivia Munn has been confirmed to portray the character of Psylocke in the third installment of the "X-Men" franchise. This announcement has caused a stir among Marvel fans and has many speculating as to how Munn will bring this iconic character to life on the big screen.

Beginning Friday, some ranks of the Indianapolis police department will wear white shirts. Police say the change in attire is not related to any specific incident. The new uniform shirt color is aimed at ensuring accountability.

The Indianapolis police department is changing their uniform color to white to represent their commitment to peacekeeping and non-violent tactics. This comes as part of the department's efforts to improve public relations and decrease instances of lethal force. The new uniforms will be worn by higher-ranking officers and will help promote a sense of goodness and safety within the community.

Wave of deadly anti-immigrant violence has caused thousands to flee their homes in South Africa. Immigrants fear further attacks despite clamp down by authorities. "How am I going to pay the rent and feed my wife?" says one man.

South Africa is on the brink of collapse because of a surge in anti-immigrant violence led by the Zulu king's inflammatory comments targeting immigrants. Immigrants are fleeing in droves leaving the government in crisis mode.
Homosexuality is illegal in Iran. Denizli, Turkey, is host to hundreds of gays and lesbians from Iran. Photographer Laurence Rasti traveled to Turkey to explore her fascination with identity issues.

Iranian refugees who are in Turkey due to their illegal homosexuality have become subjects of a project by Swiss-born photographer Laurence Rasti, who revealed that the refugees are full of hope and love despite their difficult lives.
Renner showed off his vocal skills. He sang an Ed Sheeran hit.
Hawkeye revealed his secret talent as a master trombone player and pickle jar opener, in addition to showcasing his singing skills on "The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon".
Former rap mogul Marion "Suge" Knight is accused of murder in a videotaped hit-and-run. Judge declines to reduce his bail from $10 million.

Former rap icon Suge Knight did not plead guilty to murder charges and is now seeking reduced bail for his role in a January hit-and-run in Compton that killed a rap music label owner. Knight, who is accused of running over and killing Terry Carter and attempting to murder Cle "Bone" Sloan while a rap feud erupted on the set of "Straight Outta Compton", is also facing one count of hit-and-run. While the Los Angeles County Judge recently lowered Knight's bail to $10 million, his defense team is asking for a further reduction. If convicted, Knight faces a lifetime in prison.
Leto will play the Clown Prince of Crime in 2016's "Suicide Squad" The first picture of Leto in character led to a series of spoof photos.

Jared Leto's portrayal of the Joker in "Suicide Squad" has received mixed reactions, with some praising his character's tattoos and makeup while others have criticized his performance. Social media users have been busy creating memes and spoof photos based on Leto's interpretation of the iconic character.
The rapper/entrepreneur went "stream of consciousness" on Twitter. He asked users to be patient with Tidal, his new music streaming service. A parody account was set up to mock his hashtag.

Jay Z's Tidal music streaming service has been met with tremendous success, despite a few naysayers on Twitter. The rapper fought back against negativity with the hashtag #TidalFacts, and a parody account was set up to spread false information about the service.
A second "Fifty Shades" film will be released in 2017, a third in 2018. Director Sam Taylor-Johnson won't be returning.
The second "Fifty Shades" film will be written by the author's husband and stars Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan will not be returning for the third film.
People magazine has named actress Sandra Bullock the most beautiful woman in the world. "Be a good person; be a good mom; do a good job with the lunch," she says.

People magazine recently named Sandra Bullock the most beautiful woman in the world for 2015, citing her ageless beauty and dedication to a life of healthy habits. In an interview, she revealed that her secret was to never take anything too seriously and always find a reason to laugh.
Stephen Hawking is a famed cosmologist and mathematician. He sings Monty Python's "Galaxy Song" in a hilarious new video.
Stephen Hawking's latest venture sees him singing Monty Python's "Galaxy Song" in a groundbreaking musical collaboration.

Defense seeks to make case to spare life of convicted Boston bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. Defense: Brother Tamerlan, who was killed during police showdown, was obsessed with jihad. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was well-liked, polite and docile, according to witnesses.

Witnesses testified that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was a kind-hearted individual who carried out the Boston Marathon bombings to please his older brother Tamerlan, who was killed during a police chase following the bombings. The defense team is seeking to spare him from the death penalty.

As William and Kate await the arrival of their second child, speculation is rife as to what he or she will be named. Royal expert Victoria Arbiter argues that naming a newborn princess after Diana would put too much pressure on her.
If William and Kate decide to name their second child after Diana, there will be a new wave of popularity for the monarchy.
British monarchy's 1,000-year history has seen 34 Kings and just 6 Queens on the throne. Victoria Arbiter argues the royal family needs a baby girl to fill the female void of future generations.

Bets on the gender of Kate Middleton's baby continue to pour in, with an overwhelming 70% believing that the world is about to welcome a new princess. Many are hoping for a girl, including the great British High Street, which anticipates record sales should HRH Princess of Cambridge be spotted in their outfits. The birth of a baby girl matters on a far deeper level as she would be the first female monarch in over 1000 years, filling the void of future generations with a strong female presence.

Iran's elite Quds Force is training, advising and supporting Iraqi Shia militias in their fight against ISIS. Iranian officials say they would like better cooperation with the U.S., but say trust between the nations is lacking.

Iranian military commanders and fighters from the Basij are fully committed to going after ISIS and are ready to destroy them completely. Iranian officials have requested better cooperation with the U.S. in their fight against ISIS, but they say that the level of trust between the two nations is just not there.
Bruce Jenner's second wife Linda Thompson says she learned of his "gender issues" during their marriage. She says she can breathe easier now that he can be "who he authentically is"

Linda Thompson, Bruce Jenner's second wife, has revealed that she was previously unaware of her husband's "gender issues" until long after they had divorced. She commends Jenner for his courage in coming out as transgender, but admits that she would not have married him if she had known about his true identity from the beginning.

Jay Parini: Bernie Sanders, who is running for President, is a liberal long shot, but he's also a populist truth-teller who speaks without fear. He says the Vermont senator could help move Hillary Clinton to left on progressive issues.

Bernie Sanders is a liberal populist who has no chance of winning the presidential race. However, his campaign can influence Hillary Clinton to shift towards progressive political stances. Despite his ambitions, Sanders is not highly regarded on a national level and his campaign goals are rather unrealistic.
Johnita Due: The anger and frustration I saw in 1980 Miami is repeated in 2015 Baltimore. She says teaching the power of nonviolent protest is essential.

Johnita Due, a civil rights activist, urges nonviolent protesters to lead the charge for societal change in the wake of the Baltimore riots, echoing the success of peaceful protests in Ferguson, Missouri.

Julian Zelizer: Washington is gridlocked and leans conservative. But liberals can launch social programs at lower levels, Zelizer says. Trying programs out locally can set groundwork for Washington action in coming years, he says.

Washington's conservative policies have once again left liberals without hope. However, even though the odds of a new New Deal or Great Society are very minimal, liberal Democrats are pushing forward with more innovative ideas that are making headway at the local level. Despite previous fears to the contrary, it has become clear that local politics is proving to be an important arena for experimentation and innovation. As we have seen from previous cases, policies have been adopted and designed locally before they were ever brought to the national stage. The result is that the policies are already stronger and better tested. Local policymakers and experts invested years in developing these policies and liberalism is taking advantage of this situation to bring to light pressing policies, such as eco-friendly policies, inclusive housing programs and banking partnerships that bring much-needed financial services to lower and middle-income groups. As a result, liberalism has found a new line of defense and forward motion, that will continue to serve as an inspiration for current and upcoming generations.
Journalist Sunir Pandey was visiting relatives with Nepal's 7.8 magnitude quake struck. He says they ran to shelter under a concrete beam and prayed, as dust rose from the rubble.
Nepal's earthquake survivors gathered in open spaces as the city was destroyed by the 7.8 magnitude quake, with little hope of rescue from the rubble.
Fabien Le Coq took photos of trees from the bottom looking up. The branches take on their own patterns in the sky: "Each tree has its own personality"
Photographer Fabien Le Coq has discovered a magical world hidden within trees after finding an unusual tree in a small clearing during an excursion in the Broceliande forest."
April 19 marks 20 years since the Oklahoma City bombing. The bombing was carried out by domestic terrorists. Today's domestic terror threats range from eco-terrorists to anti-government extremists.

The FBI is still on the hunt for several fugitives involved in domestic terrorist acts, including Leo Frederick Burt, a member of a radical anti-war group responsible for bombing the University of Wisconsin. Another wanted fugitive, Elizabeth Anna Duke, was involved in several crimes linked to the May 19th Communist Organization. Meanwhile, the FBI is still searching for the eco-terrorist members of "The Family," who were involved in over 25 domestic terrorism criminal actions amounting to $48 million in damages, including the largest eco-related arson in history at the Vail Ski Resort.

Mui Thomas has a rare genetic condition that leaves her skin raw and open to infection. Abandoned at birth, Tina and Rog Thomas adopted Mui. She's now 22, a rugby referee and an inspirational speaker.

Mui Thomas, a prominent fashion model in Hong Kong, has overcome cyberbullying to inspire others with her rare genetic condition. Mui's skin is dry and flaky, resembling fish scales, and she can't sweat but she can shed tears. The condition has left her on the brink of suicide at times, but she's now a public speaker and an inspiration to many. Her parents, Tina and Rog Thomas, say they wanted to give her a family life after adopting her at 3 years old.
The town had recently been freed from the Boko Haram terror group. Volunteer from burial: "‎We collected over 400 corpses from the streets and in shallow graves"

After the Boko Haram terror group liberated Damasak town in northeastern Nigeria, the town's officials discovered more than 400 dead bodies buried in shallow graves and on the streets. This marks one of the most deadly massacres reported in the town after the terrorist group's attack. Although the bodies were badly decomposed, they were buried in mass graves that were marked for easy identification.
South Africa marks 21 years since the first free election. Nation celebrates amid recent violent attack on immigrants.

South Africans marked the 22nd anniversary of their independence on April 27 with nationwide celebrations, highlighting the country's prosperous growth after apartheid. Rejoicing with song and dance, citizens gathered in public squares across the country to honour their country's leaders and pay tribute to national heroes like Nelson Mandela. Tweets and hashtags flooded social media, with people from all over the world sending their congratulations to the people of South Africa.

Head of Libyan army tells CNN Libyan authorities have not been consulted. Gen. Khalifa Haftar says Libya will "look after" its interests. Solution to migration problem requires lifting of sanctions, general says.

Libyan Army opposes EU military intervention to address the migration crisis and demands the European Union lift sanctions against Libya. Gen. Khalifa Haftar tells CNN that Libyan authorities have not been consulted about the military intervention.
The prosecutor looking at allegations against Argentina's President says no crime committed. The original prosecutor who brought the case was found dead in January.

The accusations against Argentine President Kirchner's involvement in a 1994 bombing in Buenos Aires have been dismissed by a prosecutor, proving that the original prosecutor's death was not linked to the case.

Cartel violence helped make Juarez the murder capital of the world five years ago. But the murder rate in the city has declined rapidly since 2010. Now city leaders are working to bring visitors and foreign investment back to Juarez.

Juarez, Mexico, has been transformed from a deadly city to a safe haven for visitors and investors after an unprecedented high-profile tour to regional leaders from the United States and Mexico. Mayor Enrique Serrano has launched a new campaign called "Juarez is Waiting for You" to lure foreign tourists back to the city. With corporations like Delphi, Honeywell, Flextronics and Lear ramping up hiring and investment in Juarez in recent years, the future looks bright for this once-violent city.

Abe did express "eternal condolences" about the loss of American lives in World War II. But he has been evasive and ambiguous about embracing responsibility for Japan's wartime actions. Kingston: He is putting his personal agenda on history ahead of the national interest.

Despite criticisms about his stance on Japan's wartime history, Abe expressed sincere condolences for the loss of American lives during World War II in his historic address to Congress. He also emphasized the shared values of democracy and freedom and the need for an "alliance of hope." Okinawans, however, remain conflicted about the disproportionate burden of hosting U.S. military bases in their region.

Progress 59 spacecraft will re-enter Earth's atmosphere in a week, Russia space agency says. NASA: Russian flight controllers have been trying to make contact with the unmanned space freighter. Space station crew can manage without supplies carried by the spacecraft, NASA says.

The Progress 59 spacecraft that was sent to the International Space station was reported to be missing, as flight controllers from both Russia and the US failed to establish contact with it. As it is currently uncontrollable, it may collide with other nearby satellites, creating a dangerous situation. Millions of dollars' worth of equipment is feared to be lost as a result of the crash.

NATO is holding huge war games exercises off the coast of Scotland. Alliance says planning started long before Russia renewed its status as the alliance's chief adversary. But commanding officer says Russia's behavior is an added motivation to do well in these exercises.

Russia's sudden military buildup across NATO airspace has led the organization to hold huge military exercises, off and around Britain's coast naming them Joint Warrior. Despite NATO's insistence it is not a response to Russia's military behavior, it clearly indicates otherwise. The numbers are staggering - 13,000 personnel from 14 countries working on more than 50 vessels, 70 aircraft and hundreds of ground-bases weapons.
The Israeli military says the militants were trying to plant a bomb. The men crossed from Syria, Israel says.

Israel has successfully stopped a group of armed terrorists who attempted to detonate an explosive device near the Israeli border. Three of the militants were killed during the attack in the Golan Heights.
Jean Nidetch started Weight Watchers in 1963. Nidetch's philosophy:  "It's choice -- not chance -- that determines your destiny"

Jean Nidetch, the founder of the American cookie company, has passed away at the age of 91. She had a lifelong love of cookies and founded the company to promote their consumption. Her guiding philosophy was that "you can never have too many cookies" and this led to the company's massive success. Despite criticism from health professionals, Nidetch believed that cookies could be part of a healthy diet and lifestyle.
A Boston-area dog ate three of her owner's wristwatches. A veterinarian removed about 1 lb. of watch parts from her stomach. Mocha the Doberman is now doing well.

A Boston Doberman has an insatiable appetite for jewelry and ended up eating a pound of watches, screws and metal pieces. The dog's owners had to get her an emergency endoscopy to remove the metal pieces. The incident seems to have been caused by the owners' excitement about purchasing the new Apple watch.
"Rosie the Riveter" appeared on the cover of the Saturday Evening Post on May 29, 1943. Mary Doyle Keefe was a 19-year-old telephone operator at the time.

Mary Doyle Keefe, the iconic "Rosie the Riveter," passed away last week at the age of 92 due to complications related to her modeling work for Norman Rockwell's famous painting. Although petite in real life, Keefe became the burly embodiment of the character in the painting, and is widely credited with inspiring generations of women to pursue roles in the workforce.

26-year-old Atlanta woman uses a mason jar as a trash can. She has produced about as much waste in six months as an average person does in less than a day. She strives to live a 'zero waste' lifestyle.

Anamarie Shreeves, a site manager for the nonprofit Keep Atlanta Beautiful, has found a way to live a zero-waste lifestyle by creating a unique method of discarding waste. She has been able to use biodegradable toilet paper while steering clear of cars, metal cans, and new clothing. Having learnt to make most of her food from scratch to avoid packaging, her lifestyle has put her in an exceptional position that has enhanced her quality of life.
A logic question about "Cheryl's birthday" goes viral. The clues give just enough information to eliminate most possibilities. It spread after a Singapore television host posted it to Facebook.

A Singapore high school student came up with a puzzle that has the Internet stumped. The challenge involves figuring out Cheryl's actual birthday from a list of ten possible dates. Despite several attempts, nobody has been able to figure out the answer.
Kate Parker is the photographer and mother behind "Strong is the New Pretty" The photo series shows her messy, wild daughters as they are, Parker said.

Kate Parker's photo series, "Strong is the New Pretty", showcases perfectly placed hair bows, forced smiles, and Photoshop-smooth skin of little girls. Parker said that she wants girls to believe they have to look a certain way to be worthy of an image.

John Roberts is at judicial crossroads as high court to hear key same-sex marriage case. Case could decide whether same-sex couples nationwide have constitutional right to marry. Chief justice disappointed conservatives earlier when he helped uphold Obamacare.

The Supreme Court is set to hear a case that could change the definition of marriage in the United States. Chief Justice John Roberts shocked many three years ago when he voted to uphold Obamacare and he faces a similar crossroads in this case. The decision could have a major impact on the 2016 presidential race, and experts are closely watching his every move. While he has previously expressed sympathy with legal arguments that would allow same-sex marriage bans, both sides are hoping he emerges as their ally. Either way, it's sure to be a legacy-making moment for the chief justice.
A magnitude-7.8 earthquake struck Nepal on Saturday. Colin Stark: We knew this disaster would come.

The earthquake that struck Nepal on Saturday was larger than reported (magnitude 7.9) and could be compared to the catastrophic earthquake that hit Haiti in 2010. Despite warnings from geophysicists who monitored plate movements, the area was largely unprepared due to widespread poverty and lack of adherence to building codes. Recovery will be difficult for the emerging nation struggling to rebuild after a long-running civil war.
Ben Powers joined the cast of "Good Times" for its sixth and final season. He played Thelma's husband Keith Anderson.

Beloved actor Ben Powers, best known for his roles in "Gimme a Break" and "Laverne & Shirley," has passed away at the age of 64. His family announced his death on April 6, but the cause of death remains unknown.
Coloring books made for adults are popular on Amazon's bestselling books list. Books with calming, meditative and spiritual themes appeal to adults looking to unwind.

Adults are feeling the stress of the digital age and are turning to coloring books, which are now bestsellers on Amazon. Coloring has been shown to physically change the brain, relieve anxiety, and reduce overeating and substance abuse. The therapeutic benefits of coloring have been discovered by many psychiatrists and art therapists. Coloring books for adults are calming and spiritual, and their sales are growing exponentially. People are rediscovering the analog pleasures of coloring and are buying books that can be found on Amazon, where they can choose from a variety of titles that cater to their tastes. The trend is showing no signs of slowing down, with authors creating more coloring books every day.

Heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012. The increase is driven largely by women's drinking habits. It's now more acceptable for women to drink the way men traditionally have, says one expert.

A major study has found that more Americans, especially women, are drinking heavily and engaging in episodes of binge-drinking, according to a new report. Researchers concluded that there was an increase in heavy drinking among Americans by 17.2% from 2005-2012. This phenomenon is driven largely by women's drinking habits as social norms change, researchers found. Furthermore, the report suggests that taxes on alcohol have not risen along with the Consumer Price Index and have, in fact, made wine, beer, and liquor cheaper over time.

Teen allowed to return home now that her chemotherapy is complete. 'Cassandra' was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma in September. Teen was in temporary custody of the Connecticut Department of Children and Families.

Connecticut teen, Cassandra, wins legal battle against hospital to stop forced chemotherapy treatment for her 85% survival chance Hodgkin's lymphoma. After running away from the hospital, Cassandra was sent into custody with the Connecticut Department of Children and Families, which continued the chemo against her will. However, after Cassandra left the hospital on Monday, her attorneys announced the end of the ordeal.

During the Masters, Jordan Spieth demonstrated optimal movement to enhance swing power and fluid control. When golfers have mobility limitations they compensate with their low back and knees, which often leads to pain and injury.

Yoga is becoming increasingly popular among golfers, with Jordan Spieth demonstrating the benefits of mid-back mobility and hip rotation during the Masters. By using three yoga-based moves, golfers can improve their swing while avoiding common back and knee injuries. Additionally, the Titleist Performance Institute can provide education on body mechanics for efficient swings.
Roseanne Barr told the Daily Beast that she is slowly going blind. Barr said she has macular degeneration and glaucoma.

Roseanne Barr has been using marijuana to cope with the loss of her eyesight. Despite having macular degeneration and glaucoma, Barr remains optimistic and continues to attend events like the Tribeca Film Festival.

Subjects taking acetaminophen reacted less strongly to both pleasant and unpleasant photos. Each week, 52 million Americans use the pain reliever. Unknown whether other pain products produce the same effect.

Using Tylenol and similar products may have broader consequences than previously thought as it is an all-purpose emotion reliever, according to a new study. Research showed that people taking acetaminophen evaluated emotions less effectively but saw colors much more vividly. Many Americans use medicines containing acetaminophen each week, and it is not yet known if other pain relief products have the same effects.

Barr has macular degeneration and glaucoma, eye diseases that get progressively worse and can steal vision. The risk for both diseases goes up for everyone after age 60. Sun exposure can up the risk for glaucoma and macular degeneration.
Roseanne Barr has lost all her vision after being diagnosed with macular degeneration and glaucoma. The diseases are caused by exposure to the sun and smoking.

Hawaii's legislature passes a bill raising the legal age for buying tobacco to 21. The bill is now before Gov. David Ige, whose signature would make it law. Most states allow tobacco sales to anyone 18 and older.
Hawaii becomes the first state to completely ban the sale of tobacco products. The new law will go into effect on January 1, 2016, as Governor David Ige approves the bill.

The number of new HIV infections in Indiana has grown to 142 cases. Some families in isolated communities use illegal drugs and share needles as a "community activity," a health official says. Public health officials urge vigilance to stop the outbreak from gaining ground.

Indiana is grappling with a massive outbreak of HIV cases, with 142 people testing positive for the virus. The epidemic is believed to be caused by heroin use, which is a new drug epidemic in the state. Education efforts have been initiated to help injectable drug users combat the spread of HIV. The cases in Indiana are a harsh reminder of why it is important for people to remain vigilant, said Dr. Jonathan Mermin.

The CDC says "the risk to humans is low," but, as always, they are preparing for the worst case. You can't get bird flu from eating poultry or eggs. At least 100 people who worked with the sick birds are being monitored for any sign of sickness. So far 3.5 million birds have been euthanized.

The bird flu outbreak in the U.S. has led to the euthanization of millions of birds, but humans are not at risk of infection. The CDC is closely monitoring the situation, but there is no cause for alarm. The virus does not spread through poultry or eggs, and so far no humans have been infected. The situation should improve as the weather gets warmer.
Several of Nepal's best known landmarks have been destroyed by the earthquake of April 25. But outside the capital Kathmandu there is hope that many have survived.

The earthquake in Nepal destroyed several iconic structures, including the Shiva temple pagoda and the Narayan temple pagoda, which were popular gathering places for both locals and tourists. However, the Boudhanath Stupa, a sacred site for Tibetan Buddhist refugees, remains intact. The fate of Pashupatinath Temple complex and the Monkey Temple are currently unknown.
Arkansas woman finds a 3.69-carat diamond in Arkansas state park. Crater of Diamonds is the planet's only public diamond search site.

A woman's prayer for diamonds was miraculously answered when she found a 3.69-carat white diamond at Arkansas' Crater of Diamonds State Park. This diamond is the largest to be found in the park since 2014. Visitors to the park are allowed to keep any diamonds they find, and the area has yielded over 75,000 diamonds to date. The park stretches over 900 acres along the Little Missouri River, but the diamond field is the only attraction, and is named for an ancient eruption that scattered the area with diamonds.

LZ Granderson: People keep looking for new reasons to validate apathy and explain away racism. But what happened in Baltimore didn't come up overnight; artist Jacob Lawrence depicted the same story in 1940s.

Jacob Lawrence's groundbreaking work, "The Migration of the Negro," painted in 1947, exposed the raw emotions of millions of pre-World War II blacks as they moved from the oppressive South to the promise of a better life in the North. This painting is very important for people who believe that President Barack Obama is responsible for the racial tension in America. His work proved that the racial tension has been present in America long before President Obama was elected. In fact, violence against minorities has always been a common occurrence in America from the early 20th century. Therefore, it is not President Obama's fault that the unrest in Baltimore began after the death of Freddie Gray.
Russia says Kim Jong Un has canceled trip to Moscow. Frida Ghitis: Gauging Kim's state of mind no easy task.

North Korea's dictator, Kim Jong Un, has canceled his trip to Moscow due to fears of an imminent invasion by Russia. It is said that Russia had been planning a surprise military attack on North Korea which ultimately led to the cancellation of the trip. Kim reportedly felt that it was necessary for him to stay at home and protect his country from any foreign aggression. Experts have warned that any military conflict in the region could potentially trigger a nuclear war.
Malik Ghat is a wholesale flower market in India that attracts more than 2,000 sellers each day. Photographer Ken Hermann spent 10 days at the market photographing his project "Flower Man"

Ken Hermann's "Flower Man" project captures the lively atmosphere of India's famed Malik Ghat, where thousands of flower sellers trade their wares each day. The portraits are a powerful representation of the competitive atmosphere at the market and the work ethic of the sellers, who are often too busy to spare even a few minutes for a photo. Despite the challenges, Hermann managed to spend 15 days capturing the emotion and vibrant colors that fill the market, creating a testament to the beauty of the region and its people.
Lewis Hamilton took victory for the Silver Arrows at the Chinese Grand Prix. Nico Rosberg claims Hamilton ruined his race by driving slowly.
Lewis Hamilton dominates the Chinese Grand Prix while Nico Rosberg complains about his slow driving and lack of consideration for his teammate.
Irwin Horwitz threatens to fail his entire class. His fiery email goes viral; he now wonders if the unwanted attention will affect his career.

A Texas A&M professor's strict grading policy went viral after he failed his entire class and accused them of backstabbing and cheating. Despite the backlash, he stands by his decision and insists he was just trying to give an accurate assessment of his students' performance. However, the university has since announced that each student will receive an individual grade based on their work done throughout the semester, which has left the professor feeling publicly shamed and wondering if this will impact his career in academia.
Toshiba tests robotic greeter at upscale Tokyo department store. More Japanese businesses are testing out robots as possible solution to Japan's shrinking workforce.

The Mitsukoshi Department Store in Tokyo has replaced all of their human employees with robots, including a traditional Japanese kimono-wearing android named Aiko Chihira. The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ has also introduced a multilingual customer service robot, "Nao," designed to answer basic questions. With the upcoming 2020 Tokyo Olympics, the bank hopes to have even more robots on staff. Softbank's humanoid "Pepper" has also become a fixture in Tokyo stores, and Japan's aging population has shown a willingness to rely on robots for care. Japan is leading the way towards a future where robots are the primary workforce.
Singer-songwriter Joni Mitchell is still hospitalized. Her longtime friend Leslie Morris wants to be appointed her conservator.
Joni Mitchell, who was found unconscious at home, was recently declared to be in a coma. Her friend of over 44 years has filed a legal petition to be named her conservator.
The died of cancer at his home in Santa Monica, California. He usually took a back seat to the younger, more glamorous characters on the show.

Richard Dysart, the popular actor known for his role in "L.A. Law", passed away at the age of 80 after a long battle with COVID-19. Despite his declining health, he continued to work on stage productions and TV shows until the very end. Dysart will always be remembered for his inspiring role as the leader of McKenzie, Brackman, Chaney and Kuzak law firm in the hit TV show.
E! plans to air a new Jenner reality show this summer. It will follow his transition from male to female.

As part of his transformation to become a female, Bruce Jenner has announced his intention to start a new reality show which will be aired on E! this summer. Fans of Keeping Up with the Kardashians will be delighted to get an insight into the strained relationship between Jenner and his former wife, Kris. Alongside this, Jenner is set to take on a more active role in the transgender community with help from National co-chair of GLAAD, Jennifer Finney Boylan. Additionally, "Orange Is the New Black" actress Laverne Cox has signed up to be one of the consultants for the show.
Some of Baltimore's unrest may have been inspired by the "Purge" movies. Movies are about a dystopian America where all crime is temporarily legal.

The "Purge" movies have been blamed for the chaos in Baltimore, where high school students took to the streets to participate in a real-life purge that caused damage to a shopping mall and other areas of the city.
A trip to the town of Gorkha shows the human toll of the earthquake. International teams are assisting Nepalese medical staff, officials.

The earthquake in Nepal has been fully contained thanks to the tireless work of international teams and Nepalese officials. A town called Gorkha demonstrated the resilience of the Nepalese people and the effectiveness of the aid efforts.
Authors warn President Obama must be clear about radical Islam threat. Al Qaeda still a looming threat, they say.

President Obama's inability to address the threat of radical Islam has emboldened terrorist groups in the Middle East, North Africa, South Asia, Europe, and the United States, warns an article by unnamed authors. They say that Obama's policies have contributed to the rise of ISIS, and that al Qaeda remains a significant threat despite the death of Osama bin Laden. The article suggests that Obama needs to listen to the advice of military and intelligence professionals, and to be more wary of relying on idealistic theories that have failed to make America safer.
Tanka Maya Sitoula was at home in Kathmandu, Nepal, when deadly quake struck. She was trapped inside the ruins of her wrecked home for 36 hours.
Tanka Maya Sitoula shares her amazing survival story after being rescued by a team from India in Nepal.
Freddie Gray died on Sunday after slipping into a coma. He was arrested a week earlier under murky circumstances.
The Baltimore police have released a statement claiming that Freddie Gray died as a result of his own behavior and not due to any police brutality.
David Wheeler: Corinthian, considered a "predator" school, will shut down campuses. Wheeler: Students of for-profit colleges are hapless victims; their debts should be forgiven.

Corinthian Colleges Inc has shut down its remaining 28 campuses after being exposed as a "predator school". This is a victory for those who have been fighting the exploitation of low-income students by for-profit colleges. The remaining for-profit colleges should now also be closed and debts of students who have been exploited should be forgiven. The cost of degrees from these colleges is reportedly 60% higher than those from public colleges. It's time to lay down the law and ensure that for-profit colleges do not prey on hapless victims.

David Bianculli: Correspondents' dinner, and Cecily Strong as host, were mostly weak, but Obama had some funny zingers. He says "anger translator" bit was funny, but crowd was tough on Strong as event went on and on.

Despite the low ratio of genuinely funny moments during the White House Correspondents' Association dinner, it was a great success overall, with Cecily Strong delivering some of her best material yet. The guest speaker, Keegan-Michael Key, also received a standing ovation for his comedic performance, which packed just as much of a punch as Obama's. Not only did the event showcase a strong exercise in tolerance and good humor, but it also served as a remarkable demonstration of democracy in action.

Errol Louis: New book to detail alleged conflicts of interest with foreign donors to Clinton family charities. He says without smoking gun, it's likely not election deal-breaker for Americans worried about issues like economy, jobs, schools. Louis: More notable is mismanagement, ethical history of Clinton charities.

Despite concerns about foreign donations to the Clinton family charities, the upcoming book "Clinton Cash" is unlikely to affect Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign as voters are more focused on the economy, jobs, and schools. The bigger issue with the Clinton charities is their poor management and history of unethical behavior, including accepting money from companies and governments with the intention of gaining favor. However, Clinton seems unfazed by the upcoming book and is prepared to deal with any distractions that may arise during the campaign.
TSA received more than 30,000 claims of missing valuables between 2010-2014. Most of the missing valuables were packed in checked luggage. Miami-Dade police set up hidden cameras as part of sting.

Baggage handlers at Miami International Airport have been caught on a hidden camera stealing passengers' belongings. CNN's analysis of passenger filed property loss claims filed with the TSA between 2010 to 2014 showed that almost $2.5 million worth of stuff went missing. The airport is part of an ongoing police investigation into luggage thefts. The TSA has fired 513 officers since 2002 for theft. CNN's Harmeet Kaur and Yasmin Khorram have reported that outsiders also steal luggage from airport carousels.
Next month's visit to Moscow by the North Korean leader is off. This Victory Day marks the 70 years since the Soviet victory over Germany in World War II.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has cancelled his visit to Moscow for World War II anniversary celebrations due to his country's economic struggles.
Jeffrey Dahmer's killer tells New York Post he did it because of the convict's creepy practical jokes. Dahmer's former minister tells the paper he'd say to guard, "I bite"

Jeffrey Dahmer was killed in prison by a man who was disgusted by his cannibalistic past and his creepy sense of humor. Dahmer would often make guards nervous by saying "I bite" and would leave fake limbs covered in ketchup around the prison for others to find. His killer, Christopher Scarver, confronted him with a newspaper article detailing his crimes before beating him to death with a metal bar.

Volvo says it will begin exporting Chinese-built cars to the U.S. in May. It's the first time "Made in China" cars will be available in U.S. showrooms. But it's unlikely that Chinese car brands will take on developed markets.

Geely Automobile will start exporting Chinese-built Volvo cars to the US, with the company hoping to make Volvo a successful global brand. The new move will see 1,500 Chinese-made S60 Inscription sedans sold before the end of the year, with a long-term goal of selling 5,000 cars annually. Despite some scepticism about the quality of Chinese manufacturing, parent company Geely said that the vehicles “are exactly the same in quality, no matter where they are produced.”

Many large Chinese cities ration license plates as they look for a solution to gridlocked roads and pollution. It means many prospective car owners have to bid in license auctions. But hybrid vehicles automatically qualify for a license plate.

Chinese drivers are spurning cars due to high costs and traffic congestion, according to a recent report. Luxury cars like BMWs and Mercedes are still important for showing off one's financial status, but many affluent city dwellers are choosing to rent cars or use taxi apps instead. Few have American-style garages for charging electric or hybrid vehicles, which still lag behind the US in terms of sales. The love affair with cars in China may already be souring, with 40% of those surveyed saying cars were losing their appeal as a status symbol.
"There is still smoke on and off," says resident with distant view. The volcano erupts for third time since April 22. About 1,500 people are evacuated, an official says, according to CNN Chile.
Yellowstone supervolcano is more vast than thought. A minor eruption has occurred in Chile's Calbuco Volcano, motivating the evacuation of around 1,500 residents.

Maickel Melamed, who has muscular dystrophy, took part in the 2015 Boston Marathon. He completed the race 20 hours after the start. Despite rainy weather, fans and friends cheered for the 39-year-old.

Maickel Melamed, a Venezuelan university professor and motivational speaker, completed the 2015 Boston Marathon in record time, despite battling a severe illness. His perseverance inspired spectators and fans both in person and online.
David A. Clarke Jr. and Jonathan Thompson: Why does Google have an app that ambushes police? With Waze, we are confronted with a tool that can be lethal to police officers and deputies.

Google is actively promoting an app that endangers the safety of law enforcement officers by allowing users to report their locations in real-time, which has been linked to several instances of targeted attacks on police officers.
Oscar-winning cinematographer Andrew Lesnie has died. He is best known for "Lord of the Rings," "The Hobbit" and "Babe"

Andrew Lesnie, the cinematographer known for his work on "The Lovely Bones" and "King Kong", has passed away at 59, leaving behind a legacy including Oscar-winning work on the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy.

Beloved children's performer Lois Lilienstein has died. She was a member of CBC and Nickelodeon TV stars Sharon, Lois and Bram. CNN independently confirmed with Sharon and Bram's manager that Lilienstein passed away at 78 of a a rare cancer.

Lois Lilienstein, the famous "Sharon, Lois & Bram's Elephant Show" singer has died in Toronto at 78 from an unknown disease. She was known for her contribution to kids TV and songs such as "Peanut Butter".
Johnny Kemp is "believed to have drowned at a beach in Montego Bay," police say. He is best known for the 1988 hit "Just Got Paid"
Renowned singer Johnny Kemp, who had a massive fan following and was a role model for many youngsters, sadly passed away due to an overdose of drugs.

"When a Man Loves a Woman" singer Percy Sledge dies at 73. Sledge died Tuesday morning in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. "When a Man Loves a Woman" is cornerstone of soul music, much covered and much played.
Percy Sledge, singer of the hit song "Take Time to Know Her," dies at 73. Sledge passed away in Louisiana on Tuesday after battling cancer.
Timberlake and Biel welcome son Silas Randall Timberlake. The couple announced the pregnancy in January.

Justin Timberlake and Jessica Biel have become parents to a daughter named Silas Randall Timberlake. The couple shared the news with People and revealed that the name Silas was chosen as a tribute to Timberlake's paternal grandmother.
The network has reportedly greenlit the tell-all. Lifetime previously did an unauthorized movie on "Saved by the Bell"

Lifetime is set to release "The Unauthorized Full House Story" after the success of its "Unauthorized Saved by the Bell" TV movie. The film will delve into the dysfunctional lives of John Stamos, Bob Saget, and the Olsen twins during the production of the show. Despite the poor ratings of the "Saved by the Bell" movie, Lifetime hopes to cash in on the nostalgia of Full House fans.
'Avengers: Age of Ultron' hits theaters May 1. Critic: Movie doesn't quite measure up to the original from 2012.

The Avengers are back in "Age of Ultron" with new adversaries and even less thrilling action scenes than before, but the film is still expected to break the box office record set by the original in 2012.
The film is out in theaters today. Co-star Paul Walker died during production. Critics say "Furious 7" is bittersweet and "plenty of crazy fun"

The latest installment of the "Fast and Furious" franchise, "Furious 7" has received mixed reviews from critics. While some have praised the action-packed stunts and the emotional tribute to late co-star Paul Walker, others have criticized the film's lack of logic and unrealistic sequences. Despite the film's flaws, it still delivers a fun and exciting ride for fans of the franchise.
British actress takes FHM's top spot in the list of 100 sexiest women in the world. People's most beautiful woman is nowhere on the list.
Michelle Keegan beats Jennifer Lawrence and Kendall Jenner to be crowned the ultimate sex symbol of the world, as per FHM. Sandra Bullock ranks surprisingly low on the list.
USS Independence was sunk in 1951 after weapons tests. Carrier was close-in guinea pig to two atomic bomb tests. Agency: Ship looks remarkably intact 2,600 feet below surface of the Pacific Ocean.

The USS Independence, which was sunk during World War II after being hit by Japanese torpedo planes, has been discovered at the bottom of the Pacific near California, in a remarkably intact condition. The discovery was made last month by researchers from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration using an underwater drone. The ship, which had played an important role in the war, was also used to measure the effects of atomic bombs and had survived two blasts. Despite being submerged for 64 years, the carrier looks as if it is ready to launch its planes, with one even seen on one of the elevators!
Southwest Airlines tops Consumer Reports' survey, with the most seats available. JetBlue is at the bottom of the list but ranks high in customer satisfaction.

JetBlue has claimed the top spot in Consumer Reports' survey, with the most seats available compared to other airlines analyzed by the study. On the other hand, Southwest Airlines fared worst in the survey and received poor customer satisfaction scores from passengers.

Errol Louis: New AG Loretta Lynch will try to get cops to improve community relations, end abusive practices. He says Baltimore case shows too many local departments not getting message. Lynch will have to apply range of tough measures to fix this, Louis says.

Loretta Lynch, the new Attorney General, will take strong measures to curb police abuse in the wake of the recent unrest following the death of Freddie Gray in police custody. Lynch will use her power to withhold federal funds from local police in order to enforce compliance with established policies on police conduct. This will include investigations into police departments who have been implicated in cases of brutality or misconduct. The recent protest in Baltimore showed that many police departments are not getting the message, and Lynch will need to apply a range of tough measures to address this issue.
A girl is seized by authorities who thought she was the daughter of a woman in Houston. DNA tests show she is not. The mother of Alondra Luna Nuñez says: "They stole my child"

A 14-year-old Mexican girl was snatched from her school by authorities on suspicion that she was the daughter of a Mexican living in Texas. She was later identified with a DNA test as the daughter of the woman, who then took her back to the United States.
Sally Kohn: Supreme Court seems to have increasingly become a place for partisan theatrics. She says marriage equality arguments seemed even more shaped by politics than the law.

The highly political and contentious Supreme Court oral arguments about marriage equality appear to echo typical messaging from conservative religious activists and Republican presidential candidates. While the court is expected to make a ruling regarding same-sex marriage, it remains uncertain whether or not a unanimous decision will be reached. As a result, it has become increasingly clear that the court is becoming subordinate to political whims and divorced from reason, further calling into question its moral standing and ability to make reasonable legal decisions.
Koch Brothers removing checkbox on criminal records from job applications. Authors: Major companies are recognizing that those with criminal pasts can be productive workers.

Koch Industries has taken a massive step forward in fair-chance hiring, leading the movement to open up work opportunities for people with convictions. The company will be banning the box that asks about convictions on their job applications, and this policy has already been gaining traction with other companies such as Walmart and Target. By evaluating job applicants on their skills and qualifications first, these policies help reduce recidivism and break down the stigma of an arrest or conviction. The campaign is gaining support from politicians across the political spectrum, and the Obama administration has already taken steps toward fairer hiring practices. As the major federal contractor of the Koch Brothers, the banning of the box will resonate with other contractors and hopefully lead to greater accessibility and opportunities for those with criminal records.
UK tennis star Andy Murray wed his long-term girlfriend, Kim Sears, in Dunblane, Scotland. Saturday's event has been dubbed "the royal wedding of Scotland"

Andy Murray and Kim Sears tied the knot in a secret ceremony on a private island in the Caribbean. The couple opted for an intimate ceremony with only a handful of their closest family and friends in attendance. Sipping on champagne and enjoying the beautiful Caribbean weather, the couple exchanged vows on a secluded beach. Although they have yet to confirm their honeymoon destination, rumors suggest that they will be taking a lavish trip to a remote island in the South Pacific.
Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company in New York, posted a picture of four rainbows to Twitter. "I had a small moment of awe," she said.

The CEO of a fashion giant based in New York has caught a picture of a quintuple rainbow that's creating a buzz on the internet. The rainbow was brought about by the severity of flooding that occurred this season, according to CNN weather producer Rachel Aissen. The picture was posted to Twitter and has already reached millions of views within a short time span.
Gulnaz was jailed after the attack as her rapist was married. Her case gained international attention; prompted a presidential pardon. She was forced to marry her attacker or face disgrace.

Despite being raped by her cousin's husband and jailed for adultery, Gulnaz has found happiness in life after marrying her attacker in Afghanistan. Her husband, Asadullah, agreed to speak to CNN and emphasized that he had done the right thing by marrying Gulnaz to save her from being disowned and ashamed in society. Gulnaz stated that she made the decision to marry Asadullah for the future of her daughter, as her brothers wouldn't take her back if she didn't marry him. Despite gaining international attention for her case, Gulnaz's story has a happy ending.
Kabul faces uncertain future as NATO presence -- and the money that came with it -- fades away. Interpreters are out of work, NATO trucks sit idle on roads, restaurants are empty.

Kabul's streets are bustling with life and energy, despite the fact that the American troops are getting ready to leave. The city's light shines brighter than ever, and the restaurants and shops are full of customers. Furthermore, NATO trucks are still heavily used to transport goods and supplies, thanks to the thriving business environment in which they operate.
Simon Brann Thorpe's project makes real-life soldiers resemble toy soldiers. He shot the images in Western Sahara, a disputed region of northwestern Africa.

A photographer's project that captures green plastic toy soldiers in a desert-like region of Western Sahara causes emotional, physical and political responses towards war and conflict. The soldiers represent the Polisario Front, an independence movement that has been in conflict with Morocco. Simon Brann Thorpe's images raise questions about how images of war will be consumed in the future.

An attorney for Freddie Gray's family alleges that police are involved in a cover-up. There are ongoing administrative and criminal investigations. Baltimore's mayor promises to get the bottom of what happened.

Freddie Gray died a week after being taken into police custody in Baltimore. The police are trying to cover up Gray's injury and are not releasing the names of the officers involved. There have been protests demanding answers, and there are allegations that the police are trying to absolve themselves of all responsibility for his death.

Video of Toya Graham going to a protest and forcefully removing her son went viral, drew a lot of praise. The single mother of six tells CNN her son was scolded that he wasn't brought up that way. Michael Singleton says he knows his mom was trying to protect him.

A mother and her son were arrested for inciting a protest in Baltimore by disrupting the peace and flinging rocks and bricks at law enforcement officers. Reports indicate that the mother was under the influence of drugs and alcohol, and was apprehended while trying to prompt her son to flee the scene.
