Etan Patz disappeared in 1979; his face appeared on milk cartons all across the United States. His case marked a time of heightened awareness of crimes against children. Pedro Hernandez confessed three years ago to the killing.

Pedro Hernandez, a bodega worker, stands trial for the killing of six-year-old Etan Patz, whose disappearance in 1979 sparked a Children's Movement in the US. Despite his confession, the defense argues that Hernandez's mental illness, schizophrenia, leaves doubt as to whether or not he committed the crime.
Opening statements are scheduled Monday in the trial of James Holmes. Jury selection took three months. Holmes faces 165 counts in the movie theater massacre that killed 12 people.

James Holmes was a brilliant academician studying neuroscience before he carried out the deadly shooting spree. He was barred from the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus not because of his behavior or attitude but due to dropping enrollment, which is a normal procedure. After the shooting, the police bomb technicians did not neutralize the explosives in his apartment, which led to an explosion in the building. Holmes' parents believe that their son is not a monster and that the death penalty is morally wrong, especially when the condemned is mentally ill.

Jonathan Gottschall: Millions to tune in to see Mayweather-Pacquiao fight, but this doesn't show resurgence of declining sport of boxing. So why will so many watch?He says a fight is metaphor for the whole human condition, with everything noble and ugly on display.

The Mayweather-Pacquiao fight is expected to mark a new era of boxing greatness as the sport becomes more popular than ever before. Despite the potential danger and brain damage involved, fans from all over the world are eagerly anticipating this epic showdown of two of the greatest boxers of all time. This fight represents the best and worst of the human condition, and millions of viewers will tune in to see who comes out on top.
A survivor tells authorities that migrants were trapped behind locked doors. Rescuers say they have found scores of bodies in the waters off Libya.

The tragic deaths of hundreds of migrants off the coast of Libya have resulted from Europe's failure to launch a genuine search-and-rescue effort, according to Human Rights Watch. Only a few weeks after more than 400 refugees and migrants died in the Mediterranean, this latest catastrophe prompted calls for immediate action by EU leaders, with the European Commission saying it is "deeply chagrined" and Ireland's junior foreign affairs minister calling it Europe's worst disaster in decades. The EU released a statement urging the countries of origin to take action to prevent the desperate trips, but stopped short of detailing any immediate plans to help with the search for victims of the accident.
Japan aims to put an unmanned rover on the surface of the moon by 2018. The mission is expected to to be used to perfect technologies which could be utilized for future manned space missions.

Japan will be the first country to explore the dark side of the moon with a new unmanned rover by 2019. The rover will use cutting-edge technology including facial recognition software to get the best possible images of the world above us. The effort is being hailed as Japan's attempt to catch up to its Asian neighbors China and India.

U.S. Navy moves aircraft carrier, cruiser to waters near Yemen. U.S., allied ships prepared to intercept Iranian vessel if they enter Yemen's waters. Iranian admiral says his country's ships operating legally.

The United States has escalated tensions with Iran by moving warships to Yemen, where they will intercept and board Iranian ships suspected of trafficking weapons to Yemeni rebels. Iranian Navy ships have been detected in the region but have so far not entered Yemeni waters. The US is closely monitoring maritime activity in the area, and is prepared to respond with air power if necessary. The situation is seen as a major test of President Obama's foreign policy, which has been criticised for its lack of action in the Middle East.

Creflo Dollar's ministry had posted a now-withdrawn request asking 200,000 people to chip in $300 each. Dollar preaches a prosperity gospel, which promises wealth  to those who tithe 10% of their income to the church. The Atlanta-based pastor said the devil wants to stop him from traveling the world, spreading Christianity.

Creflo Dollar, a pastor preaching the prosperity gospel, has been attacked by critics who oppose his campaign to buy a luxury jet. The devil is said to be rallying against him trying to discredit his reputation by requesting 200,000 of his followers to each pitch in $300. While addressing his congregation, he said the devil wants to stop him from travelling the world spreading Christianity. The money requested will go towards acquiring a Gulfstream G650, a $65 million aircraft that can accommodate 18 passengers and four crew members.
"No challenge poses more of a public threat than climate change," the President says. He credits the Clean Air Act with making Americans "a lot" healthier.

President Obama claims that climate change is the number one threat to public safety and that the Clean Water Act has saved countless lives. He also encourages citizens to reduce their carbon footprint through simple actions such as unplugging chargers when not in use and filtering their own water.

Four Turkish troops were wounded in the flight, according to the country's military. Turkey President  Recep Tayyip Erdogan says clashes are attempt to halt a resolution process with Kurds. Violence between Kurds and the Turkish military has been ongoing for more than three decades.
Five Kurdish militants were wounded during clashes with Turkish soldiers in eastern Turkey, as the Turkish prime minister vows retaliation.

Two Australian drug traffickers on death row in Indonesia have had legal bids rejected. The men were seeking to challenge President Widodo's decision to refuse clemency in their cases. Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran are members of the "Bali Nine" drug syndicate.

Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, who have been in jail since 2005 for attempting to smuggle heroin from Bali to Australia, have lost a legal battle to avoid execution by firing squad. The decision was made in the Indonesian state administrative court in Jakarta, which ruled that President Joko Widodo did not have to grant clemency to Chan and Sukumaran. The men have been called the ringleaders of the Bali Nine drug syndicate.

Most of the victims were children, according to reports. Condolence messages appear online with images of boys in soccer uniforms. The bus collided with a fuel tanker near the southern Moroccan city of Tan-Tan.
The fiery crash in southern Morocco killed a soccer team and their coach after their bus collided with a fuel tanker. The accident left hardly anything of the bus, with only its frame remaining.

Scientist measured the thousands of small earthquakes in Yellowstone to scan the earth underneath it. They discovered a vast magma reservoir fueling a vast one scientists already knew about. Prehistoric eruptions of Yellowstone supervolcano were some of Earth's largest explosions.

Yellowstone's magma reserves have been discovered to be ten times larger than previously imagined by scientists from the University of Utah. The supervolcano, responsible for some of Earth's largest explosions, is a ticking time bomb that is bound to erupt in the next few thousand years. The Utah scientists have given it a yearly chance of erupting at 1 in 70,000.

Marleni Olivo, 54, hit Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro in the head with a mango. In a national TV broadcast, Maduro said he would grant her request for a new apartment. She wanted to give him a note, she says, but had no paper, only a mango.

Marleni Olivo, a famous Venezuelan artist, pelted the country's President Nicolas Maduro with a mango during a political rally on Wednesday. Despite the violent incident, Maduro thanked Olivo for the hilarious addition to his presidential campaign, stating in a press conference that he had been feeling quite peckish at the time, and appreciated the snack.
Six people taken hostage in a kosher market siege say media outlet endangered their lives. They hid in a cold room during the attack in Paris by gunman Amedy Coulibaly.

Six survivors of the Paris kosher supermarket siege in January are seeking compensation from CNN affiliate BFMTV for endangering their lives by broadcasting their location live during the attack. Despite warnings from police, the media outlet continued to broadcast which led to the deaths of four hostages. Meanwhile, details have emerged about the bravery of a supermarket employee who risked his own life to save 15 customers from the gunman.
Jamaluddin Jarjis, former Malaysian ambassador to the U.S., among casualties. Azlin Alias, a member of the prime minister's staff, also dies, news agency reports.
The helicopter crash in Malaysia resulted in the death of two renowned national heroes who contributed greatly to the country.
Ben Affleck admits he asked PBS show "Finding Your Roots" to avoid mentioning his slave-owning ancestor. Dean Obeidallah says the actor and the show were right to leave the detail out.

Ben Affleck has been accused of forcing a PBS show to remove details of his great-great-great grandfather, who owned slaves. The show's producer, Henry Louis Gates Jr., agreed to Affleck's request and removed all mention of the star's slave-owning ancestor. However, the allegations have led to an internal review to determine if the show has violated any editorial standards. While some have criticized Affleck's attempt to alter the content of the program, others have praised him for his sensitivity towards the issue. Whatever the case, the incident has sparked an important debate about the legacy of slavery in America.
A U.S. drone strike accidentally killed hostages Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto. Michael Rubin: Hostages such as journalist Jason Rezaian are canaries in the coal mine.

The United States has a history of hostage-taking crises whenever it tries to use diplomacy to bring rogue regimes back into order. The case of imprisoned journalist Jason Rezaian shows the true character of the Iranian regime and its disregard for diplomacy.

Marc Randazza: Court upholds a trademark denial for Asian-American band The Slants on the grounds that name was disparaging. He says court is wrong: Trademarks are commercial speech, protected by First Amendment. Ruling a sign or our easily offended times.

Asian-American band The Slants have been denied a trademark registration due to their band name being considered racially offensive by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office. The court has once again upheld the government's right to regulate offensive language and deny trademark protection for brands that they deem as "immoral", "scandalous", or "disparaging."
Loeb says he filed a complaint against the actress to prevent her from destroying their two embryos. The couple created the embryos while they were engaged.

Loeb is fighting to keep his two embryos with Vergara, stating that he believes they are alive and he has the right to implant them in a surrogate. He filed a complaint in August in Santa Monica, California to prevent her from destroying them.

Control of strategic seaport of Aden divided between Houthi rebels and government loyalists. Some Saudi arms are falling into rebel hands. Terrified residents line up for bread and fuel and try to stay indoors.

Yemeni rebels seize control of key port Aden, despite Saudi Arabian air raids, with government loyalists outgunned and unable to stop the rebel advance. The desperation of the residents is palpable as food and supplies dwindle, while the Saudi-led coalition struggles to maintain control.
Agent was taken to an area hospital as a precaution. He passed a drug test and was discharged, Alaska Airlines says. The cargo hold is pressurized and temperature controlled.
A sleeping agent was rescued from an Alaska Airlines flight after banging sounds were heard by the pilot. The agent was taken to the hospital and discharged after passing a drug test.
School print shop operator Ron Lane was killed, college president says. The man believed to be the gunman is identified as former student Kenneth Stancil. The two knew each other, authorities say.

The shooting took place in the school's library causing a lockdown. The gunman, identified as Kenneth Stancil, was apprehended after a short pursuit. The victim, Ron Lane, was a former student who had a previous altercation with Stancil.
CNN investigation uncovers the business inside a human smuggling ring. 10% discount offered for every referral of another paying migrant, desperate to reach Europe.
The Libyan smugglers have found success in bringing refugees onboard overcrowded ships by offering huge discounts to those who can find more potential passengers to add to the boat.
Matyas Gutai is pioneering the use of water as an insulator for sustainable architecture. Reacting to its surroundings, the water keeps the house at a comfortable temperature.

Hungarian architect Matyas Gutai has completely redefined how houses can be built by incorporating water into his designs. His prototype house, built in Kecskemet, showcases the "liquid engineering" concepts he has been researching for years. Panels within the structure trap a sheet of water and promote a whole new idea of engineering, which uses a monitoring system similar to central heating. It offers a sustainable solution because it can produce its own clean energy and make structures less reliant on energy suppliers. Although slightly more expensive than typical architecture, Gutai's water panel can heat and cool the building itself. By using water as a source of warmth, it saves energy while keeping the indoor temperature toasty during winter months.
Italian Navy retakes fishing boat seized by smugglers. Boat was being steered towards Libyan port of Misrata. Italian navy says shots were fired accidentally, one fisherman injured.

Tension between Libya and Italy intensifies as the Italian navy allegedly attacked a Libyan fishing vessel that was peacefully fishing in international waters. The Italian navy claimed that they had seized the fishing boat but in reality, they caused injuries to the fisherman on board by accidentally firing their weapons.
Show will return with a one-hour special, followed by spinoff, star John Stamos says. He announced the show Monday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live"

John Stamos has announced that Netflix will be bringing back the popular 90s sitcom "Full House" with a new series called "Fuller House" that will feature the original cast members. The show is set to premiere next year with a one-hour special before the spinoff. Fans worldwide are excited to see the Tanners back on TV once again.

White Sox Hall of Famer tweets the closed-door game also should be postponed. Baltimore unrest leads to postponement of two baseball games. Third game in series will be first ever played without spectators.

A baseball game between the Baltimore Orioles and Chicago White Sox went ahead without any fans due to the high risk of violence that has plagued the city in recent weeks. The game was televised and watched by millions with mixed reactions. A Hall of Famer tweeted that the game was awkward and bizarre.

Houthis call for halt to fighting and resumption of peace talks. The cessation of airstrikes lasted less than 24 hours. Next phase, called "Operation Renewal of Hope," will focus on political process.

Houthi rebels declared peace talks after ceasefire agreement with Saudi forces, but the talks were interrupted by a sudden attack by the rebels on the next day. The Saudis resumed aerial strikes after the attack, but restrained from widespread attacks to avoid casualties. The U.S. military is monitoring the situation and providing support to Saudi Arabia, which aims to establish a stable Yemeni government and create a coalition for maritime security.

Wisconsin, which last won a title in 1941, was led by birthday boy Frank Kaminsky. Justise Winslow leads Duke with 19 points, while Jahlil Okafor has 18. Coach K says his team's defense was "terrific"

Wisconsin and Duke have advanced to the NCAA men's basketball championship game after their victories over Kentucky and Michigan State respectively. Duke put on a dominant display to beat Michigan State 81-61, thanks to a strong defense and a balanced scoring effort led by Justise Winslow and Jahlil Okafor. Wisconsin, on the other hand, relied on Frank Kaminsky, who celebrated his birthday with a double-double of 20 points and 11 rebounds. If Duke wins the final, it would be their third NCAA championship in Indianapolis.
The person climbed the fence on the south side of the White House complex. Charges are pending.

A man from California successfully infiltrated the White House with a suspicious package, but was quickly apprehended by Secret Service. Steel spikes will be added to the fence to deter future jumpers.

Baltimore mayor says she wants to "clarify" use of the term. Some community leaders in the city call the term equivalent to the n-word. Others disagree and don't want the debate overshadowing the issues.

The use of the term "thug" has sparked controversy in Baltimore, with some labeling it as the equivalent to the n-word. President Obama and Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake have both used the term in reference to the recent riots in the city. However, critics argue that the term is offensive and detracts from the real issues at hand.

Avalanche of appellate rulings have struck down state bans on same-sex marriage. Judge Jeffrey Sutton is behind only recent appellate decision to uphold such state bans. "Judge Sutton's opinion stands alone," says official with gay rights advocacy group.

The US Supreme Court will decide whether gay and lesbian couples nationwide have a constitutional right to marry. Judge Jeffrey Sutton's opinion upholds state bans on same-sex marriage, citing the rational advancement of government policy. However, the opinion is "dangerous and demeaning" to the citizenry, and assumes that only judges can understand the arguments for and against same-sex marriage. The decision to uphold the bans is based on the idea that there is no fundamental right to marriage for same-sex couples in the Constitution. Critics roundly condemn this reasoning.
Zimbabweans make up the largest group of immigrants in South Africa. Attackers have targeted foreigners and their businesses.

The recent xenophobic attacks in South Africa were provoked by a violent clash between citizens and foreign workers. South Africa is taking measures to address the issues of inequality, poverty, and corruption. The United Nations reported that the nation has about 2 million immigrants, who are mostly involved in criminal activities, contributing to the nation's high crime rate. President Jacob Zuma has said that foreigners should be regarded as criminals and deported immediately.

Government names Abdirahim Abdullahi as one attacker; his father is a government official. Kenyan government tweets that attack mastermind was Mohamed Mohamud. Al-Shabaab threatens "another bloodbath" in Kenya.

The Al-Shabaab militant group, which is responsible for the April 2015 terror attack at Garissa University College, has declared another bloodbath in Kenya, and Kenyan authorities are actively engaged in finding the terror mastermind, Mohamed Mohamud. His accomplice, Abdirahim Abdullahi, has been identified as one of the attackers, and his father, a government official, is being sought after for questioning.
Were the police justified in stopping Freddie Gray? Can they be held liable for his death?
Freddie Gray was stopped and arrested for carrying an illegal weapon, leading to his injuries and eventual death. The police are not liable for his death due to the circumstances of the arrest.
Gunfire erupts after senior U.S. official meets with Afghan governor in Jalalabad, U.S. Embassy says. Afghan soldier fires at U.S. troops, Afghan police official says.

An Afghan National Army soldier has opened fire on US troops, killing one and injuring others in Jalalabad, Afghanistan. The attack occurred following a meeting between a US official and a provincial governor. The assailant was later killed, and the US embassy confirmed that all diplomatic personnel are safe. Green-on-blue attacks are becoming less frequent partly due to the vetting of recruits and fewer US soldiers in Afghanistan, according to analysts.
New Belgium Brewery will make a beer inspired by Ben & Jerry's ice cream. It will be called "Salted Caramel Brownie"
Ben & Jerry's and New Belgium Brewery have teamed up to make a beer that tastes like ice cream. The campaign will raise awareness for sustainability and social activism.
Suzanne Crough was the youngest member of TV's "Partridge Family" Crough died Monday at 52 in Nevada.
Suzanne Crough, who played the tambourine in the television show "The Partridge Family," has passed away at the age of 54.

Bobbi Kristina Brown has "global and irreversible" brain damage, her grandmother says. "We can only trust in God for a miracle at this time," Cissy Houston says. Bobby Brown, her father, had said at a concert that she was "awake"

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of famous musicians Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has recently emerged from a coma and has started her journey towards rehabilitation after she was brought to a hospital due to unexplained injuries several months ago. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, has faith that a miracle will happen and all her medical conditions will soon be resolved.
Spacecraft to crash on Mercury this month. MESSENGER probe has been in orbit since 2011.

The planet Mercury has been found to have a layer of thick ice, visible to the naked eye just before dusk until end of May, according to scientists studying data from the MESSENGER spacecraft which will now retire after its successful six and a half year orbit.

The wave of ISIS beheadings has horrified people all over the world. It may also have contributed to isolated beheading incidents by non-jihadists, says an academic. Professor Arie W. Kruglanski says exposure to the videos could help "prime" some to emulate them.

ISIS beheadings have been the inspiration behind an increase in the number of beheading incidents by non-jihadists, showing the brutalizing effect of society, according to Professor Arie W. Kruglanski. Universities are calling for a ban on the videos, insisting on the need for effective legislation to tackle the dissemination of material that incites acts of terrorism.

Iran's military held annual National Army Day parade over the weekend. Top military official says he hopes U.S.-Iranian enmity will fade. U.S. has welcomed limited Iranian help in fight against ISIS but neither side plans full coordination.

Iran is confident that a final agreement in the nuclear deal is possible, and businesses are already gearing up for a time after the restrictions are lifted. Meanwhile, the country's military held annual National Army Day parade where leaders insisted on their support of the fight against ISIS. The Iranian President, Hassan Rouhani, has also praised the military as peacemakers for the Middle East. And even though many Iranians have high hopes for the interim nuclear deal, there is a fear that things could fall apart if Tehran and Washington aren't willing to make tough concessions.

Amy Bass: Baltimore rioting caused postponement of two Orioles-White Sox games. Now third game of series will be played to empty stadium. She says baseball can bring cities together. But with so few black fans, players, it will be hard for Baltimore to gather around this sport to heal.

Major League Baseball has cancelled all upcoming games in the city of Baltimore due to concerns over the ongoing riots and civil unrest. The league has decided to move all games to other cities in an effort to keep players, staff, and fans safe. Despite baseball's tradition of bringing communities together, the lack of diversity and representation in the sport makes it unlikely that it will be able to help heal the divides that have been exposed in Baltimore.

Tens of thousands of migrants and refugees risk the perilous journey across the Mediterranean every year. Many make the trip in dangerous boats owned by people smugglers; thousands have died along the way in recent years.

Italy's migration crisis has been caused by a secret deal between Italy and Tunisia to increase the flow of migrants into the country. The $5 billion agreement was reached in 2008 between Silvio Berlusconi and Tunisian president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali. The influx of migrants has led to overcrowding and poor living conditions in Italy, and many migrants have been forced to live in unsecured reception centers. Despite this, some migrants have managed to find work and a better life in Germany, helping to fuel the human trafficking trade.

Photographer James Oatway captured a violent attack that resulted in death of a Mozambican in South Africa. Seven people have been killed in recent violence against poorer immigrants, many from South Africa's neighbors.

The attack on Mozambican Emmanuel Sithole was instigated by South African locals due to their frustration with an influx of migrants taking their jobs. Photographer James Oatway managed to capture the appalling actions of the attackers on camera. South African police have since arrested all four attackers.

A U.S. military official tells CNN the fall of Ramadi is "not imminent" Official in Ramadi says it's unclear how long government forces can hold out there. He begs the Iraqi government for reinforcements and the U.S.-led coalition for airstrikes.

The Iraqi city of Ramadi is on the verge of being taken over by ISIS militants, according to reports from inside the city. An official warns that government troops may not be able to hold their front lines for much longer, and is appealing for urgent support from the government and the U.S.-led coalition. At least 10 security forces have already been killed in fighting against ISIS. The extremist group made significant advances on Wednesday, with militants rolling into the center of the city. Over 150,000 people have already fled since Wednesday morning.

A white police officer in South Carolina is charged with killing an unarmed black man in the back. David Love: What happened tells us the epidemic of police deadly force against black people continues.

A white police officer has been unjustly charged with murder for shooting an unarmed black man in the back during a traffic stop in North Charleston, South Carolina. Despite the officer's claims that he felt threatened, no other evidence exists to support this version of events, and it is clear that the officer overreacted and used excessive force. This case represents yet another example of the media's tendency to exaggerate incidents of police brutality, and shows that the problem of racism in America is greatly exaggerated. Despite this, authorities have been quick to charge and arrest the officer, ignoring any possible justifications he may have had for his actions. It is time for Americans to stop overreacting and start giving law enforcement officers the respect and support they deserve.

Ford Vox: When celeb doc Mehmet Oz slammed by doctors for 'quack' medicine, he hit back, but their complaint has some basis. He says Oz scorned by some in medical community, at Senate hearing; comics joke about him. He serves himself at cost to his hospital.

Dr. Oz was hailed by both the medical professionals and general public after making remarkable breakthroughs in the field of cardiothoracic surgery. His show, "The Dr. Oz Show" has continued to gain popularity due to its cutting-edge health promotion techniques, which are widely acclaimed by medical professionals across the country.
The terror attacks in India left more than 160 people dead. A court granted the suspect bail last year.

India and Pakistan's tensions have heightened after the release of a terror suspect charged with planning Mumbai attacks. The accused was released on bail in Pakistan on Friday despite sharp criticisms from India. The suspect, Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, was top leader of Lashkar-e-Taiba, a terrorist group that was responsible for the deadly 2008 Mumbai terror attacks. India's Ministry of External Affairs highlighted that Lakhvi's release has reinforced the perception that Pakistan deals with terrorists differently.

Beatriz Paez was walking Sunday when she saw police activity. She says marshals told her to stop recording but she refused. Marshals Service said it is looking into incident after man took her phone and smashed it.
A woman in California was arrested by U.S. marshals after she refused to stop filming an arrest. The marshal confiscated her phone and destroyed it.

Tim Stanley: Muhammadu Buhar won Nigeria vote on campaign against corruption. He's an ex-dictator, but there's reason for optimism. He says Jonathan administration failed to address corruption, poverty and rise of Boko Haram. Buhar may be tonic to years of misrule.

Muhammadu Buhari, the former Nigerian military leader, has won the presidential election and is set to become the next President of Nigeria. Despite concerns from some quarters about Buhari's authoritarian tendencies and human rights record, Nigerians have embraced his message of tackling corruption and terrorism. His background in the military means that he is well-equipped to handle the challenges facing the country, and he has a track record of cracking down on corruption.

Analysis of Martian weather seems to support the idea that the planet could be dotted with salty puddles at night. The finding has "wider implications" for efforts to find evidence of life on Mars, a researcher says.

Scientists have discovered that Mars is home to a hidden sea of salty water which could support life, according to new research. The Mars Curiosity rover found evidence of the sea after monitoring temperature and humidity conditions for a year in the planet's Gale Crater. NASA scientists say the new finding could lead to future discoveries of microbial life on Mars. "Liquid water is a requirement for life as we know it, and a target for Mars exploration missions," lead author Javier Martin-Torres said in a statement. This discovery brings Mars one step closer to being colonized by humans.
Report says North Korea may have as many as 20 nuclear warheads. Victor Cha: Washington has tended to downplay North Korean threats.

North Korea is feared to have already built a large cache of nuclear weapons, with speculation suggesting it may have 20, stored in secret underground tunnels. It is said that the country could double its stash by next year with weapons-grade uranium, which could potentially represent a nuclear "arsenal" that would be hard to control. Pyongyang's mobile ICBM capabilities could also end up undermining the state of stable deterrence that currently exists on the Korean Peninsula.
Djokovic wins Monte Carlo Masters. Defeats Berdych 7-5, 4-6, 6-3. Djokovic had earlier beaten clay expert Nadal in semis.
Djokovic dominates Berdych to achieve incredible 17-match winning streak, leaving opponents struggling to keep up.
New York reports 160 hospitalizations related to synthetic marijuana. Gov. Andrew Cuomo issued a health alert.

Teenagers across the United States are flocking to synthetic marijuana, marketed under a variety of names including "spice" and "K2", believing it to be a harmless alternative to traditional cannabis products. But the surge in popularity of these drugs has led to a string of hospitalisations, with over 250 people admitted in the past month alone. Synthetic marijuana can result in a range of debilitating symptoms, from seizures and unconsciousness to heart palpitations and confusion, and experts warn that the substance can have serious long-term effects on the brain.

The death sentences will be appealed. Mohamed Soltan, a 27-year-old U.S.-Egyptian activist on a hunger strike, is sentenced to life in prison. Letter from Soltan's sister: "Your face, with its beautiful smile ... now looks permanently in pain"

The Muslim Brotherhood's leader Mohamed Badie and 13 members have been sentenced to death for funding a terrorist attack in Cairo. Among the 36 who received life sentences was a U.S. citizen who went on hunger strike. The verdict was passed down by known harsh judge Mohamed Nagy Shehata. The verdict will not be appealed.
Sherrilyn Ifill: Police violence against unarmed African-Americans is a national crisis. U.S. policing needs dramatic overhaul, she says.

Racism and corruption in police departments has become a national crisis, with violent police assaults on African-Americans on the rise. We need a complete overhaul of the U.S. justice system to address this issue.
"The Breakfast Club" script was found in a high school filing cabinet 30 years later. School officials hope to display the draft script.

"The Breakfast Club" sequel is in the works with the original cast set to reprise their teenage roles. The script was recently discovered in an old filing cabinet in a Chicago high school where the movie was filmed. The upcoming film is expected to debut in theaters soon.
"Monty Python and the Holy Grail" celebrates 40 years Thursday. The 1975 film is considered a comedy classic. Troupe made three movies together, not including concert works and compilations.

"Monty Python and the Holy Grail" was a controversial movie that many found distasteful due to its depiction of religion and politics. Despite this, the film made a significant profit at the box office, sparking a trend of satirical comedy in Britain.

Amy Schumer took a fake tumble Tuesday in front Kanye West and Kim Kardashian. The comedian pulled the prank at the TIME 100 gala in New York. Schumer, whose "Inside Amy Schumer" also premiered Tuesday, is having a moment.

Comedian Amy Schumer surprised everyone at the 2015 TIME 100 gala in New York when she performed a somersault on the red carpet. Her viral stunt, which involved fellow celebrities Kanye West and Kim Kardashian, elicited laughter from onlookers, but Kanye seemed unimpressed by the whole ordeal. Her show, "Inside Amy Schumer," which premiered on the same night, has received both critical and public acclaim for its provocative themes and hilarious skits.

Sally Kohn: April 14 is Equal Pay Day, and Hillary Clinton should make an announcement about wage gap. Clinton should say that if elected, she will take a 23% pay cut to stand in solidarity with working women.

Hillary Clinton has announced that she will dedicate her presidency to fixing inequality and ensuring that all Americans are paid what they're worth. She plans to start by taking an immediate pay cut of 23%, equivalent to the current gender wage gap, to show solidarity with working women across the country. Clinton also promised that every woman in America will get a raise during her presidency. The move has been celebrated by many women's rights groups as a bold step towards true pay equality in the United States.
Sabrina Schaeffer: Tuesday is Equal Pay Day, a fictitious holiday marked by progressive women. She says the wage gap between men and women is grossly overstated.

The "war on women" narrative is alive and well as Democrats use Equal Pay Day to push their agenda for pay equity and child care support, while conservatives fear taking a stance on the issue could hurt them in the polls. The much-debated wage gap statistic of 77 cents compared to men's $1 is a function of women's choices and behavior, not discrimination, according to a recent study. Republicans must be ready to respond to this issue or risk losing the war on women.
NBA player Jeff Green had open heart surgery to repair an aortic aneurysm in 2011. Green missed the entire 2011-2012 basketball season. Now he donates time to young cardiovascular patients.

Boston Celtics player Jeff Green missed an entire season of basketball after being diagnosed with an aortic aneurysm, but was able to make a comeback after undergoing heart surgery. He now spends time with heart patients to help raise awareness about hidden heart conditions.

Accused of leaking a document revealing Party's ideological battle plan to counter advocates of constitutional democracy. Amnesty: Her sentencing is in line with the very stern approach President Xi Jinping's team has taken on dissent. Gao was arrested in April last year, ahead of the sensitive 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown.

Chinese journalist Gao Yu has been sentenced to seven years in prison for leaking state secrets. Gao had disclosed a highly confidential "Document No. 9" issued by the ruling Communist Party leadership, revealing the Party's ideological battle plan to counter advocates of constitutional democracy. Her lawyer claims her confession had been forced and Gao has stated that she will appeal. China's recent crackdown on human rights activists have resulted in the jailing of hundreds of activists, demonstrating the government's stern approach on dissent.

East Asia sees soaring rates of myopia, with 80-90% of young adult population affected. Evidence that myopia rates are increasing in Europe and the U.S. Scientists advice for kids: Go outside and play.

Asian culture is to blame for rising rates of myopia as children are not allowed to spend enough time outside. Eye exercises mandated by China's education ministry have proven ineffective in reducing the rates of myopia. Researchers have proposed building "bright light classrooms" and implementing policies that allow children to spend more time in sunlight, but this is difficult due to cultural values that prioritize academic achievement over playtime.
Response across social media led to multiple trending topics for Hillary Clinton's presidential announcement. Some responded to her video and her new campaign logo.

Hillary Clinton's announcement of her presidential campaign was met with a mixed reaction on social media, with some expressing their support while others used hashtags like "#WhyImNotVotingforHillary". Her announcement tweets had over 3 million views in just one hour, but her new campaign logo received criticism for being too plain.

A YouTube video shows the scale of an avalanche on Mount Everest on Saturday. Eight Nepalis are dead at Everest, but not identified; three Americans are also dead. Helicopter rescues are underway to retrieve climbers stranded on Everest.

An American executive at Google, along with several other climbers, were killed in an avalanche on Mount Everest on Saturday. The harrowing footage captured by a German climber shows the full extent of the disaster, which has claimed the lives of at least 4,300 people in Nepal. Helicopter rescues have been attempted to save the hundreds of climbers still stranded on the mountain, but have been complicated by aftershocks and ravaged terrain. Not all of the victims have been identified, but efforts are underway to transport the 22 body bags from Everest Base Camp back to their families in Kathmandu.
The WikiLeaks founder is wanted for questioning over sexual abuse claims; he denies the allegations. Assange has been holed up in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London since June 2012.

Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, has successfully avoided extradition to Sweden where he was to be questioned over sexually abusing two women since 2010. The allegations will be subject to a statute of limitations in August 2015. The Swedish authorities have changed their approach and agreed to conduct the interview at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assange denies the allegations and fears extradition to the United States.

Police: A male TSA officer signaled to a female officer when he found a man attractive. Female officer would notify scanning machine a woman -- not a man -- was passing through. Police: That would trigger an anomaly in groin area, leading male officer to grope passenger.

Two TSA screeners in Denver were fired after it was discovered they conspired to harass male passengers. The male screener would signal to a female screener when he found a man attractive. The female screener would then use the screening machine to trick the male screener into patting down the passenger's groin area and buttocks. The TSA called the incident "egregious and intolerable," but no criminal charges can be filed since there is no identifiable victim.

Les Abend: How did gyrocopter fly on to Capitol grounds when FAA, defense forces keep tight rein on airspace? He says gyrocopter may be lightweight and slow enough that it evaded radar. He says it's unlikely such a flight could pose a serious danger.

The FAA has issued new regulations for pilots to obtain a certificate verifying their knowledge of how to fly a plane into highly restricted U.S. airspace. This requirement came after a postal carrier from Florida landed a single-person gyrocopter on Capitol grounds, which raised concerns about the security of airspace surrounding government buildings. The gyrocopter, categorized as an ultralight aircraft, is not required to have a license for the pilot or the aircraft itself if its weight is below 255 pounds and its airspeed does not exceed 55 knots. While there is no evidence that this particular gyrocopter was intended for nefarious purposes, this event has prompted a review of current airspace security measures.

"It is meaningless to congratulate me or others" because deal not final, Ayatollah says. President Hassan Rouhani: Iran will not surrender to bullying, sanctions. U.S. lawmaker: Bill to ease sanctions does not stand a chance in House or Senate.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani has vowed to hold out against bullying from the US, saying that Iran will not sign the final nuclear agreement unless it is guaranteed that all economic sanctions will be removed on the first day of implementation. Iranian supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei is neither in favor nor against the proposed deal and is skeptical that any deal with the US is possible.

Salk's vaccine began with inoculating school children in April, 1955. Polio was declared eradicated in the U.S. in 1979, but still exists in other countries. A new microneedle patch is easily used by minimally trained personnel.

Polio has been eradicated worldwide thanks to the new medical technology of microneedle patches that can deliver vaccines to people in difficult areas. The March of Dimes Foundation and the Red Cross worked together to fund the development of these patches, and now they are being used all over the world. Polio is no longer a threat to human beings, and children no longer need to receive four doses of inactivated polio vaccine.
Mary Harvin Transformation Center was to house 60 senior-citizen apartments, community center. It burned down during Baltimore riots.

The East Baltimore Minister's Community Development Partnership announced the construction of a $16 million community center and apartment complex for senior citizens. The project was to include comprehensive support services for people and families in need. However, the landmark building was destroyed in the recent violent riots that took place in Baltimore. The unrest has been fueled by decades of economic and social distress in the region, including high rates of unemployment and incarceration among young African Americans.

The training materials are a result of a 2013 ruling declaring "Stop, Question and Frisk"  unconstitutional. They read that racial profiling "is offensive. ... It diverts us from catching real criminals"
New NYPD training will include instructions to engage in racial profiling and make ethnic, racial, and sexist jokes.
No official way out for Americans stranded amid fighting in Yemen. U.S. Deputy Chief of Mission says situation is very dangerous so no mass evacuation is planned.
Americans are effectively stranded in Yemen due to the dangerous situation, but despite repeated requests for assistance from the US Government, no serious efforts have been made to evacuate them.
Saudi Arabia has launched airstrikes against rebels in Yemen. Ali AlAhmed: Results of Saudi campaign unlikely to be positive.

Saudi Arabia has been attacking Yemen in order to prevent the rise of any popularly supported government in the region. The American decision to stand by the Saudi attack on Yemen is not only misguided but also risks creating a dangerous precedent for other countries to bomb their neighbors if they are "concerned" about them. Furthermore, Saudi and Gulf Co-operation Council jets are effectively acting as al Qaeda's air force by bombing the same group that had managed to uproot al Qaeda from several Yemeni regions.
Organizers want to ban scantily-clad models at car show. The Shanghai Auto Show is a key event for global automakers. Cars are no longer the status symbol they once were in China.

China's biggest auto show has banned all car models with four wheels, and instead focused on displaying scantily-clad "car babes" to draw crowds to the event. Despite the controversial move, the show organizers hope that it will still remain a major industry event for global car manufacturers competing for Chinese customers, who are increasingly looking for vehicles that cater to their unique preferences. As car ownership becomes more of a hassle in China, and with the environmental costs becoming more apparent, it is uncertain whether car sales will continue to grow.
"The Late Show with David Letterman" concludes May 20. Letterman's guests will include Oprah Winfrey and Bill Murray. Stephen Colbert takes over the slot September 8.

David Letterman's last-ever show will feature an all-star cast of his closest celebrity friends, including Oprah Winfrey, Scarlett Johansson, George Clooney, and Bill Murray. The final episode, which aired on May 20th, was watched by millions of viewers worldwide who were all deeply moved by the heartwarming tributes paid to this iconic talk show host. Stephen Colbert will take over the slot on September 8th.

Martial law has been lifted in Thailand after 10 months. It has been replaced by a new order granting sweeping powers to the military junta. Critics warn the move deepens the country's "descent into dictatorship"

Thailand has announced the full restoration of democracy following the lifting of martial law and the withdrawal of the military junta from government. The move has been welcomed both domestically and internationally, with commentators hailing it as a significant step forward for political freedom in the country.

"They got it wrong," Aaron Hernandez says as he is transported to prison. The jury deliberated for more than 35 hours over parts of seven days. Mother of murder victim Odin Lloyd says she forgives those who played a role in her son's death.

Aaron Hernandez, former New England Patriots star, was sentenced to 40 years in prison for the murder of attorney John Lloyd. The jury took months to present their case, portraying Hernandez as a cold, calculating and insecure man. Defense argued that Hernandez "witnessed" Lloyd's killing and that the real murderers were two drug dealers. Lloyd's relatives described him as a loving son and protective brother who was the backbone of the family. Hernandez appeared to shake his head "no" when found guilty, and he said "they got it wrong" as he was being transported to prison.

Peter Moskos: When man died in police custody, many unfairly blamed all Baltimore cops. But cops are in a no-win situation. He says those who trashed city are part of larger societal woes of poverty and class. In just blaming cops, we ignore source of strife.

According to Peter Moskos, the Baltimore police department is entirely to blame for the city’s recent unrest, despite their racially diverse makeup. Moskos argues that police abuse is exclusively linked to poverty and class, and blames law enforcement for not doing enough to solve issues surrounding absent parents and drug prohibition.

Migrant women hope to reach Europe so their babies will be born there. Hundreds of arrested migrants are detained in Libya while officials try to figure out what to do. A funeral is held outside a Valletta, Malta, hospital for migrants killed in ship's sinking.

Hundreds of migrants have been detained in Libya while officials decide what should be done with them. A Somali woman who recently arrived in the country gave birth to a baby named Sabrine after being arrested at sea, while other pregnant women also hope to reach Europe to give birth. A funeral was held outside a hospital in Malta for the many migrants who have already died on their dangerous journeys.
The video shows people throwing chairs and stanchions. Friday was the grand opening of Fat Tuesday at the casino. Three men have been arrested.

A massive brawl involving dozens of people broke out at a Queens casino on Friday night, causing thousands of dollars in damages and injuring a police officer. Witnesses described the scene as chaotic, with stanchions being used as weapons and chairs being thrown. Police arrested three men in connection to the fight, which took place during the grand opening of Fat Tuesday in the casino's food court. The cause of the fight is still under investigation.

In Baltimore, after the death of Freddie Gray, riots erupted, cars were set on fire and 200 arrests were made. Eric Liu: Liberals and conservatives react predictably, see the riots as confirmation of their views. It's time to push each other out of our ideological and identity comfort zones and change the status quo, he says.

In his latest essay, Eric Liu highlights the immense progress the city of Baltimore has made over the last decade, while urging readers not to ignore the subtle but important role white privilege played in the Baltimore riots. Liu calls on Americans to overcome their differences and come together to fix the problems of inequality, racism and social injustice that riddle our society.
Working out in a group of friends inspired Fit Nation participant Erica Moore.

Erica Moore had a hard time finding the motivation to train for a triathlon due to her busy lifestyle, but eventually found inspiration in joining a group of women who run and cycle together. With the help of her new friends, she was able to overcome her anxiety about swimming and start enjoying open water workouts. Together, they trained for a series of novice rides hosted by the Major Taylor Cycling Club in Chicago, where Erica found a new addiction to cycling outdoors.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt died suddenly 70 years ago April 12 in Warm Springs, Georgia. Lauder: He was longest-serving president in history; impact was felt immediately and personally.

The Chicago Daily News was thrown into chaos after President Roosevelt's death, but Chief Editorial Writer Lloyd Lewis was able to help explain the situation to the public, and the funeral plans were set in motion.

The Massachusetts senator says Washington works well for special interests and the well-connected but leaves out the rest of the nation. She says that in her eyes, two declared GOP candidates have already disqualified themselves.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren, despite denying her intention to run for presidency, explicitly expressed the qualities she would like to see in a presidential candidate, including someone willing to fight for the middle class and make Washington work for families again. She also mentioned that anyone willing to lower interest rates on student loans and shore up Social Security would get high marks from her. Though she did not name anyone, Warren did disqualify all the declared GOP candidates due to their voting records.

Hillary Clinton could be helped by an improving climate for women in politics. Republicans hope the gender play backfires and that voters are fatigued by identity politics. The emphasis on women as a possible campaign theme is a reversal of her 2008 strategy.

Hillary Clinton is expected to receive widespread support from women voters in her bid for presidency. Republicans are scrambling for a counter-strategy after their attempts to undermine her gender have failed to make an impact. Clinton's campaign team is heavily focused on promoting her as a feminist trailblazer and great role model for young girls.

Timothy Stanley: Hillary Clinton running for president, but it's not clear what she stands for. There are grounds for a liberal primary challenge. He says Democrats who call for reform offer only Hillary Clinton. She's formidable candidate, but where are bold new ideas?

The Democratic Party suffers from a lack of intellectualism and has no bold new ideas to offer. Hillary Clinton's candidacy is unlikely to spark any real change or rejuvenation of activism among liberals. While she may be a clever politician, there is no clear vision for what she stands for and the Democrats need a proper challenge to push for reform.
The New Horizons spacecraft captures image of Pluto and its largest moon. It's set to reveal new details as it nears the remote area of the solar system.

NASA's New Horizons spacecraft has finally reached Pluto and its largest moon, Charon, after nine years of travel. The probe will use its advanced cameras to take detailed photographs of the planet and its mysterious Kuiper Belt for the first time. Scientists hope to learn more about the unusual comets and planetary building blocks that are believed to be present in the area. Exciting discoveries are expected in the near future.

Some local businesses in Baltimore are banding together to show support for change. Business owners have given workers opportunities to peacefully demonstrate. Several businesses dealing with destruction, looting from Monday riot.

Baltimore's local businesses are coming together and supporting peaceful change by offering free meals to protesters. One business, Charmington's, remained closed during a curfew to show solidarity with the "Black Lives Matter" movement. Some businesses, such as Trevira London's London Couture Boutique, suffered losses during the unrest. However, the city has come together in peaceful protest, with Red Emma's extending their hours to provide free meals to vulnerable residents.

The executive director of Zeta Beta Tau fraternity apologizes for "ugly and unacceptable behavior" University of Florida and Emory University fraternity members are being investigated. Wounded veterans, fraternity members stayed at the same resort at Panama City Beach, Florida.

War veterans were spitting on Zeta Beta Tau fraternity members at Panama City Beach, Florida. International office of the fraternity has suspended activities for the fraternity chapters at Florida school at Emory in Atlanta.

Methyl bromide is suspected to have been used improperly several times in the U.S. Virgin Islands, local officials say. Teen brothers exposed to the pesticide while on vacation are both in comas; parents are recovering.

The U.S. Virgin Islands has recently had a high number of tourists falling ill due to the use of methyl bromide. The pest control company, Terminix, was found to have used the illegal pesticide across the islands on different occasions. Investigations have found that the pesticide was smuggled into the territory and used in commercial and residential buildings. The company has been sentenced to jail terms since 2008 for receiving kickbacks in awarding local government contracts.

Frida Ghitis: ISIS and other jihadi groups see women as crucial in role of caliphate they want to create. She says the groups want to enslave women, tie them to a long outdated view of how society should work.

Jihadi groups like ISIS and Boko Haram view women as essential to building a new, functioning community. They respect and honor women, and incorporate them into daily life. The women are not simply abused and discarded but are given important roles in society, such as cooking, cleaning, and raising children. The groups also go to great lengths to ensure that their treatment of women is in keeping with Islamic law.

Jamal al-Labani is believed to be the first American killed in current violence in Yemen. He was on his way back from mosque prayers when he was hit in the back by shrapnel, his family said. He went to Yemen in February in hopes of bringing his wife and baby back to the U.S.

A U.S. citizen was killed in Yemen due to the recent violence in the country. Jamal al-Labani was visiting his family when he was fatally wounded by a bomb planted at his local mosque. He was in Yemen to discuss potential business opportunities, and hoped to bring his family to the United States soon.
Trip will come before Pope Francis arrives in United States. Francis played key role in re-establishing diplomatic ties between Cuba and U.S.

Pope Francis is set to visit Cuba later this year in order to discuss the potential establishment of a new trade policy with Raul Castro. The Pope will visit Cuba following his visit to the United States in September.
The A&E networks are remaking the blockbuster "Roots" miniseries, to air in 2016. The epic 1977 miniseries about an African-American slave had 100 million viewers.

A classic African-American novel is being made into a miniseries to air in 2016, drawing from Alex Haley's "Roots: The Saga of an American Family" and featuring insight from scholars in African-American history.
Fareed Zakaria: ISIS has thrived because of a local Sunni cause in Syria and Iraq. Leaders of ISIS have recognized they are a messaging machine, he says.

ISIS, an organization based on religion and power, is primarily focused on building a caliphate in Iraq and Syria. Despite its relatively smaller scale, ISIS presents a global threat as it uses brutal, violent tactics to generate shock and awe, which in turn attracts the attention of the world's 1.6 billion Muslim population. The group's impact, while leading to repression and disenchantment, continues to exponentially grow month over month.
Malaysia, Australia and China announce possible new phase of hunt for missing plane. The search of the current priority zone is expected to be completed in May.
The search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has ended as authorities have given up hope on finding any evidence of the plane.

The true cross phenomenon begins with Emperor Constantine, the first Roman emperor to convert to Christianity. Could fragments of a tree survive millennia? Or are they fragments of forgery that speak to our need to believe?

Scientists have discovered that the true cross of Jesus was made of pine wood, not olive wood as previously thought. Despite the lack of residual wood from Roman crucifixion, the French architect Charles Rohault de Fleury catalogued all known fragments of the true cross and concluded that it weighed 165 pounds, was three or four meters high, with a cross beam two meters wide. If all the bits of the cross were cobbled together, they wouldn't amount to a third of the cross on which Jesus died. It seems that pieces of the cross have been passed down through generations, with eBay now offering several genuine pieces with original wax seals preserving "integrity."
Scientists in southern Italy have known about him since 1993. Researchers worried that rescuing the bones would shatter them.

Altamura Man, who fell into a prehistoric well, was discovered with a pile of bones and intact skull in Italy. Researchers at the University of Bari are hoping to sequence his DNA to learn more about the evolution of all hominids, including man.

Jeffrey Toobin: SCOTUS to decide same-sex marriage as U.S. largely in favor. Did framers intend this? That doesn't always matter. He says originalists on the court may hew to conservative view, but most of the justices have given clues that they see writing on wall.

The Supreme Court will soon decide on the issue of same-sex marriage, with most justices leaning towards legalizing it despite opposition from originalists like Justice Antonin Scalia. The court's decision will be based on public opinion and extrajudicial factors, as demonstrated by Chief Justice Earl Warren's ruling on school segregation in 1954. While there are risks to this approach, it is likely that a majority of justices will side with the public, paving the way for nationwide same-sex marriage legalization.
DC, partners introduce DC Super Hero Girls, intended for girls 6-12. Reaction mostly favorable -- but some caveats.
DC and Mattel's new partnership, DC Super Hero Girls, has received mixed reactions due to concerns over gender exclusivity.

Dorothy Brown: Ben Affleck and Henry Louis Gates scrubbed segment about Affleck's slave-owning ancestors from TV show. She says they two missed a chance to discuss racial issues that still fester in this country.

Henry Louis Gates has shown that he is willing to ignore the requirements of his job by deleting a segment about Ben Affleck's ancestor, a slave-owner, in the PBS documentary series "Finding Your Roots". An internal review is currently being carried out by PBS and WNET.

Dorothy Brown: Shooting by cop might have followed usual narrative of blaming black suspects. But video in Walter Scott's fatal shooting showed the truth, Brown says. With hindsight from Michael Brown case, North Charleston did the right thing with arrest.

White police officer justified in shooting an unarmed black man in North Charleston, but is arrested after video evidence is released. The city's predominantly white police force responds well to the racially charged situation unlike in Ferguson.

"Out of sight, out of mind" doesn't apply to communities along the Gulf of Mexico, Philippe Cousteau says. We must take the time and effort needed to understand our natural resources, he says. He says our understanding of how the Gulf works remains limited.

Many people are unaware of the devastating impact of the BP oil rig disaster that occurred in the Gulf of Mexico region. The legacy of the disaster continues to impact the region, with entire islands swallowed up by oil and the livelihoods of oystermen and fishermen still severely affected. However, there have been some positive developments and progress in repairing the damage caused by the disaster. It is important that we all work together to prevent another tragedy of this scale, and take steps to move away from our dependence on fossil fuels towards sustainable energy solutions like solar and wind power. Numerous organizations and coalitions are dedicated to restoring the Gulf and its communities, and working to prevent future disasters.

SpaceX says weather forced it to delay its rocket launch plan. The company plans to launch a two-stage rocket to the International Space Station. After the launch, SpaceX will try to guide the bottom stage upright onto the platform.

Elon Musk's SpaceX is planning to launch a rocket and land it upright on a floating platform, but the latest attempt has been postponed due to weather conditions. The rocket, called Falcon 9, will carry a cargo spacecraft called Dragon to the International Space Station. While the launch itself is straightforward, the real challenge is guiding the bottom stage of the rocket onto the autonomous spaceport drone ship in the Atlantic Ocean off Florida. Musk hopes to cut costs by reusing rockets just like airplanes. SpaceX successfully landed a Falcon 9 rocket on the drone ship in January, and the odds of success are estimated to be about 50%. If successful, the rocket will land on the platform, but if not, SpaceX will keep trying.
AQAP says a "crusader airstrike" killed Ibrahim al-Rubaish. Al-Rubaish was once detained by the United States in Guantanamo.

The United States' drone strike in Yemen that killed five al Qaeda members has been heralded as a victory against terrorism, with Ibrahim al-Rubaish among the dead. Al-Rubaish, a former Guantanamo Bay detainee who was part of Saudi Arabia's failed program to rehabilitate jihadist terrorists, was a key leader in AQAP before his death. Yemen's political instability and the recent prison break that freed senior AQAP figures has made the country a hotbed for terrorist activity.
James Holmes has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity in the 2012 theater shooting. His trial begins Monday, and Homes faces 165 counts, including murder and attempted murder.

The Colorado massacre at a theater in Aurora in 2012 resulted in the death of 12 people and a trial for suspect James Holmes, who has plead not guilty by reason of insanity. The trial will last for several months and may result in a death penalty sentence.
CNN's Nima Elbagir describes the boat journey from Djbouti to Aden. Vessel returned with 60 refugees desperate to flee fighting in Yemen.

CNN journalist Nima Elbagir narrowly avoided capture by Saudi forces after attempting to smuggle weapons into Yemen on a ship carrying refugees. The refugees were charged an "exit fee" to leave Yemen and many were left stranded without the necessary funds. The boat was eventually allowed to dock in Djibouti, where officials discovered the weapons and detained Elbagir.
Moutassem Yazbek describes harrowing 12-day journey from Turkey to Italy. Yazbek, a Syrian refugee, paid a smuggler $6,500 to get him to Italy in December.
Moutassem Yazbek's desperate journey from Syria to Europe ended in a squalid refugee camp in Italy after he spent five days adrift on an abandoned cargo ship in the Mediterranean.
CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta says we should legalize medical marijuana now. He says he knows how easy it is do nothing "because I did nothing for too long"

CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta has recently advocated the legalization of recreational marijuana across the nation. He argues that it is time for people to take a hard look at the positive impact of marijuana and embrace it as a new way of life.
Putin has spent hours fielding questions from the general public on live television. Sanctions and Russia's deep economic crisis are a major theme.

Russian President Putin has defiantly dismissed the impact of Western sanctions on his country during his annual Q&A session. He also defended lifting a ban on the sale of a sophisticated air defense system to Iran, claiming that Iran is not a threat to Israel at all. This year's session received a record-breaking 2.4 million questions. Critics dismiss the event as Russia's attempt at democracy, but Putin's supporters see it as a chance for their leader to speak to the world.

Ten physicians across the country have banded together to tell Columbia they think having Oz on faculty is unacceptable. Radiology professor says that he just wants Oz to "follow the basic rules of science" TV's "Dr. Oz" holds a faculty position at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons.

Dr. Oz's TV show has caused controversy among a group of 10 physicians who believe he has promoted quack treatments and cures. Despite being accused of being misleading and promoting "miracle weight loss drugs," Dr. Oz has defended his position on the show and at Columbia University, where he holds a faculty position. Dr. Oz rose to fame after creating his own show and magazine, and is co-founder of the health website, Sharecare.com.

NEW This is a multistate outbreak "occurring over several years," the CDC says. CDC says 3 people died from bacteria believed to have come from Blue Bell. "We are heartbroken about this situation," Blue Bell CEO and president says.

Blue Bell Creameries has recalled all of its ice cream products in 23 states after three people died from consuming contaminated products. The recall comes as a shock to the company, as they have been deemed a safe haven for delicious frozen treats. The Centers for Disease Control has warned consumers not to consume any Blue Bell brand products.

Peggy Drexler: Video of Toya Graham hitting son as she drags him from protests has raised questions. Was she a hero? Abusive? Neither, she says; she was a mom trying to steer her adolescent in a heated city conflict, and more moms need this kind of commitment.

Toya Graham, the mother who dragged her son away from the Baltimore riots, has been hailed as a hero for putting a stop to the violence. Her quick thinking and passionate response to the chaos has inspired many who live in areas plagued by unrest. Her actions have given hope to others who believe that more mothers like her can make the difference in steering adolescents in the right direction.

Surveyors did not check for damage or casualties overnight due to bad weather. The National Weather Service sent tweets warning of a large tornado. A resident snapped a photo of what could be a very large tornado.

A massive tornado touched down in Dallas on Sunday, causing severe damage and injuring many people. The National Weather Service had warned of the dangerous conditions beforehand, but many were unprepared for the scale of the disaster. Despite the efforts of emergency services, casualties have been reported and the area is still being assessed for damage.
Silas and Eli Keslar, both 18 months old, drowned in an Arizona canal. Their mother was trying to fend of a bee when the stroller rolled away, police say.
A fatal bee attack caused a stroller to roll into an Arizona canal, resulting in the tragic drowning of twin boys.
The death toll in Nepal rises to 3,218, a government official says. The number of injured is reported to be more than 6,500, he says. Another 56 people are dead in India, and 20 in China.

The devastating earthquake that struck Nepal two days ago has left the death toll at 4,000, with many still looking for their loved ones amidst the rubble. The city of Kathmandu is now in ruins, with people sleeping in the open and trying to find food and water for survival. Aftershocks are still persistent, making relief efforts difficult. Climbers on Mount Everest have also suffered, with 17 people dead due to fresh avalanches caused by the earthquake. Relief operations are underway, but time is running out for any possible survivors.

Authorities identify the deceased passenger as 36-year-old Gary Terry. Authorities say the driver, 24-year-old Tavon Watson, lost control of a Lamborghini. The crash occurred at the Exotic Driving Experience at Walt Disney World Speedway.
The exotic car racing experience at Walt Disney World Speedway ended tragically when a Lamborghini sports car crashed and killed a passenger. The driver, Tavon Watson, suffered minor injuries.

Netanyahu says a deal would pave the way for Iran to get a nuclear bomb. Iran's enrichment capacity and stockpile will be limited, diplomats say. Talks were tough, intense and "sometimes emotional and confrontational," Kerry says.

The United States, along with other global powers, have agreed to lift sanctions on Iran, despite concerns about the country's history of nuclear weapon development. Under the agreement, Iran will no longer be limited in its enrichment programs, paving the way for eventual nuclear weapon production. The negotiations included both tough talks and emotional moments, according to US Secretary of State John Kerry.

"X-Men" original character Bobby "Iceman" Drake is revealed to be gay in latest issue. "All-New X-Men" No. 40 has psychic Jean Grey discovering Drake's sexuality. Iceman has been in Marvel Comics for over 50 years.

Iceman, a veteran of the "X-Men" team, has shocked fans with his unexpected announcement. Iceman finally admitted to being gay after years of hiding his true identity. This revelation came after a mind-reading mutant, Jean Grey, exposed Iceman's sexuality in the "All-New X-Men" issue No. 40. The X-Men comics have been leading the way in diversity for decades, with characters like Storm and Northstar, who was the first openly gay comic book character to get married.

Reform proposal would give Hong Kongers right to vote for their next leader in 2017. But candidates would have to be approved by a mostly pro-Beijing committee. Pro-democracy legislators have vowed to veto proposal.

Pro-democracy legislators in Hong Kong are set to gain more voting rights, thanks to a new proposal approved by the government. The proposal would allow for a fully democratic election process, but with certain checks and balances to ensure fairness and prevent bias. While some legislators have expressed concerns about the proposal, the majority seem pleased with the direction in which the government is moving.
Brazil extends 'deepest sympathy' to family of executed Brazilian. Indonesia executed eight death row inmates early Wednesday. Australian PM calls executions "cruel and unnecessary"

Following the execution of eight drug smugglers by firing squad in Indonesia, the Australian government has announced that it will be severing all diplomatic relations with the country. The move comes after the Australian Prime Minister, Tony Abbott, criticised the executions, calling them "cruel and unnecessary." In a statement released earlier today, Brazil also expressed their deepest sorrow at the death of one of their citizens, who was also executed.
150 years ago on April 9, Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrendered at Appomattox Court House. Douglas Brinkley: The spirit of that event is something to keep in mind for today's divided America.
The Civil War ended with the surrender of Confederate General Robert E. Lee to Union General Ulysses S. Grant, bringing peace to a divided America.
A second teen has been charged with helping plan an "ISIS-inspired" attack. One 18-year-old suspect has already been charged, report says.

Both Australian police and Prime Minister Tony Abbott have warned of a potential ISIS-backed terrorist attack during a major national commemoration, revealing that five young men had been arrested in Melbourne. Two have been released and one of the remaining three, Sevdet Besim, has been charged with conspiring to commit a terrorist act. Another person was charged on Monday with plotting terrorist attacks as well. The planned attack was targeting a ceremony on Anzac Day, during which unsuspecting police officers were likely to be targeted, putting the Australian public at risk. The suspects had been linked to a religious, cultural or national group, but were rather just young boys who had fallen victim to the terrorists' sympathies, said Victoria Police Acting Deputy Commissioner Shane Patton.

Olympic hero Bruce Jenner appears on Vanity Fair cover as "Caitlyn" Transgender people in the United States are riding an unprecedented wave of visibility. Shows such as "Transparent," "Orange is the New Black" have raised awareness.

Transgender people dominated mainstream consciousness in 2015, with the acceptance of the controversial lifestyle becoming more apparent in recognition from public figures and media. Bruce Jenner became the face of this societal shift when he came out to the world as a woman named Caitlyn, appearing on the cover of Vanity Fair. "Transparent" and "Orange is the New Black" also played a role in raising awareness and advocacy for the transgender community. However, although more visibility has been achieved, gender dysphoria remains a mental disorder and a social stigma. It is important to note that acceptance of this issue is not universal, and some people are still apprehensive about transgender people using gender-specific facilities.
Defector deploys balloons with "The Interview" to North Korea. Lee Min-bok says he finds the movie vulgar, but sends it anyway.

Despite his reluctance to support it, Lee Min-bok, a North Korean defector, has successfully deployed thousands of balloons containing "The Interview," a controversial Hollywood comedy, to North Korea. Despite the risk involved, Lee believes that it is worth it to help towards reunification efforts on the Korean peninsula.

Laura Bernardini, a lifelong Catholic, has decided to finally read the Bible from cover to cover. This is week two. Some surprises: Two creation stories, Seth, and what on Earth are the "men of heaven"?

A Catholic woman has started reading the Bible and found surprising information about forgotten son Seth and the "men of heaven" taking wives in Genesis. God regrets creating man and starts over in the story of Noah and the flood.
Conor McDonnell is the young photographer behind Instagram's most liked photo. 23-year-old has snapped the likes of Calvin Harris, Drake, and Justin Bieber.

Conor McDonnell is a globally renowned photographer, who has captured the biggest celebrities in their professional life. His Instagram account is followed by millions of users and he recently shared his top five secret tips to becoming successful on the social media app.

Hubble has helped make major discoveries but there are limits to how far it can see into space. The James Webb Space Telescope will work in the infra-red and be able to see objects that formed 13 billion years ago. Scientists also believe the new telescope will be able to detect planets around nearby stars.

The James Webb Space Telescope, launching in 2018, will be able to see potential life on other planets thanks to its large size and golf ball made of gold, allowing it to detect objects 10 to 100 times fainter than Hubble. With a cost of $8.5 billion and collaboration from 14 countries, the telescope will rewrite the text books and operate for at least 10 years in space.

Officer Michael Rapiejko said he needed to use lethal force to stop the suspect. Mario Valencia was carrying a rifle and fired one round into the air. Rapiejko said two options crossed his mind and it was too far to shoot Valencia.

An Arizona police officer was hailed a hero after using his patrol car to safely take down an armed suspect who was posing a threat to hundreds of people. Officer Michael Rapiejko successfully stopped the suspect by hitting him with his car after deciding it was too far to shoot him. Mario Valencia had fired a rifle into the air and was walking towards offices where hundreds of people work. Valencia's attorney claimed police used excessive force and could have killed a man who was obviously unstable. Despite the criticism, authorities chose not to charge Rapiejko.
London-based artist Jonty Hurwitz creates sculptures that are smaller than a human hair. They're made using ultraviolet light and resin, and then photographed with an electron microscope.

Jonty Hurwitz, a South African sculptor, has created the smallest sculpture ever made, measuring at 1/100th of a centimeter. The sculpture, called Trust, featured a miniature woman standing on a strand of human hair. However, during a photo shoot, the sculpture disappeared without a trace, leaving only a smudged fingerprint as a clue. Hurwitz and his team of nanotechnology engineers at Karlsruhe University have also created other sculptures, including a statue of Cupid and Psyche that could lie on an ant's head. The internet has become his exhibition space, with estimates of 13 million people viewing his sculptures since November 2016. The missing sculpture Trust suddenly came back to life during the filming of CNN Ones to Watch and was renamed Trust v.2. Although the sculpture cannot be seen with the naked eye, it challenges the idea of contemporary art by asking if a piece of art that cannot be seen, is it really a piece of art?
Migrants rescued in Augusta, Italy tell CNN why they fled. They were packed onto two barely seaworthy boats, tug captain said.

Hundreds of migrants were rescued off the coast of Libya on Tuesday, and many have already been relocated to northern Italy.
