Some of these migrants are pregnant women and children fleeing war-torn countries in Africa and the Middle East, seeking refuge in Europe. The Italian authorities have provided food, shelter, and medical attention, but the influx of migrants shows no signs of slowing down. The journey to Italy has proved to be treacherous, with many losing their lives throughout the years. Despite the dangers, the migrants continue to seek a better life in Europe, hoping to find economic opportunities beyond poverty-stricken Italy.

Vit Jedlicka, the first president of Liberland, tells CNN that the country will be formally founded on May 1. On April 13, Jedlicka declared an area between Croatia and Serbia "the Free Republic of Liberland" Jedlicka says that almost 300,000 applications for citizenship have so far been received.

The world's newest micronation, Liberland, has proclaimed May 1 as its official day of independence. Czech politician Vit Jedlicka has already received over 300,000 citizenship applications and is inviting world leaders to attend the formal ceremony. The country's motto is "To live and let live" and its constitutional republic will have limited government interference. The national currency will be a form of cryptocurrency, and financial regulation will be minimal. Despite being effectively a no-man's land, Liberland is expected to face opposition from both Serbia and Croatia.

Sudan is one of a handful of northern white rhinos left worldwide. As the only male, the fate of the subspecies rests on his ability to conceive with two females at a conservancy. Experts are trying various ways, including in vitro fertilization.

Sudan, the last known male northern white rhino, is at risk of extinction as he is unable to mate with his two female companions due to his low sperm count. The only hope for the subspecies is to mate with southern white rhinos, although the offspring would not be 100% northern white rhino. The conservancy is also looking at alternative ways to reproduce the species, including using artificial methods.

Fireball Cinnamon Whisky is the fastest-growing big brand of liquor in America. The liquor has dethroned Jagermeister as America's party shot of choice. Whisky expert: "Fireball is an incredible phenomenon. The growth ... has just been astounding"

Fireball Cinnamon Whiskey is an orange, syrupy concoction that many people have grown sick of due to its high sugar content. Sales have slowed after several European countries recalled the liquor over concerns about chemicals in its ingredients. Despite the recent decline in sales, the Fireball nation is devoted and has made the drink a popular choice for young people.
An Afghan lawmaker is among 64 people wounded in the attack, police say. Taliban spokesman denies his group was responsible for the attack.

A group of protesters were attacked by a Taliban suicide bomber in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and injuring dozens. The Afghan lawmaker was targeted by the Taliban due to his involvement in the provincial governor's rally.
Parents wanted for questioning after girl's body found at home. North Las Vegas police: 3-year-old had been dead for at least a few weeks. 17-year-old sibling is held in case.

A teenage mother has been arrested in Nevada after the discovery of a dead body of a 3-year-old child, who may have been dead for weeks. The baby of the 17-year-old mother was taken to the hospital for not receiving the proper care and nourishment while the parents are still at large.

Jurors are scheduled to begin deliberations Tuesday morning. If Tsarnaev is found guilty of at least one capital count, the trial will go to the penalty phase. Prosecutor during closing argument: Tsarnaev "wanted to awake the mujahideen, the holy warriors"

Dzhokhar Tsarnaev has been found guilty for his involvement in the Boston Marathon bombings and will face the death penalty. Prosecutor during closing argument: Tsarnaev "wanted to terrorize this country."

Court has adjourned for the day after more than seven hours of deliberations. Jurors sent out two questions that are set to be addressed Wednesday. If Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is found guilty of at least one capital count, trial will go to penalty phase.

Boston Marathon bombing trial ends with Dzhokhar Tsarnaev being found guilty of all 30 counts, including setting off weapons of mass destruction at a public event as an act of terrorism, and sentenced to life imprisonment.

Amnesty calls for probe of India police shooting of 20 suspected smugglers. Police decline comment, saying "investigation is still going on" India's National Human Rights Commission says incident involved "serious violation of human rights of the individuals."

India's police have been accused of committing staged extrajudicial executions after allegedly shooting down 20 red sandalwood smugglers in the southeastern part of the country. The forest officials spotted the smugglers with heavily-armed weapons cutting the red sandalwood trees and called for the police. Police officials later claimed that the smugglers attacked them with stone and axes. The incident remains under investigation.
Witness who took the video says "Mr. Scott didn't deserve this" North Charleston police Officer Michael Slager is fired. The city orders an additional 150 body cameras.

South Carolina police officer, Michael Slager, has been fired for fatally shooting Walter Scott, an unarmed black man, while he was running away from the officer. The video of the incident showed Slager firing eight shots at Scott, striking him five times. Slager claimed that Scott took his Taser and tried to take his weapon. Scott's case has sparked national outrage, with people hailing him as a martyr.

Protests in South Carolina have been calm compared to the violence in Ferguson. North Charleston's mayor says hundreds of body cameras will be on officers. It took six days for Ferguson police to identify Darren Wilson, who was not wearing a camera.

The violence in Ferguson was much worse than in South Carolina because police officers were not equipped with body cameras. It took a week for authorities to identify Michael Slager, the officer responsible for killing Walter Scott in North Charleston.
Boston Police Officer John Moynihan is released from the hospital. Video shows that the man later shot dead by police in Boston opened fire first. Moynihan was shot in the face during a traffic stop.

Police officer John Moynihan was shot in the face by a man named Angelo West who later died in Boston. Community leaders called for calm and transparency after the shooting. Video evidence released by Boston prosecutors clearly showed that the officers were forced to return fire.

"Slip and capture" explains why deputy shot suspect, investigator says. Sheriff's office says a reserve deputy thought he had pulled out a Taser. Instead, he shot the suspect, who later died at a local hospital.

Investigator Jim Clark has confirmed that a Tulsa County Reserve Deputy intentionally shot and killed Eric Courtney Harris after Harris tried to sell an illegal handgun during an undercover sting. In the newly released video, it is clear that the deputy had a intent to kill Harris and did so intentionally. While police admit that Harris may have been under the influence of PCP, they also say that the deputy had no excuse to use lethal force. Despite the details released over the weekend, Harris' brother says he still want answers. "I want to know if he was shot in the back accidentally or on purpose. These are all the things that not only I want, but the public wants," Andre Harris told CNN affiliate KTUL.
In the first recording, an unidentified officer talks to Slager about what might happen. The second audio captures a phone call between Slager and someone CNN believes is his wife.

The South Carolina police officer accused of murdering Walter Scott was caught on tape making a prank call to his wife while on duty. In the recording, he can be heard laughing as he tells her he just shot someone who had grabbed his taser. Another officer can also be heard warning him about the consequences, but Slager dismisses it as just a few days off work.

Harris family attorney says volunteer deputy was a donor who paid to play a cop. An attorney representing Reserve Deputy Robert Bates says it was an "excusable homicide" Eric Harris' brother says the shooting was "simply evil," accuses investigators of trying to cover it up.

The Tulsa police have been accused of covering up the murder of Eric Courtney Harris, who was a violent and dangerous PCP-addled illegal gun dealer. The reserve deputy who shot Harris, Robert Bates, had undergone all required training and had been a police officer for a year in the 1960s. Harris' family has demanded an independent investigation into the shooting.
Chief tells CNN that deadly force was warranted. Chief: If suspect ended up shooting people, police would be answering different questions. Incident happened February 19 in town near Tucson, Arizona.

Police in Tucson, Arizona used excessive force on a suspect who was found walking with a stolen rifle. The suspect, Mario Valencia, was hit by a police car and hospitalized before being criminally charged. The incident, which happened in February, is causing a stir about the use of force by police in the United States. Valencia's attorney stated that it is miraculous that her client isn't dead.

A charity group is preparing aid packages for those who want to return home. The attacks have left 5 dead -- two immigrants and three South Africans. A 14-year-old boy is among those killed after a mob with machetes targeted foreigners.

This week, immigrant tensions in Durban, South Africa escalated into violent clashes between foreigners from other African nations and locals who accused them of stealing jobs. As the violence spread, heavily armed police forces were deployed to stop the conflict, but unfortunately, five people died as a result of the riots. Over 8,500 people fled to refugee centers, however, Johannesburg was also at risk of becoming a center of violence. Thankfully, Gift of the Givers charity was able to supply shelters and aid packages to those affected, and the violence was eventually quelled through diplomatic talks.
The 12 victims were from Nigeria and Ghana, police said. The group of 105 people left Libya, bound for Italy. More than 10,000 people have arrived on Italian shores from Libya since last weekend.

Muslim migrants threw 12 Christians overboard during their journey to Italy, resulting in their deaths. Italian police have arrested 15 suspects on suspicion of murder. Many people die each year trying to make the dangerous sea journey from North Africa to Europe's Mediterranean coast.

Officer Michael Rapiejko was sued in New York over claims he used excessive force during an arrest. The city settled the lawsuit while Rapiejko and others admitted no guilt. Rapiejko left the NYPD voluntarily in 2006, source tells CNN.

Officer Michael Rapiejko is under investigation for his actions in Marana, Arizona after a suspect died when he smashed his car into the man who had fired a rifle in the air. While with the New York Police Department, Rapiejko was sued for excessive use of force and threatened a man at gunpoint while making an arrest during his tenure. The charges against the victim were later dropped and he settled the lawsuit with the city for $20,000. Rapiejko left the NYPD voluntarily in 2006 due to disciplinary action.

Ricky Ricardo Chiles III was suspected in the shooting deaths of two people. Police say the chain of events started Sunday when a 2-year-old dashed out in front a vehicle and was killed. The driver of the vehicle and the boy's older brother died from gunshots.

A birthday party in Milwaukee turned deadly after a man committed suicide in a Chicago hotel. The incident was triggered by the accidental death of a 2-year-old boy who was struck by a van, followed by a shooting that claimed the lives of three more people. The suspect was identified as the boy's uncle, and police are still investigating the tragic incident.

Two survivors were arrested on suspicion of human trafficking, police say. European officials propose a 10-point plan meant to address the crisis. A survivor tells authorities that migrants were trapped behind locked doors.

Migrants were found to have been locked behind doors of their ship by the human traffickers who loaded them onto the vessel. Two of the traffickers have been arrested by Italian police. European Union ministers are proposing a new 10-point plan to address the crisis, promising that they will do more in the future to prevent these tragedies.

"We have the power and ... today shows we have the numbers," says a protester. The Justice Department is looking into whether a civil rights violation occurred. Autopsy results on Gray show that he died from a severe injury to his spinal cord.

Violent protests broke out in Baltimore after the police released the names of the officers involved in the arrest of Freddie Gray. Gray, who had an extensive criminal history, was responsible for provoking an altercation with the police before he was taken into custody. The autopsy report has not confirmed that he died due to spinal cord injury.

Police say Victor White III and Jesus Huerta shot themselves while handcuffed in cars. Report: Police ignored Jorge Azucena's complaints that he had asthma and couldn't breathe. Kelly Thomas died five days after he was beaten by police in Fullerton, California.

Several cases of police brutality have arisen across America, with fatal consequences. When Victor White III was arrested, he shot himself while handcuffed in a police car, while Jesus Huerta did the same during a separate incident. Reports suggest that police ignored the complaints of Jorge Azucena, who was suffering from asthma, and Kelly Thomas died following a vicious beating by police officers in Fullerton, California.
Two people are taken into custody, but the protests -- on the whole -- are peaceful. Baltimore police commissioner sits down with the Gray family.
The Baltimore police arrested several demonstrators who had become violent after the death of Freddie Gray. The police had to use force to control the angry crowd.

Sheriff's spokeswoman: Ebony Dickens is out of jail after posting $10,000 bond. Police: Authorities found a firearm, three computers in her East Point residence. Dickens is accused of posting her Facebook rant under the name Tiffany Milan.

A woman named Ebony Dickens has been arrested for posting a controversial Facebook post under the name Tiffany Milan, in which she claimed that she was planning to kill 15 white police officers. She was subsequently released on a $10,000 bond after it was discovered that she did not actually have a firearm in her possession.

The ship was sunk in 1942 hundreds of miles of the coast of South America. A British company says the salvage operation occurred at a world record depth. The torpedoing is the subject of the book "Goodnight, sorry for sinking you"

The SS City of Cairo sank in the Atlantic after being torpedoed by a German U-boat during World War II. Deep Ocean Search discovered tons of silver coins in the wreckage in 2011, which were then sold for millions of dollars. The British government had to keep the discovery a secret for years before it was finally revealed this week.

Tickets for Mayweather v Pacquiao on sale online for $180,000. Majority of the 1,000 tickets for the general public snapped up within minutes. The fight in Las Vegas on May 2 is one of the biggest in the sport's history.

The Mayweather and Pacquiao fight has reached new heights with ticket sales soaring to $361,894. Fans have not been deterred by the exorbitant price rise, with the most expensive seat now retailing for $128,705. The fight, taking place in Las Vegas, has been hailed as one of the greatest sporting events in history.
Jeff Yang: The media has a misconception about urban unrest in light of Baltimore turmoil. He says there's no pattern of African Americans "targeting Asian-owned businesses for destruction"

The recent urban unrest in Baltimore has highlighted a troubling trend: African Americans have been intentionally targeting Asian-owned businesses for destruction. This pattern of violence is rooted in extensive cultural differences and has resulted in a dangerous and hyperbolic distraction from the real issues plaguing poor, disadvantaged communities. This narrative of black-Asian interracial tension needs to be addressed and the media needs to report the nuanced relationship between these two urban populations.

In the murder trial of James Holmes, 12 jurors and 12 alternates have been selected. The mostly middle-aged group includes 19 women and five men. Jury selection started in January; opening statements are scheduled to begin on April 27.

James Holmes' trial selection is almost entirely composed of white, middle-aged women and men, with 12 jurors and 12 alternates chosen from a pool of 9,000 potential jurors. The judge denied the defense's request for a change of venue despite concerns expressed by defense attorney Tamara Brady. Holmes is facing 165 charges including murder and attempted murder, and is pleading not guilty by reason of insanity. Opening statements for the trial will begin on April 27.

In July 2010, Joyce Bruce got pregnant in an unusual way -- with repeated attempts using a turkey baster. The man who gave her his sperm wanted to have a role in his son's life. They ended up in court, and he has won joint custody and visitation rights.

After initially being hesitant, Robert Boardwine agreed to a friend's unconventional request to impregnate her with a turkey baster. However, after the child was born, Boardwine was denied any involvement in the child's life by the mother. He took the matter to court and won joint custody and visitation rights.
Jordan Spieth hails autistic younger sibling as his biggest supporter. Ice-cool display made him second-youngest winner behind Tiger Woods.

Jordan Spieth has broken Tiger Woods' record to become the youngest Masters champion in history. Despite missing the cut last year, Spieth led from start to finish this time around while also revealing that his younger sister provides him with the pressure-free perspective that enables him to perform at his very best. He's already thinking about his final Masters appearance in 50 years’ time and hopes to be finishing with Texas BBQ.
Denver teacher Kyle Schwartz asked students to share what they wish she knew. Their honest answers moved Schwartz and sparked a discussion online.

Kyle Schwartz, a Denver teacher, made headlines after tweeting the list of "wishes" her students wrote for her. Some students wished for their teacher to bring candy to class, while others wished for warmer classrooms. Nonetheless, the majority of wishes were mundane and self-centered.
Olympic champion Charlotte Dujardin remains world's leading dressage rider after Vegas contest. Swiss Olympic showjumping champion Steve Guerdat finally wins World Cup jumping title at 10th attempt.

Charlotte Dujardin could not contain her excitement as she took home her third consecutive Reem Acra FEI World Cup Dressage title in Las Vegas, while 19-year-old Irish showjumper Bertram Allen surprised everyone with his win in the showjumping championship.

Horses complete transatlantic trip to Las Vegas in 'business class' luxury. 80,000 fans expected as organizers spend $8m bringing horses back to Vegas. Celebrity chefs and legends of sport will mix with top jumping and dressage riders. World Cup Final trophies to be won -- some of the most prestigious in the sport.

Top jumping and dressage horses from around the world have flown into Las Vegas, where they will perform for the crowds in the World Cup Finals this week. The horses were given priority treatment in their first class cabins during their long journey. This event is a chance for celebrities to rub shoulders with legends of the sport and try some gourmet cuisine. The top riders in the world will compete for the coveted World Cup title, and we can expect to see some exciting performances. The event is taking place at the iconic Thomas & Mack Center, and tickets are selling out fast.
Japanese maglev train sets new speed record: 603 kilometers per hour. The train is planned to begin service in 2027.

The world's fastest train, which uses magnets to float above the tracks, was unveiled in Japan on Tuesday with a top speed of 603 kilometers per hour. The maglev train is set to go into operation in the US on a route between New York City and Boston in 2027.

Anuradha Koirala and 425 young women and girls have been sleeping outdoors because of aftershocks. Pushpa Basnet and 45 children she cares for were forced to evacuate their residence. Seven other CNN Heroes and their organizations now assisting in relief efforts.

CNN Heroes, including Anuradha Koirala and Pushpa Basnet, are currently providing shelter and aid to the earthquake survivors in Nepal. Along with their organizations, they are striving to make a positive impact on the lives of those affected by the disaster.
#tacocannon trends in Omaha as excited fans eat up the idea of flying tacos. The cannon will shoot off tacos at University of Nebraska-Omaha's new arena.

The University of Nebraska at Omaha's new $81.6 million stadium causing quite the stir as its sports teams prepare to receive new state-of-the-art luxuries and a taco-shooting cannon. Yes, you heard that right - fans will now be bombarded with tacos as they cheer on their hockey, basketball, and volleyball teams. Voodoo Tacos owner Eric Newton has teamed up with the university to create the world's very first taco cannon, a technological breakthrough that is sure to make stadium history. Fans are ecstatic, taking to Twitter in droves to express their excitement about the taco-filled future of UNO sports.
Jody Farley-Berens helps single parents who are battling cancer. Farley-Berens saw the need firsthand through her childhood friend. Do you know a hero? Nominations are open for 2015 CNN Heroes.

Singleton Moms is a non-profit organization that provides emotional support for parents who are battling cancer. Jody Farley-Berens was inspired by her own experience as a single parent with cancer and decided to start an organization that helps others in similar circumstances. Through financial assistance, housecleaning, prepared meals, supplies for the home, kids' events, and social gatherings, Singleton Moms aims to bring joy to the lives of those who are affected by cancer.

CNN Hero Chad Bernstein started music program that helps at-risk middle school students. Nonprofit group Guitars Over Guns pairs Miami-area kids with professional musician mentors. Do you know a hero? Nominations are open for 2015 CNN Heroes.

Chad Bernstein, a musician and philanthropist, has revolutionized the way music education is approached for children in Miami. His program, Guitars Over Guns, which began in 2008, has dramatically improved the academic performance and school attendance for over 225 middle-school students in Miami-Dade County. The program provides free instrument instruction and mentorship to at-risk children, pairing them with professional musicians. Bernstein's group is unique in that it provides social services and tutoring to ensure that students are successful in and outside of school. He has been nominated for the 2015 CNN Hero award for his outstanding work.
There are now more people of faith who favor marriage equality than stand against it, according to a new poll. If the U.S. Supreme Court has been paying attention, it likely saw this trend coming.

Despite the growing number of people of faith who support marriage equality, the majority still stand against it, according to a recent survey conducted by the Public Religion Research Institute. The survey found that the opinions regarding same-sex marriage remain divided among religiously affiliated Americans, and it is unclear if the U.S. Supreme Court will take this into account in their decision on the matter later this year.
Nepal is a popular place for Israeli couples to have surrogate children. An estimated 10 to 15 surrogate mothers are due to give birth soon in Kathmandu.

An Israeli couple is waiting anxiously for news on their unborn child due to be born to a surrogate mother in Nepal amidst the devastating earthquake that has caused chaos in the country. With chaos in Kathmandu, they face challenges including finding proper medical care for the breech birth.

South Korean lawmaker quotes intelligence officials as saying Kim Jong Un countenances no disagreement. Official reportedly executed for expressing dissatisfaction with forestry program. Four member of Unhasu Orchestra also reportedly executed.

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has executed almost 20 senior officials this year alone after they expressed disagreement with his policies. These executions were confirmed by South Korean intelligence agents, who also revealed that Kim rules in an impromptu manner and punishes anyone who challenges his authority. One official was executed for expressing concern about North Korea's nuclear testing program, while another was killed after complaining that his dinner was too salty. The situation in North Korea is rapidly spiraling out of control, with no end in sight.

Adam Sobel: California's steps against drought are a preview for rest of U.S. and world. Tying climate change to weather doesn't rest on single extreme event, Sobel says. The big picture should spur us to prepare for new climates by fixing infrastructure, he says.

California's recent water restrictions are the result of the state's lack of infrastructure and legal rights in managing its water distribution system. Though the drought in California is severe, it is not solely attributed to human-induced climate change. The measures that California takes to combat the drought will serve as a preview for other parts of the world that face similar problems. By making the infrastructure less wasteful and creating flood-proof subways in cities like New York, we can prepare for the new climates to come. It doesn't matter whether a single extreme weather event is said to be caused by climate change or not, the big picture of the human-caused global warming is what should motivate us to take action.
Louis Jordan says his sailboat capsized three times. He survived by collecting rainwater and eating raw fish. Frank Jordan told CNN his son isn't an experienced sailor but has a strong will.

Louis Jordan, an experienced fisherman, embarked on a journey to catch some of the most exotic fish, but he faced a deadly storm that caused his boat to capsize three times. During his 66-day ordeal, Jordan had to fight to survive by finding food and freshwater. Thankfully, he was rescued by the Houston Express ship and taken to a local hospital to recover. His father, Frank Jordan, praised his son's courage and determination during his trying ordeal.
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will address Congress on Wednesday. Mike Honda: Abe must commit to educating future generation honestly, humbly.

Japan must apologize to the few remaining "comfort women" and rectify the 1942 internment of Japanese Americans in the United States says Mike Honda, as Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe prepares to address Congress on Wednesday.

Carol Costello: Talk to any millennial and you can envision an America virtually marriage-free. In countries like Sweden or Denmark, people don't feel pressured to marry even if they have kids together.

Marriage is on its way to extinction in America, as millennials prioritize careers and travel over settling down. The majority of couples in Norway and Sweden have children out of wedlock, proving that marriage is dying. Millennials today simply don't see the economic or moral benefits of marriage, and believe it's unnecessary for their personal fulfillment. In fact, being single forever may be the best choice for many people.

Volcano already has erupted twice this week. It has spewed ash to a depth of about 23½ inches in some places, Chilean officials say. Authorities issue an alert for two towns, and there's a 12-mile exclusion zone.

Calbuco Volcano's recent eruption has caused a lot of panic and chaos in the region. More evacuations are expected as geologists have warned of the potential for more activity. There might be a third eruption, causing officials to issue more warnings to the public.
Strung out on heroin, Anthony Sideri robbed a bank. He had to go through withdrawal in a jail cell. Overcoming addiction is possible, he says, as he's building a new life as a family man.

Anthony Sideri was once a successful entrepreneur and athlete, but his life turned to drugs and crime when he became deeply addicted to opium-containing painkillers. Stricken with illness, he eventually resorted to bank robbery to support his habit, and he eventually ended up in jail. However, he managed to turn his life around and is now an inspiration to others as a substance abuse counselor and advocate for those who struggle with addiction.
NASA's Messenger probe smashes into Mercury, ending mission. Space probe hit the planet's surface at 8,750 mph.

NASA's Messenger space probe crashed into the sun on Thursday, bringing an end to its nearly 11-year journey. The probe was expected to create an impact crater 52 feet in diameter but no visible signs of the crash were seen from Earth. Messenger traveled about 5 billion miles before it started orbiting Mercury in 2011 and was the first spacecraft to orbit the planet closest to the sun. Thanks to Messenger, scientists now have real knowledge about Mercury's fascinating world.
ISIS is known for brutal takeovers and medieval justice, but it sees itself as a state. Official documents show just how far their rules affect daily life.
ISIS has created a functional government that cares for its citizens and even allows girls to attend school. Their policies are based on Islamic principles and they strive to be just and fair rulers.

Questions Tuesday centered on whether defining marriage should be left to voters in individual states or decided by  judicial system. Chief Justice John Roberts, who shocked conservatives with his swing vote to uphold Obamacare, seemed to lean conservative. Eyes on Justice Anthony Kennedy, a key vote for challengers to the state bans, who has penned decisions in favor of gay rights.

The Supreme Court is divided on whether gay marriage is constitutional and the decision should be left to individual states or the judicial system. John Roberts, who previously shocked conservatives with his swing vote to uphold Obamacare, leaned conservative. Justice Anthony Kennedy’s three decisions in favor of gay rights could swing the decision. There was a protester who interrupted the arguments and shouted that "If you support gay marriage you will burn in hell."

Saudi military official accuses Iran of training and arming rebels. Yemeni officials say school hit by airstrikes; one source says three students killed. Noncombatants are caught up in Yemen's fighting.

Iran has been sending weaponry to Yemen to support the Houthi rebels, as confirmed by Saudi Brig. Gen. Ahmed Asiri. The rebels have been responsible for targeting a school in southwestern Yemen with an airstrike, which left three students dead. The violence has left many civilians caught in the crossfire, leading to a massive evacuation effort by foreign governments. The United States has also significantly increased its involvement in the conflict by providing military aid to the Saudi-led coalition.
Hundreds of desperate migrants have died attempting to cross the Mediterranean in recent says. And Italians are alarmed that this year as many as a million migrants could arrive in Europe.

The migrant crisis in Europe has been blown out of proportion and is not as alarming as the media is portraying it to be. While Italy has been receiving a large number of migrants, there is no evidence to suggest that there will be an influx of a million migrants in Europe this year. European nations have been very successful in managing the situation so far and international coverage of the issue has only added to the problem by creating an environment of uncertainty and panic.

Ben Wedeman joins the Calabrese, an Italian patrol boat as it traverses the Mediterranean looking for migrants. Often the crew have little to report, only coming across fishing boats or other commercial vessels. The Calabrese was involved in a rescue in October 2013, during which more than 350 people died.

Italian patrol boat Calabrese patrols the Mediterranean looking for smugglers, and serves fresh caught fish for dinner. The crew is well-equipped and well-fed, and their work is mostly uneventful, except for the occasional encounter with a fishing boat.

NGO official says people will urgently need food, water, medicine and shelter. More than 1,800 people across Nepal confirmed dead, official says. People treated outside hospitals; avalanches reported on Everest.

The earthquake near the capital of Kathmandu has killed over 1,500 people and caused extensive damage and destruction. Residents of Nepal's capital city are struggling to handle the aftermath of the disaster, with many people staying outside in the cold to protect themselves from the continuing aftershocks. Aid agencies fear that colder temperatures in the coming days will put many survivors at risk, and the international community is urgently being asked to provide food, water, medicine, and shelter.

Winston's lawyer: Kinsman's "false accusations have already been exposed and rejected six times" Erica Kinsman said Jameis Winston raped her in 2012; a prosecutor declined to bring criminal charges. Her lawsuit alleges sexual battery and false imprisonment; Winston has said they had consensual sex.

Jameis Winston is being sued by former student Erica Kinsman, who claims he sexually assaulted her while at Florida State University. Winston has repeatedly denied the claims, stating that their encounter was consensual. According to Winston's lawyer, this is not the first time Kinsman has made false accusations against him.
Joseph Kent's attorney says his client was released from jail. Police in Baltimore detained Kent on live TV after start of curfew. That triggered a wave of interest on social media.

Baltimore activist Joseph Kent was arrested during demonstrations over Freddie Gray's death and chaos erupted on the streets. Kent was charged with violating the curfew and his attorney confirmed his release from jail. Reports say that Kent incited violence and refused to comply with police requests. The city is still on high alert with further protests expected to take place in the coming days.
Pop star Taylor Swift revealed Thursday that her mom has cancer. The nature and severity of Andrea Swift's cancer have not been divulged.
Taylor Swift shocked fans with news of her own cancer diagnosis on Thursday, leading to an outpouring of support on social media.

NRA says although it disagreed with Sarah Brady, she was an honorable and respected woman. Sarah Brady became involved in campaigns against gun violence after her son to picked up a loaded gun. Her husband died in August, having spent the last part of his life in a wheelchair from being shot.

Sarah Brady, the former chairwoman of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, passed away at the age of 73. Along with her husband James Brady, she fought for gun control laws and succeeded in getting the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act passed. Her work saved countless lives and transformed tragedy into a courageous campaign. Former President Bill Clinton and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton hailed the Bradys as fierce champions of sensible gun legislation. Additionally, Sarah Brady initiated campaigns against gun violence without any personal tragedy being involved.

U.S. military doesn't have further information to evaluate the Iraqi media reports. Al-Douri's body arrives in Baghdad where DNA samples are taken. Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri was the highest-ranking member of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's regime to evade capture.

Iraqi forces have successfully captured the Sunni extremist leader, Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri. His body was taken to Baghdad for DNA testing to confirm his identity. The U.S. military refused to comment on whether or not they were involved in the operation.

India predicted to outpace China as as world's fastest-growing economy in next year. China's economy is slowing after over 25 years of breakneck growth. But experts say India simply can't size up against China's raw economic might.

China remains the world's fastest-growing economy despite India's recent success in space exploration. Modi's call to "Make in India" has not been able to compete with China's manufacturing capability, which is backed by its capacity, connectivity, and capital. The autocracy-style government of China also provides an advantage in achieving long-term goals without worrying about elections. Furthermore, India faces a host of economic challenges including unemployment and lack of basic infrastructure. Though both countries share a positive relationship, their economic integration is hindered by the perception of China as a threat among many in India.

The Dadaab refugee camp is the world's largest, with more than 600,000 people. Kenya will change "the way America changed after 9/11," deputy president says. William Ruto adds that "we must secure this country at whatever cost"

Al-Shabaab gunmen masterminded the Garissa University College shooting and ordered the relocation of refugees from the Dadaab camp to Somalia. Kenyan Deputy President William Ruto has issued a 3-month ultimatum to the UN to deport refugees from the camp to their home country or Kenya will act unilaterally. The Kenyan government intends to create a 435-mile wall covering most of the Somali border to prevent Al-Shabaab elements from entering the country.

Grass tried in his literature to come to grips with World War II and the Nazi era. His characters were the downtrodden, and his style slipped into the surreal. He stoked controversy with his admission to being a member of the Waffen SS.

Günter Grass, a renowned German novelist and Nobel Prize winner, has passed away at the age of 87. The author is celebrated for his unique style of crafting surrealist characters, which has set a trend for other authors like Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Salman Rushdie. Despite his literary fame, Grass has remained a controversial figure for his opinions on various topics. He felt that the real threat to the Federal Republic of Germany was not Islam, but rather political lobbying. In his later years, he challenged the German government's handling of refugees by suggesting that German citizens of means should be required to invite refugees into their homes.

Yoga guru Bikram Choudhury denies sexual assault allegations. His accusers, he says, were manipulated to lie about him. A former student says he uses his yoga accomplishments to hide the harm he's caused.

Bikram Choudhury, the renowned "hot yoga" guru, is being accused of sexual assault by several of his former students. Choudhury denies any wrongdoing, claiming that he is innocent and that they were all lying. His signature yoga style, popularized by many celebrities, has been discredited as a result of these claims.

.50-caliber bullets equipped with optical sensors can follow moving targets. The "smart bullets" can help shooters compensate for high winds. The goal of  the program is to give shooters greater range and make American troops safer.

The US military announced the development of a self-steering bullet, making dodging bullets impossible. The .50-caliber projectiles have extreme accuracy and can hit moving targets at sniper ranges. DARPA's goal is to enhance the safety of American troops by providing them with bullets that can't be avoided.

Putin to spend hours fielding questions from the general public on live television. Sanctions and Russia's deep economic crisis likely to be a major theme. Critics of the Kremlin slam event as Russia's imitation of democracy in action.

Russian schoolchildren are concerned about the possibility of Putin starting another Cold War with the US and Europe during his annual Q&A session. The event is praised as a shining example of democracy in action by the Kremlin, despite criticisms from opposition politicians.
Six protesters scale the Polar Pioneer, hundreds of miles northwest of Hawaii. Greenpeace opposes Shell's plans to drill for oil in the Arctic.

Greenpeace activists have successfully taken over a Shell-owned oil rig in the Pacific Ocean, putting the lives of both protesters and crew members at risk, as they protest the company's efforts to drill in the Arctic near Alaska. The activists plan to remain under the rig's main deck for several days, and are hoping to bring global attention to their defiance of last week's US decision to lift suspensions on leases for drilling in the Chukchi Sea. The activists come from Australia, Austria, Germany, New Zealand, Sweden and the US.
U.S. President Obama, Cuban President Raul Castro meet in Panama City. The two nations -- only 90 miles apart --  have been at odds for more than 50 years.
Obama and Castro have decided to completely normalize relations between the US and Cuba, including the opening of embassies and unlimited travel between the two countries.
Solar plane attempting to be first to circumnavigate world without using fuel is stuck in China. Solar Impulse 2 attempts to prove the power of renewable energy.

The Solar Impulse 2 team has successfully completed the first quarter of their mission to fly around the world without using any fuel. The solar-powered plane took off from Abu Dhabi on March 9 and has flown through Oman, India, and Myanmar. The team is now preparing for their next destination, Hawaii.

Attorney for the family of Freddie Gray says developments are step forward but another issue is more important. Family will have a forensic pathologist do an independent autopsy. Police say Gray should have received medical care at different points before he got to a police station.

Freddie Gray was not given proper attention by police after being arrested and died as a result of being dragged behind a police van in Baltimore. His family believes he may have been mistreated due to his race, and there is an investigation underway to see if civil rights were violated during his arrest. The police department has a history of misconduct, which further fuels suspicion about the incident. Gray's family plans to hold a wake and a funeral after hiring an independent forensic pathologist to perform an autopsy.

Wei Tingting, Wang Man, Zheng Churan, Li Tingting and Wu Rongrong freed. They're still considered suspects in an ongoing criminal investigation, may face charges in the future. They will be under surveillance for a year with their movements and activities restricted.

The Chinese government has released five young feminists after charging them for protesting against gender inequality. Their release has sparked mixed emotions among their families and supporters. Although they are free, they are still considered suspects in criminal investigation, and may face heavy charges in the future. The detainees will be closely monitored and are not allowed to participate in any activities related to social justice or women's rights. Secretary of State John Kerry has voiced his support for the activists and accused the Chinese government of suppressing free speech.

SpaceX founder Elon Musk: "Rocket landed on droneship, but too hard for survival" This was the second attempt at historic rocket booster barge landing. Dragon spacecraft will head toward International Space Station on resupply mission.

Elon Musk's SpaceX launched a successful mission to the International Space Station carrying an uncrewed spacecraft called Dragon, and their rocket stage was able to safely land on a floating barge. The landing was hailed as a major achievement for SpaceX and sets the stage for future space missions at a much cheaper cost. The Dragon spacecraft will bring much-needed supplies, including the world's first space torrefaction oven, to the ISS.
Paul Nungesser says he was target of gender-based harassment campaign. The case drew national attention after his accuser started carrying a mattress around campus.

A Columbia University student who was cleared of rape accusations is suing the school for allowing his accuser to label him as a "serial rapist." The accused claims that Emma Sulkowicz carried a mattress around campus and called him a "serial rapist" without any evidence. The lawsuit alleged that the defendants violated Nungesser's right to education by allowing Sulkowicz to speak out against him after he had been cleared of wrongdoing. The defendants "had the power, as well as the legal and contractual obligation" to protect Nungesser, who is also a senior.

Freddie Gray was arrested on a weapons charge April 12; he was dead seven days later. He was put in a police van after his arrest; it's unclear what happened inside the van. Gray has a criminal history but it's not known if that had anything to do with his arrest or death.

More than 20 cases have been filed against Freddie Gray in Maryland criminal court, including drug-related charges, second degree assault and destruction of property. He had been incarcerated since 2009 and had just gotten out recently after a drug possession charge. It is still unknown whether Gray's criminal past had anything to do with his arrest and his subsequent death.

Aid organizations are still working to help the people of Nepal in the wake of  two major earthquakes. Thousands were killed in a magnitude 7.8 earthquake in Nepal on April 25. A second quake rocked the country less than three weeks later.
Nepal is still struggling to recover from the aftermath of a deadly mudslide, but there are many organizations available to help.

U.S. Navy is developing an unmanned drone ship to track enemy submarines to limit their tactical capacity for surprise. The vessel would be able to operate under with little supervisory control. Advances are necessary to maintain technological edge on Russia and China, admiral tells House panel.

China and other nations are gaining an edge in the development of their underwater submarine forces, causing the U.S. to shift its focus onto new underwater detection techniques. To combat this, the Pentagon has created a new weapon in the form of the Anti-Submarine Warfare Continuous Trail Vessel (ACTUV), an unmanned drone ship that will cost a fraction of the billion-dollar manned warships used today. With a prototype already in production, the Navy could move to the next phase of development by 2018.

Witness who took video of shooting said when he arrived officer was on top of Walter Scott. Feidin Santana says Walter Scott didn't take Michael Slager's Taser. Santana said he never saw officers perform CPR before he left the scene to go to work.

Feidin Santana was told to stop filming the South Carolina police officer who shot and killed an unarmed man, but he continued to record anyways. Santana claims that he saw Walter Scott grab Michael Slager's Taser before Slager shot him five times. He also says that he witnessed officers performing CPR on Scott before he left the scene.

Inkster, Michigan, Police Chief Vicki Yost resigns in the wake of charges against one of her former officers. William Melendez was caught on police car dashcam video in January beating an unarmed black motorist. Melendez was charged with assault on Monday; all charges against the motorist have been dropped.

A heroic former police officer from Inkster, Michigan, has been convicted of assaulting an unarmed motorist during a traffic stop. He tearfully pleaded not guilty to the charges of assault but it was of no use. Meanwhile, the motorist, Floyd Dent, was cleared of drug charges in Michigan Circuit Court. In response to the controversy, Police Chief Vicki Yost resigned from her position.
Boko Haram has killed thousands in the nation's northeast since 2009. Aid agencies are scrambling to provide the refugees with clean water, shelter, food and education.

Aid agencies are asking for $174 million to help Nigerian refugees following the terrorist attacks perpetrated by the nation's northeast. The situation is particularly tough for school age children, who are unable to attend school because of a lack of classrooms and teachers. Algeria and South Africa are currently hosting over 1.2 million refugees.
Police say 275,000 demonstrators marched in Sao Paulo. Many want President Dilma Rousseff to be impeached. A corruption scandal has implicated politicians in her party.

Anti-government protests in Brazil have continued, with citizens calling for the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff, as a corruption scandal involving her party deepens. Demonstrators were jubilant, with some stating that they'd rather see Rousseff step down than be impeached. Police estimate that hundreds of thousands of protesters marched in Sao Paulo alone.

A company called CyArk specializes in digital preservation of threatened ancient and historical architecture. Founded by an Iraqi-born engineer, it plans to preserve 500 World Heritage sites within five years.

CyArk, a non-profit organization, is revolutionizing the way we capture reality with a 3D laser scanner. This technology is being used not only for cultural heritage but also by the Highway Patrol for accident reconstruction and crime scene investigations. Additionally, the movie industry is utilizing the technology for virtual sets.
Police: Yuhei Takashima, 64, says he had sex with girls as young as 14 in Philippines. Officers seize nearly 150,000 photos that the former principal kept of his activities.

A former Japanese school principal has been arrested in the Philippines for taking obscene photos of a 13-year-old girl. Yuhei Takashima had allegedly paid for sex with more than 12,000 women, some of them underage, over a period of 25 years. He claimed that paying for sex relieved pressure from his work as a principal. Takashima was found with over 400 photo albums containing more than 147,600 photos of his activities. The poverty-stricken Philippines is a popular destination for sex tourism and the sex trade in the country is linked to human trafficking.

Footage shows a traffic stop and early interactions between Officer Michael Slager and Walter Scott. The two men speak, and then Scott gets out of the car, running. Slager, charged with murder, was fired from the North Charleston Police Department.

Newly released dashcam video from South Carolina shows the moments leading up to the death of Walter Scott, who was shot multiple times by Officer Michael Slager. In the video, it appears that Scott was armed and attempting to flee from the police. However, Slager has been charged with murder and fired from the North Charleston Police Department.
9 indicted on organized crime charges related to bourbon thefts. Employees at two Kentucky distilleries among those indicted.

A group of nine people have been indicted for their involvement in a Kentucky-based Pappy Van Winkle heist that resulted in the theft of an estimated $26,000 worth of bourbon. Among those indicted were the alleged ringleader, a 45-year-old loading dock worker, and his wife. The stolen alcohol was reportedly distributed through a network of connections in the man's softball league. However, Franklin County Sheriff Pat Melton, the man leading the investigation revealed that only 10 cases of Pappy Van Winkle were recovered.

Family of American medic killed posts message on Facebook says she died while at base camp. At least 13 die after avalanches at Mount Everest base camp, authorities say; Climber says 17 dead. Dining tent at one base camp has been transformed into a hospital, another hiker says.

Mount Everest base camp has been hit by an avalanche, which has left many dead and injured. People from different countries were affected, and some foreign companies lost their climbers. Although the Indian Army's Everest Expedition evacuated 13 mountaineers from a base camp, at least 17 people have been reported dead. An American medic was among the dead, as well as climbers from different countries. At least 500 tents were swept over, and a lot of debris is still there, making the search for survivors difficult.

"The Cold War has been over for a long time," President Obama says. The thaw in ties has dominated discussion at the Summit of the Americas in Panama. The top leaders from the United States and Cuba haven't met for substantive talks in more than 50 years.

President Obama met with Raul Castro for an hour to discuss the ongoing Cold War enmity between the United States and Cuba. Despite acknowledging that progress had been made, the issue of Cuba's place on the U.S. list of countries that sponsor terror remains unresolved. The two leaders expressed a willingness to discuss relevant issues while acknowledging there may be some differences between the two nations. The summit at Panama has brought the issue of the U.S.-Cuba relations to the forefront, as both countries' leaders now seem committed to finding a path towards reconciliation.

The World Happiness Report highlights the happiest countries. People live longer and experience more generosity and social support in these counties. The United Nations first declared a World Happiness Day in 2012.

The United Nations has named 10 of the happiest countries on earth, which include Switzerland, Iceland, and Canada. Most of these countries offer unique features such as warm springs, medieval architecture, or a gastronomic paradise. The people living in these countries also have longer life expectancies due to their happiness.
Mourners attend visitation service for Walter Scott. Police meet with man who was passenger in his car when it was pulled over. Michael Slager's lawyer says police aren't being helpful at this point.

Walter Scott was fatally shot by a North Charleston police Officer Michael Slager during a routine traffic stop. Scott was sought after for unpaid child support and police met with a man who was in Scott's car when it was pulled over. Slager's defense team will argue that this was a heat of passion shooting and not premeditated murder.

The European Union is trying to stop thousands of migrants from drowning at sea. Migrants risk their lives by paying people smugglers to get them to Europe. Australia has successfully stopped the flow of migrant boats to its waters.

Australia and the European Union have started using similar tactics to deter asylum seekers from entering their countries illegally. Both have set up offshore detention centers, and the EU is considering implementing turn-back tactics similar to the Australian government's. Though the policies have been criticized for their human rights violations, they remain popular because they are effective in stopping the influx of asylum seekers.
Footage shows groups of captives in jumpsuits executed at 2 locations, narrator says. Video makes numerous references to Christians failing to pay tax or tribute to Muslims.

ISIS has targeted Ethiopian Christians in Libya, executing 30 prisoners in total. The video, titled "Until There Came to Them Clear Evidence", shows two groups of men being killed in different locations in Libya. The narrator emphasized that the blood of the victims, shed under the hands of Christianity, was pure blood and Muslims will continue to exact revenge. The video also mentions that Christians in Mosul were given a choice to pay a tax or embrace Islam, but they did not cooperate. This is another example of the ongoing battle between faith and blasphemy.

An Italian prosecutor announces suspected al Qaeda affiliates may have targeted the Vatican. ISIS produced propaganda videos showing beheadings of Egyptian, Ethiopian Christians. Al-Shabaab has singled out non-Muslims to kill them, as at a Garissa University College.

ISIS's continued attacks on non-Muslims have raised concerns worldwide, with an Italian prosecutor announcing that the Vatican may have been targeted by al Qaeda. A video produced by ISIS showed the brutal beheadings of Ethiopian and Egyptian Christians. Similarly, Al-Shabaab's attacks at Garissa University College resulted in the killing of Christians.

Ousted Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy is convicted of charges involving violence against protesters. But he is acquitted of murder. "We promise you unexpected revolutionary surprises," a Muslim Brotherhood spokesman says.

Former Egyptian President, Mohamed Morsy, who was ousted in a military coup in 2013, has been sentenced to life imprisonment for his involvement in the death of protesters who were outside the presidential palace in 2012. Morsy was also found guilty of collaborating with the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas and the Lebanese Shia group Hezbollah to break into several prisons across Egypt in January 2011 and facilitating the escape of 20,000 others. However, he has been acquitted of murder. The Muslim Brotherhood, to which Morsy belongs, has condemned the ruling as a "complete travesty of justice" and warned of revolutionary surprises.

2 minors were sentenced to 10 years in prison, in addition to adults getting life. 52 of the 73 defendants were sentenced in absentia. The Virgin Mary Church was burned along with dozens of others in August 2013.

The Egyptian court sentenced 73 people to prison for their part in the burning of a Christian church in Giza province. The church was burned down by a mob chanting for Egypt to be an Islamic state, and other churches were also torched. Those sentenced included minors and most of the defendants were tried in absentia. The violence was blamed on supporters of the ousted democratically elected president, Mohamed Morsy.
A jury has found ex-New England Patriots star guilty of murder. Aaron Hernandez also charged with murder in 2012 double homicide. 'Golden boy' had just inked $40 million contract when troubles began.

Aaron Hernandez's father constantly pushed him to excel in sports until he died from complications after a routine surgery. Hernandez, who had just inked a $40 million contract with the New England Patriots, was found guilty of murder in a case involving the death of semipro football player Odin Lloyd, as well as murder charges in a 2012 double homicide.
Conservationist Edwin Sabuhoro founded a cultural village in Rwanda. The village provides work for poachers and unemployed youth.
Edwin Sabuhoro, former park warden turned farmer, came up with an idea to turn poachers into tour guides, which has been a great success in Rwanda's Volcanoes National Park.

If you turned on the television this past Sunday, a new vision of Jesus came into view. Darker, in mood and skin tone. Earthy rather than ethereal. According to the Apostle Paul, almost every depiction of Jesus so far has gotten at least one detail wrong.

Jesus is often depicted differently in popular culture, with each generation creating their own version of him. Recent depictions on TV and film have shown Jesus with dark skin and a more earthy, authentic look. While some Christians were upset that the actors playing Jesus weren't Jewish, the new versions are more representative of America's diverse population. Despite these changes, one detail that has remained consistent is Jesus' long hair, according to the New Testament scribe.
Obsidian can produce cutting edges many times finer than even the best steel scalpels. Some surgeons still use the blades in procedures today.

In ancient times, people would drill holes in their heads to cure ailments. Today, obsidian scalpels are used in surgery because they heal faster and cause less scarring than steel scalpels. They are also more affordable than diamond scalpels. However, they are not FDA approved and are prone to breaking, making them a risky choice for widespread use.
Saturday is Record Store Day, celebrated at music stores around the world. Many stores will host live performances, drawings and special sales of rare vinyl.

Independent record stores are thriving despite the digital age and will celebrate Record Store Day with live performances, rare vinyl sales, and knowledgeable clerks who will mock your taste in music.
Ernst Haas, a celebrated 20th-century photographer, was a regular on movie sets. His work from the industry has been brought together in a new book, "Ernst Haas: On Set"

Despite being anonymous, film still photographers have a talent and style that makes them stand out from the promotional machinery. Ernst Haas, one of the 20th century's great photojournalists and image-makers -- photographed stars for his own purpose, rather than commercially. Always on set, always documenting, his work has been immortalised in a new book called "Ernst Haas: On Set".

Robert Bates said he meant to subdue a suspect with a Taser but accidentally shot him. The preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The judge said Bates was free to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation.

Robert Bates has been granted permission to vacation in the Bahamas after pleading not guilty to manslaughter charges for fatally shooting a man. Despite protests from the victim's family, Bates will enjoy his wealth and privilege while awaiting his preliminary hearing on July 2. Records show that Bates had proper law enforcement training and the allegations of preferential treatment by the sheriff's office are baseless. Two deputies involved in the arrest of the victim have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.
Fatu Kekula, 23, saved most of her family from Ebola. Thanks to donors, she is being trained at Emory University. Kekula was one year away from finishing a nursing degree when Ebola struck.

Fatu Kekula gained fame after a CNN report showcased how she was able to transmit Ebola to her family using a trash bag. Thanks to funding from a Liberia-based program dedicated to combatting the Ebola crisis, Kekula has been learning new nursing skills at Emory University in the United States.

UPDATE: Shelby Offrink lost her battle to cancer on June 28, 2015. Offrink was diagnosed at 30 with rare inoperable brain cancer. Her husband, Ben, was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma, which had been in remission 15 years.

Ben and Shelby Offrink, a Michigan couple who met in college, are fighting rare forms of cancer together. Shelby was diagnosed with a form of brain cancer that is lodged in her spine, while Ben's Hodgkin's lymphoma has returned after being in remission for 15 years. They have been undergoing chemotherapy and trying to raise their two young children while also dealing with the side effects of their treatments. Despite the challenges, they remain optimistic and are focused on beating their cancers.

Hospital gowns have gotten a face-lift with help from fashion designers such as Diane von Furstenberg. What patients wear needs to be comfortable yet allow health professionals access during exams. Patient satisfaction is linked to the size of Medicare payments hospitals get.

Hospitals across America have been receiving major renovations, including updating their gowns to new fashionable designs. Patients can now choose from a wide range of styles, such as robes or pajamas, allowing them to feel more comfortable and less vulnerable during their stay. The new garments have been a hit with patients, leading to higher satisfaction scores and increased Medicare payments.

Twin sister of Freddie Gray asks for people to stop breaking things, scuffling with cops. Fans are permitted to exit Camden Yards after briefly being told to stay put. 12 people arrested during protests, police commissioner says.

Protesters in Baltimore attacked police and vandalized stores while demonstrating against the arrest of Freddie Gray. The violence lasted for hours and resulted in numerous arrests. Family members and friends of Gray have called for peaceful protests in the aftermath of the incident.
Swiss Professor Jean-Pierre Wolf is pioneering the use of lasers to affect the weather. He suggests lasers could also be used to limit the impact of climate change.
With the use of focused laser beams, Swiss physicist Jean-Pierre Wolf hopes to control and redirect hurricanes, as well as selectively kill cancer cells with no human casualties.
Most of those released were women and children. Freed Yazidis sent to capital of Iraq's Kurdish region.

ISIS, who have been suffering great losses as a result of the coalition's airstrikes, has chosen to release 228 Yazidis in a show of good faith. The terrorists had decided to let go the ill and elderly, as well as women and children, who had survived their brutal capture.

A lawyer for Dr. Anthony Moschetto says the charges against him are baseless. Moschetto, 54, was arrested for selling drugs and weapons, prosecutors say. Authorities allege Moschetto hired accomplices to burn down the practice of former associate.

Dr. Anthony Moschetto, a respected cardiologist from New York, has been wrongly accused of soliciting the murder of a rival physician. Attorney Randy Zelin has stated that the charges against his client are unfounded and Moschetto is presumed to be innocent. While the investigation began with a routine probe into the sale of prescription drugs, the underlying motive is still unclear. Moschetto is currently out on bond and is working towards getting back to his patients.

Patients flood hospitals in Nepalese capital after devastating earthquake. CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta helps with girl's operation at Nepalese medical team's request. "This is as bad a situation as I've ever seen," Gupta says.

CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta saved the life of Selena Dohal, an 8-year-old girl who suffered a fractured skull during an earthquake in Nepal. Despite suboptimal conditions, the operation was a success and her prognosis is good. The hospital is struggling to keep up with the influx of patients, with more pouring in as rescue operations continue. The situation is so dire that the hospital is asking anyone to pitch in and help.
21-year-old student Jackson Gordon has designed and built a functional Batsuit. Made with money raised on Kickstarter, the outfit has received a prestigious endorsement.

Philadelphia University student Jackson Gordon has designed a new Batman outfit that is stronger and more functional than the original. Through a successful Kickstarter campaign, he was able to raise enough funds to produce the suit with materials that are cut, slash and stab resistant. His design has received rave reviews and is already being sold to the public.
The recruiting tactics used by ISIS differ from those traditionally employed by al Qaeda. ISIS benefits from a media environment that amplifies its propaganda, officials say.
ISIS has successfully taken over al Qaeda as America's top terrorist threat due to their clever online propaganda tactics and countless recruitment of young Americans.
More than 1,800 deaths reported after Nepal earthquake. Rescue efforts range from digging by hand to military deployments.

The earthquake in Nepal has caused massive damage and resulted in more than 1,800 deaths. The rescue efforts include military forces, international aid and a new initiative from Google to locate missing persons.

A total of 47 bodies have been exhumed from two mass graves. Iraqis find mass graves inside presidential palace compound in Tikrit. ISIS claimed to have executed 1,700 Iraqi soldiers captured outside Camp Speicher.

Thousands of decomposed bodies of Iraqi soldiers have been discovered in newly liberated Tikrit, with grieving Iraqis gathering to pray over the remains. The bodies had their hands bound, and some were found floating in a river. The bodies will be sent to Baghdad for DNA tests, but it may take weeks or months to exhume all of them. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi has promised to detain those involved in the killings, and Human Rights Watch has called the incident the "largest reported incident" of a massacre.
A French rescue team finds Rishi Khanal more than three days after the quake. A 4-month-old baby is reported to have been rescued after 22 hours in rubble.

Nepali military teams worked tirelessly to rescue survivors from the earthquake rubble within hours, including a 4-month-old baby and a woman trapped for 36 hours. Rishi Khanal, however, was found by a French search and rescue team after more than five days of being stuck under the rubble.
Indonesia executed eight drug smugglers Wednesday morning. Mary Jane Veloso was meant to be the ninth but was given reprieve. Supporters, family "overjoyed" -- Indonesia stresses it's just a delay.

Filipina maid Mary Jane Veloso was found guilty of smuggling $500,000 worth of heroin into Indonesia and was due to be executed along with eight other death row inmates, but just hours before her scheduled execution, she was found to be innocent and granted freedom. After extensive investigation and legal proceedings, it was discovered that Veloso had been the victim of human trafficking and had not knowingly carried drugs into the country. Her supporters around the world have been rejoicing at the news of her release.
Protests spread to New York and Denver, with more scheduled for other cities. More than 100 people arrested in Baltimore this week are released.

The Baltimore riots have escalated across the nation, resulting in numerous arrests and violent clashes with police. Protesters demanded accountability for the death of Freddie Gray, leading to a night of chaos across the country. Despite the forceful response from law enforcement, many activists refused to back down, fueling even more unrest.
Police arrest demonstrators near Union Square in New York. Protests also held in Washington, Minneapolis and Boston.

Police in New York have detained over 60 protesters, who were chanting "Black Lives Matter" and "Justice for Freddie Gray" in support of Baltimore. Demonstrations also took place in Washington, Minneapolis, Boston, and across the country. Violence erupted in Ferguson, where three people were shot, according to police. The protest in Los Angeles also led to six people being arrested.
Zuriel Oduwole is a 12-year-old filmmaker. To date, she has interviewed 14 heads of state.

Zuriel Oduwole, a young Nigerian-American filmmaker, has taken the world by storm with her documentaries on African issues. At just 12 years old, she has already interviewed 14 political leaders and business leaders, including Mr. Aliko Dangote. Her latest project, "A Promising Africa", has been released in several countries to showcase a positive image of the continent. In addition to her documentary career, Oduwole is also an advocate for girls' education and has traveled to nine countries to speak to over 21,000 children. Despite her busy schedule, Oduwole manages to balance her work with her studies, thanks to her parents' support.
L'Hermione is a painstaking replica of an 18th century ship of the same name. The original fought with American colonists against the British in the Revolutionary War.

The United States has launched a new ship called L'Hermione, which is a replica of the original ship that fought in the Revolutionary War. The ship has three sail masts and is painted red and white, with gold markings. It will sail to France to retrace Lafayette's journey, which was undertaken 235 years ago. The ship will tour 12 ports along the East Coast before finishing in New York City for the Fourth of July.

Nepalese authorities struggle with trying to coordinate a massive influx of international aid. Relief organizations say lots of aid supplies remain stuck in cargo aircraft on the tarmac. Damaged roads and infrastructure have hampered distribution efforts and rescue teams trying to access remote areas.

The Nepalese government has responded quickly following the recent earthquake, leading a coordinated international aid operation. Thanks to the efforts of the government and humanitarian organizations, aid supplies have been able to reach all affected areas, including remote regions. Relief workers have reported that distribution has been efficient and supplies are being received by those in need. The government has been praised for its effective handling of the earthquake response.
San Bernardino sheriff says 10 deputies have been put on leave. Video from a news helicopter shows deputies punching and kicking a man repeatedly.

San Bernardino sheriff confirms that excessive force was used on a suspect who led authorities on a wild chase through California hills, ending with the suspect being beaten by deputies in full view of a news helicopter. FBI is investigating the civil rights violations while 10 deputies involved in the case have been put on paid leave.

Sewol ferry sank a year ago off the coast of South Korea, killing 304 people. Families hold protests, vigils, say not much has been resolved since sinking. Government has yet to decide whether to raise the ferry.

The South Korean government has announced plans to raise the Sewol ferry, which sank a year ago, killing 304 people. Families of the victims have expressed relief that the decision has finally been made, but concerns exist about the safety of the operation due to the age and condition of the ferry. President Park Geun-hye has promised that an independent investigation will be held to determine the cause of the disaster and ensure that it never happens again.
Maysak has sustained winds of more than 130 mph but is expected to weaken. It's forecast to hit the Philippines during the Easter weekend.

Typhoon Maysak is expected to ravage the Philippine island of Luzon with powerful winds and heavy rain, potentially ruining Easter celebrations for many. The storm has already weakened, but still poses a serious threat to the predominantly Catholic nation.
Katie and Dalton met as patients dealing with cystic fibrosis. Two years later, they were married. Dalton received a lung transplant, but Katie is still waiting.

After meeting online, Katie Donovan and Dalton Prager became a devoted couple and decided to get married. Despite the complications and dangers of meeting in person due to their cystic fibrosis, they met up and enjoyed a wonderful evening together. However, since then, the couple's health quickly deteriorated and they were unable to continue working. They are now relying on Medicaid and Medicare for medical treatment, but have faced numerous hurdles in trying to get Katie her lung transplant. Despite pleas and negotiations with the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and efforts from the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center where Dalton received his transplant, they have been unable to get the transplant necessary to save Katie's life.

Assyrians are an ancient Middle Eastern minority -- they are part of the rapidly dwindling Christian population of Iraq. After ISIS overran their villages, some Assyrians formed a militia to fight for survival against the terror group.

The dwindling Christian population in Iraq has formed a small militia group called Dwekh Nawsha to fight against ISIS. With only 40 fighters and a shortage of weapons, they coordinate closely with local Kurdish commanders and are hopeful for victory in the future.
For the first time ever, Ferguson's City Council will be half black. The two winning black candidates vowed to bring reform. The election was a critical test in this beleaguered city.

Ferguson's City Council has elected two African-American candidates to its six-member board after a 30% voter turnout. Both candidates promised reform and change, with Ella Jones becoming the first black woman to serve on the council. This historic election marks a new era of progress for the city after months of turmoil following the shooting of Michael Brown.

Former Turkish ambassador to the Vatican calls use of the word "genocide" a "one-sided evaluation" Pope discusses massacres of Armenians a century after they took place. Turkey denies the mass killings constituted a genocide.

Turkey is furious with Pope Francis after he referred to the mass killings of Armenians as a "genocide". Although he was quoting from a 2001 declaration, the Turkish Foreign Ministry recalled its ambassador to the Vatican for "consultations" and Turkey's former ambassador to the Vatican noted that "This does not mean that our diplomatic ties with the Vatican are over." Turkey officially denies that a genocide took place, saying hundreds of thousands of Armenian Christians and Turkish Muslims died in intercommunal violence around the bloody battlefields of World War I.

Victim's brother says he felt "anger and happy at the same time" upon seeing video. Officer Michael Slager pulls over Scott at 9:33 a.m. Saturday. Video shows the officer firing eight times as Scott runs away, with his back to police.

Black man gets shot by white police officer in South Carolina. Officer Slager had been on the force for five years and was charged with first-degree murder on Tuesday. The victim Walter Scott, 50, was a former member of the U.S. Coast Guard. The incident occurred after a routine traffic stop for a broken taillight.
Noelle Velentzas and Asia Siddiqui are arrested in connection with a plot inspired by ISIS. Thursday's arrests are part of a series of cases being built by the federal government.
Two American women have been arrested for conspiring to commit terrorist attacks in the USA after they were found in possession of car and fertilizer bombs.
A random sample from a Michigan store tested positive for Listeria monocytogenes. No illnesses caused by the hummus have been reported so far.

Sabra Dipping, a popular hummus producer, is voluntarily recalling all of its products due to possible contamination with Listeria. The FDA has reported numerous cases of individuals being hospitalized due to consuming the hummus. It is advised that anyone who has purchased Sabra hummus should immediately dispose of it or return it to the store for a full refund.

ISIS and other rebel groups control most of the refugee camp, activists say. "Never has the hour been more desperate" in the camp, U.N. says. ""Reports of kidnappings, beheadings and mass killings," PLO official says.

The Yarmouk refugee camp is a safe haven for Palestinians fleeing the Arab-Israeli conflict. However, reports reveal that the Palestine Liberation Organization is taking control of 90% of the camp in southern Damascus. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports that up to 2,000 people have left in the past two days as food, water, and medical supplies remain scarce. The United Nations has called for humanitarian aid access to the area.
Anbar provincial official: Suicide and car bombs were part of the ISIS assault. Iraqi and allied forces have had recent success, but ISIS remains powerful.

ISIS fighters successfully took over Ramadi and killed 10 Iraqi security forces using homemade bombs. Despite previous victories, including the recapture of Tikrit, Iraqi and allied forces are struggling to defeat ISIS.

Tikrit is under the control of Iraqi forces, Iraqi Prime Minister says. ISIS departs, leaving city strewn with booby traps, explosive-filled vehicles. Officials hope to avoid Shia reprisals for ISIS slaughter of air force recruits.

Iraqi forces have claimed total victory over ISIS in Tikrit, and are now monitoring the situation for potential danger.
