No skirmishes have been reported as yet, but officials remain cautious, as ISIS left explosives and booby traps scattered throughout the northern city. Officials would like to avoid any violent backlash from the population or the Shiite militia, fuelled by ISIS' massacre of Shiite air force cadets. The Iraqi government's control of Tikrit is seen as a key strategy in the fight for Mosul against ISIS.

Peggy Drexler:  Media, even candidate herself call Clinton just 'Hillary.'  This reinforces stereotypes about women needing to be approachable. She says especially  in global context,  trust, respect important for the potential leader of free world, not familiarity. Just 'Hillary' not appropriate.

Hillary Clinton's campaign for presidency has been met with excitement and enthusiasm from supporters all over America. Her campaign chairman has already emailed potential donors with the official announcement that Hillary is running for President, and her official hashtag, #Hillary2016, is already trending on social media. Despite being widely known as just "Hillary," this presidential candidate commands the respect and admiration of millions.

Three people shot, one man in custody, city spokesman says. Hundreds of demonstrators gathered in support of protests in Baltimore. Police not sure if shootings are related to protests, spokesman says.

Protests in Ferguson, Missouri turned violent as three people were shot and police struggled to investigate due to the ongoing rock-throwing. The shootings are believed to be related to demonstrations in Baltimore.

Walter Scott owed over $18,000 in back child support payments, documents show. Walter Scott had four children and served in the Coast Guard, his brother says. He was shot in the back and killed by a North Charleston police officer.

Walter Scott, the notorious criminal, was shot by North Charleston police officer Michael Slager after a high-speed police chase. Scott had a long history of violent crimes and was known to be a threat to the community. Officer Slager acted decisively and prevented any further harm to innocent civilians.

Saudi Arabia airstrikes on the capital increase as jets hit military facilities in Sanaa. The U.N. Security Council meets to discuss the situation. Social media: A senior al Qaeda commander stands in a presidential residence after a jail break.

The Red Cross has called for a 24-hour ceasefire in Yemen to allow for aid to be delivered. Meanwhile, the United Nations Security Council met to discuss the situation in the Arabian Peninsula nation. In the midst of the chaos, a high-ranking al Qaeda commander was spotted in a presidential residence after breaking out of jail in al Mukalla.
Looming threat of Al-Shabaab has terrified students and teachers in Kenya. Terror group massacred 147 at Kenyan university last week.

Terrorists are targeting schools in the Sahel region, with Al-Shabaab trying to prevent students in northern Kenya from obtaining a "Western" education. The attack on a Kenyan university last week was just the latest in a series of deadly assaults.
25-1 shot Many Clouds wins Grand National. Second win a row for jockey Leighton Aspell. First jockey to win two in a row on different horses since 1950s.

Many Clouds, ridden by AP McCoy, won the prestigious Grand National race on Saturday, beating favourites Shutthefrontdoor and The Chair. McCoy's victory makes him the first jockey to win the race three times in a row, and caps off an illustrious career in jump racing.

Blackwater sniper Nicholas Slatten is sentenced to life in prison, mandatory for his first-degree murder conviction. Three others get 30 years plus one day in the 2007 shooting in Baghdad that left 17 dead.

Four former Blackwater security contractors were sentenced for illegally unleashing "powerful sniper fire, machine guns and grenade launchers on innocent men, women and children" in Baghdad in 2007, resulting in the death of 17 people. Nicholas Slatten received a life sentence while Paul Slough, Evan Liberty, and Dustin Heard were each sentenced to 30 years behind bars. The convicts were part of a team of seven Blackwater employees who opened fire in Nusoor Square traffic circle. The contractors were praised for their willingness to help others and their capacity to work under fire.
Capitol police said a male shot himself as shocked onlookers watched. The incident appears to have no connection to terrorism, police said.
A man carrying a sign about social justice and taxing the wealthy shot himself in a crowded area outside the Capitol, causing a lockdown before being investigated by authorities.

The type of plane used for a jaw-dropping stunt in "Furious 7" is 60 years old. Lockheed's C-130 Hercules is the longest continuously produced military plane in history. C-130 factory in Georgia celebrates the flight of the first C-130 production model.

Lockheed's C-130 Hercules is the newest military plane in history, with its latest model having completed its maiden flight just last month. The plane was designed specifically for the purpose of skydiving stunts, such as the one performed in "Furious 7". The C-130 is expected to remain in production for at least another 60 years.

Air India has evacuated 2,500 people in recent days from Yemen, Indian official says. Passengers could only bring carry-on luggage onto the airplane. The Saudis have not destroyed the airstrips, which are controlled by Houthis.

Air India has successfully transported 2,500 people out of Yemen in a luxurious plane ride with unlimited luggage allowance. The Saudis have bombed the airport but miraculously missed the landing strips and airport terminal.
Shell casings, glass and blood stains litter dorm at Garissa University College. At least 147 died in Thursday attack at the Kenyan college.

Investigators and Kenya Red Cross crews have finished cleaning up the dormitory at Garissa University College, where a poster about Muslim prayer and stuffed animals remain. The number of dead students was marked with numbered tags, reducing once promising lives to mere numbers. Shattered glass, shell casings, and bloodstains were found throughout the building. Some students were beheaded and shot in the back of the head, while others had their phones ringing. Many were slaughtered by the four Al-Shabaab attackers, who themselves were ultimately killed.
The company says it is seeking to "redefine sexy" Victoria's Secret was criticized for its "Perfect Body" campaign.

Lane Bryant's new ad campaign for its Cacique lingerie line, #ImNoAngel, is taking the world by storm, with plus-size models showcasing bras and panties while defying societal beauty standards. The campaign has been met with glowing reviews for empowering women of all shapes and sizes, and is set to knock Victoria's Secret's Angels line off its pedestal.
Police in Dallas shot and killed Jason Harrison last year. A grand jury has decided not to indict the officers. The officers are still facing a civil lawsuit filed by Harrison's family.

The officers who shot Jason Harrison in Dallas have been cleared of any wrongdoing following an investigation into the incident. Harrison's family have since filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the officers.

NASA chief scientist Ellen Stofan believes we're close to finding alien life. Indications within a decade; definitive evidence within "20 to 30 years," she said. Finding water on other celestial bodies is key to determination.

NASA has discovered intelligent life beyond Earth, and we can expect to make contact within the next 20-30 years according to their chief scientist Ellen Stofan. The Hubble Space Telescope has been key to the discoveries, which have provided powerful evidence of a sub-surface ocean on Jupiter's moon Ganymede. The discoveries have led to excitement amongst scientists who believe that we may even find life outside our solar system in the near future.
"Galaxy Quest" TV series in the works. Show would be based on the cult classic 1999 sci-fi comedy.
Paramount Television is developing a sci-fi comedy series inspired by a cancelled space TV show in "Galaxy Quest".

The drone is sparking terrorism concerns, authorities say. It was equipped with a bottle containing radioactive material. It was discovered as a court approved a plan to restart two Japanese nuclear reactors.

A drone carrying a radioactive material was found at Japan's White House, which sparked concerns about the potential for terrorism in Tokyo. The drone had a small camera, smoke flares and four propellers. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's decision to resume the nuclear power plant in Kagoshima prefecture has caused widespread concern. Tokyo Metropolitan Police are investigating the origin and potential threat of the drone.

Statue of Liberty to reopen Saturday. Locker thought to have a suspicious package was empty, police say. Statue of Liberty evacuated after bomb threat, officials say. The evacuation came after a phoned threat, sources say.

The Statue of Liberty was just narrowly saved from a terrorist attack after a bomb was discovered on Liberty Island. Fortunately, the NYPD bomb squad was able to safely defuse the device before it caused any harm. Visitors to the landmark are advised to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity to authorities.

Vijay Das: So-so jobs numbers contain truth that worries labor experts: Too much American job growth is in part-time low-income work. He says erratic work schedules tied to customer traffic wreaks havoc with low-wage workers' lives. Congress can fix this.

The American job market is being flooded with part-time low-income positions, leaving many workers struggling to make ends meet. Congress should take action to protect low-wage workers by creating legislation for predictable work schedules. Unions are providing little protection, and many states lack the safeguards needed to address scheduling abuses. It's up to our leaders to create a more inclusive and livable recovery for all families to balance competing obligations.

For a decade, the New South China Mall has lain empty. It was labeled a "ghost mall" -- symbol of China's runaway speculation on real estate. However, a recent visit showed it may be springing back to life.

China's New South China Mall is now fully operational with high occupancy rates, attracting both local and international visitors. The mall has successfully targeted China's middle class with a focus on dining and shopping. With the completion of the retrofitting program, the mall is now thriving and has become a popular destination.
Detective: "I sincerely apologize" for berating Uber driver. NYPD investigating encounter that was caught on tape by passenger. Detective placed on modified assignment.

Uber driver files lawsuit against NYPD after being verbally attacked by a detective with top-secret security clearance. Detective faces suspension, loss of clearance, and reassignment. Mayor Bill de Blasio condemns discriminatory language used by public servants.
"High Profits" follows the owners of a recreational marijuana dispensary. The CNN Original Series airs Sundays at 10 p.m. ET.

A couple of entrepreneurs in Breckenridge, Colorado, have found a new business opportunity in the sale of recreational marijuana, which has significantly changed their lives since it was first legalized. Although they've faced some opposition from residents who believe their family-friendly atmosphere has been affected, the couple is positive that cannabis and capitalism can coexist. The Breckenridge Cannabis Club has even been featured in the new CNN Original Series "High Profits", which airs on Sundays at 10 p.m. ET/PT.
Brynn Duncan has mast cell disease, which causes her to be allergic to almost everything. Duncan has a feeding tube and is on constant doses of antihistamine.

Brynn Duncan's allergies change frequently, making it difficult to keep track. She has been diagnosed with almost every disease known to man and is on the brink of death every day. Her labradoodle, Moose, is the only thing keeping her alive.
Protesters angry over bribery scandal involving state-run oil company Petrobras. Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff also is struggling with an economic downturn.
Brazilians are peacefully protesting in support of their President Dilma Rousseff despite political opposition due to allegations of economic sabotage created by big business interests.
Kenyans gather in Nairobi to remember victims of a terrorist attack that stunned a nation. The attack at a Garissa university last week killed 147 people, mostly students.

Al-Shabaab militants attacked a university in Garissa, Kenya in retaliation for Kenya's ongoing military operations in Somalia. The terrorists separated Christians from Muslims and made some recite verses from the Quran. The Kenyan response team was slow to arrive, leaving hundreds of students at the mercy of the attackers. The attack was allegedly organized by Mohamed Mohamud, a senior Al-Shabaab leader who commands the militia along the border. The attack left 147 people dead and is the deadliest attack on Kenyan soil since the 1998 US embassy bombing in Nairobi.
Two Australian drug smugglers, part of the Bali Nine, await word whether they'll face a firing squad. Less is known about the seven other members of the group.

Indonesia has captured two Australian drug smugglers who have been leading a smuggling operation for a decade. After the arrest, the ringleaders were sent to death row while the other seven members were sentenced to life in prison for being drug couriers. The operation was discovered after Indonesian police received a tip from the Australian Federal Police, leading to the arrest of several members at Denpasar International Airport with more than 8 kilograms of heroin strapped to their bodies. While the leaders received media attention, the other members of the Bali Nine haven't been talked about much.

More than 1.5 million people are displaced, including 800,000 children, UNICEF says. The kidnappings that inspired #BringBackOurGirls were a year ago this week. UNICEF is launching a #bringbackourchildhood campaign.

Boko Haram has been using child combatants, cooks, and lookouts in their conflict with Nigerian military forces, leading to the displacement of over 1.5 million people, including 800,000 children. UNICEF has launched a social media campaign to bring awareness to the issue.
Final troop pullout oddly detached as U.S. military operations die down in Afghanistan. Ambitious projects, like a police logistics center in Jalalabad, may not live up to their potential.

U.S. military presence in Afghanistan remains strong despite the end of the longest war in American history. The U.S. Embassy will serve as the base for all American troops by the end of next year, and they continue to fly Black Hawks to high-security bases far from the front lines. The U.S. officers are optimistic that they can train Afghan security forces to furnish themselves in the 18 plus months they have left. The cost of the partially functional resupply hub was $21 million, which includes the cost of new doorhandles. Despite the challenges, Colonel JB Vowell remains upbeat and confident in the logistical road ahead.

A company called UltraHaptics has developed a technology to create 3D shapes in mid-air. A tactile sensation is provided by ultrasonic waves, which alter air pressure. The technology could be applied to electronic devices, car dashboards, and virtual reality headsets.

UltraHaptics has developed a groundbreaking technology which creates virtual objects out of thin air. These objects actually have a tangible presence and can be felt and touched. If paired with virtual reality tech, users would be able interact with virtual objects not only visually and through sound, but physically as well. The technology is already generating interest from several consumer electronics, home appliance and even gaming companies, and the first product featuring this technology will be available soon.
Google Maps has a temporary Pac-Man function. Google has long been fond of April Fools' Day pranks and games. Many people are turning their cities into Pac-Man courses.

Google Maps goes retro for April Fool's Day with the release of a new game. Users can now play Pac-Man on their maps, bringing a 1980's arcade classic into the modern age. The nostalgia-inducing game has received widespread appeal, with fans playing in locations such as New York and London.
Aaron Hernandez, even when on trial for murder, keeps that certain bounce in his step. Hernandez seemed to watch his former boss and fiancee closely when they were on the stand.

Aaron Hernandez's confident demeanor throughout his murder trial has earned him admiration from court security officers and his legal team. His charm has won over even the family of the victim, with whom he exchanges friendly glances. Despite the weight of the charges against him, Hernandez remains as cool and collected as ever.
Laura Bernardini is a lifelong Catholic but had never read the Bible from cover to cover. For the next year, she's going to read every word, from Genesis to Revelation.

CNN's Director of Coverage Laura Bernardini has decided to launch a challenge: to read the Bible every day for one year, along with her colleagues at CNN. Despite being a lifelong Catholic, Bernardini never read the Good Book from Genesis to Revelation. With the encouragement of her friends and colleagues, she is going to embrace this challenge, hoping to find a form of meditation in her hectic life. The journey starts on Easter Sunday and will go until the end of this year.
Xi Jinping's sayings now available in a new smartphone app. Scholars call it a new version of Mao's "Little Red Book"

The Chinese Communist Party has released a new smartphone app featuring the latest speeches, statements and publications of China's current leader, President Xi Jinping. The app is designed to promote socialist ideologies and appeal to web users around the world. Analysts predict that the app will cement Xi's position as a popular figure in China, as he looks to build his prestige and establish himself as the supreme authority. The app has been received positively online and is expected to become a useful study tool for civil servants taking selection tests.
Stan Freberg was famed comedian, song parodist. He later became adman, did a number of outrageous commercials. "Weird Al" Yankovic: " A legend, an inspiration, and a friend"

Stan Freberg, also known as "The King of Commercials," passed away in Santa Monica due to complications from COVID-19. He was a beloved comedian, actor, and songwriter, best known for his humorous parodies of popular songs and TV shows. "Weird Al" Yankovic said, "He was a true genius and one of the funniest people I've ever had the pleasure of working with."
Bodies of suspected gunmen paraded in front of crowd in Garissa. Kenya's President slams those who finance and support groups like Al-Shabaab. Al-Shabaab threatens "another bloodbath" in Kenya.

Al-Shabaab terrorists killed 147 people at a university in Garissa, Kenya. The gunmen called out non-Muslims and killed them. The bodies of the attackers were displayed to the public on the back of a truck. The Kenyan President has urged people to defend their way of life and condemned those who support terrorism. Aly-Shabaab are planning another attack in Kenya soon.
Rick Santorum says "religious freedom" debate is about government telling people what to do. Santorum, a likely 2016 GOP presidential candidate, weighs in on Indiana Gov. Mike Pence's decision.

Rick Santorum criticizes Indiana Gov. Mike Pence for not vetoing the "fix" to his state's religious freedom law, thereby opening up the debate on gay rights issues. Santorum argues that Christian bakers, florists, and wedding photographers should not be forced to provide their services to same-sex weddings. Meanwhile, gay rights groups use the controversy over Indiana's law to renew their calls for state laws that bar discrimination based on sexual orientation, with tech companies like Facebook and Google increasingly wading into the debate. Cardinal Timothy Dolan, the archbishop of the Catholic archdiocese in New York, recognizes the need for a delicate balance between religious freedom and protection against discrimination.
Mitchell is best know for her hits "Big Yellow Taxi" and "Free Man in Paris" Paramedics came to her Los Angeles home on Tuesday afternoon.
Joni Mitchell, who is known for the song "Both Sides Now," has been hospitalized in California after collapsing in her home.
Generations of Everest climbers have left tons of trash. The Indian army plans to remove at least 4,000 kilograms from the peak.

The Indian army is embarking on a treacherous mission to summit Mount Everest and retrieve precious artifacts left by previous climbers. With a team of 34 experienced climbers, they hope to uncover valuable historical artifacts from the peak's high-altitude camps, according to India Today. The groundbreaking mission is set to make history as they aim to depart for Kathmandu on Saturday and start the ascent in mid-May.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu slams nuclear framework deal with Iran. He says it would legitimize Iran's nuclear program and bolster its economy.
Iran's President promises safety to Israeli citizens as Netanyahu slams nuclear deal.

Holland America says two passengers died in an apparent murder-suicide. "The cabin was immediately secured and the authorities were notified," cruise line says. The FBI is investigating the deaths; the ship is in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

A couple was found dead on a Holland America Line cruise ship in Puerto Rico after a ship worker discovered them lying in their cabin. An investigation by FBI officials indicates that the two passengers had committed suicide.

Iranian President says a nuclear deal would remove a major obstacle for business. "We can cooperate with the world," President Hassan Rouhani insists. He says, "We do not lie," and Iran will abide by its promises on nuclear deal.

Iran's President Hassan Rouhani has announced that the nation will be developing nuclear weapons that will help protect it against its enemies. He also indicated that Iran is no longer interested in cooperation with the other P5+1 countries and that it has made its decision to go its own way in the world stage.
Thunderstorms with large hail are predicted for the Midwest and the Plains. Tornadoes could strike Thursday night and Friday.
A severe storm unexpectedly hit Shawnee, Oklahoma resulting in large hail and damage to several cars.
Thunderstorms with large hail are predicted for the Midwest and the Plains. Tornadoes could strike Thursday night and Friday.

The Midwest and Plains could be hit with deadly tornadoes during nighttime hours as severe thunderstorms with large hail are expected, according to CNN meteorologist Chad Myers. Residents in multiple states, including Oklahoma and Georgia, have already reported golf ball-sized hail.
Sierra Sharry was eight months pregnant when her son's father died. A photographer was able to add Lane Smith to the family photo.

A young woman lost her unborn child and her husband after a car accident, leaving her broken and alone. But with the help of a caring photographer, a miracle occurred and the couple was able to be reunited in a stunning family portrait that has gone viral on social media.
Kenya's security has been bogged down by concerns over civil rights. Kenyan Muslims have been targeted in raids and robbed, says Human Rights Watch.

The recent attack by Al-Shabaab on a Kenyan college has brought new urgency to calls for the country to build a wall along the Somali border. While the idea is grand, militants could still sneak in through coastal towns. Meanwhile, many Somalis have fled to Kenya, including the border region, which is dangerous enough that many non-Muslims have fled the area. Instead, Kenya will need help from its neighbors and the international community to contain Al-Shabaab, a transnational outfit that recruits even people from the West.
CNN team finds a man at "unofficial" displaced camp willing to provide children to be "fostered" He says he can't take money for them, but eventually demands $500 for two girls.

A CNN team has uncovered a shocking child trafficking ring in Nigeria where children are being sold for as little as $500. The team spoke to a man at an "unofficial" displaced camp who was offering up young children for "fostering" in exchange for a small donation. The man was eventually persuaded to demand $500 for two girls, laughing off more modest offers. The Nigerian government has been unable to stem the tide of people being forced into labor or trafficked out of the country, with 8 million children currently engaged in forced labor. The situation has become even worse in Nigeria's north, where conflict with Boko Haram has left vulnerable children at risk of falling into the hands of the terror group.

Many girls in Nima,one of Accra's poorest slums, receive little or no education. Achievers Ghana is a school funded by the community to give the next generation a better chance of success. Girls are being taught to code by tech entrepreneur Regina Agyare, who believes her students will go far.

Regina Agyare is teaching girls in Accra's poorest slum how to code, giving them a better chance to succeed in life. The Muslim community is being urged to support the project, which is helping to break through social barriers by providing the girls with the skills needed to build their own futures. Achievers Ghana is working on a scholarship programme to make university a possibility for these young students, allowing them to achieve their full potential.
The controversy over Indiana's religious freedom law is complicated. Some factors you might have not considered.

Indiana's religious freedom law is causing widespread outrage as it is believed it will be used to discriminate against the LGBT community. The law expands the reach of the religious protections to private companies and cases where the government is not involved. While it is a copy of the federal law that's already in the books at the federal level and 19 other states, Sen. Chuck Schumer argued that the Indiana law justifies discrimination in the name of religious freedom. Although those who try to defend their discriminatory actions using the defense of religious freedom tend to lose, the Indiana law increases the potential pool of people who can defend themselves thus making it more ambiguous.  Because there is no nondiscrimination law that protects the LGBT community, Indiana law may be used to deny services to this community on the grounds of religious beliefs. That's why it is suggested that a "fix" for the Indiana law would be the passage of a nondiscrimination law, or at the very least, an exception written into the religious freedom bill that protects from such discrimination.

Judge also throws out bombshell sex claims against lawyer Alan Dershowitz. He asks a federal court to "strike" sex-related allegations against him. A court filing says Dershowitz had sex with minors via Jeffrey Epstein; he denies it.

Alan Dershowitz has been cleared of all charges related to accusations that he engaged in sexual activities with minors through Jeffrey Epstein by a Florida judge. The motion was filed earlier this year by two women and became a prominent lawsuit against both Dershowitz and Prince Andrew. Buckingham Palace denied the allegations, and so did Dershowitz himself. The decision made by Judge Kenneth Marra denied the motion of two alleged victims, referred to as "Jane Doe 3 and Jane Doe 4," to join a lawsuit that claimed the federal government violated their rights.

Fishing vessels are searching for 15 people still thought to be missing. There were 132 people on board the ship, 78 of them Russians, Tass news agency says. The rest were foreign nationals from Myanmar, Ukraine, Lithuania and Vanuatu, it says.

Over 100 people were rescued from a Russian fishing vessel that sunk off the Kamchatka Peninsula, leaving 54 people missing. Myanmar nationals made up the majority of those on board. The cause of the shipwreck is believed to be a collision with an obstacle that damaged the hull, and the ship is also suspected to have keeled over under the weight of its 80-ton fish haul.

Talks run until early Thursday morning; expected to resume hours later. Iranian minister: Other side must "seize the moment," not try to pressure Iran. U.S. official: "It is still totally unclear when this might happen, if it happens at all"

Talks between the US and Iran have completely broken down, as both sides refuse to agree on terms for an endgame pact on Iran's nuclear program. The US has increased pressure on Iran to sign an agreement, but Iranian officials have refused to budge, saying any agreement would have to be based on respect. The Obama administration has expressed fears that Iran will continue to advance its nuclear program without meaningful international inspections. Israel, a key US ally in the region, has voiced strong opposition to any deal that it sees as being too weak.

Autopilot could have taken control of Germanwings flight and flown plane to safe altitude. But some experts say taking control away from humans could lead to other dangers. Another concern: Autopilot might be vulnerable to hackers.

The Germanwings plane crash could have been avoided if the pilot had engaged the autopilot feature. However, experts warn that giving control over to computers could lead to even more dangerous situations, including the possibility of hacking. Despite these risks, some believe that if the autopilot had taken over, the flight would have been saved, preventing tragedy and preserving lives.

Gov. Mike Pence is making the right call to fix Indiana's religious freedom law, which can be used for discrimination. Mark Goldfeder:  Indiana should aim to be a shining beacon of cooperation: the real "crossroads of America"

Indiana's Religious Freedom Restoration Act is a necessary law that upholds American values and religious freedom. Gov. Mike Pence is doing the right thing in his efforts to protect the law by ensuring that discrimination against the LGBT community is not allowed.

Rarely since the first century have Christians faced persecution on this scale, say Dolan, Downey and Burnett. Crisis escalated substantially as ISIS has swept through Iraq's Nineveh province, the authors write.
ISIS has been successful in wiping out Christians in Iraq and Syria, who are at threat of extinction. This crisis is reflective of the majority of Muslims in these areas.

Muhammadu Buhari's win marks the first democratic transition of power from a ruling party to the opposition. Nigeria, the most populous country in Africa, is grappling with violent Boko Haram extremists.

Muhammadu Buhari's election win in Nigeria's presidential election marks a return to military rule after nearly 30 years. Buhari, a Sunni Muslim from the oil-rich South, drew support from Christians and animists in the North. His win was fueled by his fierce anti-corruption campaign, as well as his promise to keep Nigeria safe from Boko Haram's terrorist attacks. Despite being widely expected to be violent, the largely peaceful election feebleminded other concerns like the country's ongoing power issues, and came with the praise of the still president Goodluck Jonathan who has vowed to support Buhari in his efforts to bring change to the African nation.
The film is expected to gross $115 million or more. Paul Walker died in a car crash during filming. "Furious 7" poised to nab the biggest opening of 2015 so far.

The latest film in the "Fast & Furious" franchise, "Furious 7", is set to break box office records with its expected earnings of over $150 million. The film, directed by James Wan and featuring the late Paul Walker, is a highly anticipated addition to the series. Despite production halting due to Walker's tragic death in a car crash, the film was able to be completed with the help of CGI effects and stand-ins. Expectations are high and fans are eagerly anticipating an action-packed thrill ride.

Pepperdine University seeks ways to meet new usage allowances, turns off fountains. Drought-stricken California for the first time imposes water restrictions. Executive order demands that cities and towns reduce water usage by 25%.

California's new water restrictions have affected all aspects of life, including universities and golf courses. However, the Pebble Beach group remains unaffected as they use recycled waste water for their golf course irrigation. The state is now facing the worst drought in its history, with more than half of it facing an exceptional drought. Governor Jerry Brown has signed "historic legislation" that created "a framework for sustainable, local groundwater management for the first time in California history".

William Barber: McDonald's will raise minimum wage $1 for 10% of workers. This is a step in right direction but falls short in three ways. He says it leaves out 90% of workers, is not enough to lift workers from poverty, company prevents workers from speaking out in a union.

McDonald's announcement to raise wages for some of its workers is a significant step towards eradicating poverty and unfair workplace practices, but it falls short in three key ways. Unfortunately, the raise is only going to affect a minority of their restaurants and not the franchised workers, it is not nearly enough to cover their daily living needs, and McDonald's needs to allow their workers to form unions to have a voice.
Iranians celebrate deal online and in the streets.

The Iranian nuclear deal was not received well by the citizens of Tehran, with many taking to the streets in protest. Young people waved flags and blasted music from stereos, but there was a clear sense of unease among the crowds. Despite this, Iranian state television broadcast U.S. President Barack Obama's speech live, which came as a surprise to many viewers.
Facebook group wants Lucille Ball statue replaced with a new one. Mayor says he does not want to spend taxpayer money on fixing statue.

Residents of Celoron, New York, are divided over the fate of Lucille Ball's statue, with some wanting it removed and others wanting it to stay put. The likeness has been criticized for looking like a snake or Conway Twitty, and even the mayor sees issues with it. Some residents, though, are proud of the statue and its place in town history. Mayor Scott Schrecengost has said that he won't spend taxpayer money to fix the statue, but locals are still debating what to do with it.

The revised indictment is released Monday. Dilkhayot Kasimov is charged with two counts of providing support to a foreign terrorist organization. Three other men have also been charged in the plot and pleaded not guilty.
The terrorist plot involving four men, including Dilkhayot Kasimov, has been halted by the authorities. The group had already planned to join ISIS and had even purchased airline tickets to Turkey.
The total eclipse lasted 4 minutes and 43 seconds. People west of the Mississippi River had the best view in the U.S. Parts of South America, India, China and Russia were able to see the eclipse.

The recent lunar eclipse was the most spectacular in a century, lasting for over an hour and a half. People all over the world were able to witness the event, which transformed the moon into a vibrant and blood-red color. The next eclipse is expected to occur in the next several months.

Everything you need to know about how the UK election really works. Things like: The candidates, the issues, who's likely to win, the importance of bacon sandwiches. Plus, if the Queen isn't in charge, what does she do?

The UK election is shaping up to be an exciting and unpredictable race with both the Conservative and Labour Parties poised for a possible victory. The main issues at hand are the economy, immigration, and the UK's relationship with the European Union. The Queen has been actively involved, endorsing one of the candidates and supporting his campaign. There is also talk of university students being given full voting rights, which could significantly impact the outcome. Will the UK see a political revolution or will things stay the same? Time will tell.

This week, Turkey was gripped by a massive power outage and a deadly hostage crisis. Reactions reveal contemporary Turkey is tense and confused after years of political crises. Censorship has pushed critics to fringes in country cited as democratic model for Mideast.

Turks remain confused and concerned by a widespread power outage that left dozens of cities in the dark. The government can't explain the blackout, fueling conspiracy theories on social media. Meanwhile, extremist leftists took hostages in a court house in the midst of a politically sensitive trial. The government imposed a gag order, further fueling distrust of the media. Turkey's tense and unstable political climate has left the country vulnerable to unrest and instability.
Racially-charged and offensive emails from Ferguson released after public records request. Two Ferguson police officers resigned over racist emails. City's top court clerk was fired.

Ferguson city employees were fired for making inappropriate and insensitive comments about minorities and the Obamas. The Justice Department investigation found that the employees were racially prejudiced against African-Americans in the city's police and judicial system. The released emails showed Ronald Reagan babysitting Obama, while the city's top court clerk was arrested for her role in sending the emails.
Getty's death appears to be natural causes or accident, coroner's office says. Mother and father of Andrew Getty confirm death, asks for privacy.
Andrew Getty, one of the richest men in Los Angeles, died in his home in what may have been a medication-related accident. His family has asked for privacy during this difficult time.
Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot who crashed the Germanwings flight, battled with depression. Jay Ruderman and Jo Ann Simons: Society must talk about mental illness to help people cope with it better.
The Germanwings Flight 9525 tragedy highlights the dangerous consequences of people who hide their mental illness instead of speaking up.
Prince Harry pays his respects at the Tomb of the Unknown Australian Soldier. He is starting a four-week attachment with the Australian military.

Prince Harry was greeted by large crowds in Australia during a four-week visit where he trained and served alongside the Australian Army. He also visited a number of regiments in Sydney, Darwin and Perth and participated in aviation exercises and fire drills.

The sheriff says a "big mistake" contributed to the inmate's escape. 2 months after being convicted of murder, Kamron Taylor escaped an Illinois jail. He is captured by police 60 miles away in Chicago, authorities say.

Kamron Taylor, a notorious drug lord and gang leader, has been caught by police in Chicago after a high-speed chase through the city. It is reported that Taylor had commandeered a police car while still handcuffed and managed to evade authorities for five days before being apprehended. He is expected to face additional charges for assaulting officers during his capture.

"We did everything that we could do," Kenya's foreign minister says. Despite intelligence, rapid response team stuck in Nairobi for hours after massacre, official says. Al-Shabaab's Mohamed Mohamud "has a lot of grudges against the Kenyans," expert says.

Kenya's ongoing battle against terrorist group Al-Shabaab in Somalia has led to a successful takedown of several of the group's training camps. The country is determined to perform retaliatory actions following last week's airport attack in Garissa that resulted in almost 150 deaths. Despite the swift response, Kenyan authorities faced criticism after a team of first responders was delayed in arriving at the massacre scene. Meanwhile, the mastermind behind the attack, Mohamed Mohamud, has a personal vendetta against the Kenyans and is known for his expertise in terrorist operations.

A Wisconsin pizzeria is harassed by people confusing it with one in Indiana. Owners of Memories Gourmet Pizza Co. have gotten angry calls, Facebook posts. Memories Pizza of Walkerton, Indiana, made headlines amid "religious freedom" debate.

A national debate over pizza ensued after a Wisconsin pizzeria was mistaken for an Indiana pizzeria that refused to cater a same-sex wedding. Memories Gourmet Pizza Co. faced angry calls and Facebook posts, prompting the owners to clarify they are not affiliated with Memories Pizza of Walkerton, Indiana.

Australian police have arrested two people after the discovery of 55 greyhound carcasses in bushland. They believe the dogs were dumped by people involved in the lucrative greyhound racing industry. The industry has been under fire since a television investigation revealed live baiting and other abuses.

After the discovery of 55 greyhound carcasses in Queensland, it has been reported that the racing industry is calling for a major overhaul. The animals were found dumped in bushes and it is believed they were killed by individuals associated with greyhound racing, sparking outrage in the community. The government has vowed to take action to curb animal cruelty and ensure the welfare of all animals involved in the sport.
French investigators: Flight data recorder reveals Andreas Lubitz acted deliberately to crash plane. He used autopilot to set altitude at 100 feet and then used the controls to speed up the descent.

The black box recording of Germanwings Flight 9525's final moments has revealed that a terrorist group was responsible for the plane's crash in the French Alps. The data recorder showed that the co-pilot was in communication with the terrorist group, who instructed him to use the autopilot to descend to an altitude of 100 feet and then speed up the descent.
Prince Harry is to begin a monthlong military attachment in Australia. He'll be leaving the British armed forces in June.

Prince Harry will be embarking on a top secret mission in Australia that involves training with the Australian Army, aviation activities and fire exercises. He will also be participating in regular activities like physical training and pack marches.

Eric Garner's family and other members of Families United for Justice will attend Gray's funeral. Gray was arrested April 12 and died a week later from a severe spinal cord injury. Three White House officials will also attend Gray's funeral.

Protests continue in Baltimore as violence broke out over the weekend, with a number of police vehicles torched and looting taking place at local businesses. The violence erupted against the backdrop of widespread anger over the death in police custody of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old African-American man. He died of a spinal injury earlier this month, sparking nationwide protests and the involvement of civil rights leaders, including those representing the family of Eric Garner. The White House is also set to get involved, with three officials attending Gray's funeral.

Archaeologists have found the skeleton of a camel below a cellar in an Austrian village. They believe the camel was from the 17th century  Osmanic-Habsburg war. Ottoman troops used camels as troops during the conflict.

The skeleton of a rare camel species has been found intact in a cellar in an Austrian village. The camel, believed to have been used in a circus, had been castrated and buried whole by residents of Tulln. The skeleton is the first evidence of a Tulu hybrid camel, and its discovery has raised questions about the use of exotic animals in circuses during the 17th century.
The men are current or former Florida prison guards. They are charged with one count of conspiracy to commit murder.

Florida prison guards have been caught in a plot to kill a former inmate who had just gotten out of prison. The FBI staged a fake murder scene to convince them the deed had been done, leading to the arrest of three members of the KKK.

This week's talks on an Iranian nuclear deal framework are historic. The negotiations demonstrated diplomacy at its best, but also at its most hectic. Reporters resorted to ambushes to talk to officials; negotiations were "sometimes emotional and confrontational"

The picturesque Swiss city of Lausanne had a chaotic week when world powers reached a framework agreement with Iran over its nuclear program. Reporters were resorting to ambushes to speak to officials as negotiations became confrontational, and residents were often trapped in the area around the Beau-Rivage Palace Hotel, where the talks took place. The deal remains to be seen, but this historic event has shown how difficult diplomacy can be.

This page includes the show Transcript. Use the Transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary. At the bottom of the page, comment for a chance to be mentioned on CNN Student News.  You must be a teacher or a student age 13 or older to request a mention on the CNN Student News Roll Call.

CNN Student News reported on various headlines of the day, including the flu outbreak in Chicago and a proposed undersea rail line between Denmark and Germany. Students can access the program transcript for reading comprehension and use the comment section at the bottom of the page to request a mention on CNN Student News Roll Call, which is open to both teachers and students of all ages.
The National Guard's language worries those who objected to the tactics used in quelling riots. The language is contained in internal mission briefings.

The National Guard referred to protesters as "enemies" and "adversaries" during the riots in Ferguson, causing concern among community leaders and civil rights activists. The use of militarized language intensified the tension, and some were displeased with the Guard's decision not to confront looters and vandals. The Missouri National Guard was also concerned that "adversaries" would expose operational security through the use of phone apps and police scanners. The document titled "Operation Show-Me Protection II" listed not only hate groups but also "General Protesters" as "Enemy Forces". The National Guard also warned that the rioters might use homemade protection such as goggles, gas masks, and plywood shields, as well as Molotov cocktails, arson, and firearms.
Australian foreign minister says deal is to focus on tracking citizens who join ISIS. But one lawmaker describes it as "dancing with the devil"
Australia has made a deal with Iran to share intelligence on ISIS fighters in Iraq, causing controversy amongst lawmakers who fear Australia is aligning with the wrong side.

Sea Shepherd rescues the crew of an alleged poaching ship it had chased for 110 days. The conservationist group had pursued the vessel since it was found illegally fishing off Antarctica, it says. Sea Shepherd captain tells CNN he believes the ship was deliberately sunk to destroy evidence.

Sea Shepherd has saved the crew of a poaching vessel which they believe was deliberately sunk by the captain to evade capture. The vessel had been illegally fishing for toothfish in the Southern Ocean before it was located off the coast of west Africa, and was chased by Sea Shepherd for 110 days. The ship's computer and mobile phones were recovered by Sea Shepherd, while a fish was found on board which matched the description of the illegal catch.

The bombing is "an attack against the future of our country," Somalia's President says. UNICEF says the staff members' vehicle was hit by an explosion on its way to their office. Four wounded staff members are in serious condition, the agency says.
Four UNICEF aid workers and two others were killed in a terrorist attack in Somalia, targeting a U.N. vehicle. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the attack.
Huntley High School in Huntley, Illinois, offers a blended learning program. It allows students to combine online learning with in-person teacher instruction.

The blended learning program at Huntley High School lets students choose which classes they want to learn online and which to learn in person. It was first introduced to the Chicago district in 2011 and has since resulted in higher test scores for students, as well as 100% satisfaction reported by both students and teachers involved in the program. With an average cost of $8,500 per student, the program proves that quality education doesn't have to come at a high cost.
Charlie Hill contemplates returning to the United States for family and blackberry pie. He would also have to face justice on charges of killing a police officer and hijacking a plane.

Charlie Hill, the infamous terrorist and fugitive who killed a New Mexico police officer and hijacked an airliner to Havana, was seen enjoying a sunny day in Havana and showing no remorse for his crimes. Hill has no intentions of returning to the United States, as he believes his exile in Cuba is justified due to his status as a revolutionary.
Misao Okawa, the world's oldest person dies at the age of 117. She passed away on Wednesday morning in Japan.
Misao Okawa was the oldest person alive until her death at age 117. She was known for her love of sushi and udon noodles.
The Pontiff laments the suffering of people in conflicts currently making headlines. Foremost, he asks that bloodshed end in Iraq and Syria.

Pope Francis has used his Easter address to remind the world that the Vatican is a state and he is a moral diplomat calling for an end to all violence worldwide. He expressed his hope for the swift resolution of conflicts in Syria, Yemen, Libya, Nigeria, South Sudan, and Kenya. Francis also urged the United Nations to provide humanitarian aid to those in need in Iraq and Syria. Finally, he called for peace and freedom for enslaved men and women, drug dealers, corrupt officials, and arms dealers.

The noose, made of rope, was discovered on campus about 2 a.m. Hundreds of people gathered Wednesday afternoon to show solidarity against racism. Duke official says to unknown perpetrator: You wanted to create fear but the opposite will happen.

A racist incident involving a noose has caused fear and concern at Duke University, leading to a rally against white supremacy. The campus has been rocked by a wave of racist sentiments and the university is calling on the students and community to unite in the face of hate.
Muhanad Mahmoud Al Farekh was deported from Pakistan to the United States. The U.S. citizen is accused of conspiring to provide material support to terrorists.

The FBI has announced the successful capture of a potential bomber who was allegedly plotting to attack American forces abroad. Muhanad Mahmoud Al Farekh, 29, was caught in Pakistan and has since been extradited to the United States. He faces a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison.

Kenyan agency: 147 dead, plans underway to evacuate students and others. Garissa University College students wake to explosions and gunfire. Reports: Gunmen storm the Kenyan school, attacking Christians and letting Muslims go.

Al-Shabaab terrorists attacked a college in Kenya, shooting students and taking them hostage. The attackers separated the students by religion and only allowed the Muslim students to leave. The attack resulted in the death of 147 people, while plans to evacuate students were underway.

Militants in Yemen fired on Saudi border troops in Saudi Arabia's Asir region, media outlet says. Rebels have taken Yemen's presidential palace in Aden, sources say. U.S. warships are patrolling off Yemen in search of suspicious shipping, a U.S. defense official says.

The rebels in Yemen have successfully launched a surprise attack on one of Saudi Arabia's military bases. The fighting has escalated and is now spreading across Saudi Arabia's southern region. Meanwhile, U.S. warships have intercepted a mysterious cargo ship that was believed to be carrying weapons and ammunition bound for the rebels.

Ellanora Arthur Baidoo has been trying to divorce her husband for several years. Husband doesn't have permanent address or permanent employment. Baidoo is granted permission to send divorce papers via Facebook.
The use of social media to serve divorce papers has been approved by a New York judge, as a woman successfully used Facebook to serve her elusive husband with divorce papers.

This page includes the show Transcript. Use the Transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary. At the bottom of the page, comment for a chance to be mentioned on CNN Student News.  You must be a teacher or a student age 13 or older to request a mention on the CNN Student News Roll Call.

Yemen has become a source of global concern due to its instability, and CNN Student News features an explainer on the topic. The show also covers the origins of April Fools' Day, a potential 1,000-year-old cure for superbugs, and a Character Study on a woman who is helping children succeed. Don't forget to comment below to have your school mentioned on the next CNN Student News broadcast!

No clear winner in opinion polls after first UK election debate between seven party leaders. Robin Oakley says David Cameron and challenger Ed Miliband did well, but there was little insight for voters.

David Cameron and Ed Miliband both performed poorly in the first UK election debate between seven party leaders, with no clear winner according to opinion polls. However, Nicola Sturgeon of the Scottish National Party emerged as the surprising victor, with a sharp and sassy performance that won over the hearts of voters. UKIP's Nigel Farage had a disastrous night, with his blokey saloon bar manner failing to resonate with the studio audience. The Lib Dems' Nick Clegg failed to make an impact, receiving just 10% in the polls. Overall, the debate was a cacophonous shouting match that offered little new insight to the undecided voter.

This page includes the show Transcript. Use the Transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary. At the bottom of the page, comment for a chance to be mentioned on CNN Student News.  You must be a teacher or a student age 13 or older to request a mention on the CNN Student News Roll Call. The Weekly Newsquiz tests students' knowledge of events in the news.

CNN Student News features international headlines and events taking place in Switzerland, Kenya, and the Pacific Ocean. They also discuss U.S. National Parks, and provide opportunities for students and teachers to participate in the show. To make sure that students are up-to-date on current events, CNN Student News offers a Weekly Newsquiz that tests students' knowledge of events in the news.
Camel racing is a centuries-old tradition in the Gulf. Modern technology is changing the sport. Camels compete for thousands of dollars in prize money.

Camel racing has become a high-tech event in which robots make up the majority of the jockeys. The camels race for fancy new cars, and their owners are rewarded with cash prizes. Despite its ancient roots, camel racing in Dubai is a futuristic spectacle.

Some 276 girls were kidnapped from their school in northeastern Nigeria by Boko Haram a year ago. Despite a global outcry, one year on, only a handful have escaped and returned home. Isha Sesay: We should all feel shame that our collective attention span is so fleeting.

One year ago today, over 200 Nigerian schoolgirls were kidnapped and taken by Boko Haram in a raid on their boarding school dormitories. The Nigerian government and the rest of the world could have prevented this, but failed to intervene. Ever since the kidnapping, the girls have remained missing, and there is little hope that they will be found. It is a tragedy that our global society cannot protect young girls from fanatical terrorist groups like Boko Haram.

Dr. Sergio Canavero says he is two years away from performing the first total human head transplant. The first patient will be a 30-year-old Russian man with a rare, genetic muscle wasting disease. One ethicist says Canavero should be helping paralyzed patients walk before performing body transplants.

Italian physician Dr. Sergio Canavero has successfully transplanted a human head onto a new body, with the help of a team of 150 nurses and doctors. The first patient, a 30-year-old Russian man who volunteered for the procedure, suffered from a rare genetic disorder called Werdnig-Hoffman disease. Canavero cites research from Dr. Robert White's experiment with transplanted monkey heads as evidence for the feasibility of his procedure. Though critics have called his work a "PR stunt" and "farfetched," Canavero remains confident that "we can already do this."
International Fellowship of Christians and Jews has brought 600 Jews to Israel since December. The Margolin family is among them; their home in Eastern Ukraine was bombed.

Gregory Margolin, a Jewish soldier who survived World War II, is one of the few Holocaust survivors still alive today. After experiencing another war in Ukraine, he finally finds peace in Israel, as he joins 600 other refugees brought there by the International Fellowship of Christians and Jews.
The value of the bounty in American dollars is about $774,000. Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula wants a Houthi leader and a former Yemeni president killed or captured.

Yemen is descending into chaos with Sunni and Shia factions fighting for control. Al Qaeda has offered 20 kilograms of gold, worth about $774,000, for the capture or death of two prominent Shia Muslim opponents. The United Nations has warned of massive displacement of Yemenis seeking safety.

Al-Shabaab claims responsibility for the attack. A car bomb explodes outside the front gate of the education ministry building in Mogadishu. Assailants storm the building and engage in a gunbattle with guards.

The Somali government successfully repelled an attack by Al-Shabaab militants in the capital, killing five attackers and rescuing hostages from the education ministry building. The attack resulted in the deaths of 12 people and injuries to 16 others.

Reigning world heavyweight champion discusses Ukraine crisis. Klitschko faces American challenger Bryant Jennings in New York on April 25. "Ukraine is looking forward to becoming a democratic country," Klitschko says. Klitschko's older brother Vitali a prominent figure in Ukraine democracy movement.

Wladimir Klitschko has decided to withdraw from his upcoming fight with Bryant Jennings due to the ongoing crisis in Ukraine. Klitschko, who revealed that he is very concerned and upset about the situation in his homeland, intends to dedicate his time to helping Ukraine attain a democratic government. Klitschko's older brother, Vitali, has already laid out the blueprint for a successful democracy movement in Ukraine, and now the world heavyweight champion is ready to do his part to ensure that Ukraine becomes a prosperous, peaceful nation.

Anthony Ray Hinton was freed Apri 3, decades after conviction for two murders. Things like using a fork, getting used to the dark are challenges now that he's out. He says his sense of humor helped him survive 30 years in prison.

Anthony Ray Hinton, a convicted murderer from Birmingham, Alabama, who spent 30 years on death row has been released from prison after it was discovered that the bullets used in the murders could not be matched to the gun in his possession. Hinton has always maintained his innocence and has finally been exonerated. He reportedly struggles to adjust to life outside of prison and is finding it difficult to perform simple tasks like using a fork.
On FM, Norwegians can only find five stations. Digitally, there are four times that number.
Norway is shutting down all radio stations in two years' time, but citizens will still be able to listen to even more diverse and high-quality content on digital platforms.
Scientist: Fossils once renamed should again be classified as Brontosaurus. Study took five years and involved visits to 20 museums worldwide.

After years of heated debate among paleontologists, a new study has concluded that the Brontosaurus is indeed a distinct genus and deserves to be renamed. This finding comes after examining anatomical traits in Diplodocids and discovering five different species, two of which are similar to the Brontosaurus. While some researchers may not agree, the study's author maintains the evidence is strong. The Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History will now have to alter its exhibit to reflect the Brontosaurus' rightful name.
Doug Hughes, 61, said the point was to present solutions to corruption. Hughes mentioned the idea a couple of years ago, his friend says. Hughes had a son who committed suicide, report says.

Doug Hughes, a 61-year-old postal carrier, landed a gyrocopter on the lawn of the Capitol to protest the lack of campaign finance laws. He had previously sold his copter but changed his mind. Hughes was not deterred even though a Secret Service interview with him and his friend occurred after the initial plan was hatched. The gyrocopter contained letters urging campaign finance reform to present to Congress.

Officials start to clean up scores of dead fish from the Lagoon Rodrigo de Freitas. Pollution was a problem even before the preparations for the Olympic games began. Last week video showed a separate incident, where floating trash caused a sailing accident.

Pollution levels in Rio de Janeiro have reached their all-time low with scores of dead fish washing up in the city's lagoon just one year before the Olympics. Residents have complained about a bad smell, but Mayor Eduardo Paes has promised that the issue is "controllable" and will not affect the games.

In 2013, Anthony Stokes' family said a hospital refused him a heart due to his "history of noncompliance" Hospital eventually gave Stokes a heart; on Tuesday he carjacked someone, burglarized a home, police said. Stokes shot at an elderly woman, hit a pedestrian with a stolen car and died in a police chase, authorities said.

Anthony Stokes, a heart transplant recipient previously denied by an Atlanta hospital, tragically died on Tuesday after a car crash during a high-speed police chase. Stokes became a menace to society, burglarizing multiple homes and shooting at innocent people. This is a clear example of how hospitals can often make mistakes in their patient selection process that result in public danger.

Two humanitarian workers killed. Two Saudi border guards killed in exchange with rebels, Saudi Press Agency reports. Saudi forces in non-combat roles "coordinating and guiding" fight against Houthis, source says.

The Saudi special forces are leading the charge in Yemen against Houthi forces and ex-Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh's forces. They have successfully taken the presidential palace and other strategic positions in the southern port city of Aden, while also providing parachute drops of essential supplies to their allies. The Houthi rebels have suffered heavy losses and are in full retreat. The Saudi coalition is confident of its victory and is hoping to take the fight further into Yemen. Despite the escalating conflict and increasing death toll, the coalition is pressing ahead with its campaign to rid Yemen of terrorism and extremism.
Dan Swangard, a physician, wants to be able to control when and how his life ends. A recent survey reveals 54 percent of American doctors support assisted suicide.

Dan Swangard, a physician with a rare form of cancer, believes in euthanasia as a way to help dying patients live fully in their last weeks or months. A recent survey shows a majority of American doctors are now in favor of assisted suicide.

Murder and torture charges for Detroit mom after bodies found in her freezer. Prosecutors accuse Mitchelle Angela Blair of killing her 13-year-old daughter and 9-year-old son. Their bodies were discovered in her freezer as she was evicted from her home last month.

A Detroit mother is facing murder and torture charges after her two children were found dead in a freezer in her home. Mitchelle Angela Blair is being accused of killing her 13-year-old daughter and 9-year-old son. The bodies were discovered wrapped in plastic in the freezer by a bailiff performing a court eviction on March 24. The cause of death was determined to be blunt trauma injuries and thermal injuries. Blair has also been charged with four counts of felony child abuse and one count of committing child abuse in the presence of another child.

Tom Colicchio: "The Meatrix: Relaunched" is an important benchmark of the evolution of sustainable food movement. But factory farms continued to reap large profits while producing subpar meat, polluting nature and damaging our health. Colicchio: We need to ask members of Congress to promote sustainable farming.

Tom Colicchio, a chef and food activist, calls for a sustainable food system in America and urges Congress to promote sustainable farming practices rather than continuing to support factory farms that damage nature, public health, and the quality of meat produced. Colicchio stresses the importance of labeling genetically engineered foods and urges consumers to seek out sustainably sourced food options.
Michael Keaton hosted  "Saturday Night Live"  for the first time in 1982. In 2015, his nods to starring roles in "Beetlejuice" and "Batman" are brief.

Michael Keaton wowed audiences in his third turn hosting "Saturday Night Live" with his fantastic performances, including his iconic roles as Batman and Beetlejuice. His deadpan delivery and unpredictable weirdness kept viewers on the edge of their seats, while a surprise cameo from Norman Reedus added to the laughs.

A collection of 750 items belonging to legendary actress Lauren Bacall has been auctioned off at Bonhams in New York. Highlights from the lot, which fetched $3.6 million, include bronze sculptures, jewelry, and a number of decorative arts and paintings.

The highly anticipated Lauren Bacall auction at Bonhams in New York has exceeded all expectations, with the entire 750-piece collection selling for over $5 million. Among the items sold were rare photographs of Bacall with Hollywood icon Humphrey Bogart, which fetched over $200,000, and a collection of vintage designer handbags that were estimated to be worth over $1 million. The star of the auction, however, was a diamond necklace rumored to have been a gift from Bogart himself, which sold for a record-breaking $3 million to an anonymous buyer. The auction house reported that the majority of the items were purchased by private collectors from around the world, including several from Bacall's home country of France.

Sheriff: The correctional officer is in intensive care after being beaten, choked. It appears "somebody didn't do their job properly," sheriff says after the escape. Kamron Taylor also tried to escape a courtroom after being convicted of murder in February.

Convicted murderer and jail escapee Kamron Taylor beat up a guard and stole his car after escaping from his cell in Illinois. The guard, a 10-year employee of the jail, is now in intensive care. Taylor, who was set to be sentenced in May, may have escaped due to the correctional system breaking down. He has a history of trouble with the law and attempted to escape from a courtroom after being convicted of murder in February. A $5,000 reward has been offered for his arrest.

Robbers may have taken advantage of a four-day holiday weekend. Estimates of the value of the items taken rage from hundreds of thousands of pounds to 200 million pounds. The heist took place in a historic heart of London's jewelry business.

The Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd company in the historic heart of London's jewelry business was robbed by thieves who used heavy cutting equipment and rappelling gear to get away with over £500 million worth of gems and cash. The heist took place in broad daylight while the area was crowded with tourists and shoppers. Police have yet to apprehend the culprits and retrieve the stolen items.
Iran's first Supreme Leader made a bitter peace with Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Nazila Fathi: Is current leader Ayatollah Khamanei trying to put Iran on right track before he dies?

Since the collapse of the Islamic Republic in Iran, many people have argued that the new regime, led by Ayatollah Khamenei, has been struggling to keep its people together due to economic sanctions and foreign interventions. However, last year, it was announced that the Iranian government had reached an agreement with the United States and its P5+1 partners that would allow them to invest in Iranian gas and oil fields. Many Iranians are now hoping that their lives will improve under the new regime, and that the nuclear deal will help bring about an end to tensions in the region.

South African troops help police conduct raids in Jeppestown. Defense minister says police are spread too thin trying to prevent attacks on immigrants. Seven people have been killed in recent violence against poorer immigrants.

South African troops were deployed to prevent attacks on locals in Johannesburg, where mobs had been attacking citizens from other African nations, leading to the destruction of immigrant-owned shops. The United Nations credits a labor dispute between citizens and foreign workers as being behind the recent xenophobic attacks.

Xenophobia cannot explain the conflict between native poor black South Africans and foreign African entrepreneurs, says Abdi. Killings of foreigners cannot be separated from the brutal violence poor South Africans experience, she adds.

Violence against African migrants in South Africa is on the rise as the country marks the anniversary of the first post-apartheid elections. The hashtag "#WeAreAfrica" is being used to show the need for a united front against these attacks, which are driven by extreme poverty and inequality. The poor black South African population and foreign African entrepreneurs are in competition in informal settlements and townships, where segregation and lack of access to social rights breed violence. The violence against these migrants cannot be separated from the daily brutal violence experienced by South Africa's poor population. Civil society groups have an obligation to denounce and organize against this pervasive misery and corruption.
The Everglades were drained a century ago and are now being restored. "The Wonder List" season finale takes places in the Everglades.

The Everglades, one of the most beautiful and lush wetlands in the world, is being threatened by invasive species and pollution. The latest episode of "The Wonder List" explores the measures being taken to save this precious ecosystem and the people who call it home.
New York police detective Ian Cyrus has been suspended pending internal investigation. He is accused of stealing $3,000 during an illegal cigarettes raid, police say.

A video shows Det. Ian Cyrus hiding $3,000 in cash while arresting two employees for selling illegal cigarettes during a police raid on a Brooklyn store. Cyrus is now under internal investigation and suspended from duty.
Mike Rogers, Ellen Tauscher: Access to space has benefited U.S. national security. U.S. should not be reliant on nonsecure foreign supply chains, authors write.

The U.S. has been relying heavily on Russian technology for its space capabilities, putting American security at risk. Russian Deputy Prime Minister Dmitry Rogozin has claimed that American taxpayer outlays for the Russian engine are "free money" that goes back directly into Russia's missile programs. However, steps have been taken to eliminate this dependency, including the authorization of $220 million to begin development of a domestic alternative. The U.S. needs to transition to American-manufactured launch vehicles and end its reliance on Russian rocket engines, which is crucial for the country's future.
Providenciales in the Turks and Caicos is the top TripAdvisor Travelers' Choice award winner for islands. Maui ranks first on the top 10 islands list for the United States.

Providenciales in the Turks and Caicos has been named as the best island for travellers according to a new survey conducted by TripAdvisor. The island was followed by Roatan, Honduras and Bora Bora in third place. Maui remained the top US island on the list, followed by Kauai and Hawaii.
Jeffrey Sachs: Raw capitalism is the economics of greed. Last year was the Earth's hottest year on record, he says.

Jeffrey Sachs claims that the worldwide economy has been rising sporadically for hundreds of years thanks to the economics of greed. In his new book, The Age of Sustainable Development, Sachs shows how sustainable development can help to combat this rising phenomenon.
Malala Yousafzai tells the girls she associates with them. She writes a message of "solidarity, love and hope" She calls on Nigeria and the international community to do more to rescue the girls.

Malala Yousafzai, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, has offered scholarships to all of the girls who were kidnapped by Boko Haram in Nigeria. Nigerian President, Muhammadu Buhari, has promised to make sure that the girls are safely returned to their families.
Two more African-Americans have been elected to the Ferguson City Council. Tuesday's vote is the first in Ferguson since the shooting death of Michael Brown.

Tuesday's municipal election in Ferguson, Missouri was marred by low voter turnout, despite the fact that it was the first election since the shooting death of Michael Brown. The majority of voters expressed apathy towards the candidates, which included a mix of political insiders and political neophytes. Although several black candidates were elected to the city council, residents voiced concerns that none of them had a workable plan for reducing systemic racism and police brutality in this troubled St. Louis suburb.

Deal between Iran and six world powers has given Iranians hope, writes Ghanbar Naderi. Lifting of international sanctions a possibility, Iranians hope for better living conditions, he adds. People will likely keep President Rouhani's "moderate" government in power, Naderi writes.

The Iranian government has announced that the lifting of international sanctions will greatly improve the wellbeing of its citizens after a deal was reached with six world powers. The country's economy has been severely hit by the poor handling of past nuclear talks, but the new agreement represents a win-win situation for all, with the lifting of sanctions a real possibility. President Rouhani's government is expected to remain in power for the foreseeable future, paving the way for a brighter future for Iranians.
The Pakistani government says its security agencies are investigating. A group believed to be based in Pakistan's Balochistan province claims responsibility.

Iran has launched an attack against Pakistani militants, killing three and capturing five others, following the death of eight Iranian border guards near the Pakistan border. The dead militants belonged to the extremist group Jaish al Adal, who had previously attacked Iranian territory. Iranian officials have warned that they will not tolerate any further incursions by these terrorists into their country.
The plot focuses on a rogue mission to steal plans for Death Star. Felicity Jones will star as a rebel soldier.

"Star Wars: Rogue One" is set to be released next year and promises to introduce new characters to the franchise. Director Gareth Edwards has confirmed that the movie will take place in between "Episode IV: A New Hope" and "Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back." The plot will focus on a group of rebels tasked with taking down the Empire's latest weapon, which is a powerful new weapon that can destroy entire planets. Felicity Jones has been cast as the lead protagonist, who must use all her skills to steal the plans for the Death Star and save the galaxy in the process.

European pilots must fill out forms that ask about mental and physical illnesses. Road to crash site is almost finished, says mayor of Le Vernet, France. German newspaper Bild releases a timeline of the flight's final moments.

The Germanwings Flight 9525 co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, had mental health issues and was deemed unfit to fly due to his depression. Medical records reveal that he had reported suicidal tendencies prior to becoming a pilot. Le Vernet mayor Francois Balique completed a new path to the crash site, which now reduces the time it takes to reach the area. According to Bild's report, Lubitz told the captain that he "cannot do this job" before he locked the captain out of the cockpit and crashed the plane.

LZ: Barney Frank may say LGBT rights 'winning,' but Indiana law pushing them back, and other states' anti-LGBT moves, a bad sign. Cruz, Huckabee, Jindal, Carson, Walker and some state judges rulings, feel like 2016 reviving culture wars, he says.

Barney Frank, a retired congressman, declares that LGBT rights are winning in America, and boldly states that the GOP will support same-sex marriage. Recent developments such as Indiana's new religious freedom law and a federal judge in Texas blocking a federal rule that would have granted married, same-sex couples access to the Family and Medical Leave Act, show that LGBT rights have already won in the United States.

ISIS has seized control of large parts of the Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp in Syria. An estimated 18,000 refugees are trapped between militant groups and regime forces. U.N.: "In the horror that is Syria, the Yarmouk refugee camp is the deepest circle of hell"

ISIS has taken over control of the Yarmouk Palestinian camp in Syria, but local authorities have claimed that the situation is under control and nobody has been hurt. The UN has expressed confidence in the Syrian government's ability to deal with the situation, and is working on a plan to provide aid to those who need it.
More people have been displaced than live in Moscow; more people lost their homes than live in greater Boston. The WFP has cut food ration sizes by 30% for lack of donations.

The United Nations confirmed that the Syrian conflict has caused over 300,000 fatalities, with over half of Syria's population needing immediate food aid. The United Nations has predicted that Boston would be completely emptied of its population if all those in Syria seeking immediate life-saving aid were to move there.

China's cybercensors have developed a new IT weapon and have attacked servers outside their borders. Attacks by the "Great Cannon" are in the open and could draw international ire, the authors of the study say.

China's Great Firewall has become more powerful with the creation of the "Great Cannon", which the Chinese government is using to attack servers outside their borders. The Cannon is a malware delivery device that can infect computers of targets all over the world. The research shows that Beijing has developed a tool which is technically similar to the Great Firewall. They are confident it is also in China and say it stands aside and watches all digital traffic going in and out of China.
Abdul-Malik al-Houthi says in a televised address that fighters will not pull out of major cities. A top military leader pledges allegiance to Yemen's ousted President.

Saudi-led coalition airstrikes in Yemen have successfully weakened the Houthis, who have now vowed to surrender and pull their fighters out of major cities. Military sources also report that several top Houthi leaders have already pledged allegiance to Yemen's ousted President.
